abstract: If the military experts at Washington are at a loss to understand the plans of the rebel Generals, civilians in New-York are not likely to explain them with any very striking perspicacity. The enemy is no doubt acquainted, at least in a general way, with the strength and positions of the National Army.
lead_paragraph: If the military experts at Washington are at a loss to understand the plans of the rebel Generals, civilians in New-York are not likely to explain them with any very striking perspicacity. The enemy is no doubt acquainted, at least in a general way, with the strength and positions of the National Army. His position on Munson's Hill enabled him, with the aid of glasses, to examine the long lines of Gen. MCCLELLAN's force, to estimate his numbers, and to form some idea of his preparations, and the probable direction in which they are to be employed. But of the enemy our commanders appear to have very imperfect information. His movements and plans are equally wrapped in obscurity. Had we any definite knowledge of the former, it would be easy to arrive at a proximate estimate of the latter; but, in the absence of all knowledge, we can only await patiently the development of events.

abstract: The United States steam-transport Albany, Capt. CHADSEY, from Washington, D.C., sixty hours, in ballast, arrived at this port yesterday. She was stopped at Indian Head by the Potomac flotilla, to await the darkness of the night to pass a rebel battery of four guns, erected on a high point of land on the Virginia shore, known as Cock Pit Point. This battery was firing into every vessel that attempted to pass.

abstract: No change of importance was made in the position of the National Army across the Potomac yesterday: The rebels are still in sight from Falls Church, which place they lately held with six ...
lead_paragraph: No change of importance was made in the position of the National Army across the Potomac yesterday: The rebels are still in sight from Falls Church, which place they lately held with six regiments and four pieces of artillery. Their pickets now occupy one end of this village, and the National pickets the other, their position being not more than a quarter of a mile apart. A rebel regiment of infantry was observed in the morning drilling on a hill between the London and Hampshire Railroad. Artillery was also observed in that direction, and from the fact that they are throwing up fresh, earth works to the left of Falls Church, on an eminence a mile and a half distant, and commanding the village, it is inferred that they intend remaining in the neighborhood. About 6 o'clock in the morning they showed a battery of six pieces of artillery, supported by a few companies of artillery at Great Falls, opposite the position occupied by Gen. MCCALL's position. They threw a few cannon-shots across the river at our men, but without effect, when a detachment of troops was sent to the river by Gen. MCCALL to dispute the passage of the river should they attempt it. The rebel force was then increased by eight regiments of infantry, to which exhibition of strength Gen. MCCALL responded by ordering forward two guns and a column of infantry. This proved to be too much for the enemy, for they immediately dispersed -- some going up the river and some down. We have no explanation of the meaning of this rebel demonstration.

abstract: The discussions with which the English Press teems in reference to the supply of cotton, to make up for the anticipated deficit in the receipts from America, will, we are ...
lead_paragraph: The discussions with which the English Press teems in reference to the supply of cotton, to make up for the anticipated deficit in the receipts from America, will, we are afraid, quite destroy the reputation of that country for good sense or provident forecast. There certainly never was a more melancholy display of ignorance, imbecility and blind confidence, that all will be well in the future simply because it is desired. The work of generations is expected to be accomplished in a few short months. For thirty years past have English manufacturers been discussing the subject of production elsewhere than in the United States, and proclaiming the necessity of throwing off the bondage to this country which this article imposed, while each year only served to strengthen it. American cotton has come to be almost the only staple used in their mills. In the prospect of its loss they are casting about for a supply elsewhere, and are flattering themselves that it is to come from some source or other, entirely oblivious to the fact that the production can nowhere be increased except at a very slow rate, and that instead of one, two or three years being sufficient to make up for the American defect, neither five, ten, nor fifteen years would suffice. While so near the verge of the precipice that they could, if they would, hear the roar beneath, they appear to fancy that everything before them is plain sailing. But, after all, we do not know that this stolidity is any cause for astonishment. When did a people, situated as is the cotton-spinner, who never yet failed of a supply, even adequately appreciate, or provide for, the possibility of a change? An event that has never been experienced is never anticipated. It is no less certain, however, that one-sixth of the whole population of the United Kingdom will soon be out of work, and in a starving condition, unless the customary supply from America goes to them in due time. The consequence of such a disaster we will not pretend to describe, because imagination cannot picture them in all their magnitude and horrors. If they are averted, it will be through the power of the Government of the United States alone, by the capture and opening of the Southern ports. Unless this can be done, not a bale of American cotton will go to market. It would be a just retribution that England should suffer for the encouragement she has extended to the rebellion; but this, unfortunately, cannot fall upon the heads deserving it. It is the English ruling classes, not the English operatives, that have sought to make Secession a power, for the purpose, by breaking up our Government, of removing an unpleasant spectacle of civil liberty more perfect than their own, and of destroying a hated commercial rival. But this rival already controls that upon which the prosperity, if not the very existence, of a large portion of the population of England depend. This fact will soon be so palpable, that we should not he in the least degree surprised at overtures from that country to assist us in breaking down the rebellion by capturing Southern ports. It will soon be seen that this is the condition precedent to the receipt of the first bale, from this country. This new role, after all the ill-will and hostility displayed toward this country, would be a most mortifying come down, but it may be preferred to self-destruction. We do not need any assistance, but it might facilitate matters somewhat. It is probable that the English Government has already discovered its mistake in the encouragement it has given the rebellion, and heartily repents it, and more than all must it be most deeply mortified to feel that its people will owe their escape from material destruction to the very power which it assumed to be defunct, with very decided expressions of complacency over such a supposition.

abstract: Yesterday was quite a busy day at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. The Alabama and Unadilla were put in commission with the usual formalities, and will shortly take their departure. The Augusta also were into commission on Saturday, and, together with the Unadilla, hauled out to the buoy yesterday.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was quite a busy day at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. The Alabama and Unadilla were put in commission with the usual formalities, and will shortly take their departure. The Augusta also were into commission on Saturday, and, together with the Unadilla, hauled out to the buoy yesterday. The James Adger remains off the Battery, waiting for the Ottawa, Alabama, Augusta, and Unadilla. As soon as these boats are ready for sea, they will sail on a secret expedition. The place of their destination has been spoken of, but under the circumstances we think it best not to give publicity to the report which is current in naval circles, which after all may prove unfounded. A guard of marines has been detailed for the Alabama, from which we infer that the commander of that boat -- Commander E. LUNIER -- will be the chief officer of the expedition. None of the other boats above named have guards of marines.

abstract: Our readers will find in our columns this morning the decision of Judge BETTS in the first of the prize cases heard and disposed of in this district. Decisions in similar cases have previ- ...
lead_paragraph: Our readers will find in our columns this morning the decision of Judge BETTS in the first of the prize cases heard and disposed of in this district. Decisions in similar cases have previously been rendered by Judge DUNLOP at Washington, Judge CADWALLADER in Philadelphia, and Judge GILES in Baltimore; and as all the Judges substantially agree in their decisions they will go up to the Appellate Courts with a weight which renders their reversal improbable. This case -- that of the bark Hiawatha -- contains the decision of the important questions of public law involved in all the cases, and the other cases following differ from it only as to the circumstances which will govern the application of those principles to the several cases.

abstract: Kentucky has suddenly become a field of exceeding interest in the war. The rebels have invaded it from several points, seizing important towns, and advancing boldly towards Louisville by the line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky has suddenly become a field of exceeding interest in the war. The rebels have invaded it from several points, seizing important towns, and advancing boldly towards Louisville by the line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. Among the conjectures connected with the disappearance of BEAUREGARD's Army from in front of Washington is this, that they will divide and go into Winter quarters -- a part falling back on Richmond to protect it, and a very large portion pushing on by Railroad through Tennessee to Kentucky, in order to seize Louisville and Cincinnati, and get clothing, houses and food for the Winter.

abstract: Seeing that the President has appointed Commissioners of such distinction and ability to represent us at the World's peaceful competition next year, our manufacturers should at once prepare to make a display that will be both creditable and profitable.
lead_paragraph: Seeing that the President has appointed Commissioners of such distinction and ability to represent us at the World's peaceful competition next year, our manufacturers should at once prepare to make a display that will be both creditable and profitable. Our efforts in 1851 were ridiculously weak; our own exhibition, up at Forty-second-street, was, on the whole, worse; and now, if in war times, such magnificent promises, as indexed by the distinguished Commission, are backed by nothing better than a few Yankee notions, we shall be laughed at -- and deserve it.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- A very charming comedicita, called the "Actress by Daylight," was produced here last evening, and brought the range of Mrs. JOHN WOOD's capabilities in a pleasing way before the public. It is nothing now, when even tradition is silent to impersonate so renowned an interpreter of the various emotions of the dramatic muse as Mrs. BRACEGIRDLE, but it is surely something to give us two scenes so varied in their character that they scarcely seem to belong to one "line of business." In doing this, Mrs. WOOD reproduces in no unworthy way, one of the historical feats of the stage. In her day, Mrs. BRACEGIRDLE was the envy of the art world, the toast of prime ministers, and the glory of the stage. That she should live in literature is not remarkable. The incidents of her life have furnished the narrative and dramatic world with material for some of its most pleasant conceits. Not long since Mr. CHARLES READE constructed a little story called " Art," in which the great actress, Mrs. BRACEGIRDLE, was the principal character. It is from this that the author of the "Actress by Daylight" has drawn his inspiration. The same sort of thing has been told a hundred times before, but never so pleasantly. A foolish poetical lad falls in love with the great actress of the hour, Mrs. Bracegirdle. He writes a tragedy for her, and in many ways, less imbecile, proves that he is a devoted swain. She tries to dissuade him, and enacts a comedy scene for the purpose of disgusting him. Falling in this, at a later period she recites a portion of the young man's tragedy to his father, by which that gentleman is reconciled to a marriage with the actress. The denouement is of course happy. On slight materials like these a very delightful comedietta has been constructed. It possesses the double advantage of showing off Mrs. WOOD's best powers in comedy, and in introducing us to a very pleasant relish of her capabilities in a higher and more serious walk of art. We have seldom seen the lady to such advantage.

abstract: Gov. JACKSON followed in the wake of PRICE's Army, with the rump of his lately deposed Legislature and this latter body has met, it seems, and passed an ordinance of secession. The rebel Congress had previously adopted resolutions authorizing President DAVIS, in this contingency, to admit Missouri into the Confederate States, and the formality is therefore complete, in rebel opinion, and Missouri has ceased to belong to the old Union.

abstract: -- The funeral of Justice J. SHERMAN BROWNELL will take place this afternoon from his late residence, No. 10 Grove-street, and the Board of Magistrates attested their respect for their deceased colleague, by deciding to suspend proceedings at the Police Courts after 12 o'clock to-day until Wednesday morning. An order was issued on Sunday directing that the Yorkville Court, where Justice BROWNELL, has presided, should be closed until after the funeral. The fact was communicated to Superintendent KENNEDY with the request that he would notify the Precincts doing business at that Court, to bring their prisoners before Justice BRENNAN, at Essex Market. Mr. KENNEDY, however, thought proper to decline compliance, and having engaged Alderman FARLEY to act as Magistrate, the Court was opened yesterday morning. The Magistrates are indignant at Mr. KENNEDY's usurpation of power, and will prevent the repetition of the offence.

abstract: Landmann's Park, corner of Sixty-ninth-street and Third-avenue, was the scene of great festivity, yesterday. The occasion was the presentation of a flag to the regiment by the patriotic ladies of Hoboken, and a farewell festival and ball. Our German citizens came out in strong force, and enjoyed themselves hugely, as is their wont on such festive occasions. On receiving the flag, Col. GEORGE V. AMSBERG, on behalf of his command, made a neat and appropriate speech, in which he thanked the fair donors for their beautiful gift. The flag is a magnificent affair, having been embroidered by Madame FRANCISCA KLEIN. In the evening the ball was well attended, and dancing was kept up till a late hour. The proceeds of the festival and ball are for the benefit of the families of the volunteers of this regiment.

abstract: The People's Convention reassembled yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in the Governor's Room. City Hall, all of the delegates present. A communication was received from Mr. A.B. CAHWELL, the nominee of Assembly in the Second District, declining the nomination, which was accepted, and on motion, the delegates from the District were authorized to fill the vacancy. The delegation after a short consultation, recommended the nomination of RICHARD J. LAWLER, which nomination was unanimously accepted by the Convention. Several gentlemen, who had voted against the ticket on Saturday, now said their chief objection against the ticket had been removed, and they were now in favor of it. Messrs. KIMBALL, SEABURY and LAMBERT were still opposed to the former action of the Convention; not that they had any objections against the candidates, but because of the manner in which they had been nominated. Mr. MUDGET, who made the motion to reconsider the nominations, and which motion was pending at the adjournment of the Convention on Saturday, said as the gentleman for whom he had made the motion had expressed himself satisfied with the former action of the Convention he would ask leave to withdraw the motion. He was permitted to do so by almost a unanimous vote. On motion of Mr. STRANAHAN, the Chairman was authorised to appoint a Committee of two to select Delegates to the Judicial Convention for the Second District. The Chairman was also authorized to appoint an Executive Committee of two members from each Assembly District, with instructions to make all necessary arrangements for the election and to prepare an address to the people of Kings County. A resolution was also adopted indorsing the action of the People's Convention at Syracuse, when the Convention gave three hearty cheers for the ticket and adjourned sine die.

abstract: The brigs E.P. Stewart and, Arabella, recently arrived at this port, reported having been chased by a suspicious looking schooner, under British colors, who upon falling to reach them, hoisted the rebel flag and kept off. This turns out to have been the British schooner Swan, of Halifax, from Black River, Jamaica, with her captain sick of yellow fever, and in want of medicines. He died un the 27th. His successor Capt. ROUEKE, reports Sept. 20, lat. 33#176; 50, lon. 74#176;, saw the brig Arabella, and being in want of medicine for Capt. SHELLNUT, stood for her with colors union down, when the brig squared away before the wind; the next day made another brig who also ran away from us.

abstract: -- Mr. FREDERICK VULTE is certainly a man of many friends. A few days ago we printed a countless list of legal gentlemen, judges, attorneys, and others, who concurred in a professional opinion that Mr. VULTE is peculiarly qualified for the functions of Sheriff, and should be chosen for that office, simply as a matter of public expediency. We give place, to-day, to an opinion of the same character, signed by very nearly all the houses of financial and commercial standing in the City; so that even before the election Mr. VULTE may be said to have suffrages of the most influential classes of the community for the office. With indorsements so strong, his merits will have careful consideration in the several Nominating Conventions.

abstract: ERN. The Persia's account of the disaster to this vessel, is about as satisfactory as the traveler's account of the loss of his leg, to the Yan kee interlocutor "It was bit off." What ...
lead_paragraph: ERN.--The Persia's account of the disaster to this vessel, is about as satisfactory as the traveler's account of the loss of his leg, to the Yan kee interlocutor "It was bit off." What carried away both paddle-wheels, the rudder-post and the boats? That this was due to size alone, is contrary to all this vessel's former experience in heavy weather. That the Great Eastern rolled excessively when the Persia spoke her, may be very satisfactorily accounted for by the loss of her paddle-wheels -- by the loss of two hundred tons of weight twenty-five feet above the water-line. It is well known that a ship loaded only at the bottom, or partly full of water, or deprived of the top weight of her masts, rolls as if she were going to capsize at each plunge. The Great Eastern had very little cargo or weight, above water, of course, to balance the enormous weight of her engines and boilers, in the bottom. A leak, filling one or two compartments near her keel would aggravate this already abnormal motion, (for the ship cannot be trimmed for heavy weather without a full cargo,) and might have caused motion enough to have sprung and broken the shafts, which had no outboard bearings. The loss of her wheels, however, is sufficient cause for excessive rolling, and does not at all condemn her dimensions as to seaworthiness. We can surmise no normal cause of the loss of the paddle-wheels except tins -- excessive racing of the wheels, to a degree never possible in smaller ships. The Great Eastern would span two waves whose crests might be four hundred to six hundred feet apart. With her bow on one and her stern on the other, it may be readily imagined that both paddle-wheels would be several feet, perhaps ten or fifteen feet, clear of the water, and so get up an excessive velocity, in default of proper regulating apparatus, properly applied and in first-rate order -- a state of things to be expected from the management of the Great Ship Company -- and so, when the rear wave let down her stern, and the forward wave rolled back, enveloping full half of both wheels in an instant, the sudden check to the motion might well have twisted the shafts off and let the wheels drop. This is the only reasonable theory in the absence of the facts -- if we ever get them.

abstract: Yesterday the libels heretofore filed against property belonging to Southern citizens, in the control of the Bank of the Republic, American Exchange Bank, and the New-York Life Insurance and Trust Company, were dismissed by Mr. Eman Allen, the Assistant United States District Attorney. The parties libeled filed with the District Attorney written assurances that the property seized was not intended to be used in promoting the rebellion, directly or indirectly, upon which Mr. Allen dismissed the proceedings.

abstract: A large number of the members of this Club assembled last evening at its rooms in the Cooper Institute. Hon. TRUMAN SMITH, of Connecticut, being present, on invitation addressed the meeting. He spoke at length on the causes of the rebellion, arguing that there was and could be no good reason for it. The South, he said, has always had more of National power and patronage than the North, and it is the love and loss of these which has precipitated the Slave States into their present treason. Mr. SMITH proposes at a future time to address the Club on secession as a constitutional question. E.H. SPOONER. Esq., next addressed the Club. He rejoiced that after what had fallen from the lips of the eloquent and patriotic Senator who had preceded him, that it was unnecessary to discuss the question of the right or wrong of secessionism. The Club was agreed that it was a crime: that it was without any adequate cause, and must and will be triumphantly crushed out. [Applause.] But there was a matter in which this Association and all other people might improve, and that is public confidence. Only by relying upon the honesty and ability of the Administration and the power of the Army can the Union be maintained. It has been intimated that Mr. SEWARD and others in the Cabinet are jealous of FREMONT, and cripple his movements, fearing him as a rival candidate for the Presidency in 1864. Why do not these grumblers remember that unless MCCLELLAN and FREMONT are successful, there will be no election in 1864, and no President to be elected. [Applause.] Mr. S. spoke at some length, after which the question of Emancipation, which has been before the Club for some evenings past, was discussed by Messrs. CROW, BOURNE and others, when, on motion, the Club adjourned.

abstract: The following in regard to the disaster to the steamship Great Eastern is taken from the English papers:
lead_paragraph: The Great Eastern left her moorings in the River Mersey at 1 1/2 o'clock on Tuesday, the 10th of September. The pilot left her at 4 o'clock. Immediately putting on full speed, all went well with her until 4 o'clock on Thursday, when a strong breeze prevailing, the aft tackle of one of the forward boats on the port side became unhooked, leaving it suspended by one tackle. The Captain endeavored to steady the ship while this was rectified; but found, to his surprise, that the ship would not answer the helm. The fact was, though it was not known at the time, the rudder-pin was broken. The fore-staysail was run up, but the wind immediately split it into ribbons. The fore-trysail was then run up, but it was blown away. The paddle engines were now stopped, and the boats ordered to be cut away, when the Great Eastern once more started on her course. The passengers then went down to dinner, and from that moment commenced a chaos of breakages which lasted without intermission for three days. Everything breakable was destroyed. Furniture, fittings, services of plate, glasses, piano -- all were involved in one common fate. It now became known that the rudder was unmanageable. About 6 o'clock the vessel had to be stopped again, owing to two rolls of sheet lead, weighing some hundred weight each, which were in the engine-room, rolling about with every oscillation of the vessel with fearful force. These having been secured, another start was made, when a tremendous grinding was heard under the paddle-boxes, which had become twisted, and the floats were grinding against the side of the ship. The paddles were stopped, and thenceforward the scene is described as fearful in the extreme. The ship rolled to violently that the boats were washed away. The cabin, besides undergoing the dangers arising from the crashes and collisions which were constantly going on, had shipped, probably through the port-holes, a great deal of water, and the stores were floating about in utter confusion and ruin. Some of the chandeliers fell down with a crash. A large mirror was smashed into a thousand fragments; rails of bannisters, bars, and numerous other fittings were broken into numberless pieces.

abstract: To-day being the opening day of the October Term, processes were returned with others in thirty-two cases commenced by the Government against vessels and various other property as enemy's property. abstract: Quiet again prevailed along the National lines across the Potomac yesterday, our troops occupying undisturbed the positions taken up by them during the first days of the week. The rebel lines are believed now to extend from Leesburgh to Aquia Creek, some sixty miles, and from the most reliable information which can be obtained, it is thought they have scattered over this extent of country between one hundred and one hundred and twenty-five thousand men. No general engagement is now anticipated immediately, as the rebel forces are too much scattered to render one probable. The force which on Monday made its appearance at Great Falls has not since shown itself in that vicinity.

abstract: At the present time, with very large Army expenditures, and some doubt as to how the money is to be raised, every economy should be practiced consistent with utility. One important saving may be made in introducing hemlock tanned leather instead of oak tanned, for all purposes of shoes, harness, and military equipments.
lead_paragraph: Oak leather is twenty-five per cent. higher than hemlock, and from its scarcity, likely to advance much more. A pair of shoes made from oak, and sewed, will cost the Government two to two and a quarter dollars, while the same shoe made from hemlock, and pegged, would cost a dollar to a dollar and a quarter. Few will assert that an oak shoe will do more service than a hemlock one. It is said to be more easy and pliable to the feet. This I doubt. Let hemlock shoes be made of the regular Army pattern, with broad soles, and not too heavy uppers, and the uppers made soft and pliable with plenty of oil, and if pegged, have a lining placed inside, and it will be quite as easy as an oak one, and quite as durable.

abstract: CATTLE STEALING IN BROOKLYN. -- Out in that part of Brooklyn bordering on old Bedford, a portion of the city somewhat rural, there is a lot of vagabond, half-grown boys that go the rounds about once a week and steal all the cows that they can find feeding outside of the lots and now and then letting out cows on the sly, in order to steal them. These cows are pounded, and the owners have to pay a fee, part of which goes to the young thieves, who claim to have found them as strays. This trick of cow-stealing is now a trade, and in the locality we speak of, the weekly haul is from thirty to forty cows -- which have been regularly stolen about once a week all Summer. In the rear of the Ninth Ward Police Station, is a public place, partly inclosed, forming it into a lane, in which these stolen cattle are unlawfully pounded, apparently under the protection of the officials there. This is a crying nuisance to the neighborhood. One of the editors of the TIMES occupies a residence opening upon this lane, and a morning or two since, as his little daughter, aged about eight years, was returning from the grocer's with a loaf of bread, some half-dozen of those young thieves came rushing in upon he heels a herd of over 30 cows, in full trot. It was only by clambering up a fence in her frigid, and tumbling headlong into a lot in the rear of the Police Station, that she escaped being trodden to death by the dashing beasts.

abstract: The movements of the rational forces in Kentucky are prompt and energetic. The demonstrations down the line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, under the direction of Gen. SHERMAN and Col. ROUSSEAU--two of the most dashing officers of the Union-- have driven back the rebels from their more advanced positions; and it is even believed ...
lead_paragraph: that they have evacuated Munfordsville, where they were thought to have two thousand men. It is supposed they will make their first stand at Bowling Green, which is one hundred and eleven miles from Louisville. This would be yielding about fifty miles of the line of the railroad which they have heretofore commanded; and if the report prove true, it will indicate a fearfulness of the enemy and a vigor on the part of SHERMAN and ROUSSEAU most auspicious to the speedy triumph of the Union cause. Bowling Green is only forty-six miles north of the Tennessee line, and to push the enemy from within forty miles of Louisville so far back as that, is a worthy achievement.

abstract: Under date of 14th inst., by steamer Connecticut, I sent an account, which you have doubtless received, of a boat expedition, under command of Lieut. JOHN H. RUSSELL, United States Navy, from this ship, for the purpose of burning a schooner which the rebels were lifting out at the Pensacola Navy-yard for a privateer, &c. In that communication I spoke of several discharges, from our howitzers, at the rebel troops that began to rally upon the wharf as our boats were withdrawing from the burning vessel. At that time I could not speak positively of the effect of the "canister shot" from the boat howitzers. By news obtained from another deserter that came to Fort Pickens from the other side, last night; I learn that thirty were killed and a number more wounded. This corroborates the observations make by some of our officers the day after the burning affair. It was noticed from Santa Rosa Island -- just opposite the Navy-yard -- that some twenty-five or thirty men were carried on board a small steamer that crime down from the town of Pensacola, to which place the steamer returned after receiving this freight. The men were carried in cots, and were, no doubt, the wounded, or a portion of them, who had received the benefits of the howitzer practice from our First and Second cutters on the night of the 13th. "W."

abstract: -- A person intimatealy known to a prominent commercial house of this City, which vouches for his entire reliability, arrived here a few days ago from North Carolina. This witness is exceedingly strong in his testimony as to the prevalence of Union sentiments in his State. He avers that Union men openly declare themselves verywhere, and the number augments daily. It will be remembered that the secession [???] at Raleigh reported the Legislature, upon the receipt of the news of the affairs at [???] was Inlet, as indulging in a demonstration which the reporters "hoped never to hear repeated." The latter expression, quite incomprehensible on the supposition of a united Legislature of traitors, caused much speculation at the moment. The present deponent explains it by saying that the demonstration consisted in vehement cheers for the Union from a large body of the members, who were at no pains to conceal their unaltered fidelity to the National flag. He adds his opinion, that every repetition of such successes upon the coast will tend to strengthen the cause of the Union, in North Carolina at least.

abstract: -- The man who makes two blades of grass grow where only one grew before, is a public benefactor. So says philosophy. The man who gives to us a thousand lives which would otherwise be laid in the grave, is a still greater public benefactor. So says common sense. And such a man, to our judgment, is the inventor of the "Patent Rope Reel," which, as a fire engine, is conveyed to a conflagration, carefully gathers up whatever slack of the rope the inequalities of the ground and so on may occasion, and keeps it from tripping up and leading to a violent death any one who might accidentally step upon it. In descending a hill for distance, when an engine or hose carriage acquires an impetus that it is difficult to restrain, exceedingly cautious men often let go of the rope, especially when exhausted by a long run, lest their feet might catch in that portion of it which, slackened by the descent, drags upon the ground. To tread upon such is almost inevitable death, and to avoid treading on it is a feat of no small dexterity. Now, it is clear that if some simple apparatus were attached to the carriage on a run which would let out the rope when more was needed and promptly gather up the superfluity whenever it slacked, all danger would be avoided. But then it must be a self-operating apparatus, and one requiring no attention of the firemen at hand, who would have at that moment something else to think about. It must be something that would act instantly, effectively, and of itself. Just such an apparatus is the "Patent Rope Reel" in all respects, and firemen and others interested have now an opportunity to scrutinize its simplicity and effectiveness with case, since its inventors, Messrs. SCHUYLER & ROCKWELL, have placed it upon the Marion Hook and Ladder No. 13, the house of which is in Third-street, near Avenue D, for public inspection. Many of the members of the Fire Department have already examined it, and they express their satisfaction in no measured terms. They are convinced that it will rescue many a human life, and that it is, on that account, a life-preserver of the first class, that no Fire Engine, Hose or Hook and Ladder Company can do without and manifest a proper regard for the security of its public-spirited associates. The "Patent Rope Reel" is, emphatically speaking, one of the great desiderata of the age. -- Sunday Times.
lead_paragraph: -- The man who makes two blades of grass grow where only one grew before, is a public benefactor. So says philosophy. The man who gives to us a thousand lives which would otherwise be laid in the grave, is a still greater public benefactor. So says common sense. And such a man, to our judgment, is the inventor of the "Patent Rope Reel," which, as a fire engine, is conveyed to a conflagration, carefully gathers up whatever slack of the rope the inequalities of the ground and so on may occasion, and keeps it from tripping up and leading to a violent death any one who might accidentally step upon it. In descending a hill for distance, when an engine or hose carriage acquires an impetus that it is difficult to restrain, exceedingly cautious men often let go of the rope, especially when exhausted by a long run, lest their feet might catch in that portion of it which, slackened by the descent, drags upon the ground. To tread upon such is almost inevitable death, and to avoid treading on it is a feat of no small dexterity. Now, it is clear that if some simple apparatus were attached to the carriage on a run which would let out the rope when more was needed and promptly gather up the superfluity whenever it slacked, all danger would be avoided. But then it must be a self-operating apparatus, and one requiring no attention of the firemen at hand, who would have at that moment something else to think about. It must be something that would act instantly, effectively, and of itself. Just such an apparatus is the "Patent Rope Reel" in all respects, and firemen and others interested have now an opportunity to scrutinize its simplicity and effectiveness with case, since its inventors, Messrs. SCHUYLER & ROCKWELL, have placed it upon the Marion Hook and Ladder No. 13, the house of which is in Third-street, near Avenue D, for public inspection. Many of the members of the Fire Department have already examined it, and they express their satisfaction in no measured terms. They are convinced that it will rescue many a human life, and that it is, on that account, a life-preserver of the first class, that no Fire Engine, Hose or Hook and Ladder Company can do without and manifest a proper regard for the security of its public-spirited associates. The "Patent Rope Reel" is, emphatically speaking, one of the great desiderata of the age. -- Sunday Times.

abstract: We are now far enough advanced in the season to see that the total value of importations of foreign merchandise, exclusive of bullion, into the United States, for the year ending Dec. 31, will not exceed $175,000,000, which is fifty per cent, less than in 1860. The falling off will probably fully equal $185,- 000,000.
lead_paragraph: We have suddenly ceased to consume a great many articles of foreign manufacture, partly from a general retrenchment of expenses, and partly from the use of domestics, which, under the present almost prohibitory tariff on all we can produce, are henceforth to take the place of foreign articles. Our factors abroad, consequently, have been notified to send home our balances in specie, which has flown in upon us, exclusive of the products of our own mines, at the rate of more than a million dollars per week since the year commenced. The current still sets toward us, and will swell the amount by the end of the year to more than $50,000,000 over the export. We exported last year $56,000,000 in specie over imports, to make good the balances against us. Here is a difference, in one short year, in the exchanges between the two countries equal to more than $100,000,000, to be liquidated in specie.

abstract: A VERY FREE LIVER. -- HUGH POWDERLY, a grocer, at No. 71 West Twenty-fifth-street, whose lugubrious looks expressed more plainly than his speech the troubled condition of his mind, appeared before Justice CONNOLLY on Monday, and complained that he had been swindled by a young colored man named JOHN CAJAY. He exhibited a letter which the accused had given to him, purporting to have been written by Capt. LEANDER BUCK, of Company F, Eighth Regiment, N.Y.S.M. The document testified to the honesty, industry and worth of the accused representing him as having been in the Captain's employment while the regiment was on its three months' campaign in Virginia, and asking that he might be furnished with groceries for his needy family, which would certainly be paid for as soon as he received his pay from the Government. The grocer having a kind heart, without hesitation, complied with the request, permitting CAJAY to run up a bill at various times, for the following choice selection: A peck of potatoes, valued at 16 cents; three pounds of ham, 39 cents; one pound of sugar, 8 cents, two heads of cabbage, 8 cents; two loaves of bread, 10 cents and a pint of brandy 12 cents; a quart of beer, 3 cents; more bread, 5 cents; an ounce of black tea, 3 cents, and two tallow candles, 4 cents; more brandy and beer, sand witched between two ounces of starch and a couple of pecks of hard coal; also, some butter, and bread to spread it upon; two pounds of meat, and another pint of brandy to assist in its deglutition -- the aggregate amount reaching $2 36. The grocer learned, after this assortment of luxuries had passed from his hands beyond hope of recovery, that Capt. BUCK's name to the letter was forged. He therefore caused the arrest of the epicurean deceiver, who was committed to prison for trial.
lead_paragraph: A VERY FREE LIVER. -- HUGH POWDERLY, a grocer, at No. 71 West Twenty-fifth-street, whose lugubrious looks expressed more plainly than his speech the troubled condition of his mind, appeared before Justice CONNOLLY on Monday, and complained that he had been swindled by a young colored man named JOHN CAJAY. abstract: Harris Aaronson vs. Meyer Cohen. -- The plaintiff herein alleged that in the Fall of 1860 the defendant procured of him a large bill of goods by means of false representations, and that he was now in this City, about to depart for unknown parts. Upon these charges the defendant was arrested. He now made application for discharge, alleging that he was in this City because he'd rather be here than in the Southern Army. He related in his papers that when the war waxed hot, he left Oxford, Miss., and went to Memphis, Tenn., where he expected to profit more than at Oxford, as it was supposed that Memphis would become a great mart. So far as business was concerned, he was soon undeceived. The cry was for war, and all must join therein. He was finally placed upon a military committee to proceed to Louisville, Ky., for uniforms, whither he went. He escaped from Louisville, North, and was much relieved thereat. He left, as alleged, an invalid brother in Memphis to attend to his business, and he had no intention of defrauding any one. He was discharged.

abstract: Foreigners who, almost up to the present moment, have regarded the civil war now raging in the United States as possessing political significance alone, and as deserving attention only from the inferences it enables them to draw unfavorable to our institutions in contrast with their own, are beginning to discover that they perhaps have a deeper interest than ourselves in the contest, and that their commerce, and not our existence and welfare as a nation, may be made shipwreck in the great maelstrom which they see raging across the Atlantic.

abstract: The complex character of modern civilization is strikingly illustrated in the terrible part which certain commercial elements have come to play in the solution of National questions.
lead_paragraph: It is not now as during the simpler organization of society, and before material interests had bound nations into a solidarity of mutual interests and mutual dependence. Then an issue was made on its own merits: now it is, to a large degree, a question of exports and imports, tariffs and exchanges. It has been wittily remarked, that the fate of the world literally hangs on a thread, in allusion to the tyranny which cotton exercises. It may not be out of season to inquire how far the fate of the world is based on smoke --in other words, what is likely to be the effect of the blockade on the tobacco supply of the European markets?

abstract: Capt. CATHCART, of the schooner Fleetwood, arrived this morning from Fort Pickens, reports that on the 20th of September, when three miles south of Cape Hatteras, saw a fore-and-aft schooner, pilot built, (probably the Henrietta,) with a color in her rigging as a signal for us to speak her, but she being a suspicious-looking customer, and seeing a large gun amidships, concluded to give her a wide berth. She made no attempt to chase us.

abstract: The United States gun-boat Seneca, just completed at the Novelty Works, yesterday made the trial trip, with the Government inspectors and a considerable party of other gentlemen on board. Among others were Capt. JOSEPH J. COMSTOCK. Commodore GREGORY, HORATIO N. ALLEN, and Capt. FORBES. The vessel left the Novelty Works at 9 1/2 o'clock A.M., and proceeded under moderate steam down the bay. During the trip the propeller was worked up to 90 revolutions per minute, the vessel attaining a speed between 10 and 11 knots an hour. The machinery worked perfectly, and gave entire satisfaction to the inspectors. During its greatest velocity, there was no heating of the journals apparent, a circumstance which was highly gratifying for the first trial. The vessel went outside the Light-ship, and on her return she was handed over to the Government, and left at the Navy-yard. This is the third vessel completed by the Novelty Works within the required time, and the fourth, the Pembina, will make her inspection trip on Friday. The Seneca is of precisely the same dimensions as the other boats, which have been fully described in the TIMES.

abstract: The Kings County Republican General Committee held a meeting, on Tuesday evening, at their rooms, No. 9 Court-street, C.W. GODARD, President, in the chair. At the last meeting, held one week ago, ...
lead_paragraph: The Kings County Republican General Committee held a meeting, on Tuesday evening, at their rooms, No. 9 Court-street, C.W. GODARD, President, in the chair. At the last meeting, held one week ago, a report of the Executive Committee, calling primary meetings to elect delegates to the different Conventions to nominate candidates for county and other offices to be filled at the ensuing election, was laid on the table to await the action of the so-called Peoples' or Union Convention, held at the City Hall last Saturday. The special business, therefore, before the Committee was the consideration of the report of the Executive Committee. Mr. COIT, of the Sixth Ward, Chairman of the Committee, moved that the consideration of the report be indefinitely postponed. This motion was put and lost by the following vote -- ayes, 35; noes, 43.

abstract: We pub  lish this morning the decisions of Judge BETTS in two more of the prize cases, the bark Pioneer and the schooner Crenshaw.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning the decisions of Judge BETTS in two more of the prize cases, the bark Pioneer and the schooner Crenshaw. In the former case no point was involved except the general questions of enemy's property, of the right to blockade, etc., which were discussed in the case of the. Hiawatha. But in the case if the Crenshaw, special questions were brought up for decision, as to whether the owners of the vessel had notice of the blockade, and whether the cargo should be forfeited, the same being claimed by persons nonresident in Virginia. Parts of the cargo were claimed to be owned by persons resident in Liverpool, and in Leith, Scotland, and was accordingly restored to them, the Court holding, as was manifestly just, that they could have had no notice of the blockade and no intention of violating it.

abstract: It is only on rare occasions that Commerce lends herself to relaxation, but when she does so it is with so complete a heartiness, that we forget her usual austerity and are carried away with the genuine pleasure of the event. The proprietors of the Liverpool, New-York and Philadelphia Steamship Company ...
lead_paragraph: It is only on rare occasions that Commerce lends herself to relaxation, but when she does so it is with so complete a heartiness, that we forget her usual austerity and are carried away with the genuine pleasure of the event. The proprietors of the Liverpool, New-York and Philadelphia Steamship Company are not given to play. Any one who takes the trouble to step upon their wharf at Pier No. 44, will find that their usual avocation is to crush, run over, and otherwise utterly annihilate the mere seeker after idleness. Carts that are driven by men who apparently thirst for your life; horses of venerable aspect but savage instincts; ropes that lie under your feet and deceitfully pretend to be fastened until you tread upon them, when they run away with a shriek; huge bales and barrels that stagger in mid-air as if they too had seen the elephant before going on board; platforms that sidle up to the ship's side insidiously, and lurch you overboard if you are not very wide-awake -- these are the sort of things that welcome the ordinary visitor to Pier No. 44. He sees around him a scene of activity. Commerce, like a sturdy wench, has her petticoats looped up, and her arms bared, and the words which drop from her lips are not the peaceful communings of a gentle spirit. The average visitor, in a word, is very apt to have enough of it.

abstract: The Fifth Senatorial Republican Convention met last evening, at RUNK's Hotel, in Grand-street. Five delegates each from the Tenth, Eleventh, Thirteenth and Seventeenth Wards, responded to their names. JOSEPH L. PERLEY was chosen Chairman, and GEORGE GAMBY, Secretary. The prominent candidates named were Supervisor THOMAS LITTLE, ANDREAS WILLMAN and ANDREW KROFT, the votes being pretty equally distributed between them. After an ineffectual effort to agree, the Convention adjourned, to meet again at the call of the Chair.

abstract: JUDGE MAYNARD ROBBED JOHN T. BROWN, formerly a constable, now a bill collector, was arrested by Officer CUMMINGS, of the Tombs Police Court, on Tuesday evening, charged with having stolen $322.32 from Judge ARBA K. MAYNARD, of the Marine Court. The accused had a claim against the ...
lead_paragraph: JUDGE MAYNARD ROBBED.--JOHN T. BROWN, formerly a constable, now a bill collector, was arrested by Officer CUMMINGS, of the Tombs Police Court, on Tuesday evening, charged with having stolen $322.32 from Judge ARBA K. MAYNARD, of the Marine Court. The accused had a claim against the Judge for collection, and presented it on Saturday, when he had no money in his pocket. Mr. MAYNARD sent BROWN to GEORGE H. PURSER, with directions for the latter to draw a check in his favor upon the Broadway Bank, payable to him or his order. Instead of doing so, BROWN requested Mr. PURSER to draw the check payable to bearer, which was done, and he, of course, had no difficulty in obtaining the money from the bank. After waiting a reasonable time, and hearing nothing of BROWN, Judge MAYNARD made inquiries which satisfied him of the man's dishonesty. He, therefore, had him arrested, and Justice OSBORNE has the case under examination. The prisoner refused to account for the money.

abstract: The Twelfth Anniversary of the American Bible Union commenced yesterday in the Church, corner of Broome and Elizabeth streets Rev. T. ...
lead_paragraph: The Twelfth Anniversary of the American Bible Union commenced yesterday in the Church, corner of Broome and Elizabeth streets Rev. T. ARMITAGE, D.D., the President, in the Chair. Although the ramifications of the Society extend throughout the whole of the United States, there were, of course, no delegates present from the South -- the attendance being, therefore, unusually small. A long list of Vice-Presidents was appointed, consisting of Reverend gentlemen from all portions of the country, and several from England, including Rev. Mr. SPURGEON.

abstract: The story we reprint this morning from the Charleston Mercury must be read with the profoundest sorrow and mortification.
lead_paragraph: The story we reprint this morning from the Charleston Mercury must be read with the profoundest sorrow and mortification. That so many of our best and bravest fellows, officers and men, should be paraded as a part of a barbarous military spectacle through the streets of a traitorous town, and that town of all others, Charleston, the fount and origin of all treason, must be perpetually remembered as one of the darkest pictures of a warfare which there have been so very few incidents to enlighten. And when the rebel melodrama ends with the consignment of these gallant hundred and fifty to the common jail of Charleston, a prison famous for its discomforts, unwholesomeness and insufficient diet, in apartments entirely destitute of beds and other furniture, we submit that we have a tale of shame and suffering which may fairly excite the commisseration of the stoutest-hearted. There is as yet no mitigation of Summer heat in the latitude of South Carolina, a circumstance that must seriously enhance the unhappy condition of the prisoners.

abstract: It is evidently no part of the plan contemplated by the rebels in arming the banks of the Potomac to waste their powder upon small merchantmen and transports. Such squandering of projectiles would be incompatible with that economy of material without which they will come distressingly short before they have reached the end of the war. So far as this class of vessels is concerned, the Potomac remains open. But if a man-of-war, or other craft of sufficient dimensions to occasion by its sinking a permanent interruption of the channel, attempt to pass the batteries below Aquia Creek, it is quite possible its impunity may not be so secure. These works have not been created with so much cost and labor without a purpose, and we know of nothing thus far that shows a disposition to abandon the first intention.

abstract: His Excellency Gov. MORGAN has been requested by the War Department to constitute one of the regiments from the State of New-York an Engineer Regiment, and to get the same ready for active duty at the seat of war with the greatness possible dispatch. He has accordingly ordered that the regiment organized by Col. SERRELL, as the Engineer and Artisan Regiment, be remustered into the service of the United States as engineer officers and soldiers. This is the only engineer regiment that has been called for by the United States Government from any of the States. The men of this regiment will receive the pay of sappers and miners, and the officers will rank other volunteers. Col. SERRELL brings a widely-known name as an Engineer to this service. Although but 34 years of age, his name is identified with many works in this country, among which are the first suspension bridge across the Niagara River and that at St. John, N.B. He has built fourteen railroads, been connected as Engineer with the water-works of Boston, Brooklyn, Bridgeport and St. John; has been four years Consulting Engineer of the Hoosac Tunnel, and was Consulting Engineer to the Committee of the House on the Pacific Railroad. He is familiar with the country and fortifications about Beaufort, N.C., where he owns a large tract of land. In fact, built the railroad connecting Beaufort with Goldsborough, and also that connecting Cape Fear River with Western North Carolina.

abstract: Since men can only understand, and so conform to the laws of Nature, by eliciting, grouping and weighing the greatest possible number of phenomena, grand improvements ...
lead_paragraph: Since men can only understand, and so conform to the laws of Nature, by eliciting, grouping and weighing the greatest possible number of phenomena, grand improvements are always the result of persevering experiment -- of alternate failure and remedy in detail, till at last the complex whole is adequate and harmonious. The only way, therefore, to perfect great enterprises -- ocean navigation for instance -- is to thank the experimenter -- that unthanked class to whom we are indebted for every improvement -- for each new fact elicited. To sneer at a whole, unconditionally, because a part is defective, after the manner of a morning cotemporary, is not only discouraging, but illiberal and ridiculous.

abstract: The news from Washington, this morning is without special interest. No movement of either Army appears to have taken place within the last twenty-four hours. Our troops, of course, still
lead_paragraph: The news from Washington, this morning is without special interest. No movement of either Army appears to have taken place within the last twenty-four hours. Our troops, of course, still occupy the advanced positions recently taken up by them, and it appears to be pretty well settled that the withdrawal of the rebel forces from these positions was simply a part of a general retrograde movement. Speculation is still indulged in as to the cause of the movement, but no satisfactory conclusion appears yet to have been arrived at. One explanation, which may be as good as any other, is that the rebels were fearful of a flank movement by the National Army, and fell back to avoid it.

abstract: The Texan soldiers on Governor's Island were paraded a few days ago for the purpose of having arms issued to them. They have been unarmed since their surrender in Texas. But only thirty out of the whole number consented to receive arms.
lead_paragraph: The Texan soldiers on Governor's Island were paraded a few days ago for the purpose of having arms issued to them. They have been unarmed since their surrender in Texas. But only thirty out of the whole number consented to receive arms. Subsequently they were again paraded and addressed by their officer, who explained that, although they were asked to take arms, it was not intended that they should be required to do anything in violation of the oath forced upon them in Texas. After this assurance, all the men, with the exception of two or three, took the arms offered them, and are now doing regular guard-duty on the island. Hitherto they have had no duty at all to attend to beyond the necessary camp policing. The men generally are dissatisfied at not receiving their discharge, which they expected would be granted to them on their arrival at Fort Hamilton.

But only thirty out of the whole number consented to receive arms. Subsequently they were again paraded and addressed by their officer, who explained that, although they were asked to take arms, it was not intended that they should be required to do anything in violation of the oath forced upon them in Texas. After this assurance, all the men, with the exception of two or three, took the arms offered them, and are now doing regular guard-duty on the island. Hitherto they have had no duty at all to attend to beyond the necessary camp policing. The men generally are dissatisfied at not receiving their discharge, which they expected would be granted to them on their arrival at Fort Hamilton.

abstract: The United States gun-boat Seneca, just completed at the Novelty Works, yesterday made the trial trip, with the Government inspectors and a considerable party of other gentlemen on board. Among others were Capt. JOSEPH J. COMSTOCK. Commodore GREGORY, HORATIO N. ALLEN, and Capt. FORBES. The vessel left the Novelty Works at 9 1/2 o'clock A.M., and proceeded under moderate steam down the bay. During the trip the propeller was worked up to 90 revolutions per minute, the vessel attaining a speed between 10 and 11 knots an hour. The machinery worked perfectly, and gave entire satisfaction to the inspectors. During its greatest velocity, there was no heating of the journals apparent, a circumstance which was highly gratifying for the first trial. The vessel went outside the Light-ship, and on her return she was handed over to the Government, and left at the Navy-yard. This is the third vessel completed by the Novelty Works within the required time, and the fourth, the Pembina, will make her inspection trip on Friday. The Seneca is of precisely the same dimensions as the other boats, which have been fully described in the TIMES.

abstract: It is only on rare occassions that Commerce lends herself to relaxation, but when she does so it is with so complete a heartiness, that we forget her usual austerity and are carried away with the genuine pleasure of the event. The proprietors of the Liverpool, New-York and Philadelphia Steamship Company ...
lead_paragraph: It is only on rare occassions that Commerce lends herself to relaxation, but when she does so it is with so complete a heartiness, that we forget her usual austerity and are carried away with the genuine pleasure of the event. The proprietors of the Liverpool, New-York and Philadelphia Steamship Company are not given to play. Any one who takes the trouble to step upon their wharf at Pier No. 44, will find that their usual avocation is to crush, run over, and otherwise utterly annihilate the mere seeker after idleness. Carts that are driven by men who apparently thirst for your life; horses of venerable aspect but savage instincts; ropes that lie under your feet and deceitfully pretend to be fastened until you tread upon them, when they run away with a shriek; huge bales and barrels that stagger in mid-air as if they too had seen the elephant before going on board; platforms that sidle up to the ship's side insidiously, and lurch you overboard if you are not very wide-awake -- these are the sort of things that welcome the ordinary visitor to Pier No. 44. He sees around him a scene of activity. Commerce, like a sturdy wench, has her petticoats looped up, and her arms bared, and the words which drop from her lips are not the peaceful communings of a gentle spirit. The average visitor, in a word, is very apt to have enough of it.

abstract: stalwart negro, whose manners proclaimed him to be demented, was arrested on Tuesday evening for assaulting Officer BOOTH, of the Twentieth Ward. The prisoner had a large bag of meal under one arm, and was mounted upon a barrel in Thirtieth-street, harranguing a crowd of men and boys. The burden of his discourse was the happiness of southern slaves, and he announced his determination of going to Dixie's Land to tender his feeble arm in support of the rebels -- the aforesaid bag of meal being provided for his journey. The policeman hearing his ravings, asked him if he had not talked enough, and at the same time pushing over the barrel caused a subsidence of the eloquence. JONES was naturally irate at the indignity, and springing to his feet, hit the officer in the face, coupling the blow with the assertion that he could whip any Yankee policeman. The result, however, did not verify the boast, and the "colored gemman" was marched to the station-house. Alderman CHIPP yesterday locked him up.

abstract: JUDGE MAYNARD ROBBED. JOHN T. BROWN, formerly a constable, now a bill collector, was arrested by Officer CUMMINGS, of the Tombs Police Court, on Tuesday evening, charged with having ...
lead_paragraph: JUDGE MAYNARD ROBBED.--JOHN T. BROWN, formerly a constable, now a bill collector, was arrested by Officer CUMMINGS, of the Tombs Police Court, on Tuesday evening, charged with having stolen $322 32 from Judge ARBA K. MAYNARD, of the Marine Court. The accused had a claim against the Judge for collection, and presented it on Saturday, when he had no money in his pocket. Mr. MAYNARD sent BROWN to GEORGE H. PURSER, with directions for the latter to draw a check in his favor upon the Broadway Bank, payable to him or his order. Instead of doing so, BROWN requested Mr. PURSER to draw the check payable to bearer, which was done, and he, of course, had no difficulty in obtaining the money from the bank. After waiting a reasonable time, and hearing nothing of BROWN, Judge MAYNARD made inquiries which satisfied him of the man's dishonesty. He, therefore, had him arrested, and Justice OSBORNE has the case under examination. The prisoner refused to account for the money.

abstract: The census returns in relation to the movement of population, the sources of the wealth, and the condition of the several States, throw
lead_paragraph: The census returns in relation to the movement of population, the sources of the wealth, and the condition of the several States, throw important light upon the probable result of the complications in which the country is involved. The total population of the revolted States in 1850 was 7,272,086, of which 2,809,362 were slaves. In 1860 the grand total was 9,466,689, of which 3,884,436 were slaves. The increase of the white population for the ten years was 1,118,630, or a fraction over 20 per cent. In 1860, in the loyal States, including Missouri and Maryland, the free white population numbered 15,402,457. In 1860 it amounted to 21,595,464. The increase, therefore, was 5,791,608, or about 37 1/2 per cent. -- nearly double that of the revolted States. It will be remembered that this increase of the loyal States is made up largely of emigration front Europe, consisting in the main of hardy, frugal, industrious people, who come to this country to better their fortunes, looking for freedom of individual labor, and a field for their enterprise, which lacked scope and verge at home; -- that they brought with them more or less of the precious metals, received for the sale of their little property in the old country, the which, with their productive industry, have added largely to the wealth and resources of this.

abstract: Hannah Tobias vs. Ann Eliza Cohn and Wm. Cohn. This action was brought by the plaintiff to recover damages for alleged injuries to real property. The plaintiff's deceased husband, Silas Tobias, by his will gave her as a residence certain apartments in a dwelling-house owned by him, known as No. 615 ...
lead_paragraph: Hannah Tobias vs. Ann Eliza Cohn and Wm. Cohn. This action was brought by the plaintiff to recover damages for alleged injuries to real property. The plaintiff's deceased husband, Silas Tobias, by his will gave her as a residence certain apartments in a dwelling-house owned by him, known as No. 615 Fourth-street, in the City of New-York. The testator was also the owner of the adjoining house, No. 617. The lots on which the buildings were erected were, together, 49 feet 6 1/2 inches, front and rear, and 96 feet 2 inches deep. The buildings were 35 feet deep, and 49 feet 6 1/2 inches in width. At the time of the death of Tobias there was no line-fence between premises, which were tenant-house. In March, 1857, the plaintiff removed from the apartments willed to her, and rented them; and in October, of the same year, the defendant, Ann Eliza Cohn, one of the executors of the will of Tobias, caused a fence to be run through the yard, thus giving each house a separate yard, and preventing the tenants of one house from using or occupying the yard of the other. In consequence of this act, the plaintiff, who was still, as alleged, not in possession of the premises or apartments willed to her by her husband, brought this action; although, as alleged by the defendant, the executrix offered to take away the fence if the plaintiff herself wished to return there to reside.

abstract: Cold, chilly nights in Virginia -- frost already appearing in the low grounds! This is a meteorological fact, full of meaning for the two armies. Our own soldiers, it is reported, are suffering somewhat -- though, doubtless, by this time, the arrangements have been perfected for supplying them with blankets and other Winter gear. But what must be the condition of JEFF. DAVIS' rebel host, sleeping blanketless in the night-fogs of Eastern Virginia, with the quicksilver down to the small figures? Those hot-blooded, thin-skinned fellows from Carolina, Georgia or the Gulf States will have a chance to get some of the fine taken out of them by the sharp blasts from the Alleghanies and the cold night sea-winds. They have relied on cotton with which to bully the world; it will prove powerless to protect their own shivering limbs withal. There was a great deal of exultation in the Southern newspapers, this Spring, as to the havoc which the Southern climate would play with the Northern troops. But the tables are now turned. We have waited till the frosts set in before attempting to march into the heart of Dixie; while, meantime, the Southerners from the warm Gulf borders are quaking at the first taste of our upper latitudes. On the whole, the effects of these early frosts cannot but be to precipitate matters with the rebel forces. From physical cowering to moral cowardice there is but a narrow interval. Great is Fahrenheit -- terrible to the Southrons is old Boreas!
lead_paragraph: Cold, chilly nights in Virginia -- frost already appearing in the low grounds! This is a meteorological fact, full of meaning for the two armies. Our own soldiers, it is reported, are suffering somewhat -- though, doubtless, by this time, the arrangements have been perfected for supplying them with blankets and other Winter gear. But what must be the condition of JEFF. DAVIS' rebel host, sleeping blanketless in the night-fogs of Eastern Virginia, with the quicksilver down to the small figures? Those hot-blooded, thin-skinned fellows from Carolina, Georgia or the Gulf States will have a chance to get some of the fine taken out of them by the sharp blasts from the Alleghanies and the cold night sea-winds. They have relied on cotton with which to bully the world; it will prove powerless to protect their own shivering limbs withal. There was a great deal of exultation in the Southern newspapers, this Spring, as to the havoc which the Southern climate would play with the Northern troops. But the tables are now turned. We have waited till the frosts set in before attempting to march into the heart of Dixie; while, meantime, the Southerners from the warm Gulf borders are quaking at the first taste of our upper latitudes. On the whole, the effects of these early frosts cannot but be to precipitate matters with the rebel forces. From physical cowering to moral cowardice there is but a narrow interval. Great is Fahrenheit -- terrible to the Southrons is old Boreas!

abstract: His Excellency Gov. MORGAN has been requested by the War Department to constitute one of the regiments from the State of New-York an Engineer Regiment, and to get the same ready for active duty at the seat of war with the greatest possible dispatch. He has accordingly ordered that the regiment organized by Col. SERRELL, as the Engineer and Artisan Regiment, be remustered into the service of the United States as engineer officers and soldiers. This is the only engineer regiment that has been called for by the United States Government from any of the States. The men of this regiment will receive the pay of sappers and miners, and the officers will rank other volunteers. Col. SERRELL brings a widely-known name as an Engineer to this service. Although but 34 years of age, his name is identified with many works in this country, among which are the first suspension bridge across the Niagara River and that at St. John, N.B. He has built fourteen railroads, been connected as Engineer with the water-works of Boston, Brooklyn, Bridgeport and St. John; has been four years Consulting Engineer of the Hoosac Tunnel, and was Consulting Engineer to the Committee of the House on the Pacific Railroad. He is familiar with the country and fortifications about Beaufort, N.C., where he owns a large tract of land. In fact, built the railroad connecting Beaufort with Goldsborough, and also that connecting Cape Fear River with Western North Carolina.

abstract: A statement of our Washington correspondent illustrates the completeness of the enemy's communications with its agents at Washington and in the North. When the rebel quarters on Mason's Hill were occupied, on Sunday, copies of the New-York journals of Saturday were found among other matters the runaways left behind them. As papers of that date had not yet been distributed among the National troops, our fellows had the curious satisfaction of receiving news rom home by the hands of the rebel fugitives. Nothing can be clearer than that the embargo our military authorities have endeavored to lay upon such intercourse is of small value; land that if the rebels fail to learn news ovalue to their enterprise from New-York papers, it is because those papers discreetly withhold from publication all material having that tendency.

abstract: United States Marshall MURRAY yesterday received orders from Washington to release the follow- ing prisoners, confined at Fort Lafayette, on their tak- ing the oath of allegiance: Win. F. McKernin, Benj. F. McCauley, Jas. Campbell, Alex. O'Connor ...
lead_paragraph: United States Marshall MURRAY yesterday received orders from Washington to release the follow- ing prisoners, confined at Fort Lafayette, on their tak- ing the oath of allegiance: Win. F. McKernin, Benj. F. McCauley, Jas. Campbell, Alex. O'Connor, Frederick Golanback, Patrick Conroy, Samuel Davidson, Geo. Gossnell, Geo. Gowmers, Philip Cassady. The Marshal repaired to the Fort, and administered the oath to all of them except CASSADY, who refused to take it. The prisoners belong to Baltimore. As they were destitute of money to pay their passage back to Baltimore, they concluded to remain the Fort last night, and meantime the Marshal has telegraphed to Washington to know whether they shall be taken back at the expense of the Government.

abstract: We could scarcely expect that the leading Powers of Europe would permitt our serious home troubles to pass, without availing themselves of the splendid opportunity thus afforded...
lead_paragraph: We could scarcely expect that the leading Powers of Europe would permitt our serious home troubles to pass, without availing themselves of the splendid opportunity thus afforded for accomplishing schemes to which, under other circumstances, we should oppose a firm and a formidable resistance. Nations, like men, make hay while the sun shines. When their rivals have their hands full at home, they feel safe in pursuing any little expedition of profit or plunder, from which, at other times, they would have been restrained by a wholesome apprehension of consequences.

abstract: A PHYSICIAN CHARGED WITH MURDERING A CHILD. Coroner JACKMAN yesterday held an inquest upon the body of an infant which was murdered on Tuesday evening, at the tenement-house No. 334 Greenwich-street, twelve hours after its birth. Its mother, a woman named MARY ANN BAKER, took apartments in the house about ten days since, and represented herself as the wife of a soldier who had gone to the war.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning she wastaken sick, and one of the neighbors sent for Dr. PETTIJEAN to attend to her. He was present when the child was born, and the mother offered him money to destroy it. Of course, he refused, and when he left the house the infant was perfectly well. A few hours later a Dr. WILSON visited the woman and took the child from its nurse. He handled it roughly, according to the testimony of witnesses, squeezing its chest with his hands and applying tight bandages to its body. Some women who were present protested against the inhuman treatment, but the Doctor said it was all right -- that he had handled children that way before. As might have been expected, it was not long before the babe exhibited symptoms of suffocating, and it soon died, its body meanwhile changing from the natural color to a dark blue. The Doctor left before death ensued, promising to return, but he has not since been seen, although an effort' has been made to find him. Other circumstances were developed by the testimony, showing conclusively that the mother was ashamed to acknowledge the child, and before its birth had submitted to treatment at WILSON'S hands with a view of getting rid of it. The jury rendered a verdict of "death from violence at the hands of Dr. WILSON, and we consider the mother, MARY ANN BAKER, an accessory before the fact." It is probable that the name of WILSON was assumed by the accused. None of the witnesses knew anything about him, but Mrs. BAKER told the Coroner that his office was in Second-street. She is at present too ill to leave her bed, but the Police have her under surveillance.

abstract: Col. HENRY W. ADAMS, late Captain United States Sharpshooters; Lieut.-Col. A.S. GIBBS, late Major-General of the Sixth Division Massachusetts Militia, have recruited about 600 men within three weeks.
lead_paragraph: Col. HENRY W. ADAMS, late Captain United States Sharpshooters; Lieut.-Col. A.S. GIBBS, late Major-General of the Sixth Division Massachusetts Militia, have recruited about 600 men within three weeks. Col. ADAMS has received both a military and collegiate education, and has served in all capacities up to a field-officer. Lieut.-Col. GIBBS has held command from a non-commissioned officer to a Major-General of the Sixth Division of Massachusetts Militia. The officers are all educated, military men. A few more recruits are wanted. Head-quarters, No. 334 Broadway.

abstract: The Hanover Company, Julius Pratt et al. vs. John Kelly, Sheriff,  This action was brought against the Sheriff to recover damages for the alleged escape of Horace B. Sheldon from the jail limits of the City and County of New-York, on the 25th ...
lead_paragraph: The Hanover Company, Julius Pratt et al. vs. John Kelly, Sheriff, &c.--This action was brought against the Sheriff to recover damages for the alleged escape of Horace B. Sheldon from the jail limits of the City and County of New-York, on the 25th of August, 1859, Sheldon having been placed upon the limits on execution against his body in favor of the above plaintiffs. The plaintiffs proved by two witnesses that they tracked Sheldon from his place of business in Warren-street to several places in the City of New-York, and finally to his residence in Hoboken, and that they there watched him, he remaining at his residence during the night.

lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The schooners Hannah M. Johnson.--This schooner was captured the 31st of May, 1861, twelve miles to the southwest of Cape Lookout, on the high seas, by the United States brig- of-war Perry, under command of Lieut, E.G. Parrott and was libeled for confiscation and condemnation, with the goods and cargo on board her, as lawful prize. She is charged with giving aid and comfort to the enemies of the United States, and during her previous voyage, and prior thereto, having carried the flag of the treasonable league called the "Confederate States of America," enemies at war with the United States. An allegation against her of having violated the blockade of New-Orleans, was abandoned by the District-Attorney on the trial of the cause.

abstract: A startling report reaches us from New-Orleans by way of St. Louis published in the Republican of the latter city. It states that a letter has been received from New-Orleans the date of
lead_paragraph: A startling report reaches us from New-Orleans by way of St. Louis--published in the Republican of the latter city. It states that a letter has been received from New-Orleans the date of which, however, is not given -- announcing that a fleet of seventy National vessels was coming up the Balize to capture the place. We cannot, of course, vouch for the truth of this report, but it is by no means an improbable one. It is well known that the Government has for sometime been purchasing and fitting out steamers for special service, and that a numerous body of sailors has been recruited -- and it is equally certain that these steamers and sailors have not been retained in the Northern ports. The comparatively defenceless position of New-Orleans, and its importance as a commercial port, have quite likely induced the Government to plan its capture, as the most effectual blow which could be struck against the rebels at the present time. It will be recollected, also, that Dr. RUSSELL, in one of his recent letters to the London Times, has made mention of such an expedition, intended to proceed up the Mississippi River to meet Gen. FREMONT on his progress down.
