abstract: The fact that Senator BRECKINRIDGE has thrown off the mask, and taken the field against the Government, is significant of what may be attempted and expected in Kentucky. Such a step would not have been taken but upon the confident expectation that this State was safe for the rebels. All their power will be put forth to overrun and hold it, to prevent which 50,000 National troops should at once be moved upon its soil. The die being cast here, no half-way measures will be resorted to by the rebels. The invasion of the State was not accidental, but a thoroughly preconcerted measure, undoubtedly in the belief that it could be made entirely successful. The importance of Kentucky to both parties cannot be over-estimated. If the rebels can hold if, they can Winter their armies there. If we can drive them from it, we can force them to disband. Both parties understand this. The contest there will be on a scale corresponding to the magnitude of the stake involved.

abstract: We had an interview, yesterday, with two gentlemen of intelligence and character, who have come North, within a few days past, from North Carolina, where they have been ...
lead_paragraph: We had an interview, yesterday, with two gentlemen of intelligence and character, who have come North, within a few days past, from North Carolina, where they have been for some time residing as agents of Northern capitalists, who had large interests in the gold mines of that State. They came by way of Nashville, where they were delayed several days by objections made to giving them passports. They applied first to the Passport Committee, organized under JEFF. DAVIS' proclamation giving resident "foreigners" forty days within which time they must depart. They were referred to Gen. FOSTER, who was in command of that Department, and who objected to letting them go mainly on the ground that their perfect familiarity with the mountains, passes and general character of the country, would render them dangerous persons. They were finally released, however, and permitted to proceed. One of them was at Nashville at the time of the Bull Run battle, -- and on passing through East Tennessee, over the line of Railroad immediately after that event, he saw troops pouring into Virginia in immense numbers and with the greatest rapidity. During the last week in July alone, 40,000 were known to have passed through that section. BRAGG'S artillery, which is generally supposed to be still at Pensacola, was at that time sent forward to Cumberland Gap, the importance of which was fully appreciated by the rebels.

abstract: Tammany Halldoes not mean to be betrayed by the Democratic wire-pullers of the State into any questionable position on the great issue of the day. It gives renewed assurance of the determination of the people of the North to postpone all party considerations and unite in the defence of the Union and the Constitution.

abstract: The London Times makes the invitation, said to have been extended by the American Government to GARIBALDI, to enter the National Army, the occasion for an elaborate
lead_paragraph: The London Times makes the invitation, said to have been extended by the American Government to GARIBALDI, to enter the National Army, the occasion for an elaborate piece of scolding. "As if despairing of native genius or enterprise," that journal says, "the President at Washington has actually sent to ask GARIBALDI to accept the post of Commander-in-Chief, throwing into the bargain the emancipation of the slaves. It costs an effort to take in the extravagant oddity and the humiliating character of this proposal." Let us say that it costs us an effort to appreciate the motive that could prompt so wanton a statement, for the Times' own correspondent at Turin, who furnishes an account of the rumored transaction, distinctly declares his disbelief in it.

abstract: If the farmers of the country were to advertise that they had breadstuffs and provisions enough to feed the Army the manufacturers merchants that they could furnish ...
lead_paragraph: If the farmers of the country were to advertise that they had breadstuffs and provisions enough to feed the Army--the manufacturers merchants that they could furnish all the clothing, including tents and blankets, needed by the soldiers -- the ship-builders and ship-owners that they could supply all the additions necessary for the Navy and for transports -- the mechanics that they could furnish all the guns, all the arms, all the wagons, and the various means of land transportation connected with the movements of the National troops -- nobody would doubt the ability of any of these to do what they proposed. If the capitalists, large and small, were to offer to the Government all the money necessary for the successful prosecution of the present war, nobody would doubt their ability to furnish it as fast as required. In fact, no one will question the ability of the American people to provide everything necessary to carry on this war, even on the gigantic scale on which it has been planned, and which the magnitude of the rebellion to be overcome demands. The problem to be solved is, Can the Government render payment for all these things in coin, or its equivalent in a credit so stable as to be accepted as a substitute?

abstract: In addition to the recall from foreign stations of almost every ship of war we had, Government has purchased and fitted with armaments, or adapted to transport service, several hundred sailing-vessels and sea-going steamers, which have been dispatched, as fast as possible, on some mission or other. As the number is greater than that necessary to maintain the blockade, it is fair to presume that a second Hatteras expedition is on foot. This gives plausibility to the report that a fleet of National ships have rendezvoused off New-Orleans, for the purpose of attacking that city. We should sappose that such an expedition would carry a large land force which can have hardly been the case. It is certain, however, that an enterprise of some kind is being directed against the Southern coast, of which the rebels have got wind, as they have recalled troops from Virginia and are rapidly garrisoning their more important property. We shall probably hear of a blow being struck in some quarter in a very few days. We are now bringing our strong arm into the contest against which the rebels have nothing whatever to oppose, and which will soon begin to give us successes to compensate for the lack of brilliant achievements on land.

abstract: Our telegraphic correspondence from St. Louis announces, on the strength of a letter received from New-Orleans, that a fleet of seventy vessels was ascending the Mississippi for the purose of attacking that city.
lead_paragraph: Our telegraphic correspondence from St. Louis announces, on the strength of a letter received from New-Orleans, that a fleet of seventy vessels was ascending the Mississippi for the purose of attacking that city. The evidence is, as yet, scarcely sufficient to warrant us in placing implicit reliance on the statement. But it may be worth while to remark that very many circumstances concur to render probable the appearance of such an expedition in that quarter at about this time.

abstract: Not one of the cotton States is self-sustaining in the matter of food. When the ordinary sources of supply are interrupted, prices, as a matter of course, advance. Bacon, the staple
lead_paragraph: Not one of the cotton States is self-sustaining in the matter of food. When the ordinary sources of supply are interrupted, prices, as a matter of course, advance. Bacon, the staple article of food for nine-tenths of their people, is now selling in all their leading towns at 600 per cent. advance over the average peace prices, or at thirty cents per pound instead of five. The supply from Kentucky, Missouri and the Free States of the West being cut off, starvation prices are already reached. Prices of many other necessaries have advanced, probably in similar ratio. Flour is at 100 per cent. advance. Such a state of things, which is quite bad enough for the permanent or local population, and renders the concentration and maintenance in one position of large bodies of troops impossible, is the real cause for the recent invasion of Kentucky by the rebels; those of a strategical character -- to oppose the march of our troops southward -- being a mere blind. The rebels knew very well in the outset that they could never sustain a war in the cotton States; hence the involving of the border or food-producing States was absolutely necessary to success. In none other could they feed their Armies, while if these could be held, they would constitute a barrier against Northern invasion. They were successful in Virginia, and consequently concentrated the great body of their troops there. This State must now be pretty well exhausted, so much so as to afford very poor Winter quarters for a large army. They encouraged their soldiery to believe that these quarters would be in the Northern cities of Baltimore. Philadelphia, and even New-York. Such expectations are now thoroughly dispelled. The Potomac marks the most northerly boundary of their power. An irresistible necessity, therefore, forces them into Kentucky. This must take the place of the rich cities that were to afford them good quarters and abundant spoil. Missouri has been occupied for a similar reason; but Missouri does not compare with Kentucky in the extent of its resources. The latter State is one of the richest in the Union in food, particularly in the abundance and excellent qualities of its beef. It has a genial climate, is easily accessible from the other States, and could not be better adapted to the necessities of the rebels. Its vast material wealth is most attractive to them, as in their estimation they have only to reach out their hands to make it their own. From necessity as well as principle, they have adopted as their motto, "Base is the slave who pays!"
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Movement upon Kentucky.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Movement upon Kentucky.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: PERSONAL. -- Mr. MUNSON, the proprietor of Munson's Hill, in Virginia, from which the rebels have just retreated, has been, with his daughter, spending several days at Salisbury, Conn. His farm embraces about two hundred acres. He was compelled to leave it after the retreat of our troops from Bull Run. His son, who remained behind for a few days, had his horse shot under him by the rebels, when he was finally compelled to fly, but escaped himself unharmed. The whole family are devoted to the Union, and Mr. M. was one of the very few persons in that vicinity who voted for LINCOLN at the last election. His house and barns have all been burned.
lead_paragraph: PERSONAL. -- Mr. MUNSON, the proprietor of Munson's Hill, in Virginia, from which the rebels have just retreated, has been, with his daughter, spending several days at Salisbury, Conn. abstract: The Mounted Artillery Company from Boston, under command of Capt. PORTER, consisting of 151 men, arrived here yesterday forenoon, in the steamers Empire State and Bay State, of the Fall River Line.
lead_paragraph: The Mounted Artillery Company from Boston, under command of Capt. PORTER, consisting of 151 men, arrived here yesterday forenoon, in the steamers Empire State and Bay State, of the Fall River Line. The battery consists of six pieces: four brass six pounders -- two of them rifled, and two smooth-bore -- and two 12-pound howitzers; three powder and six baggage-wagons, with all the appliances complete for a first-class battery. They have with them 150 trained horses, and a large quantity of SCHENCK's projectiles and ammunition. The company have been in camp at Cambridge, and came on by the Old Colony Railroad Line. The large majority of the members served in Maj. COOK's light battery, when it was stationed in Baltimore in April last. The men present a line appearance, and will no doubt equal any similar corps which has been sent to the seat of war. Quartermaster Howe made the requisite arrangements for their accommodation upon arrival, and the battery took up temporary quarters on the Battery. They will depart during the day for Washington, via the Camden and Amboy route.

abstract: The United States Notes, of $5, $10 and $20, may be properly called "Gold Notes," because they are payable in gold on demand. abstract: We have no words to waste on the Herald's fabrication about FREMONT'S removal. The public takes it as a matter of course. Even the habitual readers of that paper have no more disposition than they have right to complain of this little experiment on their credulity. They have become so accustomed to
lead_paragraph: We have no words to waste on the Herald's fabrication about FREMONT'S removal. The public takes it as a matter of course. Even the habitual readers of that paper have no more disposition than they have right to complain of this little experiment on their credulity. They have become so accustomed to these performances that they rather like them, and pronounce the Herald dull on those rare occasions when it tells the truth. When, after the repulse at Big Bethel, the Herald announced that Gen. BUTLER had proceeded in person to the place, conquered it at sight, and taken a thousand prisoners, its readers did not believe it -- but they had an agreeable "sensation" for nearly a whole day, -- and this was precisely what they had bargained for. The Herald was the first to announce the death of JEFF. DAVIS, -- and nine of its readers out of ten were inclined to give it a service of plate for a lie at once so grateful and so well timed. The truth is the Herald lives and has its being by thus titilating the public curiosity, -- by inventing news to suit the public taste; and the prosperity of which, it boasts, shows the shrewdness of its calculation. Its theory is that people take a newspaper, not for instruction, but for the gratification of an appetite; -- and that the more it can stimulate their curiosity and excite their wonder, by whatever means, the more sure it is of readers. If it tells a falsehood one day, it relies on its being forgotten the next -- while it meanwhile enjoys the luxury and profit of a day's notoriety.

abstract: It seems very difficult to please the English Press with our public affairs. One portion horrifies its readers with pictures of the anarchy already begun in our once orderly cities; socialistic ruffians meeting to denounce property as robbery, and soon to demand "bread or blood" of the Government; mobs violating
lead_paragraph: It seems very difficult to please the English Press with our public affairs. One portion horrifies its readers with pictures of the anarchy already begun in our once orderly cities; socialistic ruffians meeting to denounce property as robbery, and soon to demand "bread or blood" of the Government; mobs violating all private safeguards, plundering the houses of obnoxious citizens, and breaking up the types of papers which dared to speak their mind; the lowest classes ruling the upper, and mob law everywhere triumphant and despotic. No doubt cold thrills of horror seized upon the comfortable English country gentleman as he perused these frightful accounts over his morning tea, and he blessed his fortune which had saved him from the rule of the mob.

abstract: A NEW STEAMBOAT FOR CUBA. The new steamboat, Neustra Senora De Regla, built by JOHN ENGLIS, is now completed, and is lying at the foot of Tenth-street, East River. It is one of the finest boats ever built at our ship-yards, and is destined for Cuba. It is intended to ply between certain landings in the vicinity of Havana. The cabins attract a great deal
lead_paragraph: A NEW STEAMBOAT FOR CUBA. The new steamboat, Neustra Senora De Regla, built by JOHN ENGLIS, is now completed, and is lying at the foot of Tenth-street, East River. It is one of the finest boats ever built at our ship-yards, and is destined for Cuba. It is intended to ply between certain landings in the vicinity of Havana. The cabins attract a great deal of attention from visitors, by reason of the beautiful manner in which they are decorated. They are lined on either side with paintings, representing scenery in all parts of the world. These views are finely executed in oil, and reflect great credit on the artist, Mr. HENRY BOESE, of this City. Mr. BOESE decorated the two Brazilian steamers which were built in this City, and which left here in the forepart of August last. New-York may justly be proud of her ship-builders and artists, if the workmanship and decorations of these boats are to be regarded as specimens.

abstract: Because Quartermaster-Gen. MEIGS, whose resources and expedients seem as infinite as his industry, confesses weakness upon the single point of warm covering for sleeping soldiers, and begs contributions of blankets which the market cannot supply, we are not to infer that our Army is necessarily to winter in the northern tier of the rebel States.
lead_paragraph: Because Quartermaster-Gen. MEIGS, whose resources and expedients seem as infinite as his industry, confesses weakness upon the single point of warm covering for sleeping soldiers, and begs contributions of blankets which the market cannot supply, we are not to infer that our Army is necessarily to winter in the northern tier of the rebel States. There is a very common misunderstanding at the North about the Southern Winter. The rebel States are mainly within the tropics; and a tropical climate is assumed to be one of perpetual Summer, where magnolias bloom the year round; fruits are always awaiting the gatherer, and fields, not white with cotton or yellow with corn, are green with luxuriant grass. The popular idea is, in short, that King Frost, upon no provocation, and at no time, invades the territories of King Cotton. It is unnecessary to tell the traveler how far are such impressions from the truth. The Southern Winter, though shorter, and rarely as rigorous as that of the Middle States, nevertheless has its periods of severe cold, when ice may be found upon the streams and ponds, and snow on the ground. With the exception of Florida, none of the States is exempt from these frosty conditions. The inhabitants, of course, accustomed, five-sixths of the year, to a genial or torrid temperature, suffer from such visitations of cold much more sensitively than the Northerner, but the latter can expect neither comfort nor health in the absence of the same precautions which are demanded by the Winters of Pennsylvania.

abstract: Accounts from Mendoza to the latter part of August represent that active preparations are making to renew hostilities between Buenos Ayres and the Confederacy. On the 22d of July Buenos Ayres had in all 20,000 men ready for the war, and would invade Santa Fe within six weeks. She has 3,000 men at work upon her fortifications. So great is the enthusiasm in Buenos Ayres that mere children wish to enroll themselves. There is not a single student in the University -- all have taken up arms.

abstract: The above map of Missouri will be found full of interest at the present moment, when all eyes are turned toward that State, in view of the extraordinary events occurring there. If a line
lead_paragraph: The above map of Missouri will be found full of interest at the present moment, when all eyes are turned toward that State, in view of the extraordinary events occurring there. If a line be drawn from a point just back of Bird's Point bearing northward and verging towards Cape Girardeau, then deflecting westward, passing a little south of Ironton, and continuing on in the same general direction between Rolla and Waynesville to Versailles; thence, circling around to the west of Sedalia and Georgetown, and turning sharply eastward to Arrow Rock; and thence taking both banks of the Missouri, westward to Kansas City, the northern limit of insurrectionary domination in Missouri will be very accurately described. All south and west of the line thus drawn is under subjection to the rebels, and it is nearly one-half of the territory of the State.

abstract: A battle took place in Western Virginia on Thursday, between a portion of Gen. REYNOLDS' Brigade and the rebels under LEE. The National
lead_paragraph: A battle took place in Western Virginia on Thursday, between a portion of Gen. REYNOLDS' Brigade and the rebels under LEE. The National troops, numbering 5,000, left Cheat Mountain, to make a reconnoissance in front of the enemy's position on Greenbrier River, twelve miles distant. The objects of the expedition were fully accomplished, and the enemy during the operations was severely punished.

abstract: The news from Missouri to-day is of a stirring character. Gen. PRICE is reported to have evacuated Lexington and to have moved, one report says toward Georgetown another says toward Kansas City; and that Gen. STURGIS had shelled the rear of his retreating columns. We have doubts whether
lead_paragraph: The news from Missouri to-day is of a stirring character. Gen. PRICE is reported to have evacuated Lexington and to have moved, one report says toward Georgetown another says toward Kansas City; and that Gen. STURGIS had shelled the rear of his retreating columns. We have doubts whether either one of the former reports is true -- the last one we are very sure is not. Gen. PRICE may have thrown a heavy force towards Georgetown, and another towards Kansas City. Indeed, his pickets have been encountered within a few miles of Georgetown, feeling their way cautiously toward the Union lines. It is these movements, made no doubt in large force, that have given rise to the belief that Lexington has been evacuated. That Gen. STURGIS had shelled Lexington is palpably impossible. "Our own Correspondent," whose interesting letter we published on the 2d inst., accompanied Gen. STURGIS on his ineffectual march to MULLIGAN's relief, and he testifies to the fact that Gen. STURGIS had not in his charge "a single piece of artillery." Besides, the day after, Gen. STURGIS reached Kansas City. Escaping from before Lexington, he took a boat to St. Joseph. On his return it was published "to Jefferson City." STURGIS is not approaching Lexington, nor could he shell it if he were actually there.

abstract: This State, since the accession of Senor GARCIA MORENO and Gen. FLORES to power, has been quiet, and the Government has been principally occupied in endeavoring to arrange the question of limits with Peru, in order to avoid a war. On the 2d September, a special agent of the Peruvian Government having propositions on this matter, arrived at Guayaquil, on his way to Quito. It is doubtful if a peaceful solution can be had.

abstract: A very fine lithograph, and one of especial interest at the present moment, is published by GOUPIL & Co. As the name would indicate, "The Defenders of our Union," presents portraits of those officers of the National Army who have most prominently distinguished themselves in stemming the tide of rebellion. We have Generals McClellan, McDowell, Siegel, Wool, Dix, Banks, Heintzleman, Anderson, Fremont and Butler. As a matter of course, prominent in the foreground of the picture, stands -- or rather sits -- the imposing figure of that ponderous man of war, Winfield Scott. The title of Fremont to a place in the group will not be read so clearly by those who have followed the course of movements in Missouri of late, but the future and the foe are before him, and he may yet justify the award of the artist and the eulogiums and expectations of his friends. The portrait of Gen. Lyon might very appropriately have been included in the group. In all the Army the Union found no more gallant defender than he. And the fact of his death more richly entitles him to a place in our memories and monuments than though he were living. The portraits are very like, and the picture will probably obtain the favorable recognition it merits.

abstract: Lima and Callao were much agitated on account of a most arbitrary act of President CASTILLA, in forcibly expelling ex-President ECHENIQUE from PeruECHENIQUE, ELESPURUE, RIVAS and others, were charged with a conspiracy against the Government, and were tried and acquitted by the Court of First Instance at Callao.
lead_paragraph: Lima and Callao were much agitated on account of a most arbitrary act of President CASTILLA, in forcibly expelling ex-President ECHENIQUE from PeruECHENIQUE, ELESPURUE, RIVAS and others, were charged with a conspiracy against the Government, and were tried and acquitted by the Court of First Instance at Callao. The case was then taken by President CASTILLAto the Superior Court of Lima, where it also went against the Government, and the accused were ordered by the court to be set at liberty. Upon this, CASTILLA made preparations to expel them from the country, but, on the 9th inst., could find no naval officer who would execute the order, several having plumply refused to have any hand in it, and the commander of the war-ship Guisse having thrown up his commission rather than comply. So, on the 10th, CASTILLA himself went to Callao, and superintended the embarkation of the prisoners, Don FELIPE RIVAS, Don NORBERTO ELESPURU and Don FREDERICO LABRANAGA being placed on board a small vessel called the Iquique, and ex-President ECHENIQUE on the war-steamer Ucayali. Ten miles out at sea the Ucayali placed ECHENIQUE on board the Iquique, where bound nobody knows, but it is supposed to Australia or to Russian America. The Captain of the Iquique gets $20,000 for the job, and $300 a month for four years to travel abroad, as he dare not return to Peru to meet the public indignation. CASTILLA has probably sent them so far that they cannot get back before the Presidential election. The newspapers, generally so silent at Presidential outrages, are furious at this last despotic act, and the people cry out against it with one voice. Some think it will result in a revolution, but I opine that CASTILLA, with the Army to back him, cares but little for popular anathemas.

abstract: "A correspondent of the London News suggest that some man of position in America make the following proposition to the Free and to the Slave States: 'That instead of incurring a debt with blood shed -- among brethren speaking the same mother tongue -- they should incur a debt without bloodshed for the freedom of the slaves, and thus incur a debt which will be a lasting honor to their common country to be recorded on the bead roll of time.'"
lead_paragraph: "A correspondent of the London News suggest that some man of position in America make the following proposition to the Free and to the Slave States: 'That instead of incurring a debt with blood shed -- among brethren speaking the same mother tongue -- they should incur a debt without bloodshed for the freedom of the slaves, and thus incur a debt which will be a lasting honor to their common country to be recorded on the bead roll of time.'"

abstract: The United States Rifles, which has its head-quarters at the rooms No. 239 Broadway, is a regiment composed of citizens of all nationalities, and commanded by a body of officers such as few other American regiments are privileged with. Its commander, Col. KRZYZANOUSKI, is a Polish officer, who served with distinction in the Imperial Army, and afterwards as a patriot in the service of his own nation, and who also did good service in Washington when the Capital was menaced after the fall of Sumter. Lieut.-Col. LESKI, another child of "sorrowful- Poland," achieved distinction in the English service in the Crimea and elsewhere, and is the very beau-ideal of a chivalrous, high-toned soldier and patriot of the olden days of chivalry. The Adjutant, LEONHARDT, another Polish patriot, served his time as an officer in the Army of Prussia, and has testimonials of merit from the King and from the high military officers under whom he served. Latterly he fought for liberty in the Hungarian war of independence, and still later, achieved great fame as a leader in the Kansas war against the Border-ruffians. In 1857, he captured Fort Scott, which BEN. MCCULLOCH is now hovering near with 7,000 men, with a baker's dozen of Kansas boys, and performed many other exploits not less famous. He will undoubtedly be heard of hereafter. The Captains and Lieutenants, and indeed almost every officer in the regiment, have smelt powder and crossed steel on many a hard-fought field; and now, with "the stern joy old warriors feel," gladly unsheath their blades once more, in the cause of American freedom.

abstract: The Medical profession is now much agitated by a dispute in which, as in all those involving the principles upon which it acts, the public at large have a vital interest. The cause of the terrible war is Dr. JOHN C. PETERS, of this city; the actual point at issue is whether there must necessarily be two schools of practice, allopathic and homoeopathic, each anathematizing and excommunicating the members of the other.
lead_paragraph: The Medical profession is now much agitated by a dispute in which, as in all those involving the principles upon which it acts, the public at large have a vital interest. The cause of the terrible war is Dr. JOHN C. PETERS, of this city; the actual point at issue is whether there must necessarily be two schools of practice, allopathic and homoeopathic, each anathematizing and excommunicating the members of the other. The contest, long foreseen by those who have intelligently observed the modifications and special adaptations of practice by the more eminent and successful physicians of both schools, has been precipitated by the announcement of Dr. PETERS -- late and for some years editor of the North American Journal of Homoeopathy -- that he has resigned all connection with any and every sectarian Medical Society and publication and that he now "does not believe or practice according to any one medical dogma or exclusive system." Whereupon the homoeopathists cry, "Get you out from among us. Traitor, renegade, apostate! Anathema maranatha.!" and the allopathists, greedy of such a convert -- "Come and be one of us!" Mother Old-school opens wide her arms to her repentant son: "Welcome home, Benedictus qui verit!" But Dr. PETERS stands fast, and says, "I am not with either of you, nor against either. You are both right, and both wrong. We have none of us received the final revelation of medical truth. We must wait, and watch, and learn." And so he offends both parties; and the battle rages with a fierceness and a venom strangely common in a liberal profession which is justly celebrated for the humanity and benevolence of its members.

abstract: -- Hon. ISAAC W. STUART died in Hartford. Conn., the place of his residence, on Oct. 3. He was born in New-Haven, and was the son of the late Rev. MOSES STUART, the distinguished Biblical scholar. Mr. STUART graduated at Yale College in 1828, [???] the [???] of Greek and Latin in the College of South Carolina for several years, editing, meantime, an edition of Greek Prays, which wore very well received. Subsequently he wrote a History of Hartford in the Olden Time and a Life of Jonathan Trumbull. In politics he was an active Old Line Wing, and as such, he was repeatedly elected to one or the other branches of the State Legislature. Of late years, however, he has been in private [???].

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning report the same condition of quietude across the Potomac which has prevailed most of the time since the withdrawal of the rebel lines. Evidence continues to be received that the main body of the rebel Army has fallen back to Manassas, although yesterday it was discovered that they had an encampment of one or two regiments some seven miles from Munson's Hill, from which their pickets extend nearly to Falls Church. The rebel batteries on the lower Potomac also remain quiet, the Harriet Lane passing up yesterday, without molestation.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington this morning report the same condition of quietude across the Potomac which has prevailed most of the time since the withdrawal of the rebel lines. The rebel batteries on the lower Potomac also remain quiet, the Harriet Lane passing up yesterday, without molestation.

abstract: -- The daughter of Rev. Henry Ward Beecher was married on Wednesday last at Peekskill, to Rev. Samuel Scoville. No guests were previously invited, except relatives and household companions. The bride was dressed in pure white, without a jewel for ornament except nature's jewels of fresh buds and flowers. About the middle of the afternoon, after the wedding-feast, the new-married pair set out upon their bridal tour; not on steamboat or railroad car, but with horse and chaise -- the gift of the bride's father --trotting off for the winding roads of the Highlands of the Hudson, thence to the homes of numerous uncles and aunts in Connecticut and Massachusetts, to return after a few weeks to the town of Norwich, Chenango County, where the bridegroom has lately been called as a Congregational minister. The journey was begun under good auspices, for according to the Irish custom to secure good luck, two of the party had provided themselves each with an old shoe, and as the carriage started, the shoes were thrown after them with a will.
lead_paragraph: -- The daughter of Rev. Henry Ward Beecher was married on Wednesday last at Peekskill, to Rev. Samuel Scoville. The journey was begun under good auspices, for according to the Irish custom to secure good luck, two of the party had provided themselves each with an old shoe, and as the carriage started, the shoes were thrown after them with a will.

abstract: On Monday, Oct. 8, Iowa and Minnesota, and onTuesday, Oct. 9, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana, hold their annual State elections. These contests have little significance the present year, except in those States where the sympathizers with the rebels have succeeded in finding candidates who are willing to sacrifice their politial future for the sake of attaining an altogether unenviable notoriety in the present.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Oct. 8, Iowa and Minnesota, and onTuesday, Oct. 9, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana, hold their annual State elections. abstract: The summary of events recently transpired in Kentucky is brief, but the events themselves are important. The Legislature has passed an act authorizing a loan by the State of $2,000,000, for the purpose of self-defence, and to pay Kentucky's portion of the direct tax levied by Congress.
lead_paragraph: The summary of events recently transpired in Kentucky is brief, but the events themselves are important. The Legislature has passed an act authorizing a loan by the State of $2,000,000, for the purpose of self-defence, and to pay Kentucky's portion of the direct tax levied by Congress. In order to have the money for these objects promptly available, the Legislature provided that the amount might be borrowed from the Banks of the State. A committee was appointed to visit the Banks, apportion the loan among them according to capital, and learn whether they would advance it to the State. In every case, the Banks offered more than was required of them. Kentucky is therefore in excellent credit, as judged by the severest test -- the ability to borrow cash. The Kentucky Banks have an aggregate capital of about $12,000,000. They are in excellent condition, specie-paying, and strongly loyal. Kentucky will be the first State in the Union, apparently, to pay her part of the direct tax levied by Congress, though the Hon. JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE's last speech made before a Kentucky gathering, was a labored and treasonable attempt to induce Kentucky to refuse to pay any part of this tax.

abstract: France is the most military nation in the world, both by instinct and training. The development of the military power of the Empire engrosses the vast energies of the present, as it did those of the first NAPOLEON. Yet to put one in a hundred of his subjects into the field, or 375,000 men, thoroughly equipped for active operation, would tax his means, far exceeding those of any other ruler, to the utmost.
lead_paragraph: France is the most military nation in the world, both by instinct and training. The development of the military power of the Empire engrosses the vast energies of the present, as it did those of the first NAPOLEON. Yet to put one in a hundred of his subjects into the field, or 375,000 men, thoroughly equipped for active operation, would tax his means, far exceeding those of any other ruler, to the utmost. His lists might show a much larger number of men subject to military duty, but men are a very different thing from an army. Without training they are a mob. Without the most complete provision for their mobilization, without equipage, they are incapable of action; and without the best of food, clothing and shelter they fall victims to diseases which destroy them without being brought into the presence of the enemy. We all know what a mighty effort it cost England to put 50,000 men into the Crimea. She could have sent 200,000 there had she chosen, but only to sacrifice them to the climate, for the want of food and shelter. No European Power having no greater population than the South could possibly put more than 50,000 or 75,000 troops, properly armed, trained, provisioned and clothed, into the field. The rebels cannot do even this. They do not possess the means, either in money or materials. They have no suitable manufactories of arms or clothing, nor are they capable of putting such in motion. Their peculiar institution enables them to send a large number of men upon marauding expeditions, which are so attractive to an unemployed and turbulent people, who clothe and arm themselves after their fashion; who are willing to forego pay for the sake of flogging the Yankees, or to commute for it with what they can steal; and who are contented, in the Summer season, with lying on the ground and with rations of bacon and hominy. Such men may be valuable for a guerilla warfare, but they are utterly incapable of contending in the open field with one-third of their number of well-appointed and well-trained troops. The Spaniards are a brave people, but WELLINGTON, in his Peninsular campaign, was never so well pleased as when they were too far off to take part in his battles. No reliance could he placed upon them, and their presence only served to embarrass his operations. Such troops may do very well when opposed to green lines, and in the outbreak of the rebellion were really formidable. But they are rapidly ceasing to be so. Admitting the rebels have 250,000 men with muskets in their hands, which is one-twentieth their whole population, and which is thrice the number in ratio to its population that such a nation as France could keep under arms, they cannot by any possibility form an efficient army of 100,000 men. The thing is impossible, because such an army is the creation of money -- dollars. They have not even commenced the construction of such an army as Gen. MCCLELLAN is forming, with everything that can contribute to health, to rapid movement, to comfortable quarters, and with an abundant supply of food, and the most approved engines of destruction. A nation that wishes to form an army of 100,000 men, complete in every part, must commence by counting down $100,000,000 in hard money. No shams will do, because substance can never come of shams. Men may skirmish for a time, but they will not fight unless they are paid; nor can a commissariat ever be made up by rapine and plunder, or from voluntary contributions. We should at once admit that we should be fast going to destruction, to trust in delusions that any expedients take the place of money. Take the case of the rebels in Missouri. We presume that there is not a military man or civilian in the country who does not believe that 15,000 veteran troops could drive PRICE and his whole crew headlong from the State, no matter how large his force. The larger the worse for him, from the difficulty of handling or feeding them by plunder, as he moves from place to place.

abstract: From a file of the Philadelphia National Gazette for the year 1787, a correspondent has clipped the following paragraphs:
lead_paragraph: "At a critical period of the Revolutionary war, when there was great difficulty in procuring supplies for the American Army, and when there was great danger of a dissolution for want of provisions to keep it together, a number of patriotic gentlemen gave their bonds to the amount of about �260,000 sterling, in gold and silver, for procuring them. The provisions were procured, the Army supplied and kept together,und as a consequence of this act of patriotism, our independence was achieved.

abstract: Your aid is asked in accomplishing the object of the appeal below. It is known that the rebel army is largely supplied with clothing, arms, saddles, and even food and ammunition, by forced and voluntary contributions from the deluded people of the South.
lead_paragraph: Your aid is asked in accomplishing the object of the appeal below. It is known that the rebel army is largely supplied with clothing, arms, saddles, and even food and ammunition, by forced and voluntary contributions from the deluded people of the South. It is not right that the Army of the nation should be required in the least to depend upon such ill-assorted, uncertain, and hazardous supplies. But whenever it can be safely encouraged, aided, and strengthened at all, by voluntary gifts direct from the people, it is fitting and right that such gifts should be cheerfully and generously offered. It is hoped that the response to this imitation will prove that the heart of the people is with the Army in its defence of our nationality. There is not a man, woman or child who cannot do something to testify of a loyal disposition. There are thousands who are not fit to enter the field who cannot offer pecuniary aid, who yet are influenced by as patriotic an impulse as those who are in arms. A little concert of action, and moderate contributions from those who have a superfluity, will afford to such an opportunity of serving their country as truly and as effectually as if they subjected themselves to the hardships and privations and dangers of the campaign. Zeal, and skill, and success in this field of duty as truly testify of patriotism as ardor and sagacity and victory on the field of baise. It is not to be concealed that the occasion is one demanding the most earnest exertion of every patriot. Every ounce that can be added to the weight of the National forces, morally or physically, is wanted.

abstract: The concurrent testimony, not of one or two "reliable gentlemen from Richmond," alone, but of the great body of refugees from the South, is to the effect that the rebels are in downright, desperate, united, awful earnest about the prosecution of this war.
lead_paragraph: The concurrent testimony, not of one or two "reliable gentlemen from Richmond," alone, but of the great body of refugees from the South, is to the effect that the rebels are in downright, desperate, united, awful earnest about the prosecution of this war. Their impetuous natures, brutalized by the institution of Slavery, maddened by the ravings of higher-law Abolitionists, whom they are taught to hate as representative of the whole North, fired by the promise of rapine in the rich cities of the Free States, and blindly struggling for an independence -- that abused watchword at which all people instinctively fly to arms -- an independence pictured to the people as the wealth and luxury to be derived from cheap and universal slave labor, and grasped by the leaders as despotic power -- such natures, thus incensed, are ready to lay down all that they have, and all that they are on the altar of rebellion. Full well do they understand that failure will not permanently injure their condition -- that the commercial North will never suffer them to remain a bleckaded, invaded, thriftless province -- that allegiance restored, they will again take part in the Government, and prosper with it all the more for its being reformed and strong -- and so, if it comes to the worst, they have not "everything to lose." But they have been taught to believe that they have everything to gain, if successful. While fear of political extinction, then, does not deter them from desperate exertion, their blind, ignorant, insane hope of independent power and luxury, founded on Slavery, intensifies every struggle, neutralizes poverty, and pain, and self-denial, and calls out every whit of courage and strength, and substance of which they are masters. As a people, they do not wait to be drafted, or even recruited, but they make common cause with their leaders, and in many cases present themselves, singly, in squads and in companies, armed and equipped, and without the hope of any pay but victory and its fruits -- plunder and Slavery. In short, all these causes have kindled among them an enthusiasm which, for a time, is better than whole shoes, and uniforms, and improved arms, and numbers, and credit, and money. It may not last, indeed, but it is our terrible and desperate foe to-day.

abstract: GENT. -- An enumeration of the several fragmentary organizations in the City shows that at least seven regiments can be manufactured at once from these sources. It also appears that in the same form some twelve regiments exist in the inland counties. It only remains for Major-Gen. MORGAN to complete, by fusing these fragments, the quota of troops called for by the National Government -- a task he shouldexecute without regard to individual feelings and disappointments. Let the expenses of the recruiting officers, and all private expenditures in procuring troops, be liberally reimbursed. No other considerations should be permitted to stand in the way of an instant consolidation of all the outstanding soldiery.

abstract: DEPLORABLE ACCIDENT ON THE STATEN ISLAND RAILROAD. A sad accident occurred on the Staten Island Railroad, near the Princess Bay Station, yesterday, resulting in the almost instant death of Miss MARY AUSTIN, an interesting young lady of 16, residing at No. 165 Charles-street, in this City. Miss AUSTIN
lead_paragraph: DEPLORABLE ACCIDENT ON THE STATEN ISLAND RAILROAD.--A sad accident occurred on the Staten Island Railroad, near the Princess Bay Station, yesterday, resulting in the almost instant death of Miss MARY AUSTIN, an interesting young lady of 16, residing at No. 165 Charles-street, in this City. Miss AUSTIN had been spending a few weeks on the Island, and yesterday morning, while walking on the railroad track near the above station, accompanied by a little boy, the 9 o'clock train from Vanderbilt's Landing approached her from behind, and before she had time to jump from the track, she was caught by the cow-catcher and thrown high in the air, falling senseless on the ground some distance from the track. Medical [???] was soon called, but without avail, and the unfortunate [???] of her injuries in less than an hour. The boy accompanying her, fortunately escaped from the track in time, and was uninjured.

abstract: It is a proverb, old  almost as our language, that "they who dance must pay the piper." Our Government is learning this truth somewhat to its sorrow.
lead_paragraph: It is a proverb, old almost as our language, that "they who dance must pay the piper." Our Government is learning this truth somewhat to its sorrow. Secretary CAMERON, we are told, is quite dismayed to find that the cost of music, by the regimental bands, is running up at a rate that will amount to millions of dollars per annum. To appreciate the fearful expense fully, it may be said that what is now paying for "brass bands," that blow so mightily in dress parades and in "serenading Generals," would have supported the Navy of the United States, as it stood a few years since.

abstract: We must expect foreign journalists to take very inadequate and incorrect views of the controversy now raging on this continent, partly from an inability to appreciate its real object and significance, which can only be...
lead_paragraph: We must expect foreign journalists to take very inadequate and incorrect views of the controversy now raging on this continent, partly from an inability to appreciate its real object and significance, which can only be understood by the actors in it, not by strangers looking on at a distance of many thousand miles; and partly from a desire to record the downfall of a people whose institutions have been objects alike of admiration, of envy, and of hatred, according to the class by which they have been viewed. The argument of that class who persuade themselves that the Great Republic is destroyed, because they wish it to be, is well put, in an article copied by us a few days ago, from the London Times. This, says that journal, is only the contest, as old as history, between the centripedal and centrifugal tendency, or aspirations of the race. The North, it tells us desire union; the South, independence. The South, legally, have the worst side of the argument; historically and naturally, the best. Numberless attempts have been made in Europe to establish an empire coextensive with its territory: but the result is, that this is divided into twenty nationalities. The same law, the Times tells us, is to prevail on this continent, and is to be developed in the issue of the present contest. Slavery has nothing to do with it; commercial ideas but little. We are to be pulled apart by that law, occult in its operations, but palpable in its results, which makes political boundaries correspond with peculiarities of race, however these may be produced.

abstract: We are enabled to give, this morning, the first distinct and intelligible account thus far received of the accident which recently befel the Great Eastern. Beyond the graphic clearness of the narrative, which commends it to the reader, it tends to settle certain questions involving the intrinsic merits of the vessel itself, and of all vessels built of the same monstrous proportions, and driven and guided by similar machinery. The supposition has been that the steamship was perfectly under control, and nearly free from the convulsive motion which in a very heavy sea knocks about smaller vessels mercilessly, until the breaking of the rudder-post left her drifting at random among the tremendous billows. Our correspondent shows, however, that the rudder had ceased to control the ship, and keep her from the trough of the sea, before the fracture: and that the breaking of the steering-gear was one of the consequences, not the cause, of what happened. If this view of the accident be sustained by official inquiry, it must be confessed that so far as the rudder that all-important element of perfect success is concerned, the great ship is a failure, and that all great ships must be failures until greater strenght and leverage, combined with equal mobility, be introduced into the steering apparatus. The other lessons of the incident may be learned from the narrative we give.
lead_paragraph: We are enabled to give, this morning, the first distinct and intelligible account thus far received of the accident which recently befel the Great Eastern. Beyond the graphic clearness of the narrative, which commends it to the reader, it tends to settle certain questions involving the intrinsic merits of the vessel itself, and of all vessels built of the same monstrous proportions, and driven and guided by similar machinery. The supposition has been that the steamship was perfectly under control, and nearly free from the convulsive motion which in a very heavy sea knocks about smaller vessels mercilessly, until the breaking of the rudder-post left her drifting at random among the tremendous billows. Our correspondent shows, however, that the rudder had ceased to control the ship, and keep her from the trough of the sea, before the fracture: and that the breaking of the steering-gear was one of the consequences, not the cause, of what happened. If this view of the accident be sustained by official inquiry, it must be confessed that so far as the rudder that all-important element of perfect success is concerned, the great ship is a failure, and that all great ships must be failures until greater strenght and leverage, combined with equal mobility, be introduced into the steering apparatus. The other lessons of the incident may be learned from the narrative we give.

lead_paragraph: --The Eclectic, for October, as usual, reflects a great deal of credit upon the careful and discriminative Mr. BIDWELL. Faithful to his charge, and indefatigable with his scissors, he goes the round of the foreign periodicals, culling here and clipping there, until, at a very small cost to both himself and his subscribers, he achieves a compilation ion of sketches and essays, which have cost unfortunate foreign authors hours of weary brain-labor, and transatlantic publishers very considerable sums of money. Yet Mr. BIDWELL is not at all blameable, since in no other way could the heart of foreign periodical literature be opened to the American reader.

abstract: It is frequently spoken of as something to surprise one that a physician and surgeon, in the midst of the most active professional employment, should find time to be a prolitic and profitable writer on the various topics that fill this journal. But there should be no surprise about it.
lead_paragraph: It is frequently spoken of as something to surprise one that a physician and surgeon, in the midst of the most active professional employment, should find time to be a prolitic and profitable writer on the various topics that fill this journal. But there should be no surprise about it. It is a fact, that the more a man does, within natural bounds, the more he is capable of doing. The more practice a man has, the more skillful he becomes in his practice. The more he studies and writes about his profession, (it is Lord BACON who truly says that "writing makes the perfect man,") the more competent he becomes to deal dispatchfully and successfully with every new case brought under his consideration. Dr. DIXON has been known many years as one of our most successful operative surgeons, whose precision and skill in delicate and dangerous cases have given him a reputation not confined to the United States. He is also known as an entertaining and instructive writer on almost every subject touching the well-being of man's body and mind, resulting from, individual habits and the organization of society. It is because of the scope and deeply moving interest of these subjects that the Scalpel, published by Dr. DIXON, periodically, we may say fitfully, through a period of eleven years, has the thrilling interest of a novel, and often reminds one of the graphic pages from the Diary of a London Physician. Indeed, a well-known publisher of this City, seizing with true business tact on the example of that well known work, has already published a volume, beautifully illustrated by DARLEY, from the ample pages of Dr. DIXON's work, entitled Scenes in the Practice of a New-York Surgeon, which is held by some to more than rival that celebrated book. Be that, however, as the reader of both books may determine. We propose to speak of the Scalpel in its more comprehensive character -- that of a teacher of the laws of health. It is here that Dr. DIXON is peculiarly forcible, and takes high ground toward his profession.

abstract: The plan of publication which Mr. PUTNAM has adopted in issuing his National Edition of Irving's works, places us in a position of peculiar and regularly recurring embarrassment. With  the first of each month a new volume comes as  punctually as the new moon.
lead_paragraph: The plan of publication which Mr. PUTNAM has adopted in issuing his National Edition of Irving's works, places us in a position of peculiar and regularly recurring embarrassment. With the first of each month a new volume comes as punctually as the new moon. As a matter of course, the publisher expects that something shall be said in praise of his pets, without considering the difficulty of well-speaking when the vocabulary of praise is exhausted. It would be excessively stupid to be forever saying the same thing. After having a dozen times said that the paper is of the purest, the binding of the best, and that the whole is a wonderful achievement of American art, it is really very difficult to say anything more or to write anything new. To expatiate on the literary merits of the works would be to convict one's self of an immaturity difficult for the world at large to imagine, and painful in the extreme for the sensitive mind to acknowledge. Travelers on the Hudson now-a-days do not think it necessary to say much about the scenery to their companions on deck, nor do they, except in the case of a few misguided and inexperienced Englishmen, think it necessary to write long descriptive letters to their friends. Somewhat thus, in reading The Sketch Book or Bracebridge Hall, one gathers the beauties to his heart in silence and folds them there, confident that the world will know he has found treasures though he do not proclaim the fact aloud. To close the book with an enthusiastic emphasis, and nod and wink at all around in a rapture of delight, would be an act of self-stultification not to be permitted by judicious friends. Hereafter, beyond chronicling the advent of each volume, we shall say little further in praise of this National Edition, though we may here add, in addition to the truism that IRVING's works are something that no well-ordered library can be without, our own hearty conviction that for the edition now in course of publication every well-balanced and properly-posted shelf will particularly pine. The volume with which Mr. PUTNAM furnishes us this month is christened Astoria.

abstract: Our Washington dispatches report that yesterday was the most quiet Sunday which has been experienced in that vicinity since the occupation of the west bank of the Potomac by the National troops. The rebels did not show themselves at any point. On Saturday they brought some guns to within about a mile of Falls Church, and fired several shots at our troops, but the distance was...
lead_paragraph: Our Washington dispatches report that yesterday was the most quiet Sunday which has been experienced in that vicinity since the occupation of the west bank of the Potomac by the National troops. The rebels did not show themselves at any point. On Saturday they brought some guns to within about a mile of Falls Church, and fired several shots at our troops, but the distance was too great for them to do any damage. Two shots having been fired at them by CARLISLE's Battery, the rebels withdrew their guns and retired again over the hills. There is to be another grand review of cavalry and artillery to-morrow, which is expected to surpass any which has preceded it.

abstract: If the complete success of the Irish Brigade depended upon the meeting at the Academy of Music, last evening, it would be most indubitably assured. The house was crowded in every part with an audience composed of Erin's most stalwart sons and fairest daughters.
lead_paragraph: If the complete success of the Irish Brigade depended upon the meeting at the Academy of Music, last evening, it would be most indubitably assured. The house was crowded in every part with an audience composed of Erin's most stalwart sons and fairest daughters. From the upper private boxes depended the standards of the Emerald Isle and of the United States; and the hours from the opening of the doors to the commencement of the Oration were beguiled by music which awakened memories of the shamrock, as well as of the Stars and Stripes. Suddenly the melody swelled to a volume of martial sounds the gaslight assumed its most glaring brilliancy, and amidst the most deafening cheers and long continued plaudits, Mr. MEAGHER headed a long line of distinguished guests proceeding to the stage. Among the most familiar faces were those of Judge DALY, Collector BARNEY, Judge CONNOLLY, Lieut.-Col. NUGENT, Alderman BAGLEY, and others of equal note. Their appearance was the signal for a cry from an enthusiastic Celt, for "three cheers for Bull's Run." Failing to elicit these, he called for a similar compliment to the name of Mr. MEAGHER, which was given with a will.

abstract: Of the education which is to make us a military people, a portion will be given by our military leaders, but three-fourths will be instilled by the enemy. The encounters of the battle field will teach steadiness and courage -- surprises will teach caution. The capture of the National propeller Fanny, in [???] shows much is to be learned in the last particular. The little vessel -- imperfectly around and carrying a small body of inexperienced soldiers -- was cruising about those waters, as if every inlet, and tributary, and wave, indeed were in the possession of Union forces, andthe rebels wholly exterminated. Yet Roanoke Island was known to be thronged with hostile troops; it was known that numerous armed vessels, were anchored there, ready to pursue any offered prey; and it was hardly possible that the opportunity of recruiting their [???] by the addition of the Fanny would be foregone by the insurgents. These considerations, which should have imposed caution required the actual loss of the little vessel to reenforce them, and at this cost we have probably saved ourselves from a similar display of foolish hardhood, which ,might come infinitely dearer.

abstract: -THE WOUNDED MAN LIKELY TO DIE. -- Coroner JACKMAN was. notified yesterday that John Smith, who was stabbed on Friday evening by his brother Peter, near their residence, in Lawrence-street, was likely to die, and the Coroner repaired at once to the residence of their mother, as above, to hold an ante-mortem examination in the case. The evidence went to show that the brothers quarreled about a money mater and about Peter's having struck or pushed John's wife. Peter seized a knife, and with it stabbed John in the jaw right side and left hand. The wound in the side, it is feared, will prove fatal. Peter is in prison, awaiting the result of the injuries. The Coroner's jury rendered a verdict to the effect that the wounds were inflicted by Peter Smith.

abstract: We sailed from Liverpool under the most fa vor able auspices, about 2 o'clock in the afternoon of Tuesday, 10th September. The quays were lined with thousands I might say, scores of thousands of...
lead_paragraph: We sailed from Liverpool under the most fa vor able auspices, about 2 o'clock in the afternoon of Tuesday, 10th September. The quays were lined with thousands I might say, scores of thousands--of spectators, and we were accompanied down the river by several small steamers, some following us as far as the Bell Buoy, to take back the friends of passengers who had accompanied them so far. There was some detention there, and it was about 4 o'clock before the leviathan ship got fairly under way. Little of moment occurred that evening, some time and trouble being required to rectify confusion arising from errors in the allotment of berths. People had not settled into their places, and it was difficult for a passenger to find a steward, or to get any attendance; the superintendent of this department was slow, rude, and inefficient. Still, matters gradually settled themselves, and when bed-time came, the berths were exceedingly comfortable, linen, &c, perfect in cleanliness and quality, and the state-rooms generally, roomy and convenient. Meantime, the motion of the ship was hardly perceptible, and there was no reason why all should not sleep as well as in their own beds; and, judging by the aspect of the passengers on the following Wednesday morning, they must have generally done so. All were bright and cheerful, and the breakkstf-tables were crowded to a degree novel to an Atlantic voyager, one day out. The stewards began to understand their duties, and the attendance showed improvement upon that of the previous day, when it had been trying to the patience of an empty stomach.

abstract: There seems, after all, to have been no foundation whatever for the Herald's fabrication about FREMONT'S removal. Beyond the fact that charges had been made against him by Col. BLAIR, that Gen. MANSFIELD had gone to Fortress Monroe, and that Gen. WOOL went to Washington the whole story was a pure invention.
lead_paragraph: There seems, after all, to have been no foundation whatever for the Herald's fabrication about FREMONT'S removal. Beyond the fact that charges had been made against him by Col. BLAIR, that Gen. MANSFIELD had gone to Fortress Monroe, and that Gen. WOOL went to Washington the whole story was a pure invention. It served its purpose, -- created a "sensation," -- made the Herald talked about -- seriously damaged the recruiting interest at the West, and did all this just as effectually as if it had been true. What more can a reasonable public, which lives spasmodically and craves "sensations" as a part of its daily food, expect or ask?

abstract: Our advices from Havana are to the 28th ult., at which time business was very dull the sugar speculators asking such exorbitant prices as to check operations. Affairs in the United States engrossed public attention, and there was much speculation as to the result of the great battle expected to take place near Washington.
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Havana are to the 28th ult., at which time business was very dull the sugar speculators asking such exorbitant prices as to check operations. Affairs in the United States engrossed public attention, and there was much speculation as to the result of the great battle expected to take place near Washington. The American ship Bamberg, which arrived from Liverpool some three months ago, supposed to be loaded with arms and other warlike stores for the Southern Confederacy, was being discharged, but some surprise was occasioned by the fact that no arms had yet been found on board of her. Our correspondent intimates the probability that they had already been clandestinely removed, notwithstanding the vigilance of the American Consul, Mr. SAVAGE, and that they had been started for New-Orleans in the British schooner Joseph N. Toone, which left Havana on the evening of the 26th. The register of the Bamberg had been taken possession of by our Consul.

abstract: The cir  cumstances which surrounded the withdrawal of Capt. STRINGHAM from active service, imme  diately after the capture of the Hatteras forts, have been enveloped in more than official mystery.
lead_paragraph: The circumstances which surrounded the withdrawal of Capt. STRINGHAM from active service, imme diately after the capture of the Hatteras forts, have been enveloped in more than official mystery. Why an officer, who had so recently distinguished himself in a way that gave promise of continued services of equal value, should choose to retire, or should be dismissed, was a question asked generally, without any one pretending to answer. A partial solution is at last presented. Through a letter written from the flag-ship of the Atlantic Squadron by one of its officers, we gather that the retirement of Capt. STRINGHAM not entirely voluntary. It is represented as growing out of a trifling conflict of authority between the officer and the Navy Department. A transport, seriously damaged by a collision, had been sent to the Washington Navy-yard for repairs. It was at once returned to Fortress Monroe, with letters containing a reprimand addressed to the Commodore because of his having dispatched the vessel thither, instead of having the damages, which were serious, repaired at Newport's News, where, it is said, no facilities for such work exist. A sharp correspondence ensued between Capt. STRINGHAM and the Department, resulting in the removal of the former from the position which he had occupied so creditably.

abstract: Shortly after the battle of Carnifax Ferry, communication was cut off between the Federal camp at Elkwater and that at Cheat Mountain summit, the rebels holding possession of the road. It was necessary that communication should be reestablished between Gen. REYNOLDS at the former place and Col. KIMBALL at the latter.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the battle of Carnifax Ferry, communication was cut off between the Federal camp at Elkwater and that at Cheat Mountain summit, the rebels holding possession of the road. It was necessary that communication should be reestablished between Gen. REYNOLDS at the former place and Col. KIMBALL at the latter. Several attempts had been made, but the messengers had been killed in every case. Four had already set out and been picked off.

abstract: The loyal  people of Kentucky are working steadily and bravely, through their Legislature, to put their State fully in its proper position as an integral part of the Union, and in full sympathy with the defenders of that Union, in the national councils as well as in the field.
lead_paragraph: The loyal people of Kentucky are working steadily and bravely, through their Legislature, to put their State fully in its proper position as an integral part of the Union, and in full sympathy with the defenders of that Union, in the national councils as well as in the field. The Legislature has passed resolutions tendering hearty thanks to the States of Ohio and Indiana for promptness in sending regiments of their soldiers to Kentucky to help expel the Secession invaders. An act has passed authorizing the raising of $2,000,000, on the credit of the State, to aid in prosecuting the war against treason. And the money will be advanced immediately, as wanted, by the Banks of Kentucky. The Legislature has provided for the enrollment of 40,000 volunters in the State service, for three years or for the war, and has directed that this State force shall he under the general superior control of the officers of the United States Army engaged in Kentucky. In every respect, in the field, there is full concord between the United States Government and the State of Kentucky in the prosecution of the war for the preservation of the Constitution and the Union. The Governor. MAGOFFIN, employs himself in futile efforts to defeat this patriotic legislation by interposing vetoes, but the Legislature takes his unavailing protests indifferently, and with no delay passes all needful measures by over-whelming majorities over his vetoes.

abstract: The case of Mrs. HARTUNG has again been before the courts in Albany. Mr. HADLEY, her counsel, asked for her discharge, basing his motion upon the fact that two Courts of Oyer and Terminer have been allowed to pass over since the decision of the Court of Oyer and Terminer was revised by the Court of Appeals, which event took place about one year ago. The Court finally denied the motion, stating that the case referred to in the Revised Statutes does not reach that of MARY HARTUNG, and that as there would be an adjourned term of the present Court convened on the 29th of November next, for the trial of the celebrated ZEH forgery cases, he would designate the first day of said term to hear the argument in the case of MARY HARTUNG, and would then expect the counsel on either side to be fully prepared to proceed without any drawbacks.

abstract: We must express some surprise at the very low estimate which Mr. CHASE appears to make of the [???] of his countrymen. To be sure, this is a concio ad populum, -- an address, not to patriotic capitalists, but to patriotic private citizens. But in America every man is a man of business, and even if he were not we should have thought that very few persons possessing $50 were of so low an intelligence as to be the victims of so gross a rhetorical artifice as that which is attempted to be practiced upon them. Mr. CHASE says all that can be said with truth, -- perhaps, all that can be said in favor of the loan. But we should have thought that there must be few persons, indeed, among the public that he addresses, who do not know that there is nothing so clear that something may not be said on the other side. Let us suppose, for instance, the appeal of the Secretary for the Treasury submitted to a knot of Southern politicians. Does Mr. CHASE suppose that they would have nothing to urge against it -- we do not mean on the questions of duty and patriotism, but on the smaller, though not unimportant question, of the reward proposed for the opportune exercise of these virtues? We could imagine persons, for instanse, perverse enough to urge that the interest of seven and three-tenths per cent. by no means covered the risk to be incurred: that the provision of a revenue by Congress for one year by no maeans guaranteed a provision of the same revenue for the next; and that the creation of a sinking fund by no means implied the appropriation of that fund to the reduction of the debt. We could imagine them venturing to question the confident anticipation that the war will terminate early next, Spring, and to anticipate new loans even if that should be the case, and much more, of course, if it should not. Some persons might be disposed to think that these new loans would require more patriotism in the lenders, and therefore secure a higher reward than the old ones, and that the value of the old ones would thus be inevitably depreciated. It might be suggested, also, that the same state of feeling in the West which has rendered it necessary to tax it on a different scale from the East may result in a refusal to pay sums borrowed in the cause in which the Western States believe themselves to have but a remote and secondary interest, and it may also be thought that we have not yet reached tire limit of secession, and that heavy pecuniary burdens may be found quite as strong a disintegrating force as the protective tariffs of the North or the domestic institution of the South. We will not advert to the possibility of another defeat, for that, of coarse, is a suggestion too monstrous to be entertained for a moment. We do not presume to say what force is to be given to these rival considerations, but we think that, if Mr. CHASE chose to address his countrymen at all, he ought not to have confined himself so exclusively so his own side of the question, but ought also to have given some proof that he was capable of embracing the opposite point of view. It the interest offered is sufficient, the appeal to patriotism and the argument as to the safety of the investment are unnecessary. If it is insufficient, the remedy would have been to increase the amount, instead of appealing to considerations which, rightly viewed, amount to little more than a confession of weakness. People will be more ready to believe that a sufficient provision will be made for the payment and interest of the war loans of the Federal Government, when they see that provision has been made for bearing one farthing of the expense out of the income of the year. When this is not done, it seems not unnatural to conclude that those who are anxious during the heat and excitement of the contest to throw the whole burden on posterity, will become impatient of that burden when the heat and the contest have passed away.

abstract: Toronto Leader has not labored in vain. Col. RANKIN has been arrested, and the work of enlisting soldiers for the Federal Army in Canada has been suspended. Col. RANKIN, it will be remembered, is a member of the Provincial Legislature, who has lent himself ear- ...
lead_paragraph: Toronto Leader has not labored in vain. Col. RANKIN has been arrested, and the work of enlisting soldiers for the Federal Army in Canada has been suspended. Col. RANKIN, it will be remembered, is a member of the Provincial Legislature, who has lent himself earnestly to the business of mustering a company of Lancers for service in a regiment of that description of troops now organizing at Detroit. The Leader, as the Government organ, has followed, his labors with the utmost impatience. It has called attention to the patent violation of the Neutrality laws involved in the enterprise, and is now rewarded with the spectacle of his arrest and the cessation of the work.

abstract: BOLD HIGHWAY ROBBERY. About 11 o'clock Saturday night last, as Mr. HERMANN H. PRUSER, of No. 401 Pearl-street, was walking along New Chambers-street, he was accosted by ANN COOK and an unknown man, the latter of whom at once struck him a heavy blow in the breast, which knocked him down. Before he could regain his feet, the two pushed violently against him, soon after which PRUSER discov- ...
lead_paragraph: BOLD HIGHWAY ROBBERY.--About 11 o'clock Saturday night last, as Mr. HERMANN H. PRUSER, of No. 401 Pearl-street, was walking along New Chambers-street, he was accosted by ANN COOK and an unknown man, the latter of whom at once struck him a heavy blow in the breast, which knocked him down. Before he could regain his feet, the two pushed violently against him, soon after which PRUSER discovered that his gold watch, valued at $50, was missing. Subsequently ANN appeared at the pawn-shop of Mr. SOLOMON, in Grand-street, and wished to pledge the timepiece, but the suspicions of the pawnbroker being aroused, he detained the woman and sent to the Police head-quarters. Detective MCDOUGAL went to the place, took ANN into custody, and Justice CONNOLLY committed her to the Tombs for trial.

abstract: It having come to the knowledge of the undersigned that the sick prisoners confined in Castle William, Governors's Island, are destitute of clothing and other necessaries, to an extent requiring instant relief; and although they have been engaged in a mistaken cause, and in opposition to the Government of the United States, still we must must recognize in them a part and parcel of our humanity; and in obedience to the Divine command "To minister to the sick and clothe the naked," solicit contributions in money, clothing or other needful articles for their benefit. Surgeon SLOAN, of the hospital, has kindly consented to apply such articles as are given, and has furnished me with a list of such things as are required, which can be seen at my office; No. 142 Broadway.
