abstract: The Paris Pays has a long article on Prince NAPOLEON's journey to America. The semi-official print informs us that the great topic of the day in the United States just now is, not the war, as might be supposed by common non-official people, but the visit of the Prince. His Imperial Highness' journey from New-York to St. Louis, the Pays assures us, "was performed like the other parts of his trip, in the midst of populations who vied with each other in the warmth of their reception. In every town, in every village, the inhabitants hurried forward to meet him. On his approach, the houses were gaily decked out with flags, everything assumed a festive appearance, and it may be said that everywhere the Prince and France were by turns, or to speak more correctly, simultaneously, acclaimed." We are next informed that the "spontaneous character of these manifestations greatly enhanced their value. The people of the United States will long remember the visit," &c., &c. This is a perfect curiosity in the art of semi-official description, and its value is not at all diminished by the circumstance of the writer having drawn it all out of his own head. In France, where the American papers are not read, there are some simple-minded people who will actually believe all that the Pays describes to have really happened, and they will wonder why the Prince does not remain in a country where he meets with a popularity which he bids for in vain in Europe.
lead_paragraph: The Paris Pays has a long article on Prince NAPOLEON's journey to America. abstract: Yesterday afternoon, at about 1 o'clock, the Tenth Maine Regiment arrived, on board the steamer State of Maine, at Pier No. 4, North River, en route for the seat of war. This regiment has been for some time past encamped at Camp McClellan, Portland; on Sunday morning camp was broken, and the order to march given. On its way through Boston the regiment was loudly cheered, and the men elicited much praise for their martial appearance -- many of whom have served three months in the First Regiment. The regiment numbers 900 men, all of whom are uniformed and equipped, but not armed. The baggage wagons and horses accompanies the regiment. At 6 o'clonk, last evening, the corps proceeded to Elizabethport, and look cars for Washington. Annexed is a list of the field, staff, and line officers:

lead_paragraph: By the steamship Bavaria, which passed Cape Race on Saturday, we receive advices from Europe three days later than by the Niagara at Boston. The commercial news by this arrival possesses much interest, but the political intelligence is of not rnuch moment. Considerable excitement exists in the foreign markets, consequent upon the intimation of the announcement of the Spanish movement against Mexico, and Mexican stock had advanced more than 2 cent. The English Funds still have a downward tendency, Consuls being quoted at 93 1/8@93 1/4. for money. The Liverpool Cotton market was excited, and prices were 1/4d.@3/8d. higher, with an upward tendency. The sales for two days had been 55,000 bales, including 33,000 to speculators and exporters. Breadstuffs were tending downward, and all descriptions were lower. Provisions were dull. From Turkey, we learn that the vanguard of the Turkish Army, which, had been at Scarlah, had been forced to fall back by a bold movement of the Montenegrin insurgents, who were awaiting the Turkish Army on their own territory. There are rumors of another Ministerial crisis in Austria. Intelligence from Japan states that an attempt had been made at Kanagawa to murder the inmates of the British Legation. Two of them were wounded, but the rest escaped unhurt.

abstract: Capt. MICHAEL BERRY, at one time commander of the steamship Columbia, of the New-York and Charleston line, and more recently the captain of the steamship Marion, of the same line, was arrested yesterday by Detective RAYNOR, of Brooklyn, as an enemy to the Government. The police authorities had known, for some time past, of the captain's treasonable proclivities, and were aware that he had concealed himself either in New-York or Brooklyn. Since the 29th ult. a diligent search has been prosecuted for the offender, but not until yesterday did it result in his capture. In the early part of the rebellion Capt. BERRY showed unmistakable signs of being a rebel at heart, by expressing sympathy with the rebels. When South Carolina passed the ordinance of secession, he manifested his joy by hoisting the Palmetto flag upon his vessel, and his course in the matter gained him substantial tokens of approbation at the hands of the people of Charleston. He was taken to Fort Lafayette, and delivered into the custody of Lieut.-Col. BURKE.
lead_paragraph: Capt. MICHAEL BERRY, at one time commander of the steamship Columbia, of the New-York and Charleston line, and more recently the captain of the steamship Marion, of the same line, was arrested yesterday by Detective RAYNOR, of Brooklyn, as an enemy to the Government. The police authorities had known, for some time past, of the captain's treasonable proclivities, and were aware that he had concealed himself either in New-York or Brooklyn. Since the 29th ult. a diligent search has been prosecuted for the offender, but not until yesterday did it result in his capture. In the early part of the rebellion Capt. BERRY showed unmistakable signs of being a rebel at heart, by expressing sympathy with the rebels. When South Carolina passed the ordinance of secession, he manifested his joy by hoisting the Palmetto flag upon his vessel, and his course in the matter gained him substantial tokens of approbation at the hands of the people of Charleston. He was taken to Fort Lafayette, and delivered into the custody of Lieut.-Col. BURKE.

abstract: Yesterday, Mr. WM. H. HURD, first officer of the bark Glen, of Portland, Me., which was captured by the privateer Dixie on the 23d of July last, arrived in this City on his way to Portland. Mr. HURD was released on parole, and taken under a flag of truce to Fortress Monroe, from whence he proceeded to this City by way of Baltimore. When in Richmond Mr. HURD became acquainted with several Union prisoner, among whom was Mr. ELY, who desired him to say that he should stand firm to the last. Mr. HURD brings the following list of National officers who have been taken to Richmond since the departure of the surgeons recently released:

abstract: We have the same story of quiet from Washington which has now been repeated for so many days, and we receive no intimation that this state of affairs is to be speedily changed. It is of course impossible, however, to tell what a day  may bring forth, and nothing is more likely than that the present quiet may at any moment be broken by the clangor of advancing hosts.
lead_paragraph: We have the same story of quiet from Washington which has now been repeated for so many days, and we receive no intimation that this state of affairs is to be speedily changed. It is of course impossible, however, to tell what a day may bring forth, and nothing is more likely than that the present quiet may at any moment be broken by the clangor of advancing hosts. The apprehension of a rebel attack is now entirely dissipated. Indeed, if the reports which reach us are based on truth, the rebel leaders have their hands full in keeping in subjection their dissatisfied troops. A resident of Falls Church who visited Washington yesterday, states that there was a revolt among the men recently -- that one regiment refused to do duty, and that four regiments sent to reduce the first one to subjection also revolted. The recent general withdrawal of the rebel lines may perhaps be thus in part accounted for.

abstract: We find in some of the  Western papers a late and very feeble effort to hold the gallant Col. MULLIGAN responsible for the loss of his army at Lexington. It is suggested that he "fought well, but planned badly" and it is asked why he did not evacuate Lexington and retreat to the north side of the river.
lead_paragraph: We find in some of the Western papers a late and very feeble effort to hold the gallant Col. MULLIGAN responsible for the loss of his army at Lexington. It is suggested that he "fought well, but planned badly" and it is asked why he did not evacuate Lexington and retreat to the north side of the river while he had command of the ferry-boats, seeing, as he must have seen, that he could not long resist an investing force so large as came against him.

abstract: England and France are both largely interested in the welfare of Mexico. There are debts to be paid, there are lives to be saved. "England has a larger amount of capital employed in Mexico than France, but the subjects of the French Empire there are more numerous."
lead_paragraph: England and France are both largely interested in the welfare of Mexico. There are debts to be paid, there are lives to be saved. "England has a larger amount of capital employed in Mexico than France, but the subjects of the French Empire there are more numerous." Nor are Spain and the United States uninterested. The lives and properties of their subjects are also in imminent peril day by day. England has a right to enter and seize the custom-house, and appropriate the revenues for the payment of debt. No one can question for one moment the right of intervention. No one can doubt that the subject has occupied the anxious attention of France and England, of Spain, and even of the Government of the United States. But it is easier to note the peril than to devise the remedy. Lntervention is easy. No large force would be required to bring the country to its sense. But no Government would enter on such a course without ample deliberation and a careful forecast of the consequences. It is impossible to doubt that England and France alone, with a small force, could walk into the City of Mexico whenever they pleased; but, if needed, Spain could supply all the cavalry that such an expedition would require. There would be no difficulties in doing the business thoroughly, go far as the mere occupation of the country and capital were concerned. The difficulties would arise afterwards. They are great, but not insuperable. Any intervention of the kind we have indicated, whenever resolved on, whenever excuted, could not fail to succeed as a mere measure of military police, called for by the outrages on common humanity in Mexico. That such an intervention is extremely probable, and indeed only a question of time, is what all feel who have considered the subject. But it is clearly one that cannot be undertaken without very careful preparation, without clearly defined objects, and a due subordination of the means to the end. All the parties concerned are interested in obtaining is a recognition and liquidation of money obligations, guarantees for the security of life and property, and the exemplary punishment of those who have committed atrocious crimes on the persons of Europeans. The question is how can these objects be accomplished with the least loss of life and at the least cost? That an attempt must be made, sooner or later, to accomplish them, we are not able to doubt, althought it is not so easy to see the precise means which may be adopted for reaching the ends in view. The condition of Mexico is a world-wide scandal and a reproach to civilization, and cries aloud for amendments.

abstract: "Coming events" are, says the Preston Guardian, Sept. 18, "casting their shadows before them" in Bolton, and that, too, in a somewhat dark and extensive form. Short time is not actually adopted as to a set number of working hours, but production is very materially lessened in most cotton-spinning and ...
lead_paragraph: "Coming events" are, says the Preston Guardian, Sept. 18, "casting their shadows before them" in Bolton, and that, too, in a somewhat dark and extensive form. Short time is not actually adopted as to a set number of working hours, but production is very materially lessened in most cotton-spinning and cloth-manufacturing concerns; power-loom weavers waiting a week at once for warps, and one very large cotton-spinning concern -- that of Messrs. BOLLING & SLADE -- is closing altogether. The firm have six mills, the Carlisle Mill, the Coronation Mill, the Old-end Mill, the Spring-garden Mill, the Knott Mill and the Bridge-street Mill. In these they have seven steam-engines, of 230 horse-power, and had in their employment at Midsummer 531 females, and 256 males -- total, 787. In parting with the workpeople, they are told to seek employment immediately anywhere, as there is no probability of the mills resuming work under the existing interests. We regret to state that Messrs. JACKSON, of Queen-street Mill, Lancaster, commenced running three days per week this week, and will not start their engine till Thursday.

abstract: Our Paris correspondent represents very forcibly the injury done to the American character abroad by the constant statements that our Government is invoking the aid of foreign officers to take command of our armies. The preposterous story, that President LINCOLN has offered GARIBALDI the position of Commander-in-chief, continues to circulate through the European Press, and is almost universally believed. Similar statements concerning other officers are equally current, and are producing the impression that we are not only utterly destitute of the military ability requisite for command, but that we are ostentiously proclaiming our imbecility in this respect, and begging aid of the European Powers. An official note has been published in the Constitutionnel, intended to correct misstatements; -- it denies, very explicitly, the general statement, and seems broad enough to cover the whole case. But something still more authoritative from our own Government would be timely and useful. It ought to be made known everywhere that we do not distrust our own ability to command our own armies, and that, although foreign officers of ability and merit may find employment here, it will not be because the United States feel helpless without them.

abstract: - The People's Union movement promises to give us a better class of office-holders than the machinery of party has secured to us for the past few years. In selecting new men for places of public trust, however, those who have the movement in charge would do well not to forget that experience is of very great value in every department of the public service. Men who are entirely new to the halls of legislation, however honest, public-spirited and able they may be, lack one very important qualification for the highest usefulness, -- and their best to promote the public welfare will often fail simply from want of familiarity with the ways  and means of making them  effective. Wherever, therefore, it can be done, the public good will be promoted by the selection of men who have had some experience of public life, provided that experience has developed the other qualifications required.

abstract: "A gentleman named CHAS. RANSOM, from Boston, arrive in this city, last night, by way of Cairo and Union City, from New-Orleans, having left the latter place on the 29th of September. As he had been in New-Orleans for over three years, he experienced little difficulty in reaching Kentucky, but in order to pass the Confederate lines, he was obliged to resort to strategy; pretend that he had important business a short distance in the interior of Kentucky; and as he had formerly lived in that vicinity, he was enabled completely to deceive the rebel officers, who had no doubt of his Southern nativity and secession sympathy.

abstract: The People ex rel. Wm. B. Belch vs. Chas. Bierfield. -- This was an appeal from an order of the Special Term sustaining the plaintiff's proceedings in an attempt to reinstate himself in the office of bell-ringer, to which the defendant had been appointed in his (plaintiff's) place. The plaintiff had held the office from the 24th of February, 1854, to the 17th of January last, when he was removed, and the defendant was appointed in his stead. The defendant has since performed the duties of the office.

abstract: We have at length, in the graphic narrative from our Correspondent, published in yesterday's TIMES, a full and reliable account of the mishap encountered by the Great Eastern. His letter shows that the ship was sent to sea in the most wretched trim and disorder  every moveable in her being free to thrash and ...
lead_paragraph: We have at length, in the graphic narrative from our Correspondent, published in yesterday's TIMES, a full and reliable account of the mishap encountered by the Great Eastern. His letter shows that the ship was sent to sea in the most wretched trim and disorder every moveable in her being free to thrash and tumble about at every roll. But it also shows that as to strength of hull and engines the Great Ship was all that could be desired -- and this is a point of the highest importance, for weakness was the chief trouble apprehended. But ships must not only hold together and keep afloat; they must be guided with ease and celerity by apparatus of unfailing strength and durability. In this respect the Great Eastern failed, for it appears that she would come out of the trough of the sea before her rudder broke. Now it may have been that her helm could not be moved far enough -- we know that her steering geer was always troublesome -- or that the official investigation will show a mere accidental, not a radical defect. Let us suppose the worst, however -- that she could not be steered at all in a heavy sea. It would be idle to say that she had not headway enough, on account of the loss of her paddles; ships must be steered at a much less speed than nine knots, or they are failures. How is this grand defect to be certainly remedied? Mr. EDWIN STEVENS built a vessel, some years since, which, having a maximum speed of only eight miles, was turned end for end in one minute and a half, repeatedly, without using the rudder, or making any headway whatever. She had two screws; one was backed, the other driven forward. Various steamboats and sea-vessels, having disconnected paddle-wheels, have been spun round on their own centres, entirely irrespective of the steering apparatus. To say that the Great Eastern would not have done the same thing, similarly arranged, is to say that she could not move at all, for it is a simple question of power, and there was power enough in her to lift her into the air bodily, at the rate of a fathom a minute. Nor is there any reason to doubt that moving one of her paddle-wheels forward and backing the other, would have brought her out of the trough of the sea, or that disconnecting one and driving the other would have done it. Mr. SCOTT RUSSELL's original plan was to put in this disconnecting apparatus. But there were no paddles at all -- they had been carried away. True, but must all ships have weak paddles because the Great Eastern had them? Her wheels had no out-board bearing; the arms started from a short hub and ran diagonally, or "dishing," in the worst possible shape for lateral strength. It would be the easiest thing in the world to make stronger paddle-wheels and to disconnect them so as to spin the ship around without any rudder.

abstract: THE RIOT AT HUDSON CITY -- PRESENTATION OF A SWORD AND BANNER. -- The excitement attendant upon the difficulty which occurred on Saturday night last, between some members of the Hiram Barney Rifle Regiment and citizens of Hudson City, appeared to have very material abated yesterday, and it was thought that there would be no further difficulty. It was stated that the matter came up before the Grand Jury yesterday afternoon, but what action will be taken did not transpire. Col. KOZLAY expressed a willingness to deliver up any men to the authorities who should be identified as having been engaged in the riot. Mayor CARPENTER will be confined to the house from his injuries for some time; and in the meantime, Mr. VAN RIPER, President of the Board of Aldermen, will act as Mayor pro tem. At 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon the regiment was presented with a very costly white and blue silk banner, upon which were embroidered the American flag, eagle and shield, together with the name of the regiment. It was a present from ladies in New-York, and was embroidered by Madame FRANCISCA KLEIN. Col. KOZLAY was also the recipient of a sword, with gold mountings. After the ceremony was over, the soldiers and their friends enjoyed themselves with music and dancing until driven away by the rain. Two thousand or more men and women, friends of the soldiers, were present, and all appeared to enjoy themselves. The regiment expects to take its departure on Wednesday or Thursday.
lead_paragraph: THE RIOT AT HUDSON CITY -- PRESENTATION OF A SWORD AND BANNER. -- The excitement attendant upon the difficulty which occurred on Saturday night last, between some members of the Hiram Barney Rifle Regiment and citizens of Hudson City, appeared to have very material abated yesterday, and it was thought that there would be no further difficulty. It was stated that the matter came up before the Grand Jury yesterday afternoon, but what action will be taken did not transpire. Col. KOZLAY expressed a willingness to deliver up any men to the authorities who should be identified as having been engaged in the riot. Mayor CARPENTER will be confined to the house from his injuries for some time; and in the meantime, Mr. VAN RIPER, President of the Board of Aldermen, will act as Mayor pro tem. At 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon the regiment was presented with a very costly white and blue silk banner, upon which were embroidered the American flag, eagle and shield, together with the name of the regiment. It was a present from ladies in New-York, and was embroidered by Madame FRANCISCA KLEIN. Col. KOZLAY was also the recipient of a sword, with gold mountings. After the ceremony was over, the soldiers and their friends enjoyed themselves with music and dancing until driven away by the rain. Two thousand or more men and women, friends of the soldiers, were present, and all appeared to enjoy themselves. The regiment expects to take its departure on Wednesday or Thursday.

abstract: The South took their warrant for rebellion in the assumption that the world must be clothed, and that it could afford to allow no check to be put upon the villanies of those who produced the fibre which others spun and wore.
lead_paragraph: The South took their warrant for rebellion in the assumption that the world must be clothed, and that it could afford to allow no check to be put upon the villanies of those who produced the fibre which others spun and wore. It entitled to them to upset Government: or rather conspire for its destruction; and steal, rob and murder with impunity. Should other nations disprove or interfere, all the rebels had to do, as they supposed, was to threaten to withhold the staple, to bring the remonstrants upon their knees in abject submission. The grand text -- experimentum crucis -- has been applied. Cotton has been withheld, and the world, apparently, had manhood enough not to make the sacrifice demanded, and seeks to supply itself, as best it can, from other sources, and forego the use of what these furnish. But as if not to tempt selfishness or cupidity too far, Providence, at this juncture, gave to the North the prerogative of the supply of food, if the South had that of clothing. It is now proved that the two great nations of Europe, from whom any interference was anticipated from the blockade of cotton, are lamentably short in their grain crops; that of England lacking 64,000, bushels, and that of France 80,000,000 of an adequate supply, making the almost fabulous amount of 144,000,000 of bushels, which must be furnished by other lands. The evidence of this deficit, as well as our means of supply, are well stated in our commercial columns. If the amount of the deficit is only proximately ascertained, enough is known to show that the two countries will need the surplus of the world to save them from hunger.

abstract: The amount subscribe for the Government Loan up to this time in Michigan has been only $6,400, taken by twenty-seven subscribers, seventeen of whom are citizens of Detroit. This is a meagre sum, and places Detroit in an unfavorable light in comparison with others of equal wealth and population. The people of Detroit say, in excuse of their apparent neglect, that it is impossible to obtain gold in their city. Nevertheless, the Detroit Tribune doubts "whether this is the only or the real cause that so little has been done."

abstract: Since the commencement of the formation of the new battalion on Governor's Island, to which we have several times referred, it has been found that all disposable recruits have been absorbed, and that, inconsequence of this absorption, any special requisition for men could not be complied with. In future, therefore, the battalion will have to depend entirely upon the recruiting offices, which we particularized on Monday, and which were opened for the especial purpose of obtaining men for this battalion. The men enlisted at the old offices in this City, and in Boston, Philadelphia, Rochester and Buffalo, will, in future, be held in readiness for the execution of any special order of the War Department.

abstract: The United States steam frigate Wabash, Capt. SAMUEL MERCER commanding, arrived yesterday afternoon from Charleston Bar, which place she left on the evening of the 3d inst. The Wabash has been in active services nearly six months. After leaving Hatteras inlet it was found she had some five or six shot holes below the water line, which were temporarily plugged.
lead_paragraph: The United States steam frigate Wabash, Capt. SAMUEL MERCER commanding, arrived yesterday afternoon from Charleston Bar, which place she left on the evening of the 3d inst. The Wabash has been in active services nearly six months. After leaving Hatteras inlet it was found she had some five or six shot holes below the water line, which were temporarily plugged. She has been ordered home for some repairs to her hull and machinery, as also to have some slight changes made in her officers. In the action off Hatteras the Wabash was ordered by Flag-officer STRINGHAM to take the Cumberland in tow. Capt. BARRON's attempt was to so cripple the frigate that it would leave the Cumberland helpless in the way of maneuvering, as she would be unable to get off without the assistance of the Wabash, with the breeze that was then blowing in shore. Accordingly, as he states, his most direct firing was at this ship. While Capt. MERGER and a signal officer were standing on the bridge a shell fell in the water within four feet of the ship's side.

abstract: The special correspondent of the London Times, at Washington, has sent home his opinion, formed, it must be admitted, after an adequate survey of the subject, that the National Government will be able to repress the Slaveholders' rebellion. He believes that it only requires an exertion of the available strength and resources of the North to make its triumph per feet. It will be curious now to see what influence this declaration will have on the editoria columns of the Times. Mr. RUSSELL is a witness whom the conductors of that paper placed upon the stand. They have lost no opportunity of indorsing his entire credibility; going so far indeed as to write leading articles -- demonstrative of his infallibility; and declaring that what he saw, as at the affair of Bull Run, they saw through his eyes. When he now tells them that the American Union is not destroyed; that the inevitable laws demanding its dissolution are going to be evaded; that it will emerge from this struggle presently with social and industrial resources unimpaired, with a commerce enriched by the spoils of tributary Europe; with a Navy and Army strong enough to place it foremost among the great powers of the world; and so far as contests regarding cisatlantic questions are concerned, stronger than the united strength of Europe -- will the Times accept the testimony with these unavoidable consequences, and frankly confess the error into which a senseless malignity has led it? Undoubtedly not. The correspondent will be thrown over; his judgment reversed; and we shall have to await patiently evidence of events as the only corrective of the voluntary and persistent wrongheadedness of the leader of British opinion. Happily we can afford to wait.

abstract: The free Evening Schools of our City -- twenty-four for males and the same number for females -- began their usual Winter work last night. These are supplementary to the day schools, and are designed for persons whose ages or avocations prevent them from attending that class of instruction. Several thousand persons have taken advantage of the opportunity thus afforded for mental culture, without money and without price. It thus seems that, in spite of the anarchy in which (as we hear from the other side of the Atlantic,) we are plunged, the great beneficent system of universal free education keeps its place unmoved of fortune. Some of the English Cassandra-journals have been prognosticating violent socialistic upheavals among the ignorant classes in our Northern cities. They argued from their own state of society. We have no such class. Such elements are engendered amid mental and moral night and darkness, and it is in this condition that the great majority of the English people are plunged; for spite of the splendor of their schools for the culture of the gentle class, that country makes no provision for the education of the masses.

abstract: Not a more important office than that of Coroner is within the gift of the people of New York, and not another office has been characterized by more mediocrity on the part of its occupants. Men completely ignorant of medicine ...
lead_paragraph: Not a more important office than that of Coroner is within the gift of the people of New York, and not another office has been characterized by more mediocrity on the part of its occupants. Men completely ignorant of medicine have still been considered abundantly competent to conduct intricate examinations where scientific knowledge and skill were indispensable, and to examine and exhort witnesses in regard to obscure causes of death by poisoning or disease, in which only practical knowledge of the causes and symptoms of death could enable the examiner to reach the truth. For the sake of public morality and safety, a Coroner should be a physician, otherwise he is utterly at the mercy of the physician whom he calls to give evidence, and so far as the cause of the death is, in many cases, concerned, is as utterly incapable, external evidence excepted, of forming any opinion himself, as he might be supposed to be of the proper method of mixing colors for an artist's pallet, or of producing a beautiful tint of submarine.

abstract: The great event in Washington yesterday was the grand review of cavalry and artillery, which took place on the great plain east of the Capitol, and was witnessed by an immense crowd of gratified spectators. There were twenty-one batteries of artillery and fifty-seven companies of cavalry, on the field. The rebels did not make their appearance at any point along our lines. By the arrival from the Potomac Flotilla, we learn that the rebel camp-fires maybe now nightly seen in the vicinity of Evansport, extending a distance of three miles.

abstract: A good dealhas been said lately about certain changes said to have been introduced into the evolutions of the French Army encamped at Chalons. Our recent foreign exchanges inform us as to the nature of these innovations. The distinguishing feature of the system introduced by NAPOLEON during his wars was the rapid movement of solid masses of men upon a single point. The very great improvements recently made in the range and aim of cannon, are said to have rendered this mode of attack no longer available. Rifled cannon can now reach masses of men at very great distances, and render their approach impossible. The larger the mass the greater the exposure.

The distinguishing feature of the system introduced by NAPOLEON during his wars was the rapid movement of solid masses of men upon a single point. The very great improvements recently made in the range and aim of cannon, are said to have rendered this mode of attack no longer available. Rifled cannon can now reach masses of men at very great distances, and render their approach impossible. The larger the mass the greater the exposure.

abstract: Our foreign advices fully confirm the statements published in the TIMES, some days ago, concerning the intended intervention of the European Powers in Mexico. The London Times, of the 25th ult., says that the announcement of such a purpose created great excitement in the foreign markets, and was followed by an advance of 2 per cent, in Mexican Stocks.
lead_paragraph: Our foreign advices fully confirm the statements published in the TIMES, some days ago, concerning the intended intervention of the European Powers in Mexico. The London Times, of the 25th ult., says that the announcement of such a purpose created great excitement in the foreign markets, and was followed by an advance of 2 per cent, in Mexican Stocks. It seems that Spain is to take the lead in the matter. She has already dispatched two or three war vessels to the Gulf, and a formidable armed force has been for some time in preparation in Cuba. The part that France is to take in the expedition is not defined, though of the fact of her being one of the parties to it there is no doubt.

abstract: We have for some time contemplated effecting a thorough domestic test, through regular and diversified use, of all the varieties of Sewing Machines that compete for the favor of the public. Our design was to report impartially upon the merits and defects of the respective machines, regardless of the interests or wishes of manufacturers, and with a view solely to the advantage of our readers, multitudes of whom in succession must constantly find themselves becoming interested in knowing from an unprejudiced source, just what to depend on in choosing between sewing machines.

abstract: We beg leave to inform a correspondent who writes to us on the subject, that the letters from the Paris Opinion National, copied into the Herald as Prince NAPOLEON's, were written by a young French gentleman named SAND, who has been, for some time a correspondent of that paper. The pretence that they were written by Prince NAPOLEON was a little bit of "enterprise" on the part of the Herald, intended to create an interest in the letters on the part of the public, which the letters themselves would not excite. The absurdity of supposing that the Prince, being destitute of any other means of support, had turned newspaper correspondent, seems never to have occurred to the Herald, or if it did, that sagacious journal knew very well it would not occur to any of its readers. Like its fabrication about FREMONT's removal, this little fiction answered its purpose perfectly: -- it created a "sensation"' for a day and did nobody any harm.

abstract: There is a very loud call upon the Government in certain quarters to issue at once an edict of emancipation as a means of carrying on the War. Mr. SUMNER says that such an edict would instantly end the rebellion. Others object strenuously to ending the war at all, unless the extinction of Slavery shall have been first secured. With the ultra Abo-
lead_paragraph: There is a very loud call upon the Government in certain quarters to issue at once an edict of emancipation as a means of carrying on the War. Mr. SUMNER says that such an edict would instantly end the rebellion. Others object strenuously to ending the war at all, unless the extinction of Slavery shall have been first secured. With the ultra Abolitionist of the Wendell Phillips school, the war has no meaning or interest apart from this result. They do not desire the restoration of the Union if Slavery is to exist, as it has done hitherto, under the tacit protection of the Constitution. A larger and less radical class despair of crushing the rebellion in any other way, and advocate emancipation as the severest blow that could be inflicted upon the rebels, and as the only means of pushing the war to a successful issue.

abstract: Wm. Forest, &c., vs. The Mayor, &c. -- In this case the plaintiff seeks to recover back the amount of an assessment paid under a misapprehension of the facts concerning it. Subsequently the assessment was set aside by order of the court, and plaintiff now desires to be reimbursed. The Corporation interposesa demurrer to the complaint, upon the ground that as the plaintiff made his payment voluntarily, and without adjudication, he cannot now maintain his action against the City. The case was argued and decision reserved.

abstract: We had an interview yesterday with Capt. NEET, of Company K, Fourteenth Missouri Volunteers, under Col. WHITE. The Captain was one of the prisoners surrendered by Col. MULLIGAN, and was lucky enough to make his escape from the hands of the rebels on Monday last. He gives us some highly important information, which we proceed to detail. Capt. NEET an old resident of Lafayette County, and knows the locality of Lexington perfectly; was one of the Home Guards when his company joined the command of Col. WHITE, and seems to be a very intelligent and reliable man.

abstract: The reopening of this road would undoubtedly be a great advantage to Government in its intercourse with the West, and as an additional means of subsisting the great Army grouped around Washington. As soon as practicable, an armed protection should be extended to the whole line, allowing its reconstruction, and the running of its trains in safety. So far the Government is bound to go, whether Maryland, or the managers of this road, be loyal or disloyal. Peace and ordermust be everywhere restored. But beyond this we hope it will not go one step. The managers of this road would undoubtedly be very well pleased to have it restored to its condition year ago, without cost to them. selves. But it is well known that they were in hearty sympathy with the rebellion, and that they attempted to prevent the use of their road to carry Government troops, when the effort was first made by their allies to seize Washington. The traitors were invited into Northern Virginia by the attitude of Maryland, who would have thrown herself into their arms but for the military power of the Government. The whole disasters that have befallen that State, as well as her great highway were of her own creation. The people of this State have had a valuable lesson already, but not all they deserve, till they have repaired the losses their friends and allies have inflicted upon them. When a community is directly responsible for the losses it has suffered let it pay the penalty. A military necessity led to the reconstruction, by the Government, of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad. No such necessity exists in the case of the Baltimore and Ohio. Could Maryland have all the losses suffered for her part in the rebellion made up, she might treat the whole affair as a good frolic, to be repeated at any time, as a means of varying the monotony of ordinary events. The Border States are the parties, of all others, at fault, as they could, with the greatest ease, at one time have averted the war. They have been, or are to be, literally destroyed by their Southern allies, who, like swarms of locusts, devour any green thing in their path. Nothing pleases them so well as to destroy works which reflect the brightest glory on civilized society. We have mercifully driven back the swarm of marauders from the soil of Maryland. Such portion only of her great work as lies in Virginia has been destroyed. She already owes to Government a debt she never can repay. Give her protection, and let her repair her own losses. All she can expect is, that Government should protect her against her friends -- a priceless boon, considering what other States have suffered that have been overrun by them.

abstract: We hear from Jefferson City that troops and munitions of war are constantly going forward, that prompt activity is being exhibited on every hand, and that Gen. FREMONT is actually about to start for that portion of our State which is soon to be the seat of bloody and decisive war. It is in view of these busy preparations, in view of the indications of an immediate forward movement, that we counsel patience; for it is impossible to tell what circumstance, large or small, may not delay the advance. The signs of an early battle may yet fail, and some become disheartened; but we say, be patient and confident.

lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Brig Hallis Jackson and her cargo.--This vessel was captured on the high seas near Tybee Light, on the coast of Georgia, by the United States steamship Union, on June 10, 1861. Bernardi Sanches appeared and claimed the vessel, but did not state his residence or citizenship. Arganeqni, Gonzales & Co., of Cuba, claimed the cargo, alleging that they chartered the brig to take the cargo to Savannah, if it was not blockaded, and if it was, to some other port of the United States, and they denied any notice that Savannah was blockaded.

abstract: At the last meeting of the Board of Aldermen, Mr. FARLEY offered a resolution calling on the Comptroller for the names and compensation of parties employed in distributing the funds for the relief of needy families of volunteers. It is stated that Mr. FARLEY was stimulated to this inquiry by a report that the chief party, by whatever official title he may be known, receives $2,500 per year, and four assistants (one for each Senatorial District) $1,800 each, it has heretofore been supposed that the services of the assistants were gratuitously rendered, but the Comptroller's report will show that such has not been the case.

abstract: FATAL AFFRAY. -- On Saturday night last an affray took place in a house known as the "Rookery," on North Eighth-street, near First-street, between JOHN McCONNELL and PATRICK SWEENEY -- both of whom occupy rooms in the above-named premises -- during which McCONNELL received such injuries that he died on Monday. It appears that SWEENEY acted in the capacity of agent for the landlord, and went to McCONNELL to obtain a month's rent in advance. The latter told him that he was about to move out of the house and, therefore, would have to pay no rent. SWEENEY then demanded a balance of 75 cents due on the last month, which McCONNELL said he would pay as soon as he could get a $1 bill changed. He refused to give the bill to SWEENEY, and because of this refusal the latter kicked McCONNELL and beat him about the head, injuring him in such a way that he died from the injuries received as above stated. The accused was arrested and committed for trial.
lead_paragraph: FATAL AFFRAY. -- On Saturday night last an affray took place in a house known as the "Rookery," on North Eighth-street, near First-street, between JOHN McCONNELL and PATRICK SWEENEY -- both of whom occupy rooms in the above-named premises -- during which McCONNELL received such injuries that he died on Monday. abstract: The steamship Norwegian, from Liverpool on the 26th and Londonderry on the 27th ult., passed Father Point yesterday on her way to Quebec. Her advices from Great Britain and the Continent are two days later than were received by the Bavaria. The political news from England is of no importance, but the financial and commercial news is interesting.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Norwegian, from Liverpool on the 26th and Londonderry on the 27th ult., passed Father Point yesterday on her way to Quebec. Her advices from Great Britain and the Continent are two days later than were received by the Bavaria. The political news from England is of no importance, but the financial and commercial news is interesting. The funds were still lower. Consols having declined to 93@93 1/8 for Money. Another advance of 1/4d.@1/2d. has taken place in the Cotton market. Breadstuff's and Provisions were both dull and declining. The steamship Great Eastern, it is stated, was less damaged than at first represented, and after repairing at Milford Haven, will resume the service between Liverpool and New-York. The terms of the treaty between England, France and Spain, for immediate intervention in the affairs of Mexico, have been published by the London Post. It appears from the terms of the treaty that there is no danger of waging a territorial war, but the combined naval force of the three Powers will occupy the principal ports on the Gulf, and will sequestrate the customs revenue, retaining one-half and paying the rest to the Mexican Government. If any opposition is made by Mexico, however, an effectual blockade will be instantly established.

abstract: The People ex. rel. Mary Ann. Allen vs. Daniel H. Burtnett, Lieutenant-Colonel,  This was a habeas corpus for the discharge of the son of the relator from the United States service, he having enlisted during his minority, without the consent of his parents.
lead_paragraph: The People ex. rel. Mary Ann. Allen vs. Daniel H. Burtnett, Lieutenant-Colonel, &c.--This was a habeas corpus for the discharge of the son of the relator from the United States service, he having enlisted during his minority, without the consent of his parents. The particulars of the case and of the questions raised upon the return of the writ, were stated in the TIMES of the 4th inst. The Court has now rendered the following opinion, which sufficiently recapitulates the facts and circumstances of the case. HOFFMAN, J. -- The relator has established that William Allen, her son, was a minor, over the age of eighteen and under twenty-one years, and enlisted without the consent of either of his parents.

abstract: In Rhode Island a movement has been set on foot for the promotion of enlistments, which has already been imitated in several other States and deserves general attention. It is the formation of drill companies, the object of which is to prepare a reserve force, in case of military necessity. The companies are organized under duly-commissioned officers, and receive a loan of arms from the State, with which they drill. GOV. SPRAGUE, in a circular from the State Military Committee, sets forth the advantage of the organization, and urges it strenuously upon public attention. Col. HOWARD, who has taken a very active part in promoting it, says that one effect of it is greatly to increase the number of enlistments, as men acquire a taste for military matters, as well as knowledge of military movements. The subject merits the attention of our State authorities. It has been productive of very excellent results wherever it has been tried.

abstract: The Philadelphia North American says that, "notwithstanding the desire of Secretary WELLES to have the facts concerning the naval expedition kept out of the public prints, the New-York papers. have given all the details of the expedition with great minuteness." Every reader of the New-York papers knows this to be utterly untrue. They have scarcely even mentioned the existence of such an expedition, and have complied fully with the request made of them in regard to it. This is not the first time in which our Philadelphia cotemporary has brought this false accusation against the New-York papers.

abstract: -- Last night, at 9 1/2 o'clock, a fire broke out in the second story of the rear extension of the Hall of the Board of Education, which was promptly extinguished by the firemen, before much damage, excepting water, had been done. Soon after, a second fire broke out in the repository in the basement, in a heap of waste paper, resulting in damage to old stock of about $100. The building, which might have sustained serious damage had the fire occurred at a later hour, is valued at $30,000, and the stock of books, &c., is worth $20,000.

abstract: In the lack of experience in this country, the result only can solve many of the great questions inVolved in the war. In a time of peace the annual expenditures of Government have averaged less than  $200,000 per day. For the prosecution of the war, ...
lead_paragraph: In the lack of experience in this country, the result only can solve many of the great questions inVolved in the war. In a time of peace the annual expenditures of Government have averaged less than $200,000 per day. For the prosecution of the war, they are $1,000,000 daily. This extraordinary expenditure has been going on, say for 90 days, in which $90,000,000 have been advanced from the capital of the country, without any appreciable effect upon the rates charged for money, without any embarrassments to the foreign or domestic trade, but, in fact, with a decided advantage to the latter. So far all fears of a stringency, or of the inability of the country to sustain the burden, have proved utterly groundless. The only, question now raised is whether we can infer the future from the past, and whether we can prosecute the war ad libitum, to use the phrase, or till we increase our National debt to $500,000,000 or $1,000,000,000, without interfering injuriously with the industries of our people, or with their commerce and trade.

abstract: FREE DRAWING LESSONS. -- The facilities for instruction in the art of picturing, both for ornamental and scientific purposes, are probably greater in this City than in any other in the world. Notwithstanding the drain on our material and means, caused by the war, evening lessons in all branches of drawing are commenced this week in Cooper Union Building, at the head of the Bowery, and at the Mechanics' Society's Buildings, No. 32 Crosby-street, and in both schools the instruction is free. In the latter the architectural drawing lessons are given Tuesday and Friday evenings, and the mechanical drawing lessons are on Monday and Wednesday evening. Simultaneously with the latter class there is a large and enthusiastic class in free hand drawing, or drawing without instruments, adapted to aid stone-cutters, sign-painters and ornamentists generally.

abstract: Commander CHAUNCEY, attached to the Atlantic blockading fleet, arrived in Washington last evening, from Hatteras Inlet, with highly important intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Commander CHAUNCEY, attached to the Atlantic blockading fleet, arrived in Washington last evening, from Hatteras Inlet, with highly important intelligence. On Monday the rebels organized an expedition to attack and recapture the forts at the Inlet, which recently fell into our hands. The expedition consisted of six steamboats and about three thousand men, the steamers being armed with heavy rifled cannon and mortars for throwing shells. The attack was simultaneous and persistent, but wholly ineffectual, and the rebels finally retired, after suffering fearfully. The forts answered their fire with shell, and were assisted by our vessels stationed off the Gulf. Two of the attacking steamers are reported to have been sunk, and judging from their crowded appearance, it is estimated that about seven hundred men were drowned, besides a large loss sustained from our shot and shell, as our guns were served in the most efficient manner.

abstract: The Madrid Correspondancia states that the troops which are to be sent to Cuba, in addition to those already in the Island, will make up a contingent of 4,000 men. The squadron destined to act against Mexico will consist of twelve vessels, mounting 300 guns. To these will be added two corvettes
lead_paragraph: The Madrid Correspondancia states that the troops which are to be sent to Cuba, in addition to those already in the Island, will make up a contingent of 4,000 men. The squadron destined to act against Mexico will consist of twelve vessels, mounting 300 guns. To these will be added two corvettes and the necessary transports. The command of the and forces will be intrusted to Gen. PRIM. The Captain-General of Cuba will be empowered to weight the requisite number of merchant vessels for the use of the expedition.

abstract: The announcement from Missouri, by telegraph, this morning, of the capture of a Colonel, half a regiment of Union troops, and three valuable pieces of artillery, by a band of ...
lead_paragraph: The announcement from Missouri, by telegraph, this morning, of the capture of a Colonel, half a regiment of Union troops, and three valuable pieces of artillery, by a band of 2,000 rebels near Gasconade Bridge, adds new and startling interest to the campaign in that State. Gasconade Bridge is between St. Louis and Jefferson City -- 90 miles from the former and 35 miles from the latter, on the Pacific Railroad. Consequently the rebel force doing the mischief is in Gen. FREMONT'S rear. The object of these rebels is said to be to burn the bridge over the Gasconade River, which would at once cut of FREMONT'S communications with St. Louis. The struggle then between FREMONT and RICE, if one should take place, would be for life or death.

abstract: Mosselman et al. vs. Myer Caen. -- The plaintiffs in this action were appointed Trustees of Sickel & Co., in Belgium, of the Tribunal of Commerce. They now sought to recover $20,000, as the assignees of that Company, of the defendant here. This is the second action of the same kind, brought against the defendant by the same parties, the former of which was decided by the General Term about two months since. In that case the Court held that the plaintiffs, as foreign statutory assignees or trustees, did not acquire a title to property which was in this country at the time of their appointment. In accordance with that opinion, the Court in this instance dismissed the complaint in the case, making an allowance of $50 to the defendant.
lead_paragraph: Mosselman et al. vs. Myer Caen. -- The plaintiffs in this action were appointed Trustees of Sickel & Co., in Belgium, of the Tribunal of Commerce. In accordance with that opinion, the Court in this instance dismissed the complaint in the case, making an allowance of $50 to the defendant.

abstract: -- We have in our Washington correspondence this morning, an evidently official correction of the blunders and inventions of the foreign Press, concerning the proffer to GARIBALDI, and other distinguished European officers, of positions in our Army. It is stated that the President, learning that GARIBALDI intented soon to revisit the United States, tendered him an appointment as Major-General, -- which, for the present, at all events, he has declined. This is the whole of that story. There is nothing unusual or improper about it, -- least of all, anything to justify the comments that have been made upon it, both at home and abroad.

abstract: A dispatch from Halifax announces the arrival there of the Polar Expedition, under Dr. HAYES, which left the United States some two years ago. Two of the party have died during their absence, but the rest are well. The expedition spent last Winter at Port Foulke, near Alexander, and proceeded during the last Summer with dogs and sledges as high as lat. 81 35'.

The expedition spent last Winter at Port Foulke, near Alexander, and proceeded during the last Summer with dogs and sledges as high as lat. 810 35′.

abstract: The London Morning Post publishes an abstract of the tripartite treaty which England is said to have negotiated with France and Spain in regard to Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The London Morning Post publishes an abstract of the tripartite treaty which England is said to have negotiated with France and Spain in regard to Mexico. The three Powers, according to this summary, do not contemplate any intervention in the domestic affairs of that country beyond what is immediately designed for the collection of interest upon some few millions of foreign debt. The latter object will require the seizure of the several Custom-houses on the shore of the Gulf, the collection of duties, and the partition of the net results between the creditors of the national treasury and the treasury itself. Only in the event of Mexico resisting this foreign administration of her revenue system, will measures of a hostile character be resorted to; and then nothing more sanguinary than the establishment of a strict blockade is contemplated. Such is the exceedingly temperate programme with which the united squadrons of England. France and Spain go about this important business.
headline: {'main': 'Mexico and the European Powers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mexico and the European Powers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Mr. Manager ULLMANN, the most indefatigable of impresarios, has issued his programme for a new campaign. The war has thrown his arrangements, like those of everybody else, into great confusion, -- but he does not like to abandon the field entirely, and therefore comes forward with a proposition for two benefit performances, in order to raise the means of carrying out his plans. The Directors of the Academy have indicated their willingness to cooperate in this plan, and urge every stockholder to aid it by purchasing from five to ten tickets for each share. If this shall be generally done, Mr. ULLMANN says it will enable him to go forward with the very liberal and attractive programme which he has arranged.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. Manager ULLMANN, the most indefatigable of impresarios, has issued his programme for a new campaign. The war has thrown his arrangements, like those of everybody else, into great confusion, -- but he does not like to abandon the field entirely, and therefore comes forward with a proposition for two benefit performances, in order to raise the means of carrying out his plans. The Directors of the Academy have indicated their willingness to cooperate in this plan, and urge every stockholder to aid it by purchasing from five to ten tickets for each share. If this shall be generally done, Mr. ULLMANN says it will enable him to go forward with the very liberal and attractive programme which he has arranged.

abstract: -- The good old custom of author's benefits will be revived here to-night, when Miss GRACE WALCOT will appeal to her friends. This young and talented lady has prepared the piece now playing at Mr. JACKSON's establishment, and the "Cup and the Lip" will of course be the attraction for her benefit. Since this night of its production it has gained considerably in quickness of action. The cast is really admirable. We hope Miss WALCOT will have a crowded house.

abstract: Edward Simpson vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This is another one of those cases involving the respective rights of the Mayor and Aldermen and the Police Commissioners, to appoint Police Court Clerks. In November last, Justice MULLEN, at the Circuit of this Court, directed the jury, in a similar case, to find for the defendants, the Court holding that the Court of Appeals having decided that the Metropolitan Police act was constitutional, and the Police Commissioners, under that act, having authority to make these appointments, the plaintiff claiming as assignee or an appointee of the Mayor and Aldermen, could not recover.
lead_paragraph: Edward Simpson vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This is another one of those cases involving the respective rights of the Mayor and Aldermen and the Police Commissioners, to appoint Police Court Clerks. In November last, Justice MULLEN, at the Circuit of this Court, directed the jury, in a similar case, to find for the defendants, the Court holding that the Court of Appeals having decided that the Metropolitan Police act was constitutional, and the Police Commissioners, under that act, having authority to make these appointments, the plaintiff claiming as assignee or an appointee of the Mayor and Aldermen, could not recover.

abstract: We are indebted to Mr. LAMSON, late Quartermaster of the Thirty-first Regiment, for the following curious incident -- showing the many painful illustrations of the present war. It is a copy of a letter received by Mr. KLING, of this City, from the lieutenant commanding the company in which his son is now serving -- his elder brother being in the Confederate Army. It may be as well to mention that the boy, being in a situation in Vicksburgh, Miss., at the present outbreak, was obligated to enter the Twelfth Mississippi Volunteers -- he having not a single friend or acquaintance down there, probably prevented his escape:
lead_paragraph: We are indebted to Mr. LAMSON, late Quartermaster of the Thirty-first Regiment, for the following curious incident -- showing the many painful illustrations of the present war. It is a copy of a letter received by Mr. KLING, of this City, from the lieutenant commanding the company in which his son is now serving -- his elder brother being in the Confederate Army. It may be as well to mention that the boy, being in a situation in Vicksburgh, Miss., at the present outbreak, was obligated to enter the Twelfth Mississippi Volunteers -- he having not a single friend or acquaintance down there, probably prevented his escape:

abstract: The arrival and departure of Col. HENRY WILSON'S Twenty-second Massachusetts Regiment yestday, and the reception given them by the citizens of New-York, constituted an era in these days of military ovations. The promptness Which was so eaestly promised, was, unfortunately, not attained, ...
lead_paragraph: The arrival and departure of Col. HENRY WILSON'S Twenty-second Massachusetts Regiment yestday, and the reception given them by the citizens of New-York, constituted an era in these days of military ovations. The promptness Which was so eaestly promised, was, unfortunately, not attained, so that the welcome breakfast at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, grew into a welcome dinner, and almost exhausted the patience of the unfortunate guests who had foregone their matutinal meal for the purpose of doing justice to the welcome repast. The Sons of Massachusetts, however, waited as patiently as they could, and passed away a portion of the time in appointing as Marshals to assist Col. HOWE informing the profession, Messrs. RICHARD WARREN, ELLIOTT C. COWDIN, WALTER GREENOUGH and JOHN P. LORD. The joyful news that the train had arrived was not received until nearly 10 o'clock, although the breakfasting had been fixed at 8.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of that branch of the People's Union Convention, comprising the delegates to the Syracuse Conventions, was held at the Cooper Institute, last evening, to complete their nominations for County officers and the Judiciary. In accordance with the resolution passed at the original meeting at the Cooper Institute, six delegates from each Ward, representing the different parties, were admitted. On the call of the roll, over one hundred delegates answered to their names. Dr. JAMES M. AUSTIN occupied the Chair.
lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of that branch of the People's Union Convention, comprising the delegates to the Syracuse Conventions, was held at the Cooper Institute, last evening, to complete their nominations for County officers and the Judiciary. abstract: The Police are remarking, during this time of war and national disturbance, a sensible increase in the crime and poverty of children. It is  reported that in the Fifteenth Ward, and in the Ninth and Sixth, many very young girls are seen...
lead_paragraph: The Police are remarking, during this time of war and national disturbance, a sensible increase in the crime and poverty of children. It is reported that in the Fifteenth Ward, and in the Ninth and Sixth, many very young girls are seen about the streets who have already begun to resort to criminal practices for support. Many are arrested and taken to the Station-houses; some are removed to the House of Refuge, and the most are released again. They are either working-girls who cannot now get employment, or they are the children of laboring people who can no longer feed and clothe them as they once did.

abstract: It is no lack of respect to Dr. HAYES when we say that the brief telegram yesterday announcing his arrival at Halifax, homeward bound from his Polar Expedition, brought up to the surface of the memory a matter that had none into clean oblivion. In calmer times the ...
lead_paragraph: It is no lack of respect to Dr. HAYES when we say that the brief telegram yesterday announcing his arrival at Halifax, homeward bound from his Polar Expedition, brought up to the surface of the memory a matter that had none into clean oblivion. In calmer times the arrival of a visitor from a region nine parallels from the Pole might be a matter for at least a nine-days' wonder -- just now, the news will fall on the public ear with the languid half-interest which the Laureate describes the Lotos-eaters as feeling in the cares and coils of mankind.

abstract: Pursuant to an extended call, published in the German papers of this City during the past week, the delegates selected at the Ward meetings of German residents of all parties, held on Wednesday night...
lead_paragraph: Pursuant to an extended call, published in the German papers of this City during the past week, the delegates selected at the Ward meetings of German residents of all parties, held on Wednesday night, assembled yesterday evening at Pythagoras Man, on Canal-street. All the Wards, excepting the Third, were fully represented by six delegates for each, duly elected and empowered at the above-mentioned local meetings. A very large number of other respectable and active citizens, of the German tongue, also attested, by their presence, the deep interest they felt in the furtherance of the Union cause.

abstract: Wm. Tracy vs. The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company and G.P. Sharp. -- This case will be found of considerable interest to the traveling public, as it involves a rehearsal of the difficulties and perplexities incident to railroad traveling, every day experienced. The plaintiff in the case is the senior member of the law firm of Tracy, Powers & Tallmadge, of this City. The suit is brought against the Company and one of the Directors. In August, 1860, Mr. Tracy and his family were traveling on the road from Troy to Golden Bridge, in this State. Upon arriving at Albany, his baggage, four trunks, were marked for Golden Bridge, the plaintiff purchasing through tickets to New-York. The plaintiff testifies that the baggage-master told him that the trunks were marked all right for Golden Bridge; but that when he got to Golden Bridge the conductor refused to deliver his baggage without he, plaintiff, would pay a dollar for a hold-over ticket; that the conductor said if he would pay him a dollar he should have a hold-over ticket and one trunk; if he would pay $2 he might have all the trunks. The plaintiff refused, and the train moved on, the conductor saying the baggage must go to New-York. Mr. Tracy and his daughters were deprived of their baggage thirty hours before the trunks could be obtained. This suit was thereupon brought to recover damages for the zeizure and detention of the baggage. The conductor, being placed upon the stand for the defense, testified that he was not told where plaintiff wanted to go, nor did plaintiff say anything to him respecting baggage, he said nothing to plaintiff about baggage. The Court excluded the question put to witness as to what were the regulations of the road about the delivery of baggage at other places than those to which passengers purchased tickets.

abstract: The People ex rel. John Walers vs. The Commissioners of Emigration. Until the burning of the Quarantine buildings, the Commissioners of Emigration, as they aver, had allowed the boatmen employed...
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. John Walers vs. The Commissioners of Emigration.--Until the burning of the Quarantine buildings, the Commissioners of Emigration, as they aver, had allowed the boatmen employed by the Health Officer to bring in the sick from vessels at Quarantine to the Marine Hospital, to use a certain unoccupied building inside the inclosure, not needed or used by the Commissioners, for lodging apartments. After the destruction of those buildings, the boatmen were driven to find lodgings for themselves, and accordingly they have since rented on their own responsibility.

abstract: -The meeting called for yesterday, and which was to have been held at Room No. 10 Produce Exchange, at 1 1/4 o'clock P.M., was not formally organized. The attendance at the appointed hour was confined to about a dozen merchants. Mr. FRANCIS P. SAGE made an informal call to order, Mr. JAMES T. TAPSCOTT acting as Secretary. Mr. SAGE remarked, in view of the very small number of gentlemen present, it had been suggested that the meeting be declared adjourned to next day. A motion to that effect, offered by Mr. A.F. ROBERTS, and duly seconded, was unanimously adopted. The meeting will, consequently, be held on the regular business floor of the Produce Exchange, to-day, (Friday.) 11th inst., at 1 o'clock P.M., when the question of demurrage and other matters of interest to the Produce Trade generally, will be discussed.

abstract: The dispatches from the West announced very positively, yesterday, from Missouri, that Col. MATTHEWS had telegraphed from Hermann to Gov. GAMBLE, that he "had peen compelled to surrender his camp with three pieces of cannon, to a superior force of rebels."
lead_paragraph: The dispatches from the West announced very positively, yesterday, from Missouri, that Col. MATTHEWS had telegraphed from Hermann to Gov. GAMBLE, that he "had peen compelled to surrender his camp with three pieces of cannon, to a superior force of rebels." This superior force of rebels was said to have numbered 2,000, and their design was stated to be the burning of the Gasconade Bridge of the Pacific Railroad, which is ten miles west of Hermann. We supposed that this Colonel ought to know whether he had "surrendered his camp and three pieces of cannon to 2,000 rebels," and accordingly we credited and commented upon the supposed fact -- the chief point dwelt upon being the startling circumstance that so large a force of rebels could have made their way to FREMONT's rear, and got in dangerous proximity to Gasconade Bridge, a vital point in that General's communication with St. Louis.

abstract: The Western Press is beginning to complain with a good deal of impatience of the enormous number of troops who are collected at Washington, not only without any evident necessity, but with no immediate prospect of employment, and to the serious neglect of importent interests in other quarters.
lead_paragraph: The Western Press is beginning to complain with a good deal of impatience of the enormous number of troops who are collected at Washington, not only without any evident necessity, but with no immediate prospect of employment, and to the serious neglect of importent interests in other quarters. It is held to be a peculiar hardship that regiment after regiment should be brought to Washington from the Western States, while the Union cause in Kentucky and Missouri is in such peril. If it was understood that these troops are speedily to be employed in Virginia, or, indeed, anywhere else, the West would be reconciled to their loss: -- but they have no such consolation. The impression seems to be general that there is to be no advance from the line of the Potomac, -- that the policy of the Government, so far as the Army of the Potomac is concerned, is to be a defensive policy, and that the countless hosts which disappear from the public gaze the moment they reach Washington, are designed merely for the defence of the capital. And on this assumption, the journals of the West object very strenuously to the policy pursued.

abstract: It is useless to deny that our readers do not pay half enough attention to the great events of which the United States are now the theatre. People read the everlasting and monotonous correspondence from Rome or Naples with more curiosity and interest than...
lead_paragraph: It is useless to deny that our readers do not pay half enough attention to the great events of which the United States are now the theatre. People read the everlasting and monotonous correspondence from Rome or Naples with more curiosity and interest than the bulletins dated from the banks of the Potomac. Is this mere caprice? Is it that indifference towards distant objects with which our countrymen are too often justly reproached? Or is it a sort of secret instinct which warns our people that that which is now passing on the other side of the Atlantic is merely a prologue, and that the war once finished, the real drama will commence?

abstract: The "seat of war" does not seem to be a standing one. It changes its location almost daily. But the publishers of maps follow it up faithfully. Thus, JOHN BACHMAN, who has before published several panoramic views of other marshes where the war fever prevails, now publishes a "Bird's-Eye View," of North and South Carolina and a part of Georgia. He has judiciously introduced a few ships in the vicinity of Hatteras Inlet, and represented the bombardment and capture of that fortification. Mr. BACHMAN's maps are so arranged that they can be joined together -- each representing a part of one gigantic whole -- and he makes no extra charge for putting them through the pasting process.

abstract: The steamship Columbia, ADAMS, from Havana, Oct. 5, 5 P.M., arrived here yestetday. She experienced strong northerly gales north of Cape Hattoras. The health of Havana was much improved. The crops look well, and except in parts...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Columbia, ADAMS, from Havana, Oct. 5, 5 P.M., arrived here yestetday. She experienced strong northerly gales north of Cape Hattoras. The health of Havana was much improved. The crops look well, and except in parts of the country where there has been a severe tempest, they will be large. Markets steady. Sugars -- Nos. 11 and 12, at 9 to 9 1/2 reals per arrobe; stock in Havana, 65,000 boxes. Molasses 2 3/4 reals keg; little demand, freights for the United States improved, and still in good demand. American vessels were not so much neglected. Exchange on London, 16 1/2@17 premium. 60 days sight, New-York, 5 premium, it was reported in Havana that Gen. SERRANO is to leave for Spain on the 20th inst., and that Gen. PRIM is on his way to Cuba to assume the Captain Generalship. It is conjectured that he will also take command of the expedition against Mexico.

abstract: A rajn-storm which prevailed yesterday, prevented any new movement of our troops across the Potomac, and the day was spent in strengthening the new outposts, and preparing for the comfort of the men in the more exposed positions.
lead_paragraph: A rain-storm which prevailed yesterday, prevented any new movement of our troops across the Potomac, and the day was spent in strengthening the new outposts, and preparing for the comfort of the men in the more exposed positions. The Leesburgh turnpike was crowded all day with Government wagons, conveying camp equipage; yet such was the magnitude of the movement en Wednesday morning, that many of the men engaged in it were probably forced to bivouac last night without shelter. As we announced yesterday morning, Gen. MCCALL's Division crossed the Potomac on Wednesday night. Yesterday it occupied Langley, five miles from the Chain Bridge. The rebels did not show themselves anywhere along our lines in any considerable numbers.

abstract: COUNTERFEITERS ARRESTED. Officers QUACK, ENBUSH and MILES, of the First Precinct Police, late on Wednesday night, arrested JOHN HOPKINS and JAMES PALMER, charged with passing counterfoit $5s on the Columbia Bank of Chatham Four Corners, in...
lead_paragraph: COUNTERFEITERS ARRESTED.--Officers QUACK, ENBUSH and MILES, of the First Precinct Police, late on Wednesday night, arrested JOHN HOPKINS and JAMES PALMER, charged with passing counterfoit $5s on the Columbia Bank of Chatham Four Corners, in this State. Upon the person of HOPKINS were found $70 of this spurious money, and upon PALMER $5, and also $8 in good money. They were arrested at the foot of Roosevelt-street, just as they were about to take a ferryboat to Brooklyn. The officers had been in pursuit of them for two or three days previous. PALMER is known to be an old offender. They were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, who committed them for examination. The same evening CATHARINE O'BRIEN and JOHN WILLIAMS were taken into custody, charged with attempting to pass similar bills, the former at a store in Third-avenue, and the latter at the store of JOHN W. SHEDDEN, No. 363 Bowery. Yesterday morning Justice KELLY committed them for trial. The bills in question are new, and bear the date of September, 1861. The paper is poor, and the engraving coarse -- not calculated to deceive a judge of money.

abstract: This Committee, composed of delegates elected at primary meetings, by order of the Ward Associations, was held yesterday afternoon, in Montagus Hall, Court-street.
lead_paragraph: This Committee, composed of delegates elected at primary meetings, by order of the Ward Associations, was held yesterday afternoon, in Montagus Hall, Court-street. All the Wards and Towns in the County were represented, except the Eighteenth Ward and New-Utrecht. The Convention was called to order at 3 1/2 o'clock, by JOHN CASHOW, who nominated JAMES DE REVERE, of the Fifth Ward, as Chairman. The nomination was made unanimously. Messrs. J.O. NODYNE, Tenth Ward, and J.N. BAILEY, Fourth Ward, were elected Secretaries. On motion, Messrs. HODGES, Nineteenth Ward, HICKS, of the Eleventh Ward, and BIDDLE, of the Seventeenth Ward, were appointed a Committee on Credentials. They reported 60 delegates present.

abstract: The prospect of an early and decisive battle in Missouri, between the National troops under FREMONT, and the rebels under Gen. PRICE, has vanished, if we can credit the advices from Gen. FREMONT's camp. A correspondent of a Cincinnati paper, who is with FREMONT's army, writes on Monday, the 7th inst., from Jefferson City, stating that on that day the advance of Gen. FREMONT's headquarters was begun. The correspondent does not speak of any intended forced marches, but he says that Gen. FREMONT "hardly hopes to intercept Gen. PRICE." The news at Jefferson City was thaton the Thursday previous to Gen. FREMONT's advance on Monday, Gen. PRICE's was 30 miles south of a point 150 miles due west of Jefferson City. This would give Gen. PRICE, by any traveled roads, at least 176 miles the start of Gen. FREMONT, and three full days, from Thursday to Monday, to increase that distance. It may well he conceded, therefore, that Gen. FREMONT is not likely to overtake Gen. PRICE. HOW it is that Gen. PRICE so easily marched out of the trap in which he had been "caught" at Lexington, the "military men at St. Louis" have not yet informed the country.
