abstract: The Legislative Committee on Street Openings held another meeting yesterday, and examined three witnesses. The first, S.P. LEE, was a bill-poster, and his evidence was as to the mole of his employment and pay. He was allowed $2 per day for posting, and sometimes he posted 3 or 4 in a day, and at other times he did not go near the District for several days. The witness declined to answer whether he had ever given any portion of his pay to any other party. The Auditor in the Comptroller's office was also examined, his testimony showing that the rooms occupied by the Counsel to the Corporation, in Nassau-street (seven in number), were leased by the City at $2,200 per [???], but that the rooms occupied by H.G. BRONSON, Esq., and let occasionally to Commissioners of Street Openings, formed no portion of the premises hired by the City, but were hired and paid for by himself. JOHN H. WHITE, Esq., was also examined as to a charge of $-368 for room-hire in one case, when he was a Commissioner, but it was established that he only charged $1 per day, and the amount paid to him was regular and reasonable. The Committee will continue their sittings next week.
lead_paragraph: The Legislative Committee on Street Openings held another meeting yesterday, and examined three witnesses. The first, S.P. abstract: An English journal announces that the Mexican question has been the object of a Convention between the three Powers interested, and also gives the substance of the said Convention. The English journal has not been correctly informed. We are assured that the Government of the Emperor has completely approved of the conduct of M. DUBOIS DE SALIGNY, has manifested its extreme dissatisfaction with the Juarez Government, and its decided intention to protect the interests of the French, but as yet no decision has been taken as to the means to be adopted for securing that result.

abstract: Gen. ANDERSON, in conversation yesterday morning, speaking of his being compelled to leave his native State at this time, says he deeply regrets that his feeble health renders it necessary for him to do so. The selection of his successor is, however, entirely satisfactory to him.

ANDERSON, in conversation yesterday morning, speaking of his being compelled to leave his native State at this time, says he deeply regrets that his feeble health renders it necessary for him to do so. The selection of his successor is, however, entirely satisfactory to him. Gen. SHERMAN possesses in an eminent degree the soldierly qualifies which are now needed in Kentucky, and trusts that he may, by God helping, utterly defeat the insolent rebels, who, with professions of friendship, protection and assistance on their ups, are violating personal liberty, breaking up the happiness and unity of families, destroying both life and property, reviling the public authorities, nullifying laws, usurping the government of the State as far as they can, and endeavoring by the power of arms and terror of military rule to force Kentucky, against her repeatedly declared will, to take part with them in their unholy and wicked efforts to overthrow the National Government, and to erect in its stead a reign of tyranny and misrule such as is unknown in the history of the world. He urges upon his fellow-countrymen to rally at once-to come with any kind of arms they can get-and not let it he said that Kentucky has to rely upon her neighbors, who have so promptly and cheerfully responded to his call, from Indiana, Ohio, and Illinois. Let it be proved by their conduct, that her sons are determined to be even with the foremost in defence of her honor and the protection of her sons and daughters.

abstract: Forty horses were drafted from the Third Rhode Island Regiment, yesterday, and stabled in the City, read for embarkation on board one of the chartered steamers, which has had stalls fixed up for their accommodation. The baggage wagons are already on board. It is said these horses will be transferred to some other regiments, the Third Rhode Islanders retaining only just sufficient for their own purposes This Regiment has been in readiness to leave Fort Hamilton for some days past, and is daily expecting orders to march. It seems highly probable that the regiment will form part of the expedition which will very shortly leave this port.

abstract: We have received from our correspondent in Japan a detailed account of the armed attack made upon the British Legation, and the narrow escape of the British Minister and the members of his household from massacre Mr. OLIPHANT, whose visit to this country will be remembered, was wounded in the affray. The miscreants engaged in this assault were kept at bay by the parties assailed, and were afterwards set upon and dispersed, several of their number being wounded and three killed, by the guard of the Legation. Details of thisevent had not reached England at the departure of the last mail, although the general fact was known. In commenting upon it the London Times thinks that, while it may not be necessary to enter upon an actual war to punish the Japanese Government, there most be a display of force that will effectually prevent such occurrences in the future. Whether these outrages were perpetrated by the connivance of the authorities or not, the Times insists that the Government must be held responsible for them, inasmuch as it is in duty bound to afford ample protection to the British Legation.

abstract: The steamship Asia arrived at this port yesterday with two days later news from Europe. She left Liverpool on the 28th and Queenstown on the 29th ult. She brings about 20,000 in space on freight. The latest market reports still note an upward tendency in Cotton. The stock on hand in Liverpool was estimated at 751.500 bales, of which 441,790 were American, and the amount at sea on the way from India was estimated as high as 270,000 bales, against only 70,000 at the same time last year. Breadstuffs and Provisions are still reported dull. The English Board of Trade returns for August exhibit a falling off in exports to the United States during the month of 1,080,500 as compared with August of 1860. The English Funds were firmer, and Consols had recovered somewhat.

abstract: The record of our naval operations since the beginning of hostilities is not calculated to uphold the prestige which the Americans have hitherto enjoyed on the sea. It is a little mortifying, that while it has been demonstrated ...
lead_paragraph: The record of our naval operations since the beginning of hostilities is not calculated to uphold the prestige which the Americans have hitherto enjoyed on the sea. It is a little mortifying, that while it has been demonstrated again and again that the rebels were able to do little or nothing in the line of naval operations, their half-a-dozen privateers have made more captures among our merchant and coasting vessels than the entire Navy of the United States has made of their coasters and the shoals of craft seeking to run the blockade. Carefully collated statistics to Sept. 23, show that, up to that date, the rebels had taken seventy of our vessels while our whole coast guard had made but fifty-two prizes!

abstract: We expressed some doubt, a few days since, as to the practical effect of an edict of emancipation, even if one should be issued by the General Government. It is very clear that such a document would have no force beyond the lines of our Armies, unless it should come to the knowledge of the slaves themselves, and incite them to insurrection -- and, even if this were desirable, we have, up to the present time, not the slightest evidence of any such inclination on their part.

abstract: If our readers have any curiosity to see the kind of stuff with which our Canadian neighbors strengthen and confirm their "neutrality," in regard to our rebellion, they will find it abundantly gratified by the perusal of a letter which we [???] this morning, from the Chronicle, [???]. That paper asserts that [???] written by a gentleman of high of [???] very proudly that he is connected with the diplomatic service of the English Government. Whoever he may be, or whatever his position, he does not scruple to put in print the most barefaced and infamous falsehoods which human ingenuity can invent. He has gone deliberately to work to arouse public hostility in Canada against this country, by systematic lying. It is needless to say here that the statements of his letter are utterly false from beginning to end. He knows them to be so: -- but he also knows that they will be circulated mainly at a distance, where no contradictions can reach them, and that they will thus produce just as much effect, and do as much to plant tho seeds of eternal hatred between the two countries as if they were true, -- and this is precisely what he seeks to accomplish by them. He may find, in course of time that he has been even morn successful than he could have wished in this work of devilish malignity.

abstract: Charles Derlin vs. James B. Brady and George Mountjoy. -- This action is brought to recover upon a promissory note, originally made, as alleged by the defendant, Brady, payable to the defendant, Mountjoy, the consideration being, as alleged by Brady by way of defence, certain services which Mountjoy was to render Brady, in securing his claims; against the Corporation for work done on contracts. The note was for $8,000, and was transferred by Mountjoy to Mr. Street-Commissioner Taylor, and by him transferred to the plaintiff. Brady's defence was, first, that the only consideration for the note was Mountjoy's influence towards securing his (Brady's) claims against the Departments, and particularly the Street Department; secondly, that the plaintiff was fully informed of the facts connected with the note, of the consideration for which it was given, &c., before and at the time it came into his possession. Mountjoy did not answer. The note was discounted by the Bowery Bank.
lead_paragraph: Charles Derlin vs. James B. The note was for $8,000, and was transferred by Mountjoy to Mr. Street-Commissioner Taylor, and by him transferred to the plaintiff. Brady's defence was, first, that the only consideration for the note was Mountjoy's influence towards securing his (Brady's) claims against the Departments, and particularly the Street Department; secondly, that the plaintiff was fully informed of the facts connected with the note, of the consideration for which it was given, &c., before and at the time it came into his possession. abstract: On Tuesday, the 24th [???] Dr. GEORGE J. FISHER, of Sing Sing, assisted by Drs. STEWART, LEE, SNOWDEN, and FULLER, of Peekskill, Dr. [???] of Yonkers, and Dr. LANGER, of Davenport, O., performed the operation of ovariotomy, on the person of a married lady, aged 23 years, a resident of the village of Peekskill. The tumor had [???] the magnitude of over fifty pounds weight. Its character was what the doctors call a multilocular, cystic, ovarian tumor; that is to say, it was made up of one enormous sac, within which were thousands of lesser seas or cysts, varying in size from a pin's head, to a pea, grape, an orange, and a man's hand; each of these cysts is filled with a thick gelatinous fluid; in some so thick that it will scarcely flow out when the cyst is opened.

abstract: The assurance, in spite of the denial of the Patrie, that the British Government, in conjunction with France and Spain, and with the consent of the United States, has resolved upon an intervention in Mexico, will cause neither surprise nor dissatisfaction.
lead_paragraph: The assurance, in spite of the denial of the Patrie, that the British Government, in conjunction with France and Spain, and with the consent of the United States, has resolved upon an intervention in Mexico, will cause neither surprise nor dissatisfaction. The wonder has been that powerful nations should have been content to forego the usual rights conceded them by public law, and to leave their citizens to be robbed and murdered with impunity by the savages and fanatics of a decaying Republic. The misdeeds of the Mexican Government, or rather of the succession of factions which have borne that name, are so many that any recapitulation of grievances would be idle. The last fifteen years have been passed by foreign settlers and merchants in a state of constant uneasiness, and of late neither life nor property has been safe. We have, on more than one occasion commented on the extraordinary news which has reached us from that distracted country, and it may be said that, for the last year or two, the scandals made known by the arrival of each succeeding mail have surpassed those that had gone before. To dishonesty, to repudiation, to the legal and irremediable plunder of our countrymen by the default of a bankrupt community, we were steeled by long endurance. We were used to corrupt judges, trafficking and jobbing officials, insolent underlings, and all the hateful creatures which are generated by the rottenness of a State. Nor were we likely to be moved by ordinary crimes. Half-caste vagabonds might waylay travelers or murder respectable citizens within a few miles of the capital, and as long as it was possible to hold the Government free from responsibility, and to suppose that these were only private malefactors, England would have acted on the maximum that he who lives abroad takes the country of his residence as he finds it, and cannot appeal to his own sovereign for protection against ordinary injuries. But the time has come when forbearance will be no longer possible. It is plain law and good sense that when the injuries done to a foreign settler are owing to the act or neglect of the Government of the country where he lives, his own sovereign has a right to call upon the offending State for redress. Now, in this case, the outrages committed are, beyond a doubt, the result of the violence of political parties in Mexico and the complete anarchy into which the Republic has fallen. British subjects have been plundered not only by the rufhans to whom the evil times have given impunity, but by the chiefs of the contending factions, and even by men who have called themselves the rulers, and who have been, for the time, the rulers of the country. It would be satisfactory to be able to say that these excesses have been committed by the party which is most opposed to liberal principles, and which is constituted chiefly by the numberless priests of the country, leading the most ignorant and savage of the Mexican race. But, though undoubtedly the party if Juarez is far less guilty than its opponents, and though at the present time it is the ecclesiastical guerillas and bandits who are chiefly the terror of the foreign residents, yet no party in Mexico is free from blame, nor can any justly complain that the Republic is threatened by foreign Powers for what is the fault of a faction only.

abstract: A German justice at Washington, following a judicial precedent in our own City, having decided that "lager beet is not intoxicating," Gen. MCCLELLAN has heretofore allowed that beverage to be freely poured out in libations to the divinities of war. While all other liquors of the spiritous order are under embargo and prohibited from being brought into the camps on the Potomac, lager has enjoyed entire immunity. It seems that latterly, however, the nectar of Gambrinus, with an unseemly disregard of the judicial finding, behaves itself most strangely, and actually fuddles, elevate; and maketh "tight" our men of war. Whether this be owing to the introdction of some more ardent quality into the natural innocuousness of the beverage, or whether it be that American soldiers have not yet acquired the true Teutonic power of resistance, the foaming flagons have inebriated, as well as cheered. So larger is now tabooed. Strict orders have been issued that none shall be allowed in camp, and officers have been instructed to investigate the contents of every wagon entering the lines, to see that the enemy is not smuggled in. It is unfortunate that, for the sake of a few weak-headed Yankees, our tens of thousands of German sons of Mars should be deprived of what is nearly as necessary to their existence as pretzels or sauer-kraut. But such are the stern necessities of war!

abstract: We have full confirmation, by the last foreign mail, with more details, of the arrangements of England, France and Spain for intervention in the affairs of Mexico. The London Times states the general scope and plan of the movement, and adds that it is undertaken with the full assent and approbation of the President of the United States. This is remarkable and rather unexpected feature of the case, and will probably somewhat modify public sentiment as to the objects of the projected intervention.

abstract: NEAL DOW has been commissioned Colonel of the Thirteenth Regiment of Maine Volunteer. Mr. Dow has long desired join the ranks of the defendersof his country, but has been restrained by duties which he owed to his family, of an imperative nature; those who know him best assert that he has a natural aptitude for military affairs, and that his greatest difficulties will arise from his desire to be always busy, leading him to do, or to attempt, too much.

abstract: A good deal of indifferent logic has been expanded lately in an endeavor to prove that Mr. ALCOCK was wrong in leaving and Mr. HARRIS right in staying at Jeddo after the assassination of Mr. HEUSKEN, the interpreter. Our opinion always ran that Mr. ALCOCK was right, and Mr. HARRIS decidedly wrong, and events are showing that this is the correct view of the case. It may be, indeed, that, had Mr. HARRIS made common cause with the foreign Ministers who joined Mr. ALCOCK, we should not now have to tell of the attempt to massacre the British Legation at Japan on the night of the 5th ult.

abstract: The Patrie is at some pains to contradict the statements which have recently appeared in these columns. Our cotemporary, which has lost the semi-official character which it formerly possessed, appears to become reckless in hazarding its statements. We repeat, in the certainty that the issue will prove the truth of our assertion, that a convention will shortly be signed by the Governments of England, France and Spain, who have decided upon sending a joint expedition to Mexico, to obtain full redress for their long-standing grievances.

abstract: Within a few days most tempting and unusual facilities for observation have been placed at the disposal of the lovers of Art in this Metropolis. Messrs. GOUPIL & Co. and Mr. SCHAUS have opened, in addition to their well known public galleries, two charming picture boudoirs, where are exhibited many choice and several rare paintings. At GOUPIL's we noticed specimens from the pencils of TAIT, CHURCH, DEHAAS, FRERE, HUBNER, EASTMAN, JOHNSON, HART, and other well known and favorite artists. A landscape (sold) by CHURCH, is one of his purest efforts, and is, we understand, considered by the artist as the best of his smaller productions. HART contributes a miniature picture gallery, having nine tiny paintings in one frame, ranging through as many varieties of landscape. JOHNSON's "Cold Fingers and Toes" is a capital thing, and uncomfortably suggestive of the coming season. Then there are pictures whose faces we have seen before, but none the less pleasant forthat, including the unhappy CORDAY on her way to execution, the unpleasantly dead CAESAR, TAIT's pretty fowls, and the view "Over the Way," which is so interesting an exponent of one of the good things of life. DEHAAS contributes a large marine view, which is considered one of the best ever taken from his popular easel. The "Christian Martyr," an engraving just issued in Paris from one of DELAROCHE's pictures, has made its appearance here simultaneously. One such exquisitely rendered transcript as this does much towards acquainting us with the mind and handpower of that great artist, and we trust that Mr. KNOEDER (GOUPIL & Co.) will find its success such that he will feel justified in affording us more frequent opportunities of like nature.
lead_paragraph: Within a few days most tempting and unusual facilities for observation have been placed at the disposal of the lovers of Art in this Metropolis. Messrs. abstract: This task, in the hands of the maritime nations which are about to undertake it, is obviously rendered an easy one by the extent of the seaboard of Mexico and the relative important of its commerce. Wehave only to occupy the entrance to the principal ports, and we hold our hands upon the channel through which all the revenues of the country must flow. Following the course approved of by the Mexican Government itself when it hypothecated part of its custom duties for the payment of the interest due to foreign bondholders, it is proposed that the Consuls of the three Powers at the ports which we think proper to seize shall receive the customs dues, half of which they will pay over to the Mexican authorities, retaining the other half in satisfaction of the claims of their respective Governments. If the object sought by this proceeding can be attained there will be no necessity for landing an army in the country which is justly thought to be objectionable, on the score not only of its expense, but of its tendency to lead to future complications among the intervening powers. Of course whether or not it be desirable to march troops upon the city of Mexico, is principally a question of money, for we should not have the slightest reason to apprehend meeting any enemy whose power of resistance need be taken into account. But it is difficult to know what an Anglo-French army could do when they got to the Capitol, to bring either the authorities or the people to reason, and we could hardly hope to avoid laying the seeds of international dissensions and jealousies such as constitute the besetting danger of combined military expeditions. We adopt a much safer and more effective course, by taking hold of the neck of the Mexican purse, and levying loll in satisfaction of our grievances before we allow the broad pieces to pass into the coffers of the State.
lead_paragraph: This task, in the hands of the maritime nations which are about to undertake it, is obviously rendered an easy one by the extent of the seaboard of Mexico and the relative important of its commerce. Wehave only to occupy the entrance to the principal ports, and we hold our hands upon the channel through which all the revenues of the country must flow. Following the course approved of by the Mexican Government itself when it hypothecated part of its custom duties for the payment of the interest due to foreign bondholders, it is proposed that the Consuls of the three Powers at the ports which we think proper to seize shall receive the customs dues, half of which they will pay over to the Mexican authorities, retaining the other half in satisfaction of the claims of their respective Governments. If the object sought by this proceeding can be attained there will be no necessity for landing an army in the country which is justly thought to be objectionable, on the score not only of its expense, but of its tendency to lead to future complications among the intervening powers. Of course whether or not it be desirable to march troops upon the city of Mexico, is principally a question of money, for we should not have the slightest reason to apprehend meeting any enemy whose power of resistance need be taken into account. But it is difficult to know what an Anglo-French army could do when they got to the Capitol, to bring either the authorities or the people to reason, and we could hardly hope to avoid laying the seeds of international dissensions and jealousies such as constitute the besetting danger of combined military expeditions. We adopt a much safer and more effective course, by taking hold of the neck of the Mexican purse, and levying loll in satisfaction of our grievances before we allow the broad pieces to pass into the coffers of the State.

abstract: The operations in Mexican stock to-day have again been of an extraordinary character, both as regards number and amount, and the fluctuations have been wide in consequence of an apparently unqualified contradiction given by the Patrie to that statement published in London the day before yesterday, that the bases of a combined intervention by England, Spain and France had been definitively arranged. The last price yesterday was 26 to 1/4, and the early transactionsthis morning showed almost undiminished firmness. They varied between 25 3/4 and 26 1/4; but on the publication of the paragraph from the Patrie there was a rapid fall to 25 1/2. Many of the operators, however, still manifested full confidence, and purchases were renewed on a considerable scale, causing a rebound to 26. Ultimately the tendency to dullness predominated, and the final bargains were at 25 1/4 to 1/2. The arrangement of the account will commence to-morrow, and much agitation is likely to be again manifested, the recent range of price having been between about 21 and 26 1/2. Other foreign stocks were generally steady.

They varied between 25 3/4 and 26 1/4; but on the publication of the paragraph from the Patrie there was a rapid fall to 25 1/2. Many of the operators, however, still manifested full confidence, and purchases were renewed on a considerable scale, causing a rebound to 26. Ultimately the tendency to dullness predominated, and the final bargains were at 25 1/4 to 1/2. The arrangement of the account will commence to-morrow, and much agitation is likely to be again manifested, the recent range of price having been between about 21 and 26 1/2. Other foreign stocks were generally steady.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, Recorder HOFFMAN presiding, Thomas C. Roche and Daniel Byrne pleaded guilty to a violation of the eleventh section of the law to prevent fraud in the sale of passenger tickets, and were fined, the former $175, and the latter $150' The tickets sold by the accused failed to state the day on which the vessel would sail, as the law requires. The prisoners paid their fines, and were discharged.

abstract: Wm. Tracy vs. The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company and G.P. Sharp -- The particulars of this case were stated in the TIMES of yesterday. The plaintiff is a lawyer of this City, and sued the defendants for an alleged wrongful detention of the baggage of himself and family while they were traveling in August, 1860. The plaintiff had purchased through tickets from Albany to New-York, but desired to stop at Golden Bridge. Upon arriving there he requested that his baggage should be delivered. The conductor refused to deliver it, and the consequence was that the plaintiff and his daughters were for thirty hours afterwards without their baggage.

abstract: -- On Wednesday evening, some person or persons threw two jugs filled with powder, to which slow matches were attached, into the house of EDWARD BRAN, an Irish blacksmith, on the corner of Prentiss and Parker streets, Roxbury. An explosion quickly followed the act, and the house and furniture were badly shattered, but none of the inmates were injured. One side of the house, for a distance of fifteen feet, was blown completely out, and the inside partitions and walls were badly shattered, and nearly every window in the house was broken. The powder was thrown in through one of the rear windows into a bedroom. The family at the time were in a front room. It was evidently supposed by the perpetrators that Mr. BRAN and family had retired. If such had been the case all of them must have been killed, for the powder exploded near the bed -- Boston Courier
lead_paragraph: -- On Wednesday evening, some person or persons threw two jugs filled with powder, to which slow matches were attached, into the house of EDWARD BRAN, an Irish blacksmith, on the corner of Prentiss and Parker streets, Roxbury. abstract: The intention of Gen. McCLELLAN seems to be to strengthen the positions of his army as he proceeds further into Virginia, so that he may have intrenchments to fall back upon, in case a retrograde movement should, to any extent, become necessary. Heavy works are being constructed at all the new points recently taken possession of by our troops, in which they have not yet been interfered with by the rebels. The pickets of the enemy are again in sight along our lines, but they make no hostile demonstrations.

abstract: On a recent visit to our National Capital we took occasion to ride out to Camp Sherman, Gen. VIELE's Brigade, comprising one regiment of cavalry, one of artillery, and three of infantry. The camp is well located on the elevated plateau one mile east of the Capitol. The cavalry are well drilled, and the artillery admirably handled, but of the regiment composing the infantry, though we would make no invidious comparisons, as they constitute a common patriotic.brotherhood devoted to the vindication of the same righteous cause, yet we confess we were especially attracted to the "Continentals," Col. PERRY, classed as the Forty-eighth N.Y.S. Volunteers.

abstract: The schooner Martha T. Gause, of Wilmington, Del., attempted to run the guard-boat stationed at the Narrows, yesterday morning, and was brought to by a shot striking her amidships, carrying away the rail on the opposite side of her. The excuse offered was that the captain was drunk, and below. She was bound to Wilmington or Baltimore. after having been signaled by the cutter to come to, two guns were tired, of which she took no notice, when United States Inspector RABINEAU communicated to Fort Lafayette, upon which the Fort, "acting in cooperation with the cutter," fired a shot across the schooner's bow. She then hauled her wind, and stood towards Fort Hamilton, (she being then a short distance below the Narrows.) Soon, however, she squared away for Sandy Hook, upon seeing which the Fort gave her another shot, which struck her bulwarks amidships on the port side, passing through close to her mainmast, and out through the bulwark ou the starboard side. This had the desired effect -the schooner returning, and anchoring near the cutter. She was afterwards released, and proceeded on her voyage.

abstract: Additional European news by the Glasgow, which passed Cape Race on Friday, is given in this morning's TIMES. The intelligence from the Continent is indicative of coming trouble at several points, but more especially in Hungary and Poland. All the functionaries in the Council of Pesth have tendered their resignations, and the ...
lead_paragraph: Additional European news by the Glasgow, which passed Cape Race on Friday, is given in this morning's TIMES. The intelligence from the Continent is indicative of coming trouble at several points, but more especially in Hungary and Poland. All the functionaries in the Council of Pesth have tendered their resignations, and the Assembly Chamber at Pesth had been occupied by military, the members being forcibly prevented from entering. From Poland we learn that a solemn meeting of the Poles had been called for the 10th of this month, at Lublin. Turkey also seems to be getting into further difficulty. It is stated that the Bosnians and Servians had declared in favor of the Montenegrins. The appearance of a pamphlet at Florence, condemning the temporal power of the Pope, had created considerable excitement there.

abstract: The October Number of Macmillan's Magazine, London, contains an article on the nature, origin and cause of the war, and the duty and power of the North to maintain the Union, written, as we learn from an editorial note, by "a lawyer of eminence in New-York, in no way connected with political parties or taking part in public affairs." The article was sent, by the author, as a letter to Mr. E. CHADWICK, well known in England by his strong opinions on the poor law and education questions -- with whom he has been accustomed to correspond -- and Mr. CHADWICK has thought fit to authorize its publication. The writer says that he was asked by a highly intelligent Manchester solicitor, with whom also he corresponds, and who is much interested in American affairs, "Why not let the South go?" To answer this question is the object of his letter to Mr. CHADWICK, and he does it in a very able manner, showing what the Union really is, and what are the limits of State rights, and completely demolishing the arguments of the Secessionists. As regards such States as Texas and Florida, it is shown that the effect of annulling the ordinances by which they were erected, is simply to restore them to the condition of territories, to be governed by Congress. The writer thus illustrates his position by a supposititious case:
lead_paragraph: The October Number of Macmillan's Magazine, London, contains an article on the nature, origin and cause of the war, and the duty and power of the North to maintain the Union, written, as we learn from an editorial note, by "a lawyer of eminence in New-York, in no way connected with political parties or taking part in public affairs." The article was sent, by the author, as a letter to Mr. E. CHADWICK, well known in England by his strong opinions on the poor law and education questions -- with whom he has been accustomed to correspond -- and Mr. CHADWICK has thought fit to authorize its publication. The writer says that he was asked by a highly intelligent Manchester solicitor, with whom also he corresponds, and who is much interested in American affairs, "Why not let the South go?" To answer this question is the object of his letter to Mr. CHADWICK, and he does it in a very able manner, showing what the Union really is, and what are the limits of State rights, and completely demolishing the arguments of the Secessionists. As regards such States as Texas and Florida, it is shown that the effect of annulling the ordinances by which they were erected, is simply to restore them to the condition of territories, to be governed by Congress. The writer thus illustrates his position by a supposititious case:

abstract: A telegraphicrumor reports Col. WILSON's Regiment of Zouaves as the objects of a successful attack by the rebels. The Zouaves have been encamped during the Summer upon Santa Rosa Island, generally within reach of Fort Pickens. The story runs that a large force of the rebels, who have swarmed for six months within gun-shot of the fort, crossed to the island at night, and taking the Union troops by surprise, killed, wounded or captured a large number of them. More extended and authentic accounts may reduce the proportions of the affair; but the simple fact of such a landing and attack at least demonstrates that whatever enterprise or energy exists in that quarter is on the side of the rebels.

abstract: The Clevelandpapers report a prodigious cock-and-bull story concerning the discovery of a wide-spread development of the Order of Knights of the Golden Circle in Ohio, the whole of which State, according to these statements, is honey-combed with "castles" of this treasonable Order. One of the castles is said to have been discovered in Marion County, the " Commander" of which has been arrested, and the traps of the concern secured. In another County, near the Western Reserve, there are reported to be eleven hundred Knights of the Order, which has its signs, grips and pass-words, and is furnished with arms. The aim of the conspiracy is "to paralyze all war effort in Ohio; resist by force the collection of the war tax, and in every way embarrass the present Administration, and, if possible, gain control over the next, and when the State is bound hand and foot these conspirators have promise of a military force from the South that shall, to use the expressive language of the Southern emissary, 'clean out' the Abolitionists." The Knights take an oath, and swear, in the presence of Almighty God and the Knights of the Golden Circle, that they "will not rest or sleep until ABRAHAM LINCOLN, now President, shall be removed out of the Presidential chair." Also, that they "will wade up to their knees in blood as soon as JEFF. DAVIS sees proper to march with his army to take the City of Washington and the White House!" Which it is not likely they will wade.

abstract: The approaching cold weather has created such a demand for overcoats and thick garments for the troop's, that all the available cloth of every description is brought into requisition. Our woolen manufactures are doing a splendid business, and those who failed to be successful in early bids, when competition run so high, are now reaping a good harvest. We understand that Major VINTON, a short time since, rejected a certain line of goods, for which he is now obliged to pay an aggregate advance of over $150,000. The advance in the price of overcoats has been from one dollar to one and a-quarter. -- Boston Commercial Bulletin, Oct. 12.

abstract: It is a fact no longer to be disputed that British sentiment, wherever it exists in the world, has been thrown into the scale of secession, and against the reconstruction of the American Union. As a people, we have been accused of a sensitiveness on this point ...
lead_paragraph: It is a fact no longer to be disputed that British sentiment, wherever it exists in the world, has been thrown into the scale of secession, and against the reconstruction of the American Union. As a people, we have been accused of a sensitiveness on this point that smacks of provincialism, and brings us back to times when we were, still a dependency of the Crown of England. The accusation is not altogether just, nor wholly unjust. Practically, the mere sympathies of a foreign people cannot affect the issues of the struggle in which we are engaged. But, on the other hand, it is only natural that we should be disappointed at the present attitude of a nation which; for half a century has been so vehement in its protestations against the institution of Slavery; it is only natural we should regret that the moral support given by Great Britain to this rebellion, should have been the means of its prolongation, and that a great, a kindred, and friendly people should suddenly veer from their professions of attachment, and appear before, us as bitter, uncompromising enemies-for what enemies are worse than those who compass or desire our destruction!

abstract: When the report reached St. Louis that Gen. The people in the East were led to believe that this was all true; but we find out from the Western papers that it was all false. abstract: The result of the municipal election in Baltimore on Wednesday last is very auspicious. The Union candidates for seats in the City Council were elected by a highly respectable vote. The real strength of the Unionists was not called out, as there was no contest of parties whatever the secession faction merely contenting itself with throwing two or three votes ...
lead_paragraph: The result of the municipal election in Baltimore on Wednesday last is very auspicious. The Union candidates for seats in the City Council were elected by a highly respectable vote. The real strength of the Unionists was not called out, as there was no contest of parties whatever the secession faction merely contenting itself with throwing two or three votes for JEFF. DAVIS. But the poll, nevertheless, was heavier than that cast in the same city last April for the rebel members of the Maryland Legislature, who now hold their sessions in the casemates of Fort Lafayette; and the election stands as an unmistakable declaration of allegiance to the Government on the part of ten thousand of the legal voters of Baltimore.

abstract: The fact that a powerful naval and military expedition has been preparing for some time at New-York is too generally understood to require any further affectation of secrecy. If the squadron and convoy have not put to sea before this sheet is printed, there is little doubt that another day will not pass without ...
lead_paragraph: The fact that a powerful naval and military expedition has been preparing for some time at New-York is too generally understood to require any further affectation of secrecy. If the squadron and convoy have not put to sea before this sheet is printed, there is little doubt that another day will not pass without their departure. Touching at Annapolis to complete its complement of men drawn from the finest corps at Washington, the expedition will proceed southward to the point of destination. What that point may be is a matter to be properly withheld from publication.

abstract: It has long been a favorite dogma with the enemies of republican freedom, that our institutions are unsuited to an extensive territory, and that, sooner or later, the Union must crumble to pieces amid the discordant and jarring interests of the numerous peoples and States.
lead_paragraph: It has long been a favorite dogma with the enemies of republican freedom, that our institutions are unsuited to an extensive territory, and that, sooner or later, the Union must crumble to pieces amid the discordant and jarring interests of the numerous peoples and States. It is naturally enough believed by the enemies of popular freedom, that nothing short of overwhelming brute force will keep an extensive empire together; and practically assuming the correctness of the infidel theory of HOBBS, that war is the normal condition of mankind, and that nations are natural enemies, they have fondly cherished the hope that their malevolent philosophy would find its illustration in the downfall of the American Union. A rebellion and civil war have broken out among us, springing from a peculiar state of society in one half of the Union, and these enemies of popular government jump to the conclusion that their theories are verified -- that henceforth the era of counter revolutions is to begin, which are to culminate in the overthrow of republican freedom, and the permanent establishment of monarchy. The London Times is among the most conspicuous advocates of this anti-republican and anti-social theory of the impossibility or a great empire of freemen, and makes no effort to conceal the delight which actuates its conductors at viewing what is regarded as the failure of the last and greatest experiment of republican Government.

abstract: Coroner Schirmer held an inquest yesterday at the New-York Hospital upon the body of FRANZ KARTEN, a soldier of the Forty-fifth Regiment, New-York Volunteers, who died the day previous from injuries produced by pistol ball, fired from a pistol in the hands ...
lead_paragraph: --Coroner Schirmer held an inquest yesterday at the New-York Hospital upon the body of FRANZ KARTEN, a soldier of the Forty-fifth Regiment, New-York Volunteers, who died the day previous from injuries produced by pistol ball, fired from a pistol in the hands of a fellow-soldier, named WITTEN. The evidence is somewhat contradictory, but several of the witnesses testified that just before the pistol was fired WITTEN was sitting on a mattress, when deceased came towards him, and spitting in his hand held it out towards WITTEN, saying, "Shake hands, brother." WITTEN immediately pulled out a five-barreled revolver and struck it towards deceased. The revolver exploded, and KARTEN fell. WITTEN at once [???] off the matters, exclaiming, "I did not hit you." A few minutes before a sergeant had tikled WITTEN's car, and WITTEN declared that he would shoot the man that again disturbed him. The sergeant reported the act of [???] and WITTEN struck out his pistol toward him, but which [???] to shoot the sergeant [???] is [???] The [???] was adjourned in order to obtain the evidence of two witnesses, who were present and [???] it is believed, will be able to throw some light upon the intention of WITTEN, who has been [???] into custody, and is now [???] to await the result of the laquest.

abstract: Perhaps the public will consider this a joke. Let us see. The Sound steamers encounter the stormy Atlantic every day of the Winter. The middle Atlantic in June is rarely as rough as it is off Point Judith in November. English engineers are sending boats of 250 feet length, and 15 inches depth, from London around the Cape to India.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the public will consider this a joke. Let us see. The Sound steamers encounter the stormy Atlantic every day of the Winter. The middle Atlantic in June is rarely as rough as it is off Point Judith in November. English engineers are sending boats of 250 feet length, and 15 inches depth, from London around the Cape to India. The Sound boats are built for heavy weather, and are quite as strong as the steamers built here for the Pacific Ocean, and sent round the Horn. There are plenty of coasting steamers and lake steamers of the precise American river steamboat pattern, that regularly encounter, particularly on the lakes, more trying seas than are usual on the Summer Atlantic. Their guards are high, and more protected than those of river boats from the action of waves, and still further temporary protection might be readily applied. As to absolute strength, the Metropolis, with her hogging frames, is all that could be required. Coal could be carried in a convoy, and we doubt not that navigators would be quite willing to take the job of sailing a strong Sound or Lake steamer to London.

abstract: The preparations for the Naval Expedition to the coast of Secessia (exact point not stated) which have been making at this port for several weeks past are now nearly completed) and in a few days, perhaps a few hours, the whole fleet will be moving toward its destination. Two of the transports, viz., the Cahawba and Coatzacoalcos sailed last evening, and others may be under way before this meets the eyes of our readers. The Cahawba took out the Third Rhode Island Regiment, lately encamped at Fort Hamilton, and both vessels are supplied with surf boats, and experienced surfmen from Toms River, Long Branch, Squan and other places on the Jersey coat.

abstract: A movement of the rebels threatening our lines across the Potomac is noted in our Washington dispatches, which may mean a great deal more than is at present apparent. They advanced a large force yesterday in the direction of Prospect Hill, driving in the National pickets to that ...
lead_paragraph: A movement of the rebels threatening our lines across the Potomac is noted in our Washington dispatches, which may mean a great deal more than is at present apparent. They advanced a large force yesterday in the direction of Prospect Hill, driving in the National pickets to that point. The Division of Gen. McCALL, stationed at Langley, was immediately formal in line of battle and got in readiness to advance, supported by cavalry and artillery, and the Divisions of Gens. SMITH. PORTER and McDOWELL. were also rapidly prepared for any emergency. Several shots were fired by a rebel battery at Gen. McCALL'S Division, but being out of range, their guns did no damage. The rebels attempted nothing further, and our troops did not advance. It is impossible at present to tell the meaning of this demonstration, but it may possibly have been intended to attract attention from some more important movement elsewhere.

abstract: The great object of attraction here is LANE'S Brigade, and the eccentric commandant of that institution is the "rage" all about here. Hundreds. -- and a, chronicler of ordinarily brilliant imagination, and less regard for strict numerical accuracy than myself, would say thousands -- of curious people are constantly thronging his quarters to get a glimpse of the great leader, or to shove a letter from some influential individual under his nose. However, the ubiquitous gentleman rather beat them yesterday, and he accomplished the skillful manoeuvre in this way: When he arrived here on Monday, he was habilitated in aa old straw hat, cow-hide boots, blue blouse, which had been thrown away by a private in MONTGOMERY'S Regiment, some sort of apology for pantaloons, and a butternut brown woolen shirt, with beard, hair, face, &c., to correspond; and, thus decorated, every one, by instinct, could detect the hero of Black Jack and Hickory Point. Yesterday morning, at 9 o'clock, I visited his tent, and found an immense crowd wandering about the neighborhood, each inquiring of the other if he had seen or knew the whereabouts of "Ginerl LANE." Upon approaching his tent, I found therein a solitary gentleman seated upon an old split-bottomed chair, one leg thrown across the other, intently engaged in caressing, with thumb and finger of right hand, a beard, if not remarkably luxurious, yet splendidly variegated in color. Upon a careful reconnoissance I discovered this figure to be the very specimen of mortality which the adjacent crowd wore so anxious to see. He had donned the new rig made expressly for him in Boston -- blue coat and pants, buff vest, black chapeau, and feather as long as a war leader in the Times, and such boots as would make Gen. LOSEE, or any other fast horseman, stick his eyes out far enough for SAM [???] Thanksgiving turkey, (which he is going to buy, and not eat along) to roost upon. In this make up he so there as quiet and undisturbed as if he were in a wilderness, seemingly enjoying the discomfiture of the [???] about him, when a man with long whickers, who looked if he had traveled once with a [???] and asked if Gen. LANE were in. "No," was the [???] of the hero, with the least bit of a [???] in the [???] of his left eye -- (I sat [???] of him) -- and the [???] evaporated [???]. " Sien" is war.

abstract: It may interest a good many persons besides the Italians resident here, to know that the Consul-General of the Kingdom of Italy in this City, receives subscriptions in aid of the movement to erect a monument to the memory of Count CAVOUR. His own countrymen, very naturally, take the lead in thus honoring one who was so conspicuous in re-creating their country: -- but there is no free country in the world whose inhabitants can fail to sympathize with whatever seeks to perpetuate the memory of so illustrious and so gifted a statesman. The Consul's office is at No. 40 Beaver-street.

abstract: The Ninth Anniversary of "S, Ann's Church for Deaf Mutes and others willing to promote their welfare" was celebrated on Sunday, the 6th inst. A discourse was preached by the Hector, the Rev. THOMAS GALLAUDET, setting forth the following statistics: Families 86, (15 whose heads are deaf mutes;) individuals about 700, (150 deaf mutes;) baptisms, adults 23. (2 deaf mutes;) infants 27, (1 of deaf mutes;) total, 50. Confirmed 57, (6 deaf mutes;) marriages 14 (2 of deaf mutes:) 26 burial, (1 deaf mute, and 2 children of deaf mutes.) The income of S. Ann's Church for the year was, offerings $5,299 26; donations from friends mostly outside of the parish, $5.156 03; from Trinity Church, $300; other sources, $31 35; total, $10.786 64. Could this church at once receive about $4.000 it would be in a self-sustaining position. The general scope of the sermon, with its affecting incidents, showed that much had been accomplished in the way of improving the condition of deaf mutes in temporal as well as spiritual matters, and that this parish should be sustained in its interesting mission by the church at large.

abstract: The Southern newspapers just now confine editorial discussion to the difficult point  where shall the rebel army pass the Winter? One recommends Missouri, another Kentucky  and Kanawha, another Maryland, while the Richmond journals, vicing with each other ...
lead_paragraph: The Southern newspapers just now confine editorial discussion to the difficult point where shall the rebel army pass the Winter? One recommends Missouri, another Kentucky and Kanawha, another Maryland, while the Richmond journals, vicing with each other through long habit in unreason and audacity, select Ohio and Pennsylvania as the more eligible seats. In all this there is nothing either positive, or practical, or practicable. What is positive and to the purpose is, that they fully recognize the impracticability of the army remaining where it is; and also the impossibility of retiring to the Southern States, followed into the heart of the slave-inhabited and cotton-growing region by the National forces. For, it is never to be forgotton that the mass of the Southern people are kept to the work only by the perpetuation and invention of delusions. One engagement made by their leaders through the Press no sooner fails than another takes its place, to be replaced in turn by others equally dazzling. Last Spring the rebels were led to expect certain victory at every step of their northward advance. Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, New-York, Boston, were to be but milestones in a journey of a Summer's day; and Winter, when it came, was to find them sheltered and quite comfortable in Fifth-avenue mansions, or in the shadow of Bunker Hill. To have suggested a possibility that frost might overtake their armies just where Spring left them, in the shelter of their tents, imperfectly clothed, and at a distance from supplies of food and fuel, would quite certainly have brought upon the doubter fatal suspicions of his fidelity to the cause of treason. This illusion has been dispelled, and another succeeds it. It is manifestly out of the question to maintain the army all Winter at Manassas. It will never do to present too suddenly the spectacle of retreat to a people already much suffering, much deceived, and much complaining. To promise the recovery of the doubtful Border States, or to tell confidently of Winter quarters in Pennsylvania or Ohio, is an intermediate deception, which shall prepare the way for the mortifying disappointment that must very shortly visit the entire Southern population. What could not be done in the Spring, when the North was at every disadvantage, and the South in the possession of numbers and means it can never in the most favorable circumstances repeat certainly cannot be hoped for in the Autumn, when all the conditions of the contest incline to the side of the loyal States. Aggressions they dared not attempt then, in the presence of an inferior force imperfectly armed and provided, they will not attempt now against armies of superior strength, amply armed with all the inventions of modern scientific warfare, and supplied from the abounding granaries of a country ready to feed the world. Against such resources it is impossible to maintain a show of resistance. The rebel Generals have not ventured to tell the people of Richmond that the abandonment of Virginia is a foregone conclusion; that it remains with the National leaders to fix the time when the rebels shall evacuate the Commonwealth; but they are ascertainly aware that the fact is so as that they possess the most elementary knowledge of the art of war.

abstract: There are few public characters that can stand the test of Time. At the application of this touchstone reputations shrivel, and giants dwindle down into dwarfs. The world daily demands something new of its idols. A sustained flight will not at all satisfy the popular craving. Higher altitudes must be reached, or condemnation swiftly follows the voice ...
lead_paragraph: There are few public characters that can stand the test of Time. At the application of this touchstone reputations shrivel, and giants dwindle down into dwarfs. The world daily demands something new of its idols. A sustained flight will not at all satisfy the popular craving. Higher altitudes must be reached, or condemnation swiftly follows the voice of praise. Among the foolish many there are a wise few who fully comprehend this peculiarity of an impulsive public. These few wisely husband their resources; they "let themselves out" by degrees, and always contrive to keep an extra force in reserve to meet this inevitable demand. Several eminent wits have kept their choicest bon mots for their death-beds. Congressmen not infrequently adopt this rule, and, after sputtering through a session like imperfect candles, go out in ablaze of glory. HERRMANN understands this true secret of successfully. His pachydactylous rival, the hippopotamus, didn't, and here HERRMANN has proved himself the greater of the two. The hippopotamus had the advantage in point of size -- HERRMANN has in sagacity. The former opened his mouth unguardedly and unreservedly, showing all his wonders at once. The consequence was that we soon tired of him, and answered his benevolent and smiling attempts to please by responsive yawns. Had he at first but opened his mouth by inches, he could have given the public an ell when they demanded it. He might have managed his countenance on the principle of a climax, rising by degrees to finish by castanetting the outer surfaces of his jaws together behind his tufted tail, to the confusion of his Nubian keeper. Or he might have doubled his aesophagus up in compartments, and only exhibited quarter sections at a time. But all this he didn't do, and hence his failure, hence these tears.

abstract: Recruiting for the regular army continues very quiet, not only in New-York, buy also at all the outstations, with the exception of Buffalo, which is doing nearly as much business as Boston, Philadelphia and New-York put together.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the regular army continues very quiet, not only in New-York, buy also at all the outstations, with the exception of Buffalo, which is doing nearly as much business as Boston, Philadelphia and New-York put together. The old offices here booked only ten men last week; Buffalo sent in twelve; Rochester, Boston and Philadelphia, none. The four new offices at Albany, Reading, Penn., Wilmington, Del., and Bridgeport, Conn., which were opened about the middle of September, have not yet succeeded in enlisting a single man.

abstract: Hon. HENRN MAY, of Baltimore, we are pleased to learn, has been set at liberty. When arrested and inclosed in Fort Lafayette, the sentence of Mr. MAY was approved by the public, upon the supposition either that he was the forerunner of other disloyal Congressmen, like ...
lead_paragraph: Hon. HENRN MAY, of Baltimore, we are pleased to learn, has been set at liberty. When arrested and inclosed in Fort Lafayette, the sentence of Mr. MAY was approved by the public, upon the supposition either that he was the forerunner of other disloyal Congressmen, like VALLANDIGHAM and WOOD, who would at once be sent to share his seclusion, or that his intrigues at Richmond demanded this exemplary treatment of conduct which made his case so much worse than theirs. Events have proved both these suppositions incorrect. Mr. MAY's seditious colleagues in Congress have been left undisturbed, and the disclosures recently made by Judge LOGAN show that the journey to Richmond had the approbation of the Administration; and consequently whatever treason characterized or prompted that mission, was participated in by those who would be exceedingly reluctant to condemn themselves to the hospitalities of Col. BURKE. In these circumstances, the imprisonment of the treasonable Congressman was open to a palpable charge of injustice and partiality, which nothing but his release could palliate.

abstract: HUGHES. The Herald reiterates feebly, though it makes no attempt to justify, its shameless signature of the name of Archbishop HUGHES to an editorial article in reply to Dr. BROWNSON on the Rebellion in a late number of the Metropolitan ...
lead_paragraph: HUGHES. -- The Herald reiterates feebly, though it makes no attempt to justify, its shameless signature of the name of Archbishop HUGHES to an editorial article in reply to Dr. BROWNSON on the Rebellion in a late number of the Metropolitan Record. It backs down a little from a similar fraud in the case of Prince NAPOLEON, and now only claims that the letters to which it originally affixed his name were written "under his inspiration" -- which is probably just about as true as the more adventurous statement which it made at first. In the Archbishop's case, however, it sticks to its text, and assumes that he wrote the article. Perhaps he did, -- but the public has not the slightest reason to think so, and a great many reasons for regarding the Herald's imputation of its authorship to him as only one of its ordinary devices for attracting public attention, and creating a "sensation."

abstract: In spite of the neutral declaration of Great Britain, we have evidence of the strongest kind that the Government of that country, whatever its professions may be, is influenced, in its America policy, by an unquestionable partiality. Not to speak of the bias of the ...
lead_paragraph: In spite of the neutral declaration of Great Britain, we have evidence of the strongest kind that the Government of that country, whatever its professions may be, is influenced, in its America policy, by an unquestionable partiality. Not to speak of the bias of the London Press, and notoriously of those journals supposed to receive their inspiration from official sources, we wait in vain for a rebuke to those West Indian authorities who permitted a rebel privateer to take in coal, provisions, and even munitions of war, at Port of Spain, in the Island of Trinidad. No satisfactory explanation has been yet given of the large additions to the army in Canada; and assured, as we must be, that the sentiment of the governing classes in England is hostile to a reconstruction of the Union, we may well doubt, without being over suspicious, the honesty of the excuses advanced for the military movements in the adjacent Province. We have been so utterly deceived in regard to the reputed aversion of the British Government and people to Slavery and slave institutions, that we may be pardoned, for the future, if we mistrust their professions and doubt their most solemn assurances.

abstract: The official accounts of the trade and navigation of the United Kingdom for the months ending Aug. 31, which were issued by the Board of Trade on the 28th ult., and an extract furnished by our London correspondent, show an increase ...
lead_paragraph: The official accounts of the trade and navigation of the United Kingdom for the months ending Aug. 31, which were issued by the Board of Trade on the 28th ult., and an extract furnished by our London correspondent, show an increase from 117 to 171 vessels, and from 98,363 to 112,981 tons of shipping entered at British ports from the United States during that month, as compared with the corresponding period of last year; whilst the departures for American ports decreased from 185 to 109, and the tonnage from 173,238 to 105,743 tons. Taking the eight months ended on the same day of the two years, the difference is much less, showing that the irregularity of trade has been increasing as the year has rolled on. The shipping arrived at British ports from the United States amounted, during the larger period, to 1,592,459 tons, against, 1,217,951 tons in the first eight months of last year; whilst the shipping cleared for American ports was only 918,617 tons, against 1,033,951 tons. The details of the trade accounts correspond with those of the shipping Britain imported, during these eight months, 1,790,212 qrs. of wheat, and 3,678,484 cwts. of flour, the produce of the United States, against 387,367 qrs. of wheat, and 887,479 cwts. of flour in the corresponding period of last year. The only other article, the origin of which is distinguished in the Board of Trade tables, is cotton, of which there was imported into England from the United States, during the eight months, 7,162,560 cwts., against 8,556,291 cwts. in the corresponding period of 1860. There was an equal falling off in the imports from Brazil and Egypt, but the receipts from India show a considerable increase. The August account shows an increase from all parts except the United States, the supply from which diminished from 669,274 cwts. to 448,061 cwts., as compared with last year. The imports of Indian cotton, on the contrary, were double the average monthly receipts of the year, and nearly three times as much as was imported in the corresponding months of 1860. The enhanced value of the article is shown by the fact that, though the imports of American cotton declined in quantity, the value is computed at ¤23,989,450 for the eight months, against ¤23,579,504 last year.

abstract: ARREST OF NOTED THIEVES. Officers KING, of the Tenth Precinct, and EDSALL, of the Ninth, yesterday arrested Mary Palmer alias Johnson, Charles Rothchilds and Alexander Schietz, on suspicion of ...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF NOTED THIEVES.--Officers KING, of the Tenth Precinct, and EDSALL, of the Ninth, yesterday arrested Mary Palmer alias Johnson, Charles Rothchilds and Alexander Schietz, on suspicion of being concerned in some recent heavy robberies in this City. The officers have been watching this trio for some time past, and they have been noticed prowling around the Broadway stores with the evident intention of purloining goods when opportunity offered. The female prisoner is said to be one of the most expert thieves in the country. She was released from State Prison only a few weeks since, having been sentenced there for a period of five years upon conviction of grand larceny in stealing silks from STEWART's, in Broadway. Soon after entering the prison she succeeded in convincing the agent of the Prison Association, Mr. BEALE, that she was innocent, and by his advice and that of other respectable gentlemen Gov. MORGAN granted her a pardon. Since her discharge she has been constantly with her old companions, and engaged in her old practices. Upon searching her rooms yesterday, a large quantity of silks, muslins, cigars and other goods were found, believed to have been stolen. The articles recovered are at the Tenth Precinct Station-house, where they may be seen by parties interested. Justice CONNOLLY committed them all to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury. An attempt was made to bribe the officers and let the accused go free, but without success.

abstract: Scholarship used to be a name for something humane and noble. He was citizen of a State larger than the confines of any one people, ...
lead_paragraph: Scholarship used to be a name for something humane and noble. It was supposed that a man engaged in "the study of the true, the beautiful, and the good," was above the narrow prejudices of race and the bitter hostilities of national rivalry. He was citizen of a State larger than the confines of any one people, and to whose immunities virtue and knowledge were the only conditions. While nation clashed against nation, and tribe met tribe in bloody collision, through all ages the scholars have preserved the commune vinculum, and have joined hands in a humane and cosmopolitan union. Letters have softened the hatred and quenched the wrath of rival communities, and inspired the gentle spirit of humanity and civilization to peoples, yet half barbarous, in their mutual envies and jealousies. Scholars have usually felt the responsibility of their position; that, in some respects, they were to be the leaders of human progress, and were to show a broad sympathy with man and a kindly feeling, which should rise far above the passions of the time. Even when fired with patriotism, they have related the brave achievements of their countrymen, in some struggle with foreign injustice or oppression, in words which posterity should record: they have felt it to be one of the bounden courtesies of their class to chronicle fairly the brave deeds of the enemy and to do manly justice to him.

abstract: A movement of the rebels threatening our lines across the Potomac, was noted in yesterday's TIMES. They advanced a large force on Saturday in the direction of Prospect Hill, driving in the National pickets to that point. The Division of Gen. McCALL, stationed at Langley, was immediately formed in line of ...
lead_paragraph: A movement of the rebels threatening our lines across the Potomac, was noted in yesterday's TIMES. They advanced a large force on Saturday in the direction of Prospect Hill, driving in the National pickets to that point. The Division of Gen. McCALL, stationed at Langley, was immediately formed in line of battle and got in readiness to advance, supported by cavalry and artillery, and the Divisions of Gens. SMITH, PORTER and MCDOWELL were also rapidly prepared for any emergency. The rebels attempted nothing further, and finally retired. Yesterday morning they again appeared in some force on Prospect Hill, which is near Great Falls, but again retired without doing more than make observations. It is impossible at present to tell the meaning of these demonstrations, but they may have been intended to attract attention from some more important movement elsewhere.

abstract: Few books of the season have achieved so complete a success as the Free Labor in the West Indies, of W.G. SEWELL, published by SAMPSON, Low, Son  Co., of London, simultaneously with its publication in this country by the HARPERS. The Journals and Literary Reviews on the other side ...
lead_paragraph: --Few books of the season have achieved so complete a success as the Free Labor in the West Indies, of W.G. SEWELL, published by SAMPSON, Low, Son Co., of London, simultaneously with its publication in this country by the HARPERS. The Journals and Literary Reviews on the otherside the water accord it the same hearty recognition and cordial appreciation that it obtained on this. One of the leading foreign authorities pronounces it, unhesitatingly and unqualifiedly, "the best discussion of the emancipation question extant," claiming for the author, in an eminent degree, "candor of investigation and impartiality of judgment." Our readers will remember that the series of letters which constitute the book originally appeared in the columns of this paper.

abstract: A copy of the Norfolk Day Book, of a late date contains dispatches from New-Orleans giving an account of a surprise and attack made on Col. BILLY WILSON'S Zouaves, at Santa Rosa Island, on the 8th inst. Detachments from several Mississippi, Louisiana ...
lead_paragraph: A copy of the Norfolk Day Book, of a late date contains dispatches from New-Orleans giving an account of a surprise and attack made on Col. BILLY WILSON'S Zouaves, at Santa Rosa Island, on the 8th inst. Detachments from several Mississippi, Louisiana and Alabama regiments, made a landing in the night and drove in WILSON's pickets, and shortly afterwards a fierce fight began, The Zouaves of Col. WILSON are credited with having fought with great bravery, and the rebels admit a loss of forty killed and about double that number wounded. The rebels claim to have spiked the guns of the Zouaves and destroyed all their camp equipage. They also claim to have committed great slaughter among the Zouaves, but give no number of the killed. The rebels also say they carried off a number of prisoners.

abstract: The great naval expedition that has been in the course of preparation at this port for some weeks begins to assume colossal proportions. The steamers Cahawba and Coatzacoalcos sailed on Saturday evening, carrying the Rhode Island Regiment lately encamped at Fort Hamilton, besides a force of experienced surfmen, with their boats.
lead_paragraph: The great naval expedition that has been in the course of preparation at this port for some weeks begins to assume colossal proportions. The steamers Cahawba and Coatzacoalcos sailed on Saturday evening, carrying the Rhode Island Regiment lately encamped at Fort Hamilton, besides a force of experienced surfmen, with their boats. Yesterday morning the Star of the South followed, having on board Col. SERRELL's Engineer Regiment, previously announced as having gone to Washington. This regiment numbers 500 men, all of whom are practical engineers or mechanics.

abstract: -It may interest a good many persons besides the Italians resident here, to know that the Consul-General of the Kingdom of Italy in this City, receives subscriptions in aid of the movement to erect a monument to the memory of Count CAVOUR. His own countrymen, very naturally, take the lead in thus honoring one who was so conspicuous in re-creating their country: -- but there is no free country in the world whose inhabitants can fail to sympathize with whatever seeks to perpetuate the memory of so illustrious and so gifted a statesman. The Consul's office is at No. 40 Beaver-street.

abstract: Hard times are in store for the laboring people of England. All the assurances of her orators and journalists as to the attainability of an adequate supply of cotton, cannot allay the apprehensions of her manufacturers. In vain the capacity of India and Egypt is dwelt ...
lead_paragraph: Hard times are in store for the laboring people of England. All the assurances of her orators and journalists as to the attainability of an adequate supply of cotton, cannot allay the apprehensions of her manufacturers. In vain the capacity of India and Egypt is dwelt on; in vain associations are formed to stimulate the production of the precious staple; in vain the Government promises to facilitate its importation by every means in its power; despite of all, the panic spreads, and already its effects are becoming visible. The malady first showed itself in Manchester, the capital of cottondom. There, a few weeks since, a circular from one of the leading firms gave notice to the people that "short-time" was probable and economy necessary. This was only a politic mode of communicating unwelcome intelligence to the masses, and was merely a prelude to the still more disheartening notices that subsequently appeared, announcing the actual adoption of "short-time" by such and such mill-owners. From Manchester the epidemic has extended to Bolton, Rochdale and Blackburn. In Bolton one very large firm, having six mills, and which employed, last Summer, 787 hands, has closed altogether, and warned its discharged operatives to seek work elsewhere, as there was no likelihood of business being resumed. In Rochdale eight firms are working only four days a week, and one has stopped in toto. While in Blackburn and its vicinity, no less than twelve firms, some of them owning several mills, are now working only four days weekly, and consider even four days too many, in the present state of trade. In a word, there are thousands of people in England already either wholly or partially out of employment, in consequence of the cotton panic, and tens of thousands more will be in the same deplorable situation, from the same cause, before the Winter sets in. Yet, strange to say, while such is the condition of the manufacturing districts, cargoes of cotton are shipped from Liverpool to America -- a phenomenon which can only be paralleled by the incessant exportation of provisions from Ireland throughout the period of the famine!

abstract: In another place  We are enabled to give a statement of the taxable property of the State, as just determined by the Board of Equalization. The table teaches a perplexing lesson to those who seek curiously in all direction for some symptom of weakness and exhaustion resulting ...
lead_paragraph: --In another place We are enabled to give a statement of the taxable property of the State, as just determined by the Board of Equalization. The table teaches a perplexing lesson to those who seek curiously in all direction for some symptom of weakness and exhaustion resulting from the great struggle we are engaged in. It will be seen that, with all the uncertainty of the future added to the actual certainty of heavy burdens to be borne, and losses sustained in prosecuting so costly a contest, the Board has advanced the aggregate valuation from $1,419,297,560, the figure for the last year of peace, to $1,441,767,430 in the present year of war -- an augmentation of very nearly $22,500,000. The City of New-York gains by a very much larger ratio -- the valuation in 1860 being $550,078,788, and in 1861 rising to $571,078,798 -- a gain of $21,000,000. In fact, the additional valuation may be said to fall bodily upon the City -- a circumstance which proves, if nothing else, what unlimited confidence is reposed in the power of our people, even at this moment of supreme effort and endurance, to accept the burdens of necessary taxation. The fact may take its place among several other problems which are distracting European statesmanship.

abstract: Although the loyal public is not permitted to know upon what part of the Southern coast the iminense naval expedition now about sailing is to be precipitated, we think we do not mistake in saying that it is the almost universal wish of the people that Charleston, South ...
lead_paragraph: Although the loyal public is not permitted to know upon what part of the Southern coast the iminense naval expedition now about sailing is to be precipitated, we think we do not mistake in saying that it is the almost universal wish of the people that Charleston, South Carolina, if it receive not the present, may not long await a similar blow. If the Government would arouse the liveliest sympathy of Unionists, in the South as well as in the North, let it be seen that a clear and distinct memory is kept of the origin of this war, and a resolute purpose held, however the conflict may otherwise go, and whensoever it may terminate, not to fail administering a fearful rebuke upon that accursed city and State, whose crime it is to have originated the war.

abstract: No new movement, either of the National or the rebel army, is reported from Washington, and there is no explanation of the cause of the appearance of a large rebel force on Saturday and Sunday, threatening our lines above the Chain Bridge, near Prospect Hill. The rebels seem indisposed ...
lead_paragraph: No new movement, either of the National or the rebel army, is reported from Washington, and there is no explanation of the cause of the appearance of a large rebel force on Saturday and Sunday, threatening our lines above the Chain Bridge, near Prospect Hill. The rebels seem indisposed to make a trial of strength on a fair field, although they have been repeatedly invited to it; and there is at present little prospect that a battle of any magnitude will take place for some" time to come, as no advance movement of the National army seems likely to be made immediately. Meantime our outposts on the left of the line have been extended to the mouth of Little Hunting Creek, six miles below Alexandria, and important defensive works are being constructed there, which will complete the line of fortifications on the Virginia side of the Potomac, from that point to the Chain Bridge above. It is considered doubtful whether any considerable rebel force is collected at any point in that vicinity, as scouting parties have penetrated further each day to the South and Southwest of Alexandria, without discovering more than an occasional picket. There was some skirmishing yesterday afternoon along the right our lines, but not much damage was done.

abstract: By law, the Inspectors of Registry in this City are required to hold their first meeting to-day to register the names of persons entitled to vote at the ensuing election. In the Districts where there are less than four hundred voters the inspector will hold but one meeting; where there are more voters they will hold two meetings. On the 29th inst. they will hold a final meeting, for the purpose of perfecting the Registry.
