abstract: Those whohave an interest in the conjugal fate of the Prince of Wales will be pleased to know that the Princess ANNA of Denmark, one of the ladies spoken of as his destined bride, is just 15, very fair, with a most brilliant complexion, and lovely fair hair, clustering in thick curls about her neck and shoulders. Her Royal Highness has been most carefully brought up, and is possessed of a most splendid musical talent, cultivated to its utmost extent by the first masters in Europe. Altogether, she is considered one of the most accomplished princesses in Europe; and her portrait, in white muslin, with blue ribbons, and a single rosebud in her golden hair, long formed one of the greatest attractions of GIROUX's exhibitions at the Boulevards. The Princess of Hesse Darmstadt is not so well known, but is described as being fair and comely, with chestnut hair, and is not only the beauty of the family, but is remarkable for great sweetness and amiability of disposition, and is also slightly "blue." The Grand Ducal Palace, at which the Princess ALICE is to reside, bears the reputation of "a little paradise on earth," because of its undisturbed harmony. -- Ex-change.

abstract: The schooner Howard, Capt. CLARK, arrived here yesterday morning, from Key West, having left that port on the 30th ult. The Howard on the 15th ult. was run into by the United States frigate Potomac, and badly damaged. She put back for repairs. The United States steamer Richmond was off Fort Jefferson, to sail in a few hours. All well. The Richmond had been on a coral reef for thirty hours, but was got off after lightening. She received no damage. She had a pilot on board at the time.
lead_paragraph: The schooner Howard, Capt. CLARK, arrived here yesterday morning, from Key West, having left that port on the 30th ult. abstract: According to the latest reports from Richmond, the rebel population of that enterprising capital are earnestly discussing the subject of Winter quarters for the Confederate army.
lead_paragraph: Free speech is allowed on this matter, and accordingly we find the greatest diversity of opinion prevailing. A part of the rebel disputants claim that Baltimore, Philadelphia and New-York possess advantages superior to all other places for quartering BEAUREGARD'S army during the Winter. And there is much to sustain this view of the case. There are in the cities named, great numbers of well-constructed, warm and comfortable houses, both of brick and stone. And there is likewise a most ample supply of coal, bituminous and anthracite, well fitted for grates, stoves and ranges, whereby bodily comfort can be most fully secured, throughout the coldest term that "E. M." might have to chronicle. And there are, also, inexhaustible supplies of meat, flour and vegetables, sugar, salt and coffee, and whatever else rebel stomachs might crave, while vindicating secession and lording it over the Yankees. And to crown all, there are boots and shoes, hats, caps, blankets, and all manner of clothing, which Southern rebels never despise, however much they may despise the men who make them.
headline: {'main': 'Winter Quarters for the Rebels.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Winter Quarters for the Rebels.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There are some curious facts about the comparative destructiveness of round and rifle shot, and of large and small calibres, that seem to indorse the American system, and limit the uses of rifled cannon.
lead_paragraph: There are some curious facts about the comparative destructiveness of round and rifle shot, and of large and small calibres, that seem to indorse the American system, and limit the uses of rifled cannon. That long range and great accuracy depend on spinning the projectile upon its own axis, is certainly proved. Hence the value of the rifle shell in the field, and on shipboard, and in fortifications, when directed against bodies of men; but the long range and precision of shot, and the whirling contents and fragments of shells never so accurately planted, are of limited destructiveness if directed against objects that they can neither smash nor tear into pieces -- the iron-sheathed sides of ships.

abstract: Our neighbors of the Express affect a great deal of alarm lest the rebels should receive aid and comfort from our announcement of the departure of the naval expedition for the Southern coast. It thinks they will be perfectly prepared to receive it. This is a good joke. Perhaps the Express will tell us where they will make their preparations. Our neighbor may not be aware that the Southern coast is a somewhat extended affair, and that the rebels must go else where than to the New-York journals to learn whether this expedition is to land at Beaufort Charleston, Savannah, Mobile, New-Orleans or Galveston If they choose to send a [???] army to all these points, very well; they will thereby very considerably Facilitate Gen. Mr. CLELLAN's march to [???] by way of [???], or then abouts. [???] confine their efforts to any one if the [???],they will be very likely [???]. The Government has not the slightest objection to letting the rebels know that they will soon be called upon "at home." The Express can safely calm its fears. Our "disclosures" of what everybody in town has known are not likely to do anybody any harm.

abstract: We see it announced that no more troops will be drawn to Washington from the Western States, and it is not unlikely that some portion of those now there may ere long be spared for effective service elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: We see it announced that no more troops will be drawn to Washington from the Western States, and it is not unlikely that some portion of those now there may ere long be spared for effective service elsewhere. We are very glad of this; in the first place, because it will appease the rising uneasiness of the West at the apparently inordinate attention bestowed upon the Capital, and next, because it confirms the belief that the Commanding General is nearly ready for an effective movement in advance.

abstract: The delegates from the various Union organizations, met at the Everett House last evening, for the purpose of conference, and if possible, an agreement upon single ticket for the coming election. The organizations represented were the Fifth-avenue, St. Nicholas, Tax-payers, Marshal Union, and German Workingmen's Consolidated Union League. The delegates from the Austin Bradford, Cooper Institute, Syracuse Union Party wore refused admittance. The Conference, after due deliberation, decided by resolution to go into a secret informal ballot for candidates before discussing their merits. The result was the indorsement of THOMAS W. CLERKE for the Supreme Court, MURRAY HOFFMAN and L.B. WOODRUFF for the Superior Court, JOHN R. BRADY for the Common Pleas, and HIRAM KETCHUM for the Marine Court. These indorsements were made unanimously, and the Convention adjourned to Monday evening next.

These indorsements were made unanimously, and the Convention adjourned to Monday evening next.

abstract: An agricultural dinner inEngland is a very curious assemblage. The member for the county is compelled to attend, to drink a great deal of bad Port wine, manufactured perhaps in the county, and to talk an equal quantity of nonsense, He probably has been absent from the House of Commons all the session, has answered few letters from his constitutents, and been negligent in the discharge of his Parliamentary duties. The Fall arrives, the partridges await his advent, he returns to his ancestral hall, and a sensation must be made at a county dinner, instead of at the hustings. Sir EDWARD LYTTON BULWER LYTTON, the member from the County of Hertford finds himself in this position, and before this congregated agricultural intellect of tenant-farmers and top-booted squires, determines upon making an oration. An eminent English counsel was once asked where he had been -- for he had kept the Court of Queen's Bench waiting to hear his argument for nearly half an hour; his answer was: "That he had been drinking as much porter as he could swallow to reduce his intellect to the level of the tribunal he was about to address." So it must have been with Sir EDWARD BULWER LYTTON, or the man who had rilled the office of Colonial Secretary could never have discoursed as he did before the Hertfordshire yeomanry. Five-sixths of his auditory most probably were ignorant of the geographical position of America, and knew as much of our political institutions as they did of Patagonia. Another great advantage he also possessed -- he had it all his own way, as the intelligent animal that lives on thistles observed, when he danced a minuet among the chickens -- otherwise he could not have spoken as he did. To have stated that America must fall to pieces from its own vastness -- that it would be better for her and for her power and influence amongst the nations of the world to be subdivided into several small republics, is so extraordinary and so anomalous that we must confess our surprise at such ignorance, both of ancient and modern history. He tells the farmers that he venerates our republic and our free institutions, and that he loves us so much that he would deal with us as Juliet wished to do with her beloved Romeo -- he would "cut us into little stars," to increase our dignity and our grandeur.

abstract: A lecture will be delivered this evening at the Cooper Union, by Mr. P. C. KENDALL, on an available substitute for the plant from which the Slave Statesderive their cotton. Mr. KENDALL, whose acquaintance with the cotton-growing, territory of the Gulf States, and long residence in South Africa and South America, qualify him to speak understandingly upon his topic, has found in a tree which grows spontaneously and perennially in the higher and cooler regions of Chili and Peru, an abundant producer of the fibre, the want of which threatens England with revolution. This tree, Mr. KENDALL, after careful observation, finds suited to any climate where Indian corn can be raised. He has placed a number of the trees upon his farm in Maryland, where they give satisfactory promise. Mr. KENDALL, after counseling with Gov. SPRAQUE and other New-England gentlemen, largely engaged in the consumption of cotton, has decided to lay the valuable information he possesses in regard to the subject, before the public, with sole reference to public utility. If he contributes in any degree toward rendering the North independent of the Southern cotton despotism, he will be sufficiently rewarded. The lecture this evening is suggested and promoted by some of our most highly respected citizens. It will doubtless have full attendance.

abstract: The valiant ROGER A. PRYOR is a candidate for Congress, and the Enquirer says that " to recount the services of Col. PRYOR, to the cause in which is embarked all that is dear to the Southern heart, may ...
lead_paragraph: The valiant ROGER A. PRYOR is a candidate for Congress, and the Enquirer says that " to recount the services of Col. PRYOR, to the cause in which is embarked all that is dear to the Southern heart, may seem to be unnecessary. Wherever spoken, his name is the synonym of Southern chivalry, generosity, and devotion. On the accession of LINCOLN, his eloquent voice was everywhere heard proclaiming resistance to the death; and to add the force of example to the effect of his burning counsels, he hastened at the first blast of the trumpet to lead the van from Virginia, in the struggle for Southern independence. Before the walls of Sumter he deliberately put his neck in the halter,' while his native State was yet weighing the cost of resistance with the price of submission." Of his military career, the writer does not speak so confidently, but thinks he has been of great service. No allusion is made to his tear of bowie knives, nor to the white feather he exhibited, when he "put his neck in the halter" that the chivalric POTTER prepared for him.

abstract: John Bull is no more prone than the rest of the world to confess himself in the wrong. Indeed, if common report does not mistake, his horror of the stool of repentance passes ordinary bounds. Of late, however, and especially since the more appreciative spirit ...
lead_paragraph: John Bull is no more prone than the rest of the world to confess himself in the wrong. Indeed, if common report does not mistake, his horror of the stool of repentance passes ordinary bounds. Of late, however, and especially since the more appreciative spirit manifested by Russia, he has been tormented by an uneasy suspicion that there are some points in his late relations to us which it were well to make a clean breast of. Indeed, it must be confessed that, if the policy of England towards this country had been controlled during the last few months by some subtle enemy, it could scarcely have been more injurious to her true interests. On this point, the ablest British statesmen seem to be gradually making their way to the conviction which long ago was patent to the rest of the world. The decline in the funds, the rumored dissensions in the Cabinet, the altered tone of the leaders of parties, the delay of the troops ordered to Canada, the modification of the Mexican programme, the official avoidance of giving umbrage to our Government, and the late assurances that the rebel States shall receive no immediate countenance or sanction, combine with other circumstances, to indicate a new phase of public opinion; while in spite of the absurd rhodomontades of the London Times, Economist and Saturday Review, it cannot be doubted that the apprehensions of a cotton famine, and the appalling terrors it would let loose on one-sixth of the population of England, and through them on the whole Kingdom, render it not improbable that, except a more acceptable policy be adopted, the Palmerston Cabinet may be ere long swept away by the swelling tide of popular feeling relative to American affairs. For it is beginning to be better understood by the British people, whatever their rulers may have wished or believed, that cotton can be had. if at all, only through the good office of our National Government; and time it is the interest off all who need cotton to give the whole moral force of their sanction and support to the suppression of rebellion and the corroboration of the Union.

abstract: Lieut. J.D. WICKHAM, of the Ninth Regiment N.Y.S.M., leaves this afternoon for the seat of war, with one hundred and twenty-eight recruits for the regiment, which is now at Darnelsville, in Gen. BANKS' division. This entire number has been recruited by Lieut. W. in the short space of two weeks, and, although so recently enlisted,they have already attained a most creditable degree of proficiency in drill and marching. Every man is completely uniformed and equipped, save the arms, which will be delivered to them at Washington. The departure of Lieut. W. for the regiment affords an opportunity which will be embraced, of transmitting to the regiment the elegant stand of colors presented by the City, and which have been lying many weeks in the Governor's room in the City Mall. Lieut. WICKHAM will, therefore, have the pleasure of transferring to his regiment the colors, which will be escorted by his recruits. They will form at 2 P.M., at the armory, on the corner of Thirteenth-street and University-place, and march thence to the Park, where the colors wilt be placed in his charge by a deputation from the Common Council.

abstract: THE OBSEQUIES OF TERENCE BELLEW McMANUS.  The ceremonies attendant on the removal, from Calvary Cemetery, of the remains of the deceased frish patriot, T.B. McMANUS, will take place on Friday next. A Committee has been appointed to take ...
lead_paragraph: THE OBSEQUIES OF TERENCE BELLEW MCMANUS. -- The ceremonies attendant on the removal, from Calvary Cemetery, of the remains of the deceased frish patriot, T.B. McMANUS, will take place on Friday next. A Committee has been appointed to take charge of the relics and accompany them to Ireland. They will be conveyed to the land of his birth and his love in the next steamer, and will be escorted to the point of their departure by the various Irish societies, civic and military, of this and the adjoining cities. Archbishop [???] has expressed his warmest good wishes for the [???] successor of the expedition, and would readily participate in the solemnities, but that he is unable to take part in any political display, and [???] regrets in the more, as the invitation to do so was conveyed [???] a Committee composed of Col. [???] ( of the Irish American,) and Capt. [???]. The Executive Committee [???] (Tuesday) at [???], at No. 6 [???], to [???] their arrangements. The [???] of the [???] who have been [???] the [???] to the old country, are [???] J. [???], Esq.

abstract: The Secretary of War has returned from his visit to Gen. FREMONT'S headquarters, and will now be able to act intelligently upon the various matters urged against the General's management of military affairs in that Department.
lead_paragraph: -- The Secretary of War has returned from his visit to Gen. FREMONT'S headquarters, and will now be able to act intelligently upon the various matters urged against the General's management of military affairs in that Department. So far as appears, no steps have been taken toward interfering in any way with Gen. FREMONT's command, nor is there any authentic intimation that a Court-martial will be ordered to investigate the allegations of Col. BLAIR against him. Indeed, we think it altogether likely that the proceedings will be dropped in the case of both these officers, and that whatever action the Administration may resolve upon will be taken without regard to the complaints of either against the other.

abstract: John B. Dingeldein vs. The Third-avenue Railroad Company. In June, 1853, a partnership existed which owned and operated the Third-avenue Railroad. The Corporation of the City of New-York determining to build two sewers in places that might ...
lead_paragraph: John B. Dingeldein vs. The Third-avenue Railroad Company. -- In June, 1853, a partnership existed which owned and operated the Third-avenue Railroad. The Corporation of the City of New-York determining to build two sewers in places that might interfere with the track of the railroad, the owners of the road deemed it advisable, as was alleged, to get within their control the construction of the sewers, so as to guard against any interruption to the use of the road, and against having black mail levied upon them by the contractor.

abstract: Our Washington dispatches this morning give interesting details of various skirmishes which have taken place across the Potomac, in some of which the exchange of shots has been quite sharp, though without damage on our side.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington dispatches this morning give interesting details of various skirmishes which have taken place across the Potomac, in some of which the exchange of shots has been quite sharp, though without damage on our side. The fighting has all resulted to our advantage. From the Lower Potomac we hear of the erection of new batteries by the rebels, one at the mouth of Quantico Creek, the scene of the late exploit by Lieut. NARRELL. The Pokahontas and the Seminole yesterday exchanged shots with it, but without result.

abstract: The financial question of the war has been solved with an ease which is an agreeable surprise to ourselves. We had overlooked the preparation made for it by the action of the banks in November last, in view of political difficulties then impending. It was a part of the plan of the conspirators to break down the Government by undermining its credit, and to destroy the power of the North by precipitating a financial crisis.

abstract: During the last few days there has been more than ordinary activity at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and every exertion is made to complete the fitting out of the various vessels in the Yard, so as to have them all ready for sea in a very short time.
lead_paragraph: During the last few days there has been more than ordinary activity at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and every exertion is made to complete the fitting out of the various vessels in the Yard, so as to have them all ready for sea in a very short time. We reported two vessels -- the Seneca and the Release -- having gone into commission on Monday. Two more -- the ship Courier and the bark Gem of the Seas -- were put in commission yesterday, the former at 9 o'clock, and the latter at 2 o'clock; and the purchased steamer Isaac Smith will be put in commission to-day. The Courier is a splendid clipper-ship, having made the shortest passage on record from New-York to Rio de Janeiro, viz.: in twenty-one days. Her officers are:

abstract: On the afternoon of Sept. 30, a memorial, numerously signed by merchants and others connected with Mexico, was presented to Mr. LAYARD at the Foreign-office.
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Sept. 30, a memorial, numerously signed by merchants and others connected with Mexico, was presented to Mr. LAYARD at the Foreign-office. It will be recollected that this document, which appeared in the London Times of the 18th ult., appeals to the English Government to interfere by force of arms in the affairs of Mexico, in conjuction, if possible, with the Government of France. The signatures attached to it are those of the principal firms, not only in the City of London, where the memorial originated, but also in Manchester Liverpool, Glasgow, and all the other large towns in the United Kingdom. The memorial was presented by Mr. SAMUEL BROWN, and Mr. LAYARD, without entering into the subject of it, stated that he would take the earliest opportunity of bringing under it the notice of Earl RUSSEL.

abstract: This is the dayfor new projects concerning cotton. The Southern rebellion has opened the eyes of the whole world to the inconvenience and danger of being dependent upon a single section for the supply of one of the most indispensable articles of consumption. England is straining every nerve to find new fields for the production of cotton; and thus to make herself independent of the Southern States. Meantime, we have a new and rather startling theory broached by Mr. KENDALL, who has had a good deal of practical experience in raising cotton. In a lecture delivered last evening, of which a report will be found in another column, he maintains that cotton may be raised with the utmost facility and with great profit, in nearly every part of the Northern States. It is not the ordinary cotton plant of the South, -- but the cotton tree of Peru of which he speaks, -- but he presents many considerations to show that it may be made, to a very great extent, a substitute for the cotton raised in the Southern States. The subject deserves and will doubtless receive the attention of capitalists and others interested in it.

abstract: One of the most picturesque stories of brigandage that the modern Press has produced is M. EDMOND ABOUT'S Roi des Montagnes. Written with great felicity of style sad admirable knowledge of effect, it is not astonishing that it has found its way to the stage.
lead_paragraph: One of the most picturesque stories of brigandage that the modern Press has produced is M. EDMOND ABOUT'S Roi des Montagnes. Written with great felicity of style sad admirable knowledge of effect, it is not astonishing that it has found its way to the stage. Happy is the dramatist who alights on so capital a story. His path is clear before him. From being the pleasant surprise of the literary season, "The King of the Mountains" bids fair to become the most agreeable treat of the dramatic one. We shall be greatly mistaken if the work does not monopolize the attention of the public in both forms for many months to come.

abstract: THE FREEDOM OF THE CITY OF NEW-YORK TO GEN. ANDERSON. -- Messrs. BALL, BLACK & Co. have on exhibition a beautiful specimen of their handiwork, in the shape of a golden casket, intended to contain the freedom of the City, voted to Major ROBERT ANDERSON, for his heroic defence of Fort Sumter. The casket is oblong, with the corners cut off, five and a quarter inches in length by three and three-quarters in height. On the front is the following inscription: "The Freedom of the City of New-York, conferred upon Major ROBERT ANDERSON by its Corporate authorities, in recognition of his gallant conduct in defending Fort Sumter against the attacks of the rebels of South Carolina, April 12 and 13, 1861." The sides of the casket are exquisitely chased, and the lid is surmounted by the infinitessimal statuettes, representing the gallant Major in a kneeling position, in the act of being crowned by the Goddess of Liberty, and notwithstanding the diminutive size of the statuettes, the likeness of Major ANDERSON is a marvel of fidelity. As the gallant officer will doubtless pass through this City en route for Washington, whither he is directed to proceed, as soon as his health will permit, he will be enabled to receive in person this well-merited tribute to loyalty and courage.
lead_paragraph: THE FREEDOM OF THE CITY OF NEW-YORK TO GEN. ANDERSON. -- Messrs. BALL, BLACK & Co. have on exhibition a beautiful specimen of their handiwork, in the shape of a golden casket, intended to contain the freedom of the City, voted to Major ROBERT ANDERSON, for his heroic defence of Fort Sumter. As the gallant officer will doubtless pass through this City en route for Washington, whither he is directed to proceed, as soon as his health will permit, he will be enabled to receive in person this well-merited tribute to loyalty and courage.

abstract: The State Legislature, at its last session, created a commission in this City to prepare a new City Charter. It was composed of well-known citizens, representing equally the different political ...
lead_paragraph: The State Legislature, at its last session, created a commission in this City to prepare a new City Charter. It was composed of well-known citizens, representing equally the different political parties, and was directed to prepare the new instrument and publish it at least thirty days in advance of the next Municipal election. Their work ought, therefore, to be completed by the 1st of November. But they have wasted the whole Spring and Summer, and now -- within a fortnight of the time fixed for completing their work -- they have done absolutely nothing whatever in regard to it. Their principal topic of discussion thus far has been the selection of newspapers in which to publish their proceedings; and even this they have not accomplished.

abstract: The doubts we ventured to express upon the first announcement, by the London Post, of the terms of a European treaty for the settlement of Mexican matters, have been confirmed by each subsequent arrival. Even when the London Times came to the rescue of the Post, its indorsement by no means covered the original statement.
lead_paragraph: The doubts we ventured to express upon the first announcement, by the London Post, of the terms of a European treaty for the settlement of Mexican matters, have been confirmed by each subsequent arrival. Even when the London Times came to the rescue of the Post, its indorsement by no means covered the original statement. There had enough, probably, passed between the British and French Governments to prove that both were satisfied the time had come to give the condition of Mexico a very careful consideration; and there had, possibly, been an interchange of inchoate ideas and suggestions, pointing in the direction of some joint intervention; out while the Times did not assert that even the preliminaries had been arranged, the Paris Patric declared the French Government was not a party to any negotiations; and the Constitutioanel, equally a semi-official print, has since confirmed this declaration.

abstract: The steamship North American passed Father Point, on her way to Quebec, yasterday afternoon. She left Liverpool on the 3d and Londonderry on the 4th Inst., and her advices are consequently two days later than had been received by previous arrivals.
lead_paragraph: The steamship North American passed Father Point, on her way to Quebec, yasterday afternoon. She left Liverpool on the 3d and Londonderry on the 4th Inst., and her advices are consequently two days later than had been received by previous arrivals. During the four months past there have been 3,703 bales of cotton shipped from Liverpool to the United States, most of which was American. The imports of wheat and flour into England, during the eight months ending with August, reached the value of twenty millions sterling, against only seven millions for the same time last year. The sales in the Liverpool Cotton Market for the week footed up 67,330 bales, of which speculators had taken 28,500, and exporters 8,500. The tendency of the market was upward, an advance of 1/8d. lb. having taken place. Breadstuffs and Provisions continue about as last reported. Political meters in England were without interest. The contest for the Lord Mayoralty of London had terminated by the withdrawal of the candidate opposing the present incumbent.

abstract: HENRY T. BLOW, Esq., of Missouri, Minister to Venezuela, appointed by President LINCOLN, sails today on his mission. He proceeds to Halifax, by the Niagara, where he will obtain a British West India steamer that will take him to his destination. Mr. BLOW received his appointment several months ago, but has been detained in Missouri by the disturbed condition of affairs, and his anxiety to do something to strengthen the Union cause there. He is one of the largest owners of the famous Granby Lead Mines, and is a heavy loser by the rebel occupation and robbery of that property.

abstract: TILLOTT, an operator, for many years connected with the Southern Magnetic and American Telegraph Companies, in this and Southern cities, died yesterday morning, in Philadelphia, after a lingering and painful illness of many mouths' duration. Mr. TILLOTT was, at the time of his death, in the employ of the American Telegraph Company, by whom he was highly esteemed for his integrity and correct deportment. Hewas also sincerely beloved by his brother operators and office associates, for his mild mid amiable disposition, and by them, in a especial manner, is his death most keenly felt and deplored.

abstract: We are indebted to the rebels for late and important news from New-Orleans and the mouth of the Mississippi. The only trouble we have is to determine how much of it is worthy of belief; for we have found that a ...
lead_paragraph: We are indebted to the rebels for late and important news from New-Orleans and the mouth of the Mississippi. The only trouble we have is to determine how much of it is worthy of belief; for we have found that a rebel bulletin of victory has followed every clash of arms, no matter how unfortunate the result may have been to the rebel side. It is a part of the rebel system of warfare, and felt to be necessary, no doubt, in order to keep the cause alive, to make the rebel population believe that their arms are always triumphant. And hence, perhaps, the present boastful dispatch from New-Orleans.

abstract: The reported loss of the firgate Saranac, whether verified or not, points attention to a serious obstacle, which for several months must interfere, more or less, with the energetic prosecution of the war.
lead_paragraph: The reported loss of the firgate Saranac, whether verified or not, points attention to a serious obstacle, which for several months must interfere, more or less, with the energetic prosecution of the war. The weather of Winter will fight on the side of the rebels. Severe gales will render it difficult for blockading vessels to lay off their proper ports, without occasionally, for the sake of safety, standing out to sea, and leaving opportunities for the enemy to escape, or for the vigilant cotton ship to beat in, and load its valuable cargo. Our squadrons will suffer more frequent damages, and will more often be compelled to leave their various stations for repairs. If all of them escape shipwreck, strong as they are, along an exposed and dangerous coast, it will be, indeed, marvelous. And, in any event, the over-mastering necessity of self-preservation will do very much to diminish the efficiency of the fleet.
headline: {'main': 'The Weather and the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Weather and the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: One of the soldiers of the New-York Thirtyfourth, captured with others two weeks ago, while on a scout opposite Col. LA DEW'S encampment, returned yesterday. abstract: Pursuant to adjournment this Convention met at the Cooper Institute last evening, ANDREW LEWIS in the Chair. The Committee of Conference appointed by the Convention at their meeting reported that they met at the Everett House on Monday evening last, in pursuance of the published calls for the Conference ...
lead_paragraph: Pursuant to adjournment this Convention met at the Cooper Institute last evening, ANDREW LEWIS in the Chair. The Committee of Conference appointed by the Convention at their meeting reported that they met at the Everett House on Monday evening last, in pursuance of the published calls for the Conference Committees of the different parties to meet at that place, and they found the room set apart for the meeting in possession of the Fifth-avenue and St. Nicholas Hotel -- self-constituted -- Committees, and that they presented through Mr. WITTHAUS their credentials and after waiting a reasonable time, and receiving no reply, they addressed to them a note requesting either the return of their papers or the acceptance of their Committee. The papers were thereupon returned to the Committee with a statement to the following effect:

abstract: Secretary SEWARD has addressed an official circular to the Governors of the seaboard States, inviting them to take steps, in advance of the action of Congress, for the more effectual defence of our seaports against foreign invasion.
lead_paragraph: Secretary SEWARD has addressed an official circular to the Governors of the seaboard States, inviting them to take steps, in advance of the action of Congress, for the more effectual defence of our seaports against foreign invasion. He takes care to accompany this suggestion with the assurance that our foreign relations are less threatening now than they have been at anytime since the outbreak of the rebellion. Still the fact of making this request thus publicly, taken in connection with the aspect of our foreign affairs, will scarcely fail to create some uneasiness in the public mind. The cotton crisis in England is close at hand; -- and it is evident that in spite of all their efforts to procure a supply from other sources, the attempt can only be partially successful, and very many mills must stop. Agents of the South are actively at work abroad, urging England and France to break the blockade, and Mr. LINDSAY'S speech in Parliament shows that their efforts have not been wholly unsuccessful.

lead_paragraph: One of the most interesting and pleasing ceremonies that has been witnessed in the civil walks of life, since the present war period began, was attended yesterday by a brilliant and distinguished throng of our citizens and their fair dames and daughters. The announcement of the inauguration of the new Medical College attached to that time-honored and celebrated institution, the Bellevue Hospital, drew together at the appointed hour (12 M.) an unusual, and, as the Faculty assured us, an unexpected con course of New-Yorkers and strangers, eminent not only in the medical profession, but in all its sister sciences and every other sphere of public service.

abstract: A SOLDIER RUN OVER ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday at the depot of the Hudson River Railroad, in Thirty-first-street, upon the body of a soldier of the Sixth Regiment of the New-York State Militia, named DAVID GRIFFITHS, Who was run over by a train on the Hudson River Railroad on Monday afternoon. Capt.
lead_paragraph: A SOLDIER RUN OVER ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD. -- Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday at the depot of the Hudson River Railroad, in Thirty-first-street, upon the body of a soldier of the Sixth Regiment of the New-York State Militia, named DAVID GRIFFITHS, Who was run over by a train on the Hudson River Railroad on Monday afternoon. Capt. FRANCIS GRIMM testified that deceased was a member of his company, connected with the Sixth Regiment, quartered at present in Elm Park, at Eighty-ninth-street; that he gave him a furlough on Monday last, which permitted him to be absent from 9 to 12 o'clock; that about 2 P.M., on Monday, he first heard of his death; that deceased was a sober, steady man, about 23 years of age, and had recently joined the regiment, having come here from Iowa. RANSOM R. GRAVES, the engineer in charge of the train, testified that as he was running the down train from Sing Sing, which was due in New-York at 12.40 P.M. on Monday, when nearing Ninety-sixth-street, he saw something on the track, but at first supposed it was a bundle; as he approached nearer, saw it was a man, but thought it was a workman sighting the track; he was apparently stooping down looking for something; when he got nearer to him, saw that he was directly on the ground; upon noticing his face more particularly thought it had a blue appearance, and supposed then that he was dead; he stopped the train, backed up and took the body on the platform to Thirty-first-street Depot. CALEB WARD testified that he was a brakeman on the train, and that, nine or ten rods above Ninety-sixth-street, where the accident happened, he noticed that the brakes were applied, and soon after passing the body the train stopped; did not notice whether the body was warm or cold. Dr. WOOSTER BEACH made an examination of the body, and testified that the bones of the back part of the skull and the left arm in several places were badly fractured; that the shoulders were crushed, and that there were other injuries on the legs, arms and left side. He further testified: "The injuries, in my opinion, were produced by a blow from a locomotive, and were the cause of death." The verdict was, that deceased came to his death by causes unknown to the Jury.

abstract: We cannot wish for the success of the Southern rebellion in the interest of the slave, and furthermore we object to the separation of the Republic in the interest of Canada. We desire peace on this Continent, for it is peace that has given us our present development. If a perpetual war is kept up between the North and South, Canada will suffer with the rest of the Continent.
lead_paragraph: We cannot wish for the success of the Southern rebellion in the interest of the slave, and furthermore we object to the separation of the Republic in the interest of Canada. We desire peace on this Continent, for it is peace that has given us our present development. If a perpetual war is kept up between the North and South, Canada will suffer with the rest of the Continent. Her greatest progress has been made during the times of greatest prosperity in the Northern States, and desolation there will make depression and embarrassment here. If the North succeeds, we may look for a speedy end to the war, and the return or prosperity. If it fails, we must expect a long contest at present, and perpetual trouble in the future. If the North is deprived of the South, and the bitter feeling which the Ministerial Press is trying, to excite between Canada and the States continues, the Reciprocity Treaty will be abolished. It was the South that gave us reciprocity to serve its own ends, and without its aid in Congress it will be almost hopeless to attempt to save the treaty. It seems to us that some members of the Government and the Editor of the Leader, annexationists of an extreme kind, are working to bring about the abrogation of the treaty, hoping that annexation may follow. We can imagine nothing more unwise, coming from any friend of British connexion than abuse of the Northern States and expressions of sympathy for the South. We have no connection with the Slave States, and can have none. All our trade is with the North. Interest as well as duty prompt us to sympathize with its cause. We are ready to make sacrifices for a worthy object. The dangers of war ought not to be regarded if it principle is at stake. But when we are asked to take sides with JEFF. DAVIS and his manhunting, [???] associates, and to denounce those with whom we are in daily and friendly intercourse, and who are engaged in fighting for a good cause, it is a little too much. When we are told, in addition, by the annexationist editor of the Leader, that our loyalty is questionable, because we do not homologate to the slave propaganda, disgust and indignation entirely get the better of us.

abstract: His Grace the Right Reverend JOHN HUGHES was the next to address the large and delighted audience. He began by saying that it was not the first time he had heard the sound of his own voice, nor was he afraid of it, but that he felt more than usual emotion in the presence of so many scientific gentlemen and patrons of all that is charitable. He had not the slightest knowledge of medicine, nor when he was at College did he feel disposed to engage in the study, because he observed that all who were so engaged there were prone to imagine themselves afflicted with every disease under the sun. [Laughter and applause.]

abstract: A report reaches us from Harper's Ferry, by way of Washington, that an engagement took place yesterday at Bolivar, between a body of about 3,000 rebels and Col. GEARY'S Pennsylvania Regiment, assisted by six companies of the Thirteenth Massachusetts, all under command of Major GOULD.
lead_paragraph: A report reaches us from Harper's Ferry, by way of Washington, that an engagement took place yesterday at Bolivar, between a body of about 3,000 rebels and Col. GEARY'S Pennsylvania Regiment, assisted by six companies of the Thirteenth Massachusetts, all under command of Major GOULD. Our men, it appears, had been across the river for some time gathering wheat and foraging through the adjacent country. The rebels, it is reported, were three times repulsed by our troops, but the final result of the battle is not known, as the messenger left for Washington while it was in progress.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mr. ULMANN will take his first benefit at this establishment to-night. It is an occasion which should draw forth all the generosity of the operatic public. On its success, indeed, depends the future of musical matters at this, the leading place for their interpretation. Moreover, the performance is one which commends itself especially to an American audience.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. ULMANN will take his first benefit at this establishment to-night. It is an occasion which should draw forth all the generosity of the operatic public. On its success, indeed, depends the future of musical matters at this, the leading place for their interpretation. Moreover, the performance is one which commends itself especially to an American audience. Miss KELLOGG, the most gifted of our cantatrices, will assume a role which, whilst it has been made prominent by a former artist, is none the less worthy of a wider interpretation, such as we are sure the genius of the remarkable artist we have named will impart to it. Signor MANCUSI will also make his debut, and the opera being VERDI's latest and best approved, namely, the "Ballo in Maschera," there is not, we trust, the slightest suspicion of a doubt that the house will be crowded to its greatest capacity.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Arabia reached Halifax yesterday morning with advices from Europe two days later than were received by the Norwegian. Provisions were quiet. Another fall had taken place in the English funds, and Consols were quoted at 92 7/8@93 for money, Capt. abstract: On Sunday evening last, while a party of gentlemen were making a tour of Goat Island by moonlight, one of the party, Mr. PERCY CLARKE, indiscreetly ventured too near the edge of the rock forming a portion of the Central Fall. At this point the earth above the rock is insecure, and Mr. CLARKE, while passing forward to catch a closer view of the torrent, the ...
lead_paragraph: On Sunday evening last, while a party of gentlemen were making a tour of Goat Island by moonlight, one of the party, Mr. PERCY CLARKE, indiscreetly ventured too near the edge of the rock forming a portion of the Central Fall. At this point the earth above the rock is insecure, and Mr. CLARKE, while passing forward to catch a closer view of the torrent, the earth gave way under his feet, and he was precipitated upon the rock below. In the partial darkness, as the moon was at that moment obscured by passing clouds, it was almost impossible to distinguish Mr. CLARKE'S position, and for a moment it was thought he had been swept over the Fall. All was confusion, and in the wild roar of the cataract it was difficult to hear his cries for help. At this moment, Mr. HOWARD PAUL, of London, who was one of the party, sprung forward, and instantly removing his coat prostrated himself upon the bank, and clinging to the roots of a tree, threw one end of the garment to the unfortunate gentleman, and succeeded, at the risk of his own life, in rescuing Mr. CLARK from his perilous and fearful position. When discovered he was hanging to an abutting crag or fragment of rock, which forms the precipice of the Central Fall, within a single foot of the immense sheet of falling water which roars and tumbles a distance of one hundred and fifty feet below. Had it not been for Mr. HOWARD PAUL'S courage and presence of mind, there would most likely have been added another victim to the list of those who have lost their lives by adventuring too near the terriffic dangers of Niagara Falls.
headline: {'main': 'Narrow Escape at Niagara Falls.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Narrow Escape at Niagara Falls.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Bryan and Lunt vs. Bowles. -- In this case the plaintiffs brought their action against the defendant to recover for supplies furnished a vessel whose registry was made upon the defendant's affidavit of ownership. Upon the trial, the defendant offered evidence to show that his ownership consisted only in a bill of sale of the vessel, which he held merely as a mortgage. This evidence was excluded by the Court, who ruled that the defendant's affidavit, upon which the registry was made, established the ownership, and excluded the defendant from offering evidence contrary thereto. The Court also excluded other evidence offered by the defendant, to show that at the time the supplies were furnished, other parties were in actual possession of the vessel, which was under their control and management for the voyage, in respect to which the supplies were furnished. The defendant appealed from a judgment against him, and the Court, at General Term, have rendered the following opinion on the appeal:

abstract: Our British friends are becoming exceedingly anxious about the war. Mr. LINDSAY has urged in Parliament the propriety of pressing the American Government to relax the blockade, in order that, the British may get cotton for their mills.
lead_paragraph: Our British friends are becoming exceedingly anxious about the war. Mr. LINDSAY has urged in Parliament the propriety of pressing the American Government to relax the blockade, in order that, the British may get cotton for their mills. He goes even further, and suggests that, "in the interest of humanity," this war ought to be ended, and the independence of the South recognized. His remarks were received with cheers and hisses by his audience, showing a decided difference of opinion on this subject in the British House of Commons.

abstract: It has been the custom from time immemorial of civilized nations to treat prisoners of war with marked consideration. To show them any want of respect, or to insult them by word or action, is no only the sign of a barbarous people, but the mark of a low and vulgar mind.
lead_paragraph: It has been the custom from time immemorial of civilized nations to treat prisoners of war with marked consideration. To show them any want of respect, or to insult them by word or action, is no only the sign of a barbarous people, but the mark of a low and vulgar mind. None but the base can exult over the misfortunes of their fellow men. In the most chivalric ago of the world courtesy to the captive warrior was frequently carried to an absurd extent. And in modern times, nations, far from the highest in the scale of refinement, have been distinguished for a delicate regard to the feelings of prisoners taken in battle. When our own gallant Gen BOYD, who, after the American war, served in the English army in the East Indies, had the misfortuno to be taken prisoner there, he was the object of the most polite attentions from those into whose hands he had been thrown by the fortunes of war. As he moved along with his captors, they endeavored to keep out of sight as much as possible the fact that he was under restraint. When the native commander came to a convenient camping ground for the night, he invariably sent a messenger to Gen. Born to ask If it would be his pleasure that the army should halt. And in the morning, when they were ready to march, the same messenger presented himself at his tent, to ask if it was his pleasure that the army should move, Doubtless this was an exaggerated form of politeness,' but it was an exaggeration in the right direction.

abstract: WARD. -- Wednesday night, between 9 and 10 o'clock, a row took place in No. 94 James-street, a dance-house, which resulted in JOHN PECK stabbing CHARLES PETERSON, a Norwegian sailor, in the back and in the abdomen. PETERSON was taken to the Hospital, where his wounds were declared dangerous, one of them probably fatal. PECK had not been arrested at a late hour. Capt. THORNE, of the Fourth Precinct, arrested the inmates of the house as witnesses.

abstract: of San Francisco, who arrived here by the last California steamer, on his way to. Europe, to enjoy there the freedom of which he had been deprived by the horrid despotism, now dominant in the Golden State, made an extraordinary speech in the California Presbytery (Old School) a few days before he left, which we find reported in the Pacific, papers which came yesterday. A series of resolutions had been introduced by Rev. Mr. LOOMIS, declaring that the rebellion which now rages threatens to overthrow our Government, and destroy our liberty and prosperity, proclaiming the loyalty of the Presbyterian Church to the Government, and urging ministers to warn the people of the awful crime of rebellion. Dr. SCOTT, in response, said that only one thing was lacking, and that was to resolve the Presbytery into a political organization; and he then, "with a great deal of vim and voice," says the report, (and he himself has testified to the correctness of this part of the report.)

abstract: Shortly after the flight of Capt. LOVELL, the late Deputy Street-Commissioner, there appeared in several of our morning journals an article copied from a Richmond paper, in which, after announcing that Mr. G.W. SMITH had been rewarded for his treason with the commission of a Major-General in the rebel army, certain comparisons are drawn between him and Gen. McCLELLAN.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the flight of Capt. LOVELL, the late Deputy Street-Commissioner, there appeared in several of our morning journals an article copied from a Richmond paper, in which, after announcing that Mr. G.W. SMITH had been rewarded for his treason with the commission of a Major-General in the rebel army, certain comparisons are drawn between him and Gen. MCCLELLAN. It is there stated that Mr. SMITH beat MCCLELLAN in the struggle for class honors at West Point -- he (SMITH) having graduated No. 1. The truth is simply this: GUSTAVUS W. SMITH graduated in July, 1842. Instead of being No. 1 in rank, he graduated No. 8. Above him were several who are now officers in the loyal army, and among them Gen. ROSECRANS.

abstract: Several prisoners, who were tried a short time since, by general Court-martial, on Governor's Island, and sentenced to various terms of confinement and hard labor, for desertion and other offences, have been pardoned and returned to duty, on recommendation of Col. G. LOOMIS, the commanding officer, who has always borne the character of a kind-hearted gentleman. The men have shown their appreciation of the clemency extended to them, by behaving like good and well-conducted soldiers since their liberation.

abstract: Our advices from Washington this morning are of the highest importance. The conjectures of prominent military men, that the rebel forces are falling back even beyond their original lines, are likely, it appears, to prove correct.
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Washington this morning are of the highest importance. The conjectures of prominent military men, that the rebel forces are falling back even beyond their original lines, are likely, it appears, to prove correct. The large force at Aquia Creek, concentrated there to prevent a surprise, and the cutting off of the communications with Richmond, is believed to be in reality now the right wing of the rebel army -- the line extending in a northwesterly direction to the gap in the Blue Ridge, a little west of the Manassas Gap. Their base of operations in this case is behind the Rappahannock, while above that river they have only scattered pickets, scouts and foraging parties. In proof of the correctness of this supposition, the fact is known that, on Sunday last, there were not more than six regiments at Leesburgh, unincumbered with baggage; and positive information has been received that, on Tuesday last, a brigade which has been at Sangster's Station, on the Manassas and Alexandria Railroad, ever since the battle of Bull Run, had commenced to retreat, and had already proceeded as far as Union Mills, the other side of the late battle-field. The rebel force at Fairfax is known to be small, and it is doubtful whether there is any considerable number of troops at Fairfax Court-house or Vienna.

abstract: Naturally enough Mr. SEWARD'S circular which we published yesterday, calling on the Governors of the several States to prepare to resist a foreign invasion, excited a good deal of attention and anxiety.
lead_paragraph: Naturally enough Mr. SEWARD'S circular which we published yesterday, calling on the Governors of the several States to prepare to resist a foreign invasion, excited a good deal of attention and anxiety. It is quite certain that so important and so unusual a document would not have been issued without some adequate motive. The natural inference of every one is, that there must be something in the condition of our foreign relations which suggests the possibility, at least, of a foreign war.

abstract: At this period of the year the critic usually performs his most pleasing task. It is in ordinary times permitted to him to record the opening of the operatic campaign, and to anticipate with no unreasonable avidity the promised banquet of the management.
lead_paragraph: At this period of the year the critic usually performs his most pleasing task. It is in ordinary times permitted to him to record the opening of the operatic campaign, and to anticipate with no unreasonable avidity the promised banquet of the management. He can talk of the operas that are to be produced -- of the singers who will make their appearance -- of the rows which will inevitably occur -- and of all the other little matters which contribute so agreeably to a fashionable excitement. We were in danger of missing this accustomed treat. The public complained of its impecuniosity, and the manager rather triumphantly declared that he was without funds. If that manager were any other than Mr. ULLMAN, the chances are that the halls of our musical temple would remain silent and deserted until more prosperous times blessed the land. But as the ablest Generals are those who distinguish themselves most in adversity, so is if with the managerial resources of Mr. ULLMAN. Precisely at the moment when he seems to be most crushed, he is in fact in the liveliest state of recuperation, Thus, although there seems to be no hope of a regular early Winter season, he has contrived to fire off a big operatic gun, for the purpose, it would seem, of letting us know that he is at the post of danger, and ready for hostilities when the right time comes. The event has been managed with so much dexterity, that every one feels warmed and cheered by its significance. Of the hundreds who were present last evening, there was probably not one who did not feel that he was assisting a courageous man in a good cause. Where the right sentiment is awakened a small amount of material assistance will carry a great undertaking to a successful issue. After witnessing the enthusiasm of last evening, we do not doubt that Mr. ULLMAN will succeed in organizing an operatic troupe, and perfecting, a little later than usual, perhaps, a creditable season. When art is in danger, as it always is in periods of strife and commercial depression, it is certainly gratifying to witness a response so prompt and hearty as that which has in this instance greeted a manager's appeal.

abstract: In case of a foreign war, the State of New  York would be of all the States most exposed to hostile attack. Should any wretched combination of events plunge the nation into a conflict with France or England, it would be at the City of New-York, as the heart of the ...
lead_paragraph: In case of a foreign war, the State of New York would be of all the States most exposed to hostile attack. Should any wretched combination of events plunge the nation into a conflict with France or England, it would be at the City of New-York, as the heart of the country, the seat and radiating centre of commerce, wealth and intelligence, that the concentrated efforts of the enemy would be directed. If England were the adversary, we should also have to provide against invasion from Canada. Hence the necessity of protecting all the principal points confronting the Canada line. But attack from that quarter would be simply a flank movement upon this place, and should be yet further provided for by such defences as have been pronounced by the Engineer Department of the army essential to the safety of the City.

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, upon the body of JAMES DAVY, who died of injuries accidentally received on the 16th inst. Deceased lived in Fiftyseventh-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, ...
lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT. -- Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, upon the body of JAMES DAVY, who died of injuries accidentally received on the 16th inst. Deceased lived in Fiftyseventh-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, and at the time of the accident was walking on Eighth-avenue, near One Hundreth street, when a two-horse the truck with a heavy stone upon it passed him. When opposite the truck the stone was suddenly jarred off and fell upon his legs, crushing them in a terrible manner. He was at once removed to the hospital and amputation of his legs performed, soon after which he died. deceased was a native of Ireland, 34 years of age.

abstract: The Ordnance Department and the public are very anxious to test the RODMAN 15-inch gun by actual experiment. It is not doubted that the Union gun and the FLOYD gun, at Fortress Monroe, will smash in the sides of any ship or battery that the rebels may have loaded down with armor up to the limits of flotation. Here is a fact for them: Upward of five years ago, the Mersey Steel & Iron Company fired a 282 lb. shot with 25 lbs. of powder, at 120 yards range, from their 13-inch gun, at a plate made for one of the English iron-clad ships, by the Messrs. HORSFALL. The plate was 3 feet 9 inches, by 2 feet 9 inches, by 4 3/8 inches thick, and weighed 17 cwt. The plate was placed against the ends of nine bulks of timber, 6 feet long by 14 inches square, secured together by cross-plank, and bedded in sand. The ball struck the plate a little to the left of the centre, and drove the portion against which it struck, a distance of 300 yards, shattering the whole plate, and driving the timbers to some distance. The shot was also shattered. After this report, which is official, we need stand in no fear of any mailed fleets yet afloat, if we can get a shot at them with our 15-inch guns, of which the balls weigh 425 lbs., and are driven by 40 lbs. of powder. The shot of a 20-inch gun, which is deemed practicable by RODMAN's process of casting, would weigh half a ton.
lead_paragraph: The Ordnance Department and the public are very anxious to test the RODMAN 15-inch gun by actual experiment. It is not doubted that the Union gun and the FLOYD gun, at Fortress Monroe, will smash in the sides of any ship or battery that the rebels may have loaded down with armor up to the limits of flotation. Here is a fact for them: Upward of five years ago, the Mersey Steel & Iron Company fired a 282 lb. shot with 25 lbs. of powder, at 120 yards range, from their 13-inch gun, at a plate made for one of the English iron-clad ships, by the Messrs. HORSFALL. The plate was 3 feet 9 inches, by 2 feet 9 inches, by 4 3/8 inches thick, and weighed 17 cwt. The plate was placed against the ends of nine bulks of timber, 6 feet long by 14 inches square, secured together by cross-plank, and bedded in sand. The ball struck the plate a little to the left of the centre, and drove the portion against which it struck, a distance of 300 yards, shattering the whole plate, and driving the timbers to some distance. The shot was also shattered. After this report, which is official, we need stand in no fear of any mailed fleets yet afloat, if we can get a shot at them with our 15-inch guns, of which the balls weigh 425 lbs., and are driven by 40 lbs. of powder. The shot of a 20-inch gun, which is deemed practicable by RODMAN's process of casting, would weigh half a ton.

abstract: "The army has advanced as far as Lewinsville." So the telegraph announces briefly, concisely, and as unsatisfactorily as the telegraph and especially the army telegraph always tells of "an event." It has the same curt, abortive expression for the light manifestations of a company of skirmishers as for the ponderous, overwhelming momentum of a great Division, with all its glittering muskets, its clattering hoofs and rumbling wheels.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Oct. 15, 1861.

abstract: That portion of our citizens who have been clamoring so loudly for political reform, will now be compelled to shoulder the entire responsibility if they fail to effect it. The war has aroused the whole community to the absolute necessity of taking control of our public affairs out of the hands of the partisan gamblers who have exercised it hitherto.
lead_paragraph: That portion of our citizens who have been clamoring so loudly for political reform, will now be compelled to shoulder the entire responsibility if they fail to effect it. The war has aroused the whole community to the absolute necessity of taking control of our public affairs out of the hands of the partisan gamblers who have exercised it hitherto. The perfection of party machinery has offered an insurmountable barrier to every attempt at reform through the ordinary modes of political action. Ward politicians. -- adventurers in politics, -- men who sought office as a means of plundering the public, had obtained complete control of all nominations, and would at pleasure fill every place with their own accomplices or tools. The respectable portion of our citizens groaned under the infliction, which seemed, however, as inevitable as fate.

abstract: To the charitable, who have so kindly met my appeal, made in behalf of sick prisoners confined on Governor's Island, I submit the following correspondence, and would take this opportunity to state that I have received and forwarded to Surgeon SLOAN, twenty-three bundles of clothing, and, with the funds left with me, have purchased supplies for the present, consisting of tea, sugar, lemons, barley, sago, arrowroot, and other articles, for which I hold receipts from Surgeon SLOAN, in charge of the Hospital, Governor's Island. WM. COXE DUSENBERY,

abstract: Application of Charles Cobel. -- The petitioner was recently committed by Coroner JACKMAN on the charge of having smothered a child to death soon after its birth. The case was published at the time of the Coroner's investigation. The maiter was now brought up on certiorari for the purpose of reviewing the facts upon which the commitment was made, and, if possible, obtain the discharge of the accused.

abstract: We publish this morning news which left Utah yesterday!The completion of the Pacific line of telegraph to Great Salt Lake City brings us into immediate communication with our polygamous friends of Mormondom. Twenty-five years ago this would have been deemed a miracle; -- now,so commonplace a matter has telegraphic communication become, that it will scarcely elicit a passing remark. The first message, moreover, is a protest from BRIGHAM YOUNG against secession. This is scarcely less surprising than the other. He has evidently forgiven the United States Government the war it waged upon him a few years since, or else he fears the South might prove still worse masters than Uncle Sam.

abstract: The following naval officers, recently arrived from the coast of Africa in the storeship Relief, having tendered their resignations, were arrested yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy-yard and conveyed to Fort Fafayette: Lieut. HAMILTON H. DALTON, of the sloop-of-war Saratoga; Surgeon PHILIP LANSDALE, also of the Saratoga; and Assistant Surgeon WILLIAM M. PAGE, of the Relief. Lieut. DALTON is a native of North Carolina, and was appointed from Mississippi, on the 1st of October, 1851, as midshipman to the steam-frigate Wabash. Dr. LANSDALE is a native of Maryland, and was appointed from that Slate in March, 1847, to the Bureau of Medicine and Surgery. Dr. PAGE was born in Virginia, and appointed to the sloop-of-war Falmouth in October, 1855.

abstract: Evidence accumulates that the rebel army has really made another general movement in retreat' and has formed an entirely new line of operations' which deprives them of Manassas as their stronghold.
lead_paragraph: Evidence accumulates that the rebel army has really made another general movement in retreat' and has formed an entirely new line of operations' which deprives them of Manassas as their stronghold. Information was yesterday received, that their entire force lately stationed at Leesburgh. has been withdrawn, even to the scouts and pickets, and on Thursday night their pickets were withdrawn from Vienna and in front of Fairfax Court-house. A balloon reconnoissance yesterday, discovered no rebels anywhere this side of Fairfax, and but few there. The disposition of their line is believed to be as described in yesterday's TIMES, with the right resting on the Potomac at Aquia Creek, and the left on the Blue Ridge.

abstract: Since the arrival of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, on its return from Virginia, there has not been assembled in the streets of New-York so large a throng of the children of Ireland as that which yesterday lined them, from Twenty-third-street, along Broadway to the Park, and from Broadway along Canalstreet to the North River.
lead_paragraph: Since the arrival of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, on its return from Virginia, there has not been assembled in the streets of New-York so large a throng of the children of Ireland as that which yesterday lined them, from Twenty-third-street, along Broadway to the Park, and from Broadway along Canalstreet to the North River. The series of pageants and receptions which have attended the progress of the honored remains of TERRENCE BELLEW MCMANUS, from the distant shores of California toward their destined resting-place in the land of the dead patriot's birth, closed yesterday with a scene which strongly marks the sympathy still felt by the Hibernians in America for the doctrines and the leaders of the Young Ireland Party. Early in the morning, a vast multitude began to assemble at the Twenty-third, street ferry, and by 10 o'clock, when the body was landed and received by the appointed Committee, every adjacent space was packed with a dense mass of men, women and children, all full of interest in the occasion, and eager not to lose a glimpse of the scene.

abstract: EXTENSIVE FIRE IN ELDRIDGE-STREET. At 5   o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out on the second floor of the five-story brick building No. 91 Eldridge-street. Messrs. GROTH  TRABERT, mahogany and lumber dealers, occupied the second floor, and their loss is in the neighborhood of $1,200.
lead_paragraph: EXTENSIVE FIRE IN ELDRIDGE-STREET. -- At 5 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out on the second floor of the five-story brick building No. 91 Eldridge-street. Messrs. GROTH TRABERT, mahogany and lumber dealers, occupied the second floor, and their loss is in the neighborhood of $1,200. The fire extended to the third floor, occupied by STEVENS & SMITH, carriage-makers. Their loss is about $800, upon which there was no insurance. The fourth floor was occupied by GEORGE HELM, as a carpenter and cabinet-maker's sho. His loss is about $300; no insurance. Mr. STEVEN THORNE occupied the fifth floor, as a piano-forte manufactory. His loss amounts to about $1,500, upon which there was no insurance. The building was owned by Mr. CHARLES GESSEL, and was damaged to [???] extent of about $2,000; insured. The origin of the fire is at present unknown, but the Fire Marshal was yesterday investigating the matter.

abstract: Jonas Smith et al. vs. the bark Mansanito, her cargo,  This case came up on an application to the Court for payment of the remnants and proceeds out of the Registry.
lead_paragraph: Jonas Smith et al. vs. the bark Mansanito, her cargo, &c. -- This case came up on an application to the Court for payment of the remnants and proceeds out of the Registry. The vessel and her cargo was abandoned at sea on March 28, 1861, brought into this port by salvors as derelict, and libeled by them, and the Court awarded one-half the proceeds of the vessel and cargo as salvage. At the time of her abandonment the vessel was carrying a cargo of iron, under a charter to deliver it at City Point in Virginia. The owners of the cargo abandoned the cargo to the underwriters, and appeared in the salvage suit only as representing them. The vessel arrived in New-York April 10; the decree in the cause was rendered June 13; the vessel was solo June 29 to the original owners, and the cargo was sold July 5. On July 2 the owners of the vessel gave notice to the owners of the cargo, that they held themselves in readiness to forward the cargo to its destination as soon as the blockade of Virginia, established April 30, was removed, and claimed their right to hold the cargo for that purpose, and suggested that one hall of the cargo should be delivered up to satisfy the salvage decree against it, and that if the owners of the cargo desired to have the cargo remain here some settlement be made as to the freight, otherwise the vessel would claim her lien on the cargo and its proceeds for freight. No such agreement was made, and the cargo was sold, and the proceeds remaining in Court, after satisfying the salvage decree, amounting to about $6,200.

abstract: Yesterday morning, the Eighth Regiment, Col. HARLAND, of Connecticut, arrived in this City. The regiment numbers over one thousand men, all of whom are fully armed and equipped. Accompanying the regiment is the requisite supply of camp equipage, baggage-wagons, ambulances, &c. It was supposed that the men would be quartered on Staten Island; on arriving here, however, the destination was changed, the men were landed at Hunter's Point, and at once proceeded to Hempstead, L.I.

abstract: AFFAIRS. -- It is quite a luxury to find a speech by an Englishman on the American Rebellion which evinces anything like an accurate knowledge of its character, or a just estimate of its prospects. Mr. FORSTER, member of Parliament for Bradford, delivered a lecture before the Mechanics' Institute, in that town which substantially meets both these requirements. He is not humbugged in the least, either by the clamor of British Abolitionists that the war is not waged for the emancipation of the slaves, nor by the selfish demand for peace on the pretext that the South cannot be conquered. He sees the necessity which compels the North to fight for the Government, and understands, moreover, that the war is waged against the political power of Slavery. His address is in marked contrast with that which Mr. LINDSAY made to his constituents at Sunderland a few days before, it is not at all impossible that in course of time the English may come to take a very sensible view of our affairs.
lead_paragraph: AFFAIRS. -- It is quite a luxury to find a speech by an Englishman on the American Rebellion which evinces anything like an accurate knowledge of its character, or a just estimate of its prospects. Mr. FORSTER, member of Parliament for Bradford, delivered a lecture before the Mechanics' Institute, in that town which substantially meets both these requirements. He is not humbugged in the least, either by the clamor of British Abolitionists that the war is not waged for the emancipation of the slaves, nor by the selfish demand for peace on the pretext that the South cannot be conquered. He sees the necessity which compels the North to fight for the Government, and understands, moreover, that the war is waged against the political power of Slavery. His address is in marked contrast with that which Mr. LINDSAY made to his constituents at Sunderland a few days before, it is not at all impossible that in course of time the English may come to take a very sensible view of our affairs.

abstract: We have been permitted to make the following extracts from a letter just received by a gentleman in Brooklyn, from his brother in Kansas. The Kansas "settler" has a store, is agent of the Bible Society, Sunday School Union, and fills other important stations in society.
lead_paragraph: We have been permitted to make the following extracts from a letter just received by a gentleman in Brooklyn, from his brother in Kansas. The Kansas "settler" has a store, is agent of the Bible Society, Sunday School Union, and fills other important stations in society. Among others, he occupies a prominent position as a "Home Guard," keeping, as rewrites, five or six loaded guns in his house (store,) and rising as often in the night to reconnoitre for prowling enemies. Of course the times are exciting in his vicinity, and his letter interesting.

abstract: Wm. Lindeman and Herman Lindeman vs. Robert Fox and John C. Curran. -- This action was brought to recover of the defendants, the proprietors of Canterbury Hall, a concert saloon on Broadway, the value of a piano rented of the plaintiffs. By a written contract made in January last, the defendants hired the piano for $7 per month, the piano being of the value of $300. The contract was to return it in as good a condition as it was at the time it was hired, the ordinary wear, &c., being excepted. The old Canterbury Hall was subsequently burned, and with it the piano. The only question in the case was whether the defendant were liable for the piano on that contract, it having been destroyed without any fault or negligence of theirs. The Court held that they were liable, according to the following authorities: Beach vs. Crain, 2d Comstock, 86; Harmony vs. Bingham, 2d Kernan, 99; and Beebe vs. Johnson, 19 Wendell, 500. Judgment for the plaintiffs.

lead_paragraph: A sufficient proof of the immense strides made by modern science -- or, at least, in one branch of it -- is afforded in our columns this morning. abstract: TENTIARIES Everybody, no doubt, is now following in fancy the great sea-chase of our leash of sea-dogs after MASON and SLIDELL, the brace of Confederate "Plenipotentiaries"  the rarest piece of sport of the season.
lead_paragraph: TENTIARIES -- Everybody, no doubt, is now following in fancy the great sea-chase of our leash of sea-dogs after MASON and SLIDELL, the brace of Confederate "Plenipotentiaries" -- the rarest piece of sport of the season. The three steamers which the Government has dispatched after the Nashville, are now many hundreds of miles out on the blue Atlantic, under full stress of steam and full crowd of canvas. The rebel fugitives wil doubtless make their best "time." for they run with the fiend at their heels, and the Davis diplomats would probably rather go to Davy's locker than fall into the hands of the pursuers. For any good it will do the Confederate cause, we don't care the toss of a Confederate picayune whether the precious pair of "Plenipotentiaries to the Courts of St. James and St. Cloud" ever reach their destination; but in a mere artistic sense, we own it would afford us a very lively satisfaction should our fellows catch the scoundrels. What are the chances of the chase?
headline: {'main': 'THE SEA-CHASE AFTER THE FUGITIVE PLENIPOTENTIARIES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE SEA-CHASE AFTER THE FUGITIVE PLENIPOTENTIARIES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The escape of the rebel steamer Nashville, from the harbor of Charleston, S.C., on the night of the 11th inst., causes much vexation to the Government, and, according to report no little excitement in the diplomatic circles of Washington.
lead_paragraph: The escape of the rebel steamer Nashville, from the harbor of Charleston, S.C., on the night of the 11th inst., causes much vexation to the Government, and, according to report no little excitement in the diplomatic circles of Washington. The Nashville bore two fully accredited Ministers of the Confederate Government to the two first Courts of Europe -- Hon. JOHN M. MASON to England, and Hon. JOHN SLIDELL to France. It is supposed that the arrival of these two functionaries, who have been eminent in the United States service, with two distinguished gentlemen, Mr. MAOFARLAND, of Virginia, and Mr. EUSTIS, of Louisiana, as Private Secretaries -- representing the Confederate Government, and having sailed in their own steamer direct from a leading port in the South, which is claimed to be blockaded, will have a profound effect in Europe, very favorable to the independence of the Confederate States. This opinion will prove erroneous.
