abstract: To put the fortifications of New-York in the condition designed by the Engineer Bureau, will cost three and a-half millions of dollars, and an amount of time which will render their completion too late for present emergencies.
lead_paragraph: To put the fortifications of New-York in the condition designed by the Engineer Bureau, will cost three and a-half millions of dollars, and an amount of time which will render their completion too late for present emergencies. And when they are finished, at this cost, it is by no means agreed, among military authorities, that they can destroy, or even stop, an entire iron-clad fleet and its accompanying swarm of gunboats. Let one frigate, or a dozen gunboats, once get past the one East River fortification, or out of shot-range up the North River, and this City is at the mercy of their shells. There is no doubt that a very few fifteen-inch shot would smash in the Warrior's sides if they were to hit her -- but the Warrior sails at fifteen knots, while any one fort would not be within telling shot-range of her for more than fifteen minutes. Speed, iron mail, and subdivision of attacking force, are features of modern warfare which make running the gauntlet of forts more feasible than it was in old times. It is difficult enough to hit a rapidly-moving object at all; add to this the necessity of hitting and disabling a great number of small objects -- gunboats -- while shifting their course in every direction, and the task of keeping a fleet at bay by fixed guns on shore, seems almost hopeless. Were this our defence if we had these fourteen forts completed, armed and manned, what is it now?

abstract: Our reports from Washington indicate that the rebel army in front of the Capital has made a very important change in its position within the last few days.
lead_paragraph: Our reports from Washington indicate that the rebel army in front of the Capital has made a very important change in its position within the last few days. Its extreme left has been withdrawn from Leesburgh, -- its right has been extended southward, so that it now rests on the Potomac at Aquia Creek, -- and the whole army has been formed behind the Rappahannock, which now serves to protect it as Bull Run did before. Some of our cotemporaries represent this as a retreat, and as indicating an unwillingness to fight a battle in front of Washington. We do not regard it in that light. On the contrary, it seems to us a strategetic movement of decided skill, and one which may have an important influence on the progress of the war.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Change of Front.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Change of Front.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In common with every revolution, the war waged by the South changes its character as it advances. At the outset, all the South asked was to be "let alone;" now it talks of invading the Northern States.
lead_paragraph: In common with every revolution, the war waged by the South changes its character as it advances. At the outset, all the South asked was to be "let alone;" now it talks of invading the Northern States. Then it was a war purely of self-defence; -- now it is a war of boundaries. Then the doctrine of State rights was paramount, and the right of each State to secede at will from the new Confederacy was expressly recognized in their Constitution; -- now every Slave State that hesitates must be coerced into subjection.

abstract: As we have still a few croakers amongst us, a glance at the condition of the trade of the North may not be amiss. The injurious effect of the war upon the trade of the country came more from the effect of the panic upon the rotten financial system of the West...
lead_paragraph: As we have still a few croakers amongst us, a glance at the condition of the trade of the North may not be amiss. The injurious effect of the war upon the trade of the country came more from the effect of the panic upon the rotten financial system of the West than from any cause absolutely belonging to a state of war, and as soon as the system of exchange between the West and East had time to regulate itself, the trade of the country revived. Our present condition is now one of more general prosperity than we have had for years, regarding our condition simply from a commercial point of view. Our transactions are for cash or upon very short credits.

abstract: The rebels have adopted another expedient for obstructing the navigation of the Lower Potomac, and to some purpose, as it enabled them yesterday to make a capture. They have stretched a chain across the channel at Pasawamsic Creek, and when the Resolute, with the...
lead_paragraph: The rebels have adopted another expedient for obstructing the navigation of the Lower Potomac, and to some purpose, as it enabled them yesterday to make a capture. They have stretched a chain across the channel at Pasawamsic Creek, and when the Resolute, with the schooners Fairfax and Lady Ann in tow, passed up, she ran against it, and was unable to proceed until the Fairfax broke loose and drifted toward the shore, when the rebels in boats started out and captured her, the Resolute at the same time being fired upon by the shore battery, and being unable to render any assistance to the Fairfax, which was heavily loaded with hay. The Resolute finally succeeded in getting over the chain, with the other schooner, after remaining as a target for the batteries for upwards of an hour, during which time about a hundred and fifty shot and shell were fired at her. She, as well as the Lady Ann, was struck several times, but no one on board was injured. It is difficult to imagine how a chain of sufficient strength to stop the progress of a steamer, could have been stretched across the river without the knowledge of some one of the flotilla.

abstract: -- WILLIAM SCHAW LINDSAY, who in the course of his late speechifying to his constituents at Sunderland made such a funny jumble of cotton-spinning and humanity, is a keen Scotchman, whose enterprise, industry, and sagacity have pushed him forward as a power in the British mercantile marine, made a fortune for him, and given him a seat in the House of Commons. Last year he was a volunteer missionary to this country to persuade our merchants that free trade was for their advantage; and considering that he himself owns a fleet of ships, and would necessarily profit by the carrying trade, it was very disinterested advice to request the British Government to have the blockade removed! It might seem strange that clear-headed, freedom-loving Scotchmen should sympathize with the Slavery insurgents. But self-interest strangely colors the spectacles through which people view things. It is a curious trait that there are no such virulent upholders of the rebellion as the manufacturers of Glasgow, Paisley, and other Scotch spinning towns. The Manchester men don't begin to hold a candle to them.
lead_paragraph: -- WILLIAM SCHAW LINDSAY, who in the course of his late speechifying to his constituents at Sunderland made such a funny jumble of cotton-spinning and humanity, is a keen Scotchman, whose enterprise, industry, and sagacity have pushed him forward as a power in the British mercantile marine, made a fortune for him, and given him a seat in the House of Commons. Last year he was a volunteer missionary to this country to persuade our merchants that free trade was for their advantage; and considering that he himself owns a fleet of ships, and would necessarily profit by the carrying trade, it was very disinterested advice to request the British Government to have the blockade removed! It might seem strange that clear-headed, freedom-loving Scotchmen should sympathize with the Slavery insurgents. But self-interest strangely colors the spectacles through which people view things. It is a curious trait that there are no such virulent upholders of the rebellion as the manufacturers of Glasgow, Paisley, and other Scotch spinning towns. The Manchester men don't begin to hold a candle to them.

abstract: The correspondence which has taken place between Lord LYONS, the British Minister, and Mr. SEWARD, is another assurance that our relations with England rest upon a satisfactory basis. Two English subjects, sus  pected upon sufficient grounds of promoting the southern rebellion, had been arrested and...
lead_paragraph: The correspondence which has taken place between Lord LYONS, the British Minister, and Mr. SEWARD, is another assurance that our relations with England rest upon a satisfactory basis. Two English subjects, sus pected upon sufficient grounds of promoting the southern rebellion, had been arrested and sent to Fort Lafayette. The British Envoy, properly mindful of the rights of his country-men,made their confinement the subject of protect; and in reply the Secretary of State justifies the measure by appealing to that supreme law of self-preservation, which in extreme circumstances authorizes a Government to employ exceptional means of protection. With this response the correspondence neccessarily ends, for the gentlemen whose cases provoked it, were released some time since.

abstract: FUNERAL OBSEQUIES OF FATHER CASSIDY. Nearly forty Catholic priests, and an immense number of the laity, assembled yesterday at the little church which adjoins the residence of the Catholic pastor of Flatbush, to pay their last tribute of love...
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OBSEQUIES OF FATHER CASSIDY. -- Nearly forty Catholic priests, and an immense number of the laity, assembled yesterday at the little church which adjoins the residence of the Catholic pastor of Flatbush, to pay their last tribute of love and esteem to their late young and amiable pastor, Father STEPHEN CASSIDY. He was obliged recently to abandon his curacy because of ill-health, incurred in the discharge of his duties, and retired for a time for change of air to the residence of his friend, Rev. CHAS. SLEVIN, of Dover Plains. There, surrounded by some of his most intimate clerical friends, and having received all the consolations and graces which religion can impart, he calmly resigned himself to death. No physical pang marked his parting moments. Right Rev. Bishop LOUGHLIN, of Brooklyn, presided over the funeral ceremonies, and preached the sermon. Father SLEVIN acted as celebrant of the solemn Mass of Requiem, which was said over the remains; Father THOMAS TREANOR acted as Deacon, Father F. MCLOUGHLIN as Sub-Deacon, and Rev. EUGENE CASSIDY -- the namesake, though not the relative of the deceased, and one of the choicest of his friends -- as master of the ceremonies.

abstract: Approaching Columbus, it proved there the same as elsewhere, an easy matter to pass the pickets and get in, the only difficult to be feared that of getting cut, which, as my companion was a Kentuckian, and on business to Columbus, where he was known, a correspondent found himself turned into a country...
lead_paragraph: Approaching Columbus, it proved there the same as elsewhere, an easy matter to pass the pickets and get in, the only difficult to be feared that of getting cut, which, as my companion was a Kentuckian, and on business to Columbus, where he was known, a correspondent found himself turned into a country clerk crown on the same soil and travelling with his employer. If the food and drill agreed with him, as the latter observed to a Captain with a villainous eye and long hair, he might (?) become a good Confederate soldier. The country clerk preferred a wish to keep on ribbon measuring, and opened his eyes wide to see what there was to see, but failed in discovering anything at all remarkable at first. The novelty of the situation, surrounded by men whose arms were lifted, CAIN-like against their brothers, and ARNOLD-like to strike their country, was somewhat exciting, but that was all. Columbus is a monotenous, dull appearing little village, of usually five hundred inhabitants or thereabouts, but now populated by an army drawn from the glades of Florida, the cities of the South, the lines of the border, to meet that mighty host who have risen to seek among the cypress and cotton those stars stricken so rudely from their flag.

abstract: The Toronto Leader is not chargeable with the weakness of loving the American people wisely or well. It loses no chance of saying venomous, or doing damaging, things to-us-ward; and would evidently like to promote a state of feeling which shall forever render a union of Canada with the United States impossible. Such, perhaps, is its duty as the organ of a Government constituted and instructed in Downing-street, and averse from anything tending to augment the inconvenient greatness of the American Republic. In the remarks of the Leader upon Mr. SEWARD's circular respecting fortifications, it chooses to regard the recommendations of the letter as a menace directed against Canada, and at once suggests warlike measures in response. It is needless to say the letter admits of no such construction. So far from proposing hostile measures, it deprecates hostilities, and would avoid them by precautions purely defensive. But had it taken a less forbearing direction, and, pointing to the sudden presence of several regiments, the flower of the British army, on our Northern frontier, and the sudden and complete preparation of Quebec to resist invasion and assault, argued the necessity of putting that boundary in a state of defence, the Leader would still have been without reason to stigmatize the measure as threatening. The menace would be, as it is, from the other side. We will only add that if out of the irritating efforts of the Canada Press to excite feelings of estrangement and jealousy between the people of Canada and this country a war should unhappily spring, the Leader will find it has overacted its part, perhaps fatally.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Leader is not chargeable with the weakness of loving the American people wisely or well. It loses no chance of saying venomous, or doing damaging, things to-us-ward; and would evidently like to promote a state of feeling which shall forever render a union of Canada with the United States impossible. Such, perhaps, is its duty as the organ of a Government constituted and instructed in Downing-street, and averse from anything tending to augment the inconvenient greatness of the American Republic. In the remarks of the Leader upon Mr. SEWARD's circular respecting fortifications, it chooses to regard the recommendations of the letter as a menace directed against Canada, and at once suggests warlike measures in response. It is needless to say the letter admits of no such construction. So far from proposing hostile measures, it deprecates hostilities, and would avoid them by precautions purely defensive. But had it taken a less forbearing direction, and, pointing to the sudden presence of several regiments, the flower of the British army, on our Northern frontier, and the sudden and complete preparation of Quebec to resist invasion and assault, argued the necessity of putting that boundary in a state of defence, the Leader would still have been without reason to stigmatize the measure as threatening. The menace would be, as it is, from the other side. We will only add that if out of the irritating efforts of the Canada Press to excite feelings of estrangement and jealousy between the people of Canada and this country a war should unhappily spring, the Leader will find it has overacted its part, perhaps fatally.

abstract: We have published full particulars of the recent capture of about fifty members of the Indiana Twentieth Regiment, on board the steamer Fanny, near Cape Hatteras, and also of the subsequent retreat of the regiment, taken from the correspondence of the Eastern papers. We find in the Indianapolis Journal several letters from a member of the Indiana troops at Hatteras, which are very interesting, and throw new light upon some of the statements already laid before our readers. We make copious extracts. About the last of September the greater part of the regiment had been sent about forty miles from Fort Hatteras, and by the 2d of October were short of provisions. The events which followed are thus described:

abstract: Shortly after BUCKNER and his troops established themselves at Bowling Green, his commissaries made large contracts with people in the surrounding country to furnish meat, grain and provisions of all kinds for the support of the army. This indicated that the expectation was to remain there for a considerable time. On Thursday, Friday and Saturday of last week, notices were sent out annulling all the contracts made. This indicates that a speedy movement from Bowling Graen is contemplated.

abstract: The Journal's leader of to-day is very cheering. It states that from the firing on Fort Sumter to the present hour, the Union sentiment and cooperation in Kentucky have never been as strong as at this hour; that the work of enlistment for the war has never...
lead_paragraph: The Journal's leader of to-day is very cheering. It states that from the firing on Fort Sumter to the present hour, the Union sentiment and cooperation in Kentucky have never been as strong as at this hour; that the work of enlistment for the war has never been as active in Kentucky as since Col. MULLIGAN's surrender, and the recruiting of the rebels in this State has never been as feeble as it is now; that as a general rule the Home Guards have fully redeemed their promises of defending their homes; that the Home Guards in Southern Kentucky are biding their time, as the oppressed Unionists in the South are, and a terrible settlement will be made; that upwards of 20,000 of Kentucky's fighting material are now under the Stars and Stripes, enlisted for the war, and many more thousands (among them some of our wealthiest and best citizens) will soon be in the same ranks. The Journal editors never fell more hopeful of Kentucky than they do now -- nor did I ever feel more hopeful. The Journal does not regard Southern and Western Kentucky as lost -- nor do I. The vigorous and formidable preparations being made by the rest of the State, and by her neighbors and the Government may, and I believe will, save not only Southern and Western Kentucky, but also Eastern Tennessee, within perhaps six weeks. Let the Administration swell the Union forces and strengthen the Union hands in Kentucky, to the utmost extent consistent with the Administration's safety and success elsewhere, and all must soon come out right in this important quarter.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer of the 11th of October has an account of the confiscation of estates and property in Virginia, which have occured under the sequestration act of the rebel Congress, since the 30th of September.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Enquirer of the 11th of October has an account of the confiscation of estates and property in Virginia, which have occured under the sequestration act of the rebel Congress, since the 30th of September. The aggregate value of the property thus confiscated owned by Northern citizens or loyal Virginians, is estimated at $800,000. But this was the result of only ten days' adjudications. Doubtless the work will go on until every species and vestige of property in Virginia "belonging or in any wise appertaining." as the lawyers say, to Northern and loyal citizens, has been confiscated and sold, and the proceeds paid into the rebel Confederate treasury. The Virginia papers estimate the amount of property in that State owned by Northern Unionists at $30,000,000. The aggregate value of the first ten days' confiscations, as computed by the Richmond Enquirer, indicates that the sum is more, likely to be greater than less.

abstract: This quaint and quiet town has been galvanized into life, and divested of its rusty, cobwebish appearance, by the establishment here, within the past two weeks, of camps of instruction for the soldiers of the National army.
lead_paragraph: This quaint and quiet town has been galvanized into life, and divested of its rusty, cobwebish appearance, by the establishment here, within the past two weeks, of camps of instruction for the soldiers of the National army. Admirably adapted camping-grounds are afforded everywhere in the vicinity of the town, and it is probable that during the continuance of the war the Government will send raw troops here to be educated.

abstract: A meeting of the Workingmen's Central Committee, under the name of the Patriotic Union League, was held at Union Hall, No. 187 Bowery, a few evenings since, JOHN COMMERFORD, Esq., in the Chair. The Committee appointed at the last meeting to confer with similar Union organizations reported, through IRA B. DAVIS, their Chairman, that the organizations assembled at JOHN LIVINGSTON'S office had refused to unite with their movement, on the ground that the call of the Conference had reference only to the Tax-payers. St. Nicholas, Fifth-avenue and Twenty-third-street Union organizations; that the German Union League had agreed to adopt their resolutions as their platform, the report recommended the making of separate nominations, which, after some discussion was adopted. The Committee on Ward Organization reported that Associations had been established in the Fourth, Sixth, Eighth, Tenth, Fourteenth, Seventeenth. Eighteenth and Twentieth Wards, and several thousand copies of the prospectus of the organization had been printed, and upward of twenty-seven hundred signatures obtained.

abstract: -- English papers announce the death of Mr. LOFTUS OTWAY, at one time the British Plenipotentiary in Mexico. His decease is quite unreservedly ascribed to a broken-heart, the vulgar synonym of disappointed passion and mortified vanity. In England, the diplomatic corps is a close corporation. Its honors are conferred with strict regard to seniority and precedence; the Government very rarely indeed stepping outside the profession, or violating the regular order of promotion, in making diplomatic appointments. Mr. OTWAY, after arduous service, had attained the elevated rank of Minister Plenipotentiary. His next step was a transfer to a Court of higher importance, and then were to come, in proper time, an ambassadorship, a retiring pension, a peerage, and perhaps a garter. Most unhappily, Mr. OTWAY missed all these splendid rewards of the profession. His mismanagement of British interests in Mexico destroyed him. Influenced by his wife, a Spanish lady and a devoted Roman Catholic, and by DE GABRIAC, the French resident, equally strong in his religious partialities, Mr. OTWAY gave himself wholly to the interests of the clerical reactionary party, intrigued for it, aided it with money and counsel, disregarded entirely the obligations of neutrality and the demands of British subjects for protection or redress, and refused even to protest, when several of them were pitilessly butchered by his friends at Tacubaya. And worse than all, he so grossly misrepresented the nature of the issue between the contending parties, and so blinded and prejudiced the Foreign Office in London as to Mexican affairs generally, that his dishonest partisanship is still bearing fruit in a proposed hostile expedition and forcible intervention.
lead_paragraph: -- English papers announce the death of Mr. LOFTUS OTWAY, at one time the British Plenipotentiary in Mexico. His decease is quite unreservedly ascribed to a broken-heart, the vulgar synonym of disappointed passion and mortified vanity. In England, the diplomatic corps is a close corporation. Its honors are conferred with strict regard to seniority and precedence; the Government very rarely indeed stepping outside the profession, or violating the regular order of promotion, in making diplomatic appointments. Mr. OTWAY, after arduous service, had attained the elevated rank of Minister Plenipotentiary. His next step was a transfer to a Court of higher importance, and then were to come, in proper time, an ambassadorship, a retiring pension, a peerage, and perhaps a garter. Most unhappily, Mr. OTWAY missed all these splendid rewards of the profession. His mismanagement of British interests in Mexico destroyed him. Influenced by his wife, a Spanish lady and a devoted Roman Catholic, and by DE GABRIAC, the French resident, equally strong in his religious partialities, Mr. OTWAY gave himself wholly to the interests of the clerical reactionary party, intrigued for it, aided it with money and counsel, disregarded entirely the obligations of neutrality and the demands of British subjects for protection or redress, and refused even to protest, when several of them were pitilessly butchered by his friends at Tacubaya. And worse than all, he so grossly misrepresented the nature of the issue between the contending parties, and so blinded and prejudiced the Foreign Office in London as to Mexican affairs generally, that his dishonest partisanship is still bearing fruit in a proposed hostile expedition and forcible intervention.

abstract: Reports from the rebel army tell us that the influence of those few Northern newspapers which find their way among the soldiers is found to be very prejudicial to their efficiency, and that the officers complain that...
lead_paragraph: Reports from the rebel army tell us that the influence of those few Northern newspapers which find their way among the soldiers is found to be very prejudicial to their efficiency, and that the officers complain that their presence tends to "promote cowardice" among the troops. We can readily understand that this must be so. The logical faculty cannot be entirely blotted out of the minds of the rebels, though it would indeed seem as if its working had been suspended for a time, and the old influence which Northern newspapers have had with them in days that are past, cannot have been entirely destroyed. And so, when they read in the columns of Northern papers of the state of feeling among us, of the settled determination to preserve the Union unbroken, and of the power that is cheerfully committed to the Government by the people for the accomplishment of that purpose; when they contrast the state of things here with that which exists throughout the Southern States -- the abundant means poured into the lap of the National Government, with the desperate shifts of the Confederate Treasury; the revival of business among us with its destruction at the South; the general prosperity which exists throughout the North, in spite of the heavy burdens of the war, with the ruin which menaces the Southern States, of which a token stares them in the face as they contrast the diminished sheets and dingy paper of the Southern newspapers with the sheets, white and sightly as of old, of the Northern paper which has been smuggled in among them; when they consider all these things, how can it be but that the soldier shall ask himself what has brought about all this difference, and what it is that he is fighting for. And if he gets no satisfactory answer to these questionings, what wonder if he somewhat loses heart under the discomforts of his camp life, and losing heart, shows what his officer calls cowardice, but which is really the uprising of reason and common sense.

abstract: We are indebted to our London namesake for the publication of a very remarkable document. It is a circular, addressed by the "Chamber of Commerce of Atlanta, Georgia," to the Chamber of Commerce of London, England.
lead_paragraph: We are indebted to our London namesake for the publication of a very remarkable document. It is a circular, addressed by the "Chamber of Commerce of Atlanta, Georgia," to the Chamber of Commerce of London, England. What that august body of Southern commercial philosophers think and desire is sufficiently set forth in the single sentence forming the exordium of this grand, gloomy and peculiar document.

abstract: The second of Mr. ULLMAN'S Benefits will take place to-night at the Academy of Music, when VERDI'S "Ballo en Maschera" will be played for the last time. There will be no other operatic performance in the City until Monday next, the occasion of Mr. ULLMAN'S third benefit, which will close the brief series.
lead_paragraph: The second of Mr. ULLMAN'S Benefits will take place to-night at the Academy of Music, when VERDI'S "Ballo en Maschera" will be played for the last time. There will be no other operatic performance in the City until Monday next, the occasion of Mr. ULLMAN'S third benefit, which will close the brief series. During the past week, Mr. HERRMANN has been delighting our Brooklyn friends. His soirees at the Academy of Music were crowded. The prestidigitator's regular season has come to an end, but two additional performances will be given in Fourteenth-street during the present week. The first of these is for the benefit of Madame HERRMANN, and will take place to-morrow-night. In addition to a number of new tricks by the prestidigitator, there will be a grand concert in which CARLOTTA PATTI will sing. Madame HERRMANN will also, on this occasion, make her debut as a pianist.

abstract: We have at no time given credence to the report that the rebel Gen. PRICE, of Missouri, with his entire army, was making a precipitate retreat out of the State, after his evacuation of Lexington.
lead_paragraph: We have at no time given credence to the report that the rebel Gen. PRICE, of Missouri, with his entire army, was making a precipitate retreat out of the State, after his evacuation of Lexington. On the contrary, we gave to that rebel leader credit for military strategy and a moral power among his secession followers, that would render him a formidable opponent to FREMONT, or to any General that the National Government might send against him. Our views seem to be confirmed by the news that we now have from the West. It is said that FREMONT believes, from the evidence before him, that PRICE has "retraced his steps," (after having crossed the Osage,) and will wait and give him battle on the banks of that stream.

abstract: The Herald had a moment of candor the other day, and very frankly avowed the general principle on which it is conducted. In speaking of one of the correspondents of the London newspapers in this country, it said that "when he was impertinent, malicious, inventive and slanderous, he was at least readable.
lead_paragraph: The Herald had a moment of candor the other day, and very frankly avowed the general principle on which it is conducted. In speaking of one of the correspondents of the London newspapers in this country, it said that "when he was impertinent, malicious, inventive and slanderous, he was at least readable. The general public," adds the Herald, "LIKES A LIE, WELL TOLD." There certainly can be no higher authority as to the taste of the "general public" on this point than the Herald. It has been experimenting now for thirty years upon this matter, and ought to know precisely what the public does like in this way.

abstract: STABBING AFFAIR. Late on Saturday evening a man named JAMES WABLETON was arrested on a charge of committing a violent assault and battery, and stabbing a woman named ANN JONES, residing on Railroad-avenue, Jersey City. The wound was not of a very serious nature. The difficulty grew out of drinking. WABLETON was locked up for examination.
lead_paragraph: STABBING AFFAIR. -- Late on Saturday evening a man named JAMES WABLETON was arrested on a charge of committing a violent assault and battery, and stabbing a woman named ANN JONES, residing on Railroad-avenue, Jersey City. abstract: Recruiting for the regular army has been more than usually unsuccessful during the past week. If the recruiting returns might be considered reliable data, we should have no hesitation in concluding that all the men have gone to the war.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the regular army has been more than usually unsuccessful during the past week. If the recruiting returns might be considered reliable data, we should have no hesitation in concluding that all the men have gone to the war. The general service offices in Hudson-street, Chatham-street, and Cedar-street, and the Twelfth Infantry office in Chatham-street, booked two men last week. There were actually no applicants at some of the rendezvous, not even unacceptable applicants. About twenty boys were enlisted for the field-music corps on Governor's Island, and twelve or fourteen sent there on trial; but not a single man.

abstract: The correspondence between the Secretary of State and Lord LYONS, in reference to arrests and imprisonment of British subjects, is most timely, and is calculated to exert the...
lead_paragraph: The correspondence between the Secretary of State and Lord LYONS, in reference to arrests and imprisonment of British subjects, is most timely, and is calculated to exert the most happy influence, not only over the public mind of this country, but in maintaining the existing harmony of our relations with all European powers; for the letter of Mr. SEWARD exhausts the whole subject it discusses; places the action of our Government on grounds entirely unassailable, and is in effect addressed to every foreign court. The courteousness of tone on both sides will tend to relieve any apprehension our people might entertain, in this emergency, of unwelcome interference on the part of Great Britain. The letter of Mr. SEWARD, both in its spirit, and in the facts it states, must be a satisfactory answer to the remonstrance, while in its tone and argument it has greatly the advantage of the British Minister. It shows that not the slightest ground of complaint existed; that the persons temporarily imprisoned were arrested in a strictly regular manner, upon sufficient reason, and were discharged as soon as their cases could be inquired into. At the time of their arrests our Government had no knowledge whatever of their being British subjects, and only applied to them the regime to which every American citizen, violating our laws or incurring reasonable suspicion, may be subject.

abstract: The new Catholic Church of St. Andrew, of which Rev. Father CURRAN is pastor, with Rev. Father CONRON as assistant, was solemnly dedicated yesterday. In a literal sense, the church is not new. It is only a renovation. Every one in the habit of passing the corner of Duane-street and City Hall-place, a year or more ago, must have remarked a dingy-looking edifice, of most unprepossessing exterior, which bore testimony to its use only by the cross which rose above its gable.

abstract: MORTALITY. There were 119 deaths in this city last week, classified as follows: Men, 27; women, 18; boys, 45; girls, 29; Adults, 45; children, 74. Males, 72; females, 47. Colored persons, 1.
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY. -- There were 119 deaths in this city last week, classified as follows: Men, 27; women, 18; boys, 45; girls, 29; Adults, 45; children, 74. Males, 72; females, 47. Colored persons, 1. Diseases. -- Bleeding from the navel, bronchitis, constipation of bowels, convulsions, (puerperal,) delirium tremens, diarrhaea, dropsy, dropsy in head, dropsy in heart, epilepsy, erysipelas, nervous fever, disease of heart, inflammation of bowels, inflammation of stomach, marasmus, (adult,) rheumatism, suffocation, one each. Asphyxia, bleeding from lungs, burned, congestion of lungs, dysentery, congestive fever, inflammation of brain, inflammation of lungs, scrofula, softening of the brain, suicide, two each. Scarlet fever, three. Congestion of the brain, remittent fever, typhoid fever, small pox, four each. Cancer, croup, debility, (infantile,) premature birth, five each. Hydrocephalus, marasmus, (infantile,) six each. Convulsions, (infantile,) 10. Consumption, 13. Sixty-five of the one hundred and nineteen were five years old and under, and eighty-five were natives of the United States. The deaths occurred in the several wards as follows: First Ward, 5; Second Ward, 3; Fourth Ward, 4; Fifth Ward, 9; Sixth Ward, 7; Seventh Ward, 7; Eighth Ward, 1; Ninth Ward, 8; Tenth Ward, 10; Eleventh Ward, 12; Twelfth Ward, 6; Thirteenth Ward, 10; Fourteenth Ward, 11; Fifteenth Ward, 4; Sixteenth Ward, 13; Seventeenth Ward, 3; Eighteenth Ward, 9; Nineteenth Ward, 4.

abstract: organizations which profess to aim at a common object the rigorous prosecution of the war and a purification of our political machinery, seem to be making some progress towards a union of their forces; but they have yet a good deal to do if they hope for success.
lead_paragraph: organizations which profess to aim at a common object -- the rigorous prosecution of the war and a purification of our political machinery, seem to be making some progress towards a union of their forces; but they have yet a good deal to do if they hope for success. The old parties cling with a tenacity which seems unaccountable to their distinctive organizations, and evince as little inclination to surrender personal preferences as if they were certain of success by their own unaided efforts. They must act upon a wiser estimate of circumstances if they hope to maintain themselves either now or in the future. No matter what the leaders of old parties may think,--the old parties themselves are substantially dead. They have died with the issues which created them,--and the new issues coming up will create the parties which are to succeed them. The men who act together now will be very likely to act together hereafter,--especially if they come together in a spirit of concession and fair dealing. It will be well for the various parties who are trying each to maintain its own ground without regard to others, to bear this in mind.

abstract: FUNERAL OBSEQUIES OF FATHER CASSIDY.  Nearly forty Catholic priests, and an immense number of the laity, assembled on Saturday at the little church which adjoins the residence of the Catholic pastor of Flatbush, to pay their last tribute of love and esteem to their late young and amiable pastor, Father STEPHEN CASSIDY.
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OBSEQUIES OF FATHER CASSIDY. -- Nearly forty Catholic priests, and an immense number of the laity, assembled on Saturday at the little church which adjoins the residence of the Catholic pastor of Flatbush, to pay their last tribute of love and esteem to their late young and amiable pastor, Father STEPHEN CASSIDY. He was obliged recently to abandon his curacy because of ill-health, incurred in the discharge of his duties, and retired for a time for change of air to the residence of his friend, Rev. CHAS. SLEVIN, of Dover Plains. There, surrounded by some of his most intimate clerical friends, and having received all the consolations and graces which religion can impart, he calmly resigned himself to death. No physical pang marked his parting moments. Right Rev. Bishop LOUGHLIN, of Brooklyn, presided over the funeral ceremonies, and preached the sermon. Father SLEVIN acted as celebrant of the solemn Mass of Requiem, which was said over the remains; Father THOMAS TREANOR acted as Deacon, Father F. MCLOUGHLIN as Sub-Deacon, and Rev. EUGENE CASSIDY -- the namesake, though not the relative of the deceased, and one of the choicest of his friends -- as master of the ceremonies.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Etna, which left Liverpool on the 9th and Queenstown on the 10th inst., with four days' later European news, passed Cape Race on Friday night, and her advices, which are generally unimportant, were briefly given in yesterday's TIMES. The sales of Cotton in the Liverpool market for two days had been thirty thousand bales, at firm prices. In Breadstuffs there was an upward tendency, and Provisions were quiet but steady. The English funds continued rather flat, Consols being quoted at 92 7/8@93.

abstract: When it was pointed out in this journal three weeks ago that the rebels, through their batteries along the Potomac, were rapidly getting control of water-way to the Capital, we were met with the hue and cry of being an alarmist.
lead_paragraph: When it was pointed out in this journal three weeks ago that the rebels, through their batteries along the Potomac, were rapidly getting control of water-way to the Capital, we were met with the hue and cry of being an alarmist. The enemy having quietly completed his work, has commenced felling the trees in front of his operations, and revealed the fact that the entire distance from Quantico Creek to Chopowamsic Creek is literally enfiladed with miles of batteries! It is now beyond question that the Potomac can be effectually closed to our vessels whenever the rebels choose to exercise their power. Transports do, indeed, pass up at night under cover of the darkness or a favoring fog, and our war vessels, sandwiched between a couple of haybarges, manage to escape the raking fire -- such are the humiliating dodges to which we are compelled to resort! Since the attack on the Seminole on Monday last, transit has in great measure stopped, and one hundred vessels are reported lying below the Evansport battery by Occoquan Creek, not daring to pass up without convoy!

abstract: We have repeatedly expressed ourselves in favor of exchanging prisoners with the insurgents. We believe it expedient, and even necessary, without, in the least, carrying along with it the character of an implied acknowledgement of the enemy as a lawful belligerent. Our Government has recently liberated a number of prisoners equal to a number of prisoners liberated by the insurgents; but an entirely new question arises, to which serious attention ought to be directed.

abstract: The People ex rel. Thomas Crimmins et al. vs. Thomas McManus et al. The relators brought their action to set aside the election of the defendants to the office of Trustees of the Nineteenth Ward.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. Thomas Crimmins et al. vs. Thomas McManus et al. -- The relators brought their action to set aside the election of the defendants to the office of Trustees of the Nineteenth Ward. The relators claimed that, by the exclusion of certain ballots cast for them, because of their being headed for "Trustees of Public Schools," Instead of "Trustees of Common Schools," the term of the statute, they were defeated. Also, that certain votes were rejected because they were not indorsed "School Officers, No. 10." Had these been received by the District Canvassers the plaintiffs claim they would have been elected. They further alleged that one of the defendants acted as Inspector of Election in his District, and that his election was thus vitiated. The case was stated in the TIMES fully, May 9, 1861. The following is the opinion of the General Term in the case:

abstract: We publish, rather as a curiosity than from any importance attaching to it, a letter which has been addressed to Gen. FREMONT by a little knot of Englishmen, calling themselves a "Foreign Affairs Committee," and having their headquarters apparently at Sheffield.
lead_paragraph: We publish, rather as a curiosity than from any importance attaching to it, a letter which has been addressed to Gen. FREMONT by a little knot of Englishmen, calling themselves a "Foreign Affairs Committee," and having their headquarters apparently at Sheffield. England is a great country for hobby-riders, and for hobby-riding Committees; and there is this peculiarity about them, that they never abandon a hobby which they have once adopted. We doubt not there are Committees in England still in existence to resist the Jacobinism of the French Revolution, and to crush the ambitious designs of the First NAPOLEON. The Sheffield gentlemen, who have opened a correspondence with Gen. FREMONT, have become afflicted with the Russia-phobia which broke out so violently in the Crimean war, but which is chronic with a considerable body of Her Majesty's subjects. Russia is their bugbear. She is at the bottom of all the evil that is done under the sun. It is against her that all the world must be on its guard. Gen. FREMONT is told by these one-idea men that Russia has marked the American continent "for her prey" -- that "there is not a square foot of the United States which Russia has not coveted, has not marked as her own;" and Gen. FREMONT is looked up to with confidence by the people of Europe as her destined conqueror.

abstract: A volume of sermons is not the book at which the general reader first grasps when an hour of leisure intervenes in his plodding toil, and he desires for the moment to unbend the bow of life, and luxuriate in some sprightly recreation. Sermons heard and sermons read appeal to us under very different circumstances. We read unmoved the same discourse, which, if heard, would stir the soul to its inner depths. This only proves that the ear is the readiest avenue to the soul, and that the preacher who undertakes another approach labors under a decided disadvantage. The dull printed page cannot convey the flashes of inspiration and conviction that fall from the pulpit; the type cannot glow and quicken like the earnest eye, the charm of eloquence fades from the printed words and we at once awake to a sad appreciation of the vast difference between spoken and written logic. Dr. WALKER, the author of the volume before us, is known as one of our most impressive pulpit orators. Less than many others of his profession does he suffer from the publication of his sermons. Their interest does not turn upon rhetoric alone; unlike the productions of many whose names are more prominent in the public mouth, their effectiveness does not depend principally upon trick of voice and gesture. Dr. WALKER is a deep and earnest thinker, and appeals to the intellect as well as to the ear. His words lodge and remain after the tones of the voice that uttered them have faded away. His sermons are especially commendable for their practicality. They touch the plane of every-day life, instead of reaching vaguely after an indefinite something that very few of the multitude can comprehend; and accordingly, we venture to predict that they will be read with an interest which printed sermons do not always command, while they will wield, from the forcible logic which enters into their structure, an influence which printed sermons are seldom destined to attain.

abstract: While it is certainly possible to attach too much importance to the occasional manifestations of Union sentiment in the seceded States, they are nevertheless entitled to very great weight in our judgment of the future.
lead_paragraph: While it is certainly possible to attach too much importance to the occasional manifestations of Union sentiment in the seceded States, they are nevertheless entitled to very great weight in our judgment of the future. Even such facts as that a preacher in a village of South Carolina has lately been denounced as a "Lincolnite at heart" -- or that in a certain locality in Tennessee the Stars and Stripes were the other day defiantly raised -- or that ever since the Hatteras victory the dwellers along the Coast have come to the forts to take the oath of allegiance -- or that we hear of " Union lodges" and secret organizations of loyally throughout the South -- are all noteworthy and prophetic signs. These scattered demonstrations are indications of what will become an immense uprising as soon as the National Government exhibits its power to protect those whose latent loyalty is now cowed and overwhelmed by superior force.

abstract: The Annual Fair of this Society, which has for its especial object the relief of the Roman Catholic poor of the City, commenced, last night, at the City Assembly rooms. The parishes represented are fewer in number this than last year, and comprise those of St. Patrick's, St. Peter's, St. Francis Xavier...
lead_paragraph: The Annual Fair of this Society, which has for its especial object the relief of the Roman Catholic poor of the City, commenced, last night, at the City Assembly rooms. The parishes represented are fewer in number this than last year, and comprise those of St. Patrick's, St. Peter's, St. Francis Xavier the Transfiguration and Nativity. Each church of parish has its respective table, and appropriates the proceeds thereof, while the money taken at the entrance is equally divided among all, the general expense being jointly supported.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors held their regular meeting yesterday, the special business in first order being the appointment of Inspectors and Canvassers of Election. This, however, was postponed until the next meeting. A communication was received from the Commissioners of Police, giving the following estimate of the amount necessary for the year 1862, viz.: General expenses, $39,500; New-York Police,$1,749,912; Brooklyn Police, $217,500 making a total of $2,000,912.

abstract: The rebels have the reporting the naval encounter on the Mississippi in their own hands. For the next fortnight or so they may give it what proportions they please, expanding or contracting them at pleasure. It will be only when some stray vessel returning from the Gulf brings tidings from the National vessels, that the truth will be absolutely reached, and the meed of immortality which posterity shall accord to HOLLINS be determined, with that impartial accuracy, which shall give no leaf of laurel the victor did not fully and honestly earn. The original story is already deprived of much of its splendor. The encounter appears to have been nothing more than an accidental collision in the dark. One of the National vessels, probably at anchor in the stream, was run into by a rebel gunboat drifting in the rapid current, and sunk; some shots were confusedly exchanged, and then the Hollins' squadron fairly turned tail and ran away. Such is the result of an expedition which has been nearly half a year in boastful preparation; and even this will in all likelihood shrink to still less respectable magnitude when the truth gets around the Florida Capes.

abstract: of the Second Precinct, yesterday, arrested a man, who gave his name as JOHN SMITH, for picking the pocket of Mr. OLIVER H.P. BRUSH, of No. 156 West Porty-second-street. It appears that Mr. BRUSH was looking at some engravings in a show-window in Nassau-street, near Fulton, when he felt something suddenly pulling at his vest, and looking around he saw the accused standing behind him with his hand hold of the guard-chain of his gold watch, valued at $100, which he had pulled from the fob, and was about to transfer to his own pocket. Justice WELCH committed the accused in default of $500 bail. The prisoner is said to be an old offender. The Police have his likeness in their gallery, and they pronounce him to be very expert in relieving people of the contents of their pockets.

abstract: MADDEN, a Frenchman, who for several months past has been confined in the Tombs, attempted to commit suicide on Saturday night last, by jumping from the third tier of cells, where he was confined, to the lower floor. His left ankle was fractured very seriously and his right arm broken in two places. He left a letter in his cell, saying that he was tired of a life in the Tombs, and intended to end it by suicide. He was taken to the Penitentiary Hospital for treatment.

abstract: placed on trial, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday, for the murder of JAMES HENRY, on the night of the 27th of May last. The deceased, accused, and other parties, were at the corner of Front and North Ninth-street, on the night in question, all much intoxicated, and before they separated got into a fight, during which HENRY was stabbed several times, and from the effects of one wound in the abdomen he died on the following Wednesday. The case is still on.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen, last evening, after the reference of petitions and resolutions, a report was adopted authorising the Comptroller to purchase a lot in Pike-street, at a price not exceeding $3,000, for Hose Co. No. 1. Mr. BARNEY moved so to amend Rule 40, (in accordance with previous notice,) as that only thirteen votes would be required to suspend the rules, instead of sixteen, as the rule now stands. Mr. ORTON denounced the proposition, as being, in the present condition of the Board, calculated to give to the thirteen the power to rush any kind of business through, leaving the minority of eleven perfectly helpless. Mr. KEECH also opposed the change, which was supported mainly by Mr. BARNEY, and was carried -- ayes 13, noes 10.

abstract: The Enquirer says: "CALVIN HUSON, Esq., one of the civilians captured at the battle of Manassas, died yesterday morning of typhoid fever, at the residence of one of our citizens, to which he was carried several days ago, with the consent of Gen. WINDER, Mr. HUSON had been ill since early in September, and received every necessary attention, not only from the prison authorities, but from Mr. ELY, also a prisoner, whose competitor he was as the Democratic candidate for the United States Congress from the Rochester District.

abstract: The London Times gives way to apprehensions that its Special Correspondent may come to grief at the hands of indignant Americans. The fear is only another evidence of the ignorance which discolors everything which that perspicacious journal has to say of eisatlantic affairs; Mr. RUSSELL has had...
lead_paragraph: The London Times gives way to apprehensions that its Special Correspondent may come to grief at the hands of indignant Americans. The fear is only another evidence of the ignorance which discolors everything which that perspicacious journal has to say of eisatlantic affairs; Mr. RUSSELL has had no reason, we believe, to complain of the slightest act of discourtesy since his arrival in this country, where he has certainly experienced cordial hospitality, the personal appreciation his striking and peculiar talents command, and every conceivable facility for acquiring truthful information for his letters. The only transaction tinged with ill feeling was exhibited in the memorial to which the Times alludes, wherein the attention of the Secretary of State was called to the propriety of restraining the somewhat too liberal disclosure of affairs at Washington contained in these letters; an application made, we have reason to believe, in a humorous spirit; certainly with no more serious design than to caution the Departments at Washington, as well as Mr. RUSSELL, against an excess of frankness, and to mark the supposed discrimination of the authorities in favor of the British correspondent as compared with the American Press. Mr. RUSSELL has passed through half the loyal States since his description of the Bull Run disaster was written, without meeting with an instance, so far as we can learn, of unfriendly or resentful treatment No one, probably, will be more amused with the fears of his employers than the Special Correspondent himself.

abstract: The confused and contradictory rumors which have been circulating in relation to the commander of the army of the West, this morning assume consistency. The Administration has determined to deprive Gen. FREMONT of his command. This decision is not founded upon demonstrated unfitness of the General for the actual duties of the soldier. His courage is undisputed; his ability to lead...
lead_paragraph: The confused and contradictory rumors which have been circulating in relation to the commander of the army of the West, this morning assume consistency. The Administration has determined to deprive Gen. FREMONT of his command. This decision is not founded upon demonstrated unfitness of the General for the actual duties of the soldier. His courage is undisputed; his ability to lead an army into battle and manage it so as to insure victory, is untried. No one indeed will call in question the many frank and gallant qualities which have given a romantic interest to his history, and so strongly attracted the regard of a large portion of the people. But to the General in charge of a large military department, something more than the dash and chivalrous brilliancy of a gay cavalier is needed. Upon the mere military leader must be grafted great administrative ability; an acquaintance with the minutest details of business, and the ability to grasp them all; a keen insight into character, and an inflexible determination to exact honesty, fidelity and economy from all those necessarily intrusted with the conduct of detail. In these necessary qualifications Gen. FREMONT has been found lacking. It is not the Administration which has condemned him. The Congressional Committee, appointed at the extra session, to investigate the character of the army contracts, has sat at St. Louis, and patiently investigated the entire method and result of Gen. FREMONT's administration; and has been obliged to condemn and disapprove it, and to pronounce his unfitness for the position. President LINCOLN' after such an inquest and verdict, has no alternative but to transfer the General to some other theatre, where his purely military capacity may have a chance to prove itself; and to place in his stead a calmer and a more prudent officer, who shall bring to the fulfillment of his duties patience, moderation, and practical business talent. Gen. HUNTER, who probably succeeds Gen. FREMONT, is understood to be thus qualified.

abstract: The reported occupation of Greensburg by the rebels is premature. A small number went there and took twenty mules, which had been placed as contraband in care of Gen. WARD. It is reported that Gen. WARD fell baek twelve miles from Greenburg to Campbellsville. He dispatched 150 cavalry to reconnoiter, intending that they should return yesterday. They had not returned when our informant left. Gen. WARD has about 3,000 troops.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Monday, Oct. 21.

abstract: We spoke yesterday of the probable change of rebel tactics in the West, which will lead the rebel generals to transfer again to Missouri their daring, aggressive enterprises. Their failure to get possession of Louisville, and the tremendous Union rally in that State, have put them on the defensive. They are blowing up the bridges between themselves and the Union armies in Kentucky, thus proving their fear of attack rather than their disposition to advance.
lead_paragraph: We spoke yesterday of the probable change of rebel tactics in the West, which will lead the rebel generals to transfer again to Missouri their daring, aggressive enterprises. Their failure to get possession of Louisville, and the tremendous Union rally in that State, have put them on the defensive. They are blowing up the bridges between themselves and the Union armies in Kentucky, thus proving their fear of attack rather than their disposition to advance. It is very clear that a strong army at Cairo, ready to move down the Mississippi River, cooperating with the immense Union hosts that will soon be prepared to advance southward in Kentucky, would hold Memphis at its mercy, against the most desperate resistance that the Confederate arms in that quarter could make.

abstract: The Pensacola Observer was received on the 11th inst., at Augusta, Ga. A dispatch says: "The Observer contains the correspondence between Col. BROWN, in command at Fort Pickens, and Gen. BRAGG, commander of the Confederate forces at Pensacola, relative to the hospital at the Navy-yard. Col. BROWN says he notices a large yellow flag on the building in the line of his batteries, and says it may be used as a protection for the Confederate troops; and gives notice to Gen. BRAGG to have all the women, children and sick removed.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer positively contradicts the statement heretofore received through the Southern papers, that the steamer Nashville had run the blockade at Charleston, and sailed to Europe with Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL as Ministers from the Confederate States to England and France. The Enquirer says that the Nashville is still in Charleston harbor, and that she is not the vessel on which Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL sailed -- by which it is implied that these gentlemen are nevertheless off to Europe.

abstract: When a very alarming account was published a few days since, of the extent of rebel batteries erected on the Potomac, a reassuring dispatch was sent out from Washington, that vessels loading for that point need not be frightened out of their trips, inasmuch as "convoys" would be furnished of Government steamers, to accompany them through the perils of the Potomac.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Alderman FRANKS in the chair. A communication from the Chief Engineer of the Western District Fire Department, asking for 8,000 from hose, was together with a similar application from...
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Alderman FRANKS in the chair. The grading and paving of Willoughby-street, from Graham-street to Classon-avenue, was accepted. A communication from the Chief Engineer of the Western District Fire Department, asking for 8,000 from hose, was together with a similar application from the Eastern District Department, for 4,000 feet of hose, referred to the Joint Fire Department Committee, with authority to purchase the same if, in their opinion, it is necessary. An extension of forty days was granted Mr. BRADSHAW, in which to complete his contract for regrading Fifth and Sixth avenues, Wyckoff and other streets in that vicinity. The matter of permitting the Brooklyn City Railroad Company to pave a portion of Hamilton-avenue, between Smith-street and Third-avenue, was referred to the Railroad Committee. The Mayor returned, without his approval, the resolution adopted on the 7th inst., directing the Comptroller to enter into contract with JAMES RODWELL for building a house for Hose Company No. 7, E.D., for the principal reason that there is no money in the Treasury for that purpose. A communication was received from Brig.-Gen. CROOKE, giving notice of the death of Col. ABEL SMITH, whereupon Alderman S. TAYLOR offered the following resolutions:

lead_paragraph: An interesting meeting of Chaplains of the regiments stationed near the Capital, and of those interested in the religious welfare of the soldiers, was held in Rev. Dr. BUTLER's Church, in Washington, on Oct. 19. Rev. C.P. McILVAINE presided, and preliminary steps were taken for effecting a more thorougtr organization of the modes of supplying religious reading and other Christian aid to the army and navy. It was proposed to effect a combination of the Chaplains, and to institute a commission at Washington to accomplish the desired end systematically and effectually.

abstract: THE SLAVER MARY FRANCIS. -- The examination in the case of JOHN A. MACHADO, charged with fitting out the Mary Francis and other slavers from this port, was resumed, yesterday, before Commissioner OSBORNE. John A. DOWDALD, the mate of the Mary Francis, and two or three others of her crew, were examined in relation to MACHADO's connection with the vessel, but nothing was elicited tending to establish the fact of his legal responsibility for her fitting out as a slaver, or that he had any connection with her while she remained in this port. A certain mysterious lady, named Mrs. WATSON, everywhere intervenes between the accused and all legal responsibility in the case, and the law, having failed to secure Mrs. WATSON, appears likely from the evidence thus far to retain but a slippery hold on MACHADO. The examination will be continued to-day.
lead_paragraph: THE SLAVER MARY FRANCIS. -- The examination in the case of JOHN A. abstract: In order that the citizens of Denver might not be behind the rest of the world in dramatic amusements, a number of mechanics, last Spring, associated together, under the name of "The Platte Valley Theatre Company," and immediately commenced building a temple of Thespis. The main building is 50 by 100 feet, besides a green-room and ladies' dressing-room. It has a dress-circle, parquette and gallery, and altogether will seat 1,500 persons. The entire stage room is 30 feet deep and height of proscenium 18 feet; ventilating and heating arrangements perfect. The interior is being finished with taste and elegance. Mr. MURPHY is to be the theatrical manager, and will open it in about two weeks, with a good Eastern company. They are engaged for a season of thirteen weeks. INAUGURAL ADDRESS OF GOV. CONNELLY, OF NEW-

abstract: Theimportant case of JACOB SHARP against the Corporation has resulted in a verdict of $49,502 for the plaintiff. No time could be more inopportune for so heavy a draft on the Treasury; and, in fact, at no time should the neglect of the corporate authorities have exposed the Treasury to so formidable a fine for their reckless administration of our municipal affairs. The case made by SHARP was extremely simple. Having leased from the City the necessary frontage on the East River, he proceeded to construct the slips and ferry-houses for the new Wall-street Ferry. He completed these preliminaries at a serious cost, and was about to enter upon the enjoyment of the resulting profit, when one-half of the ground he had leased was claimed by a private owner, and the claim, upon investigation, proving valid, Mr. SHARP turned to the City for damages, in having conveyed to him an interest where it had no title. His claim was, some time ago, submitted to a referee, who made an award substantially the same, with the interest added, as the present verdict. Thus, because of the carelessness of the Common Council, the overburdened taxpayer must see this pretty figure of $50,000 in the next tax-levy, and must bear, as well as he may, the penalty of negligent legislation.

abstract: The most important intelligence, this morning, is from the Upper Potomac. It appears that yesterday morning, about one o'clock, five companies of the Fifteenth Massachusetts Regiment crossed the river at Harrison's Island, some distance aboce Edwards' Ferry, and at daybreak had proceeded to within a mile and a half of Leesburgh without meeting the enemy. They were subsequently encountered, however, and the Massachusetts men were reinforced by the remainder...
lead_paragraph: The most important intelligence, this morning, is from the Upper Potomac. It appears that yesterday morning, about one o'clock, five companies of the Fifteenth Massachusetts Regiment crossed the river at Harrison's Island, some distance aboce Edwards' Ferry, and at daybreak had proceeded to within a mile and a half of Leesburgh without meeting the enemy. They were subsequently encountered, however, and the Massachusetts men were reinforced by the remainder of the regiment, and by a part of the Twentieth, but the rebel force was much superior, and our troops were ultimately driven back. Col. BAKER, it will be seen, was killed while gallantly leading his regiment, which threw his command into confusion, and caused the retreat. A crossing was also made at Edwards' Ferry, and our troops now occupy the Virginia side. A cavalry reconnoissance was made from there in the morning, in the direction of Leesburgh, and the Fourteenth Mississippi regiment was encountered, but without loss to our troops.

abstract: At a regular meeting of this Board last evening, Ald. FREAR in the Chair, Mr. CORNELL moved that the report of the Committee on National Affairs, in relation to the appointment of Allotment Commissioner to disburse the soldiers' funds, a portion of which (appointing Mr. A.V. Stout as said Commissioner) was adopted at the last meeting, be reconsidered, and the whole subject referred back to the Committee.
lead_paragraph: At a regular meeting of this Board last evening, Ald. FREAR in the Chair, Mr. CORNELL moved that the report of the Committee on National Affairs, in relation to the appointment of Allotment Commissioner to disburse the soldiers' funds, a portion of which (appointing Mr. A.V. Stout as said Commissioner) was adopted at the last meeting, be reconsidered, and the whole subject referred back to the Committee. Mr. CORNELL said that, from certain facts that had come to his knowledge since the last meeting of the Board, he was convinced that the disbursement of said funds should be made by the City authorities. The motion to reconsider and refer back was carried without debate.

abstract: We cannot imagine why Mr. EAGAN did not continue the aliases of his story to infinity. The title might have been made much longer and more optional. To Lady Maud, the Wonder of Kingswood Chace; or, Earl Gower; or, The Secret Marriage he might have added, or the Phantom and the Heir; or, the Doom of the House of Kingswood; or, the Mystery and the Forest; or, the Power of Love in a Silver Horn, or any other thing sonorous and suggestive. But Mr. EAGAN, in his baptismal paroxysm, thought proper to stop short this side of infinity, and for this let us be properly thankful, without puzzling to determine why he did not go on. The author of Lady Maud stands forth as the representative of melodramatic literature, -- on his shoulders the mantle of Mrs. RADCLIFFE has fallen and seems determined to rest. The scenes of his stories are always laid in haunted castles, in tangled copses, or among ruins; his heroes and heroines are always discovered by their resemblance to ghostly portraits hanging in old halls, they rustle among dusty drapery, and remember scraps of feudal ballads that old nurses crooned over their cradles. But Mr. EAGAN is always just if not generous. Rightful heirs come by their own; true lovers are rewarded with a greater guerdon than virtue in real life ever asks or expects; false lovers are visited with a vengeance that would singularly confuse society if our courts should choose to emulate Mr. EAGAN. Faithful to the true instincts of the novelist, Mr. EAGAN couples deformity and depravity together; ugliness and sin are in his estimation inseperable companions. He would undoubtedly pronounce it as an axiom that he who squints will steal. But, after all, these peculiarities of our novelist can do no lasting harm. His youthful readers will very soon find that obliquity of vision is not always accompanied by obliquity of morals, and that a man with a crooked spine can walk quite as erectly in Virtue's path as any one else. And while they shake their little fists at imaginary villains who never comb their hair and seldom change their linen, they themselves will be very apt to scrupulously attend to these little obligations of civilization, for morality's as well as for cleanliness' sake.

abstract: A Cabinet meeting in reference to the case of Gen. FREMONT was held yesterday, at which, our correspondent assures us, it was decided not to interfere for the present with Gen. FREMONT in his command. Meantime, however, Judge DAVIS, of Illinois, has been commissioned to take testimony in reference to the contracts made in the Western Department, and it is understood that whatever bills he may pass will be paid.
lead_paragraph: A Cabinet meeting in reference to the case of Gen. FREMONT was held yesterday, at which, our correspondent assures us, it was decided not to interfere for the present with Gen. abstract: Action of some sort must soon take place on the Potomac. The position of the two armies, the approach of cold weather, the spirit of our men, and the impatience of the public mind, combine to render necessary some active and vigorous measures towards prosecuting the war.
lead_paragraph: Action of some sort must soon take place on the Potomac. The position of the two armies, the approach of cold weather, the spirit of our men, and the impatience of the public mind, combine to render necessary some active and vigorous measures towards prosecuting the war. Our people are not satisfied with a defensive position. It is not enough that we hold Washington: -- we must strike a blow at the rebels. We must redeem the defeat and disgrace of Bull Run. We must relieve the Potomac, and break the strength of the army which threatens us from its banks. One thorough defeat of the forces the enemy has gathered there would shatter the disjointed fabric of their Government, and go far towards precipitating their ruin.
headline: {'main': 'Our Army on the Potomac.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Army on the Potomac.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A memorial has been presented to Mr. SEWARD' the Secretary of State, with a view to prevent our correspondent continuing to send letters from the Union.
lead_paragraph: A memorial has been presented to Mr. SEWARD' the Secretary of State, with a view to prevent our correspondent continuing to send letters from the Union. This document represents one of his communications to contain "treasonable matter," and declares the conviction of the memoralists that "it is the design of the writer to bring the credit and fame of this Government into disrepute in foreign countries." For such passages it is easy to judge what amount of common sense belonged to the framers and signers of the memorial. That an English writer should wish to bring the American Government into disrepute is, perhaps, an idea which might enter the minds of the most ignorant and angry citizens, but that the evil could be remedied by declaring unfreindly comments to be treasonable and ejecting the writer from the country could be the fancy only of men from whose minds passion had driven out all power of judgment. The reply of Mr. SEWARD is in substance sensible enough, though there is an evident under-current of spite, directed against English opinion in general, and the Times newspaper in particular. The politician who a few months since was for conquering Canada to make up for the loss of the South, which in his opinion it would be preposterous to attempt to coerce by war, is now as intolerant of all difference from his new creed as the memorialists themselves, though his common sense forces him to reject their application. The usual official style of "not having read," and being "engrossed with public cares and duties," is assumed, after the fashion of the politicians of Europe, but the accusations of "libel," of "Perverting hospitality," and "writing injurious publications," is in accordance with the spirit of the American memorialists. However, Mr. WARD comes to the proper conclusion, that there is no reason for interference, and so far we must thank him for a just exercise of his judgment.

abstract: The New-York Herald is actually bursting with anxiety to see our Government involved in a war with England. It has labored in this cause for months, and as the hope of success fades, it gets actually raving for a foreign fight. It is quite apparent to the Herald and the rest of the world, that the United States Government has its hands full trying to reestablish its authority over the seceded States.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Herald is actually bursting with anxiety to see our Government involved in a war with England. It has labored in this cause for months, and as the hope of success fades, it gets actually raving for a foreign fight. It is quite apparent to the Herald and the rest of the world, that the United States Government has its hands full trying to reestablish its authority over the seceded States War with the second military power in the world, (the first in its ability to assail us,) occurring in conjunction with the Southern rebellion, might break down the American Union completely, or at all events postpone for twenty years its reassertion of control over the territory of the South. Hence the Herald craves a war with England, writes for it, bullies for it, begs for it, lies for it.

abstract: Below we give the quotations at the New-York Stock Exchange for the shares of the leading Banks in the City of New-York, as they were on the 19th of October for three years past. It will be seen that the range of present prices is on an average fully 20 cent. below that for 1860 and 1859. The real value of the Bank Stocks in this city cannot, we are confident, be much less than it was in 1859, nor more than 10 cent. less than in 1860. It is the opinion of those having the best opportunities for knowing that 10 cent, is an ample guarantee for all the losses sustained by the recent crisis. If so, the prices of shares are excessively depreciated. The Banks are now in a very prosperous condition, and in the Government loan have all the paper they need at a very high rate of interest. The aid they have extended to Government is calculated to greatly strengthen their customers and the public generally. Attention has only to be turned towards these institutions to cause a large advance in their shares.

abstract: FALL OF A BUILDING ONE PERSON KILLED  SEVERAL OTHERS INJURED. At about 11  o'clock yesterday morning,the roof of a three-story brick building on Furman, near Fulton-street, fell with a heavy crash, killing instantly one person, and seriously injuring three others. The front of the building has been down for some time, leaving the partitions and rear wall in a very dangerous condition. The property is in litigation, and no one therefore seems to ...
lead_paragraph: FALL OF A BUILDING ONE PERSON KILLED SEVERAL OTHERS INJURED. At about 11 o'clock yesterday morning,the roof of a three-story brick building on Furman, near Fulton-street, fell with a heavy crash, killing instantly one person, and seriously injuring three others. The front of the building has been down for some time, leaving the partitions and rear wall in a very dangerous condition. The property is in litigation, and no one therefore seems to have had any care of it, for children have been permitted to carry off the wookwork until the weight of the roof brought the whole structure to the ground. When it fell there were four persons gathering wood on the premises, viz.; JAMES LEDDY, a boy, who was instantly killed; HENRY PRITCHARD had one leg broken; EDWARD MCLAUGHLIN was fatally injured, it is supposed, and Mrs. DUFFY was also severely injured, but, notwithstanding her injuries, she clung all the while to an armful of wood she had gathered. Messrs. TAPSCOTT & CO. formerly occupied the premises. Coroner HUTON, took charge of the body of young LEDDY, and will give the case a thorough investigation. LEDDY's parents reside at No. 5 Doughty-street; MCLAUGHLIN lives at No. 6 Columbia-street, and PRITCHARD, at No. 66 Portland-avenue.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mme. HERRMANN who has contributed so charmingly to the enjoyability of Mr. HERRMANN'S soirees will take her benefit here tonight. It is rightly made a special occasion by the management, and will, we hope, be remembered as such by the public.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mme. HERRMANN who has contributed so charmingly to the enjoyability of Mr. HERRMANN'S soirees will take her benefit here tonight. It is rightly made a special occasion by the management, and will, we hope, be remembered as such by the public. There will be a grand concert, in which Miss CARLOTTA PATTI will appear. Mme. HERRMANN herself will also, on this occasion, make her debut as a musical artiste -- playing the piano part of a duet with Mr. THOMAS, the violinist. The prestidigitatorial character of the entertainment will be preserved by Mr. HERRMANN, who, in addition to his usual budget of wonders, will introduce four entirely new tricks.
