abstract: The ruling caste in England give law and public opinion to that country. The newspaper press there is only its mouthpiece. This class and press have been constant in their assertions that the rebellion in this country could not be put down. In this way they have contributed more than all other causes to give courage and persistency to it.
lead_paragraph: The ruling caste in England give law and public opinion to that country. The newspaper press there is only its mouthpiece. This class and press have been constant in their assertions that the rebellion in this country could not be put down. In this way they have contributed more than all other causes to give courage and persistency to it. It was this assumption of its strength that led the British Government to recognize the rebels us belligerents. The ruling classes in that country professed an indifference to the result which men affect, when they expect soon to see it, by the natural course of events, turn in their favor. They readily acknowledged the blockade under a belief that it would be speedily ended by our inability to maintain it. The quarrel they asserted was purely a local one, not concerning them, and of which they chose to remain passive spectators, under the idea, apparently, that whichever way it might turn, they certainly would not be the losers.

abstract: We record the arrival of four steamers from Europe this morning -- the Etna at this port, the North Briton at Father Point, and the Teutonia and the Africa off Cape Race. The latter brings advices to Sunday afternoon, the 13th inst., three days later than were previously received. The Liverpool cotton market is reported to be considerably excited, and during the week there had been an advance of 1/4d.@3/8d. on all qualities. The market closed firm. Breadstuffs are also reported firm, while provisions were dull. The latest quotations for consols was 92 3/4 for money. The Paris Bourse is weak. It is reported that the loss of cash during the month, in the Bank of France, has been 81,000,000f. The Prince NAPOLEON had reached Brest, on his return from America. The political news from the Continent is of no particular significance.

abstract: So long as the insurrection of the South seemed a spiteful rebellion against the results of a particular election we were compelled to regard it as utterly unjustifiable. If it meant only, as has been asserted, "bullet" against "ballot," we should look upon it as a wicked and treasonable act; for never could the North be charged, notwithstanding its commercial bias, with a want of consideration for the institutions of the South. If, again, the question could be argued on pure grounds of expediency, we should here also, though not so decidedly, pronounce against the resolution taken by the South to divorce itself from the North. But the actual case is very different. The last twelve months have shown that Northerners and Southerners are as irreconcilable as Greeks and Turks, or Germans and Magyars. This war will but intensify and perpetuate animosities which the very nature of things had long ago created. "Sectional" antipathies have proved as stubborn as national antipathies. They could not be assuaged by compromise, and they will assuredly not be abolished by conquest. The armies of the North may overpower the armies of the South, but South and North can never be expected to amalgamate again. It is for this reason, and because territories so prodigious as those of the Southern States can never be retained by armed occupation, that we think the policy of the Federal Government wrong. If the whole case of the war is to be analyzed, we must needs say the Northerners have the right on their side, for the Southerners have destroyed, without provocation, a mighty political fabric, and have impaired the glory and strength of the great American Republic. But, as they have chosen to do this, as they have shown themselves hitherto no less powerful than their antagonists, as the decision of so large a population cannot be contemned, and as we cannot persuade ourselves that a genuine peace is likely to spring from protracted war, we should rejoice to see the pacification of America promoted by other means.

abstract: The New-Orleans Picayune of the 12th, editorially contratulates its readers on the success of HOLLINS' flotilla on the Mississippi, and particularly the exploit of the Manassas. It urges the Southern people to be prepared to drive the Northern invaders from their ports and coasts at every sacrifice and exertion.

abstract: The difference between the Northern and Southern practice of repudiation in America is considerable, although the result to the bondholder is the same. Mississippi prefers a bold, Michigan a covert course. When Col. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in the Legislative Hall that had been built with foreign money, laughed at the "crocodile tears" of those who had been so foolish as to lend it, there was no attempt at sophistry. Mississippi intended to repudiate, and manifested her chivalrous pride in an open avowal of the fact. Michigan, on the contrary, resorts to subterfuges, and professes herself the victim of false accusations. She repudiates, and tries to cover her shame by fresh delinquencies. In a recent number of a leading New-York journal, the fraud practised by Michigan on her creditors is described as a "difficulty" about which "financial opinion has differed on both sides of the Atlantic ever since the original default occurred;" and a letter is inserted from Mr. JAMES F. JOY, who is mentioned as a well-known legal authority at Detroit, to prove that London capitalists are altogether wrong in classing Michigan with Mississippi as a repudiating State. But the statements of Mr. JOY, notwithstanding his rank as a legal authority in Michigan, are all erroneous. The bonds were issued by the State of Michigan to the Bank of the United States, and were to be paid for by that establishment in four half-yearly instalments. Only the first of these was met when the bank failed, but previously to that event the bank, through its agent, Mr. JAUDON, had negotiated the bonds in Europe at the price of 85 to the following houses, namely: Messsrs. DENISON & CO., of London, $900,000; Messrs. ROTHSCHILD, of Paris, $1,431,000, and Messrs. HOPE & CO., of Amsterdam, $1,252,000, the total being $3,583,000, or L716,000. Subsequently the State repudiated all liability on these bonds except for the small sum she had received from the Bank of the United States, and even in that case she proposed to deduct 25 per cent. "damages." Five years after the original default she offered the pittance in question, and reduced her claim for damages from 25 to 3 per cent. This proceeding was accompanied by a solemn declaration on the part of the State that she would pay no more, and some of the individuals to whom the bonds had passed, and who had been exposed to great suffering, were compelled to accept the amount and to content themselves with a formal denunciation of the iniquity that had been practiced. The version, however, now given by Mr. JAMES F. JOY, and circulated by the New-York journals, is that the amount advanced on the bonds by the European subscribers was less than that which the State of Michigan had received from the Bank of the United States, and that consequently the offer of Michigan amounted to a proposal to return them all the money they had advanced when the bonds were pledged to them. In corroboration Mr. JOY winds up by citing the fact of a large proportion of the creditors having accepted the sum accorded, in proof that they were quite satisfied, although upon application at the Treasury Department he might have been furnished with copies of the protests under which the spoliation was submitted to by a class of sufferers who knew that their debtor was not subject to any legal process, and that the only security they possessed was founded on the "honor and good faith" of the State in its promise to pay "in gold or silver" both principal and interest, with punctuality at New-York. Until the actual circumstances can be blotted from history, or the State shall have made amends, it will be better, therefore, that not only every well-known legal authority of Michigan, but also the New-York admirers of her conduct, should forbear from challenging a reproduction of the narrative. It may be desired just now to create favorable impressions of the financial antecedents of the North in contrast with those of the South, and there is no wish on this side to impede that object; but some regard must be paid to precision, and, looking at the present details, persons may possibly be found to prefer the frank style of Col. JEFFERSON DAVIS in dealing with such questions to the more special course of Mr. JAMES F. JOY.

abstract: It is a singular fact that a large majority of the people of the United States are unacquainted with the great importance of the cause for which the soldiers of the Union are fighting. abstract: The Paris Patrie publishes some details of the death of the Queen of Madagascar, RANAVALO. She had been suffering from a cancerous disease for more than a year, and had submitted to a severe operation; but the disease reappeared three months afterwards, and her European surgeon warned the Royal family that recovery was hopeless. The Queen died on the 18th of August. She had entered her seventieth year. The chief Minister, who was a devoted partisan of the Queen's nephew, RAMBOASALAM, attempted to conceal the fact of her death, in order to gain time to proclaim the nephew as successor to the throne. This was to have been done on the morning of the 19th, but a European, an intimate friend of the Queen's son, the Prince Royal, informed him of the plan. He assembled his adherents secretly during the night, and at daybreak of the 19th, as the Minister and Prince RAMBOASALAM left the Palace to go to the Temple, where the proclamation was to be made, their escort was attacked, and the Minister and the Prince himself were killed in the confusion of the fight that ensued. This event changed the whole state of affairs. The Queen's son was immediately proclaimed King, by the title of RAKOUT-RADAMA I. His first measure was to publish an amnesty, and to cancel the edicts of the late Queen forbidding foreigners to enter the country. This entire change of policy is attributed to French influence.

abstract: There has been a considerable outcry in the North in reference to the means whereby several States have been what is called "forced out of the Union." But it is not to be expected that in the struggle for States between the Confederation and the United States some acts should not be committed by the latter which have very much the look of "forcing them not to go out of the Union."

abstract: The Convention met at the Everett House on Monday evening, according to adjournment. Delegates were present from the People's Union Party, the Fifth-avenue Party, the Tax-payers Party, and the German Union League. Each of these parties was represented by seven delegates. The Convention was presided over by JAMES W. BEEKMAN. The first business of importance was to ascertain what Committees were delegated with full power to act for their organizations. All, excepting the People's Union Committee, represented that their organizations would be bound by the action of the consolidated Committees. The People's Union Committee informed the Convention that they were instructed to report to their General Committee, and although they believed that their action would be indorsed, still the General Committee had reserved the right to repudiate their action, if they deemed that course advisable. This statement produced a lengthy discussion, during which Messrs. PIERREPONT, SWAN and WITTHAUS, of the Fifth-avenue Party, persisted that the People's Union Committee should not be allowed to vote, while Messrs. BEEKMAN and WESENDONK, of the German Committee, and several other members of the Convention, were equally clamorous in urging that the People's Union Committee should be recognized. A vote was finally taken, and all the Committees voted for their expulsion, with the exception of the German Union League. The People's Union Committee then withdrew from the room.

abstract: This Committee held a meeting yesterday. Mr. William H. Arthur, stationer, corner of Liberty and Nassau streets, was the first witness examined. He stated that his books would show the amount of stationery furnished by him to the Commissioners; the accounts were kept in various books comprising the ledger, journal, &c., and it would be necessary to look over them all in order to get a complete list of the items; the dates extend back about one year; he had never made an application to the Commissioners to furnish them with stationery as it was not usual to send in proposals, but it was usually intimated by the Corporation Counsel where supplies could be obtained; he did not know why this course was taken by the Corporation Counsel, but he knew the Comissioners generally met at the office of the Counsel, and it was there decided upon the matter of stationery, posters, &c., and if a Commissioner had a friend whom he wished to patronize, it was made known at that time; the stipulation usually made by the Commissioners was that the supplies should be furnished at the same rates as those exacted from private individuals; the character of the stationery was the same as that furnished to merchants, such as engrossing paper, minute books, ink-stands, pencils, blotting paper, pen-holders, and other small articles; he never furnished gold pens, unless upon a written order from the Commissioners; in one or two instances gold pens had been furnished; a clerk was furnished now and then with a pen-knife, but no charge was made for the same; he usually furnished all the items in the bill rendered, for which he received a draft on the Comptroller.
lead_paragraph: This Committee held a meeting yesterday. Mr. William H. Arthur, stationer, corner of Liberty and Nassau streets, was the first witness examined. abstract: The Guardia-Murillo Convention, by which the State agrees to achnowledge Gen. abstract: The very brilliant success of Col. PLUMMER'S attack upon the rebels at Fredericktown, Mo., adds another proof to the proposition that the loyalists are ever an overmatch for traitors when they meet in anything like equal numbers. The rebels under JEFF. THOMPSON and Col. LOWE, are said to have numbered about 5,000. Col. PLUMMER brought against them about an equal force; and the rebels were utterly routed, being "severely peppered," and taking to the woods pell-mell for safety.

abstract: The Lexington Observer notices the arrival in that city of a battle of refugees from Knox and Lau-rel Counties. Among them was Mr. VANNOY, a clergyman. He states that ZOLLICOFFER'S men took from the stores, groceries and private dwellings everything they desired, but seemed to be more particularly solicitous for clothing, shoes, blankets, and provisions. They also took possession of and drove off all the live stock upon the farms in that country, and many persons had been robbed of all their horses, cattle, sheep and hogs that they possessed. They even went further, and, in the spirit of mere wantonness and brutality, they destroyed what they did not want, even to the clothing of the women and children. He says there are but three of the male inhabitants left in Barboursvile, and they are permitted to remain there in security simply because they are Secessionists. The Union men have all been compelled to fly. He was at Col. GARRARD'S camp last week, and he states that it is daily increasing in numbers, by men from the surrounding counties, but their efficiency as soldiers is rendered unavailable by reason of the inability of Col. GARRARD to supply them with arms.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. When the drama of "The Octoroon" which was revived here last night was produced some two years ago, it came on the heels of a great excitement. The John Brown raid occupied...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. When the drama of "The Octoroon" which was revived here last night was produced some two years ago, it came on the heels of a great excitement. The John Brown raid occupied the attention of the public; the South fulminated its wrath against the North, and the loyal people of the North indignantly protested against the injurious imputation that they sympathized with the mad scheme of the unhappy Abolitionist. In the very phrenzy of this affair, Mr. BOURCICAULT, who never failed to take advantage of a powerfulcotemporaneous event, gave to the public a view of Southern life, extending even to the offensive feature of a slave sale. There was "nothing extenuate, nor aught set down in malice." Moderate people on both sides of the line accepted it as a fair picture of actual events. But the timid and extravagant denounced it as untimely, and there were rumors of an intended interruption of the performance. Now no one can ride out a storm with more graceful ease than Mr. BOURCICAULT, and his face actually beamed with the prospect of having a theatre torn to pieces beneath his eyes. The great public assembled on the 6th of December, 1859, to record its verdict. It heard the story of poor Zoe with tearful attention; ground its awful teeth at the villainies of McCloskey, and triumphed with the triumph of the Yankee Salem Scudder. When the piece came to an end there was a yell of approbation, every one admitted that it was a powerful drama, singularly replete with incident, had been constructed out of forbidden materials, and every one wondered why something of the kind had not been done before. Mr. BOURCICAULT, a baffled man deprived, and, as it were, defrauded of his riot, subsequently took refuge in a congenial law-suit. The papers were filled with the case of the "Octoroon." Since then the piece has assumed the position to which it is eminently entitled, that of being one of the few good standard plays of which the American stage can boast. We recall these circumstances because its revival last night was attended with some of the incidents which marked its production. A few persons were again pleased to regard it as untimely, why, it would be difficult to say. The public, however, reaffirmed its verdict, and we do not hesitate to predict for the piece a prosperous run. It happens, curiously enough, that the week which witnesses its revival here, will, in all probability, see its production in London, it was to have been broughtout at the Adelphi Theatre on Monday last.

abstract: This Cityhas appropriated a large sum of money to the relief of the families of volunteers in the public service. The language of the ordinance is so interpreted, however, as to prevent the distribution of these funds to families until the volunteers are actually in Washington, or whatever other department they may be ordered to. While they are in camp here they can get nothing. We do not see the justice of this distinction. These men are just as much "in the field," and just as completely deprived of all the means of supporting their families, while in camp, as when they reach Washington. It seems only fair that their families should draw their share of these moneys from the day they are mustered into the service of the United States. Such an amendment of the ordinance would afford very great relief to many families and carry into more full effect the real intentions of the City in making the appropriation.

abstract: On Tuesday, thirteen regiments embarked from Annapolis on board steamers, to rendezvous at Fortress Monroe, where they have been joined by an equal force in all numbering about 20,000 men in addition to the naval force required to man and work the ships, which are very likely to play the most important part in the coming events.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, thirteen regiments embarked from Annapolis on board steamers, to rendezvous at Fortress Monroe, where they have been joined by an equal force in all numbering about 20,000 men in addition to the naval force required to man and work the ships, which are very likely to play the most important part in the coming events. The ships-of-war that accompany the expedition are, where they can be brought into action, equal to a land force thrice as great as they can carry. The expedition is under command of able and experienced officers, and is made up principally of regiments from New-England or enlisted from the seaboard in the Middle States, and are selected with peculiar fitness to the campaign to which they have been assigned. It is unquestionably admirably provided in every particular, and great expectations are with good reason indulged as to its success.

abstract: The probability of an early recognition of the Southern Confederacy by France is the leading topic in the latest batch of foreign news. The several Chambers of Commerce in the Empire are said to be busily petitioning the Government to that effect.
lead_paragraph: The probability of an early recognition of the Southern Confederacy by France is the leading topic in the latest batch of foreign news. The several Chambers of Commerce in the Empire are said to be busily petitioning the Government to that effect. The Paris Presse, which, however, has no official, or even semi-official, inspiration, asserts that the mind of the Emperor is definitely fixed upon that policy, and that the time for executing it is not distant. Beyond these rumors, which may or may not be true, we have the unquestionable fact that France is, at this moment, a greater sufferer by the American war than even the United States. A Winter, which promises to be of extraordinary severity, threatens her population; while a deficient harvest has so enhanced the price of breadstuffs, that those ominous clamors for bread, so often constituting the overture of European revolutions, are already making themselves heard in Paris and Lyons, and must be silenced, or danger too great for pre-calculation will ensue. To this clamorous mob, the sudden withdrawal of American cotton, and American custom, is presently to add other multitudes. Southern doggedness and the blockade have shut off the supplies of the indispensable fibre, and the mills of Mulhausen must suspend. The prudent economy of the Northern people precludes the use of costly silks, sumptuous shawls, and impulpable laces; French wines are out of the reach of self-indulgent epicures; and whisky, unrefined by a transatlantic voyage, takes the place of brandy. Lyons, Rheims, Bordeaux, are threatened with ruin. Busy communities are everywhere reduced to idleness; idleness at a moment when even industry can hardly earn the means to buy the fuel of life.
headline: {'main': 'France and the Southern Confederacy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'France and the Southern Confederacy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We regret to hear from Washington that the health of Gen. SCOTT is becoming less and less adequate to the severe and unremitting labors imposed by his position. His fatigues have...
lead_paragraph: We regret to hear from Washington that the health of Gen. SCOTT is becoming less and less adequate to the severe and unremitting labors imposed by his position. His fatigues have had such an effect upon his system that he now finds it difficult to attend to business for more than two hours at a time, without refreshing himself by sleep. He is unable to walk or ride to any considerable distance, and for a portion of the past few days he has been confined quite closely to his house.

abstract: CLOAK. The Commission to revise the City Charter is throwing off all disguise and abandoning even the pretension of doing anything towards the work for which it was appointed. It has been a sham from the beginning.
lead_paragraph: CLOAK. The Commission to revise the City Charter is throwing off all disguise and abandoning even the pretension of doing anything towards the work for which it was appointed. It has been a sham from the beginning. Possibly two or three of its members may have intended at the outset to make some attempt to reform the City Charter, but it is clear that the controlling majority had no such purpose. They were probably too well satisfied with the existing state of things in the City to permit any change if they could prevent it, -- and the result shows that they have been successful.

abstract: ARREST OF A SWINDLER. PETER DEMBEY, a colored man, who claims to be a fugitive slave from the State of Maryland, was yesterday arrested and taken before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Tombs, upon the compliant of CHARLES A. DANA, of No. 154 Nassau-street, who charges that the prisoner applied to him for a sum of money sufficient to take him to Canada, at the same time exhibiting a letter, purporting ...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A SWINDLER. PETER DEMBEY, a colored man, who claims to be a fugitive slave from the State of Maryland, was yesterday arrested and taken before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Tombs, upon the compliant of CHARLES A. DANA, of No. 154 Nassau-street, who charges that the prisoner applied to him for a sum of money sufficient to take him to Canada, at the same time exhibiting a letter, purporting to have been signed by Mr. GEORGE WILKENS, of Trenton, N.J., in which the bearer was represented as a worthy object of charity, and representing that Mr. DANA would aid him in his escape to Canada. The complainant at once recognized the swindler as a man who, two years since, had applied to him for money for the same pretended purpose, and to whom he had then given a sum sufficient to have taken him where he desired to go. Mrs. MARY S. TREMBLY, of No. 21 East Twenty-fifth-street, was called as a witness, and testified that DEMBEY was in the habit of practicing these impositions upon the public. The Justice committed him to the Workhouse for [???] months.

abstract: serve several useful purposes if the truth were permitted to follow a little more closely on the heels of Southern rumor.
lead_paragraph: serve several useful purposes if the truth were permitted to follow a little more closely on the heels of Southern rumor. Sixteen days have passed since the attack upon the National forces on Santa Rosa Island; and thirteen since the naval encounter upon the Mississippi. Of both transactions, we have only the rebel account; evidently grossly exaggerated, but how grossly we are still without means of deciding. And what is worse, the stories have gone to Europe; and will have produced their undue and mischievous effect, and been forgotten, before the correct version takes tardy passage from this side.

abstract: Ex-Gov. WOODBRIDGE, who died at his residence in Detroit, Mich., on Oct. 20, was born in Hartford, Conn., in 1779. He occupied the Gubernatorial Chair of that State in 1840 and 1841. In the year following he was sent to the United States Senate, and, at the conclusion of his term, retired to private life. He was a man of rare literary acquirements, a profound lawyer, and a thorough gentleman of the old school.

abstract: suppose that we at the North have a monopoly of complaints and misgivings in regard to the war. The rebels, judging from the slight and occasional glimpses, which is all we are permitted to know of their condition ...
lead_paragraph: suppose that we at the North have a monopoly of complaints and misgivings in regard to the war. The rebels, judging from the slight and occasional glimpses, which is all we are permitted to know of their condition seem to have quite as much ground for grumbling and discouragement as we have. An article copied from the Richmond Whig complains of the inactivity of their troops, denounces the defensive policy of their leaders, censures the appointment of civilians to high command, and says that there is a general feeling pervading the community that they are "on the eve of some great disaster." The Whig thinks that unless there is a very prompt and decided change in the conduct of the war, they may as well be "looking out for terms of submission, and the sooner the better." This does not look as if everything was smooth and prosperous with our Southern friends.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, Recorder HOFFMAN presiding, Henry Franks, 26 years, a native of Germany, pleaded guilty to false pretences in passing three one dollar bills of a worthless Tennessee Bank upon Catharine Smith, of No. 223 Stanton-street, receiving therefor pennies in change. The prisoner, who has two more indictments for the same offence standing against him, was remanded for sentence. James H. La Grange, 35 years, British subject, pleaded guilty to obtaining a diamond ring, valued at $65, from Freeman & Bennett's store, No. 825 Broadway, by false pretences -- the accused having presented a check in payment for the same on the Bank of America, where he had no funds on deposit. Remanded for sentence on Saturday, George E. Williams, 26 years, native of England, was tried for grand larceny, in stealing clothing and money from his fellow-boaaders, at No. 16 Harrison-street. Remandedfor sentence.

abstract: The United States vs. The Cargo of the Schooner Lynchburg. On June 17, 1861, by consent of all parties, Joseph Rush was appointed appraiser to value the vessel and her cargo, and on June 20, he reported that he had appraised the vessel at $5,000, and the cargo at $24,593 85. On his report was indorsed a consent ...
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Cargo of the Schooner Lynchburg. On June 17, 1861, by consent of all parties, Joseph Rush was appointed appraiser to value the vessel and her cargo, and on June 20, he reported that he had appraised the vessel at $5,000, and the cargo at $24,593 85. On his report was indorsed a consent signed by the Assistant United States Attorney, that this latter sum be divided as follows; viz. that 1,008 bags of coffee, part of said cargo claimed by Wortham & Co., be valued at $8,497 95, and the rest, 2,045 bags claimed by Brown Brothers & Co., be valued at $16,395 90. These portions of the cargo were delivered to the claimants on their giving bonds respectively in those amounts on notice to the District-Attorney.

abstract: JAMES A. MCMASTERS,Esq., Editor of the late Freeman's Journal, was released yesterday from Fort Lafayette, by order of Secretary SEWARD. The condition of his release was, that he should take the oath of allegiance prescribed by Congress, to support the Constitution and Government of the United States, which he did, -- at the same time protesting against the requirement as being without warrant of justice or law. Mr. MCMASTERS states that, while he has no ground of complaint in his own case, the treatment extended to many of the State prisoners in the Fort is not only exceedingly harsh toward them, but unworthy of the Government of the United States. They are not only deprived of the comforts to which they have been accustomed, but of very many things absolutely essential to their health. It would be well for the Secretary of State to cause some inquiries to be made into this matter, as he certainly has no disposition to make the condition of these men, most of whom are under arrest mainly as a measure of precaution, any more painful than the necessity of the case may require.
lead_paragraph: JAMES A. MCMASTERS,Esq., Editor of the late Freeman's Journal, was released yesterday from Fort Lafayette, by order of Secretary SEWARD. The condition of his release was, that he should take the oath of allegiance prescribed by Congress, to support the Constitution and Government of the United States, which he did, -- at the same time protesting against the requirement as being without warrant of justice or law. Mr. MCMASTERS states that, while he has no ground of complaint in his own case, the treatment extended to many of the State prisoners in the Fort is not only exceedingly harsh toward them, but unworthy of the Government of the United States. They are not only deprived of the comforts to which they have been accustomed, but of very many things absolutely essential to their health. It would be well for the Secretary of State to cause some inquiries to be made into this matter, as he certainly has no disposition to make the condition of these men, most of whom are under arrest mainly as a measure of precaution, any more painful than the necessity of the case may require.

abstract: The more complete accounts of the affair near Leesburgh on Monday, in which Col. BAKER lost his life, show that it was one of more importance than at first appeared, and resulted in advantages of a decided character to our army.
lead_paragraph: The more complete accounts of the affair near Leesburgh on Monday, in which Col. BAKER lost his life, show that it was one of more importance than at first appeared, and resulted in advantages of a decided character to our army. It appears, also, to have been somewhat unpremeditated. The enemy's scouts were first discovered by the Thirteenth Massachusetts Regiment, who were stationed on Hamilton Island, and five companies were ordered to advance and repulse the enemy, which they did, and returned. The enemy, however, soon reappeared in considerable numbers, and attacked the Massachusetts men, who were soon reinforced, and the fighting became more serious. Gen. STONE rapidly passed his men over the river at Hamilton Island and at Edwards' Ferry. At the latter point the enemy appeared to the number of five thousand, under command of Gen. EVANS, with cavalry and artillery; and here Col. BAKER fell, while gallantly leading a charge. Our troops subsequently fell back, but held possession of the Virginia side, and the enemy did not renew the attack. It is understood that on Monday night Gen. BANKS moved his division across the river at Hamilton Island and Edwards' Ferry, and that the two divisions of Gens. BANKS and STONE are now combined, under the command of the former. The enemy did not renew the attack on Tuesday, but it is understood that they were heavily reinforced, and another engagement was expected. Gen. MCCLELLAN spent the day with Gen. BANKS yesterday, and the army will probably move upon Leesburgh to-day, everything being in readiness for the advance.

abstract: It is understood that the Government regards with favor the proposition of Mr. ELLET, from whom a letter on this subject will be found in another column, that steam-rams be constructed to smash and sink the ships of an enemy. To drive a huge hulk at great velocity,...
lead_paragraph: It is understood that the Government regards with favor the proposition of Mr. ELLET, from whom a letter on this subject will be found in another column, that steam-rams be constructed to smash and sink the ships of an enemy. To drive a huge hulk at great velocity, clashing through the sides of an enemy's frigate, sending crew, cannon and costly stores all struggling to the bottom at a blow, is one of the grandest schemes of the times. That its execution may not be attended with costly failure, we would urge engineers, -- and half the people one meets are military and naval engineers, and likely to send in a proposition, -- to consider carefully the extraordinary difficulties of such an undertaking.

abstract: President CASTILLA had dismissed all the naval officers who had refused to assist in the arbitrary and illegal expulsion from the country of Ex-President ECHENIQUE. The people, on their part, loudly condemned his violent action, and are very restive under his despotic sway. The election for President to succeed CASTILLA, who, by the Constitution, cannot succeed himself, was to come off in a month, and the persecution of ECHENIQUE by CASTILLA was making the former a prominent candidate. Gen. SAN ROMAN and Senor LA MAR are also preminent in the lists. Should ECHENIQUE be elected, his assumption of power would be opposed by CASTILLA, at the head of the army. Gen. PEZET'S late election in Second Vice-President of Peru, which was supported with so much zeal by the Government, has been declared informal, and a new election is to be had.

abstract: There seems to be a probability that the fight in the neighborhood of Leesburgh, in which Col. BAKER lost his life, may lead to a general engagement between the two grand armies of the Potomac. Gen. STONE, it appears ...
lead_paragraph: There seems to be a probability that the fight in the neighborhood of Leesburgh, in which Col. BAKER lost his life, may lead to a general engagement between the two grand armies of the Potomac. Gen. STONE, it appears has crossed into Virginia with his forces, and Gen. BANKS has followed with his army. There are, therefore, about 25,000 Union soldiers on the Virginia side of the Potomac, under the command of these two Generals, excited by the incidents of a serious conflict and impatient of more decisive results. Before them is a force of rebels, nearly equal in numbers, well officered, and not deficient in confidence from the result of the first day's fighting.

abstract: Corbett vs. Eno et al. This action was upon a promissory note, made, as alleged, by the defendants as partners. The defendants constituted a firm of four members, three of them general partners, and the fourth a special partner. The general partners set up...
lead_paragraph: Corbett vs. Eno et al. This action was upon a promissory note, made, as alleged, by the defendants as partners. The defendants constituted a firm of four members, three of them general partners, and the fourth a special partner. The general partners set up for a defence that the plaintiff was not the real party in interest, nor the lawful holder and owner of the note. This answer was verified upon information and belief. Motion was made to strike out the answer as sham.

abstract: The sudden change in the affairs of Arizona, by which that Territory deprived itself of the protection of the United States, has overwhelmed it in anarchy and ruin. There is no such thing as safety for life or property -- the Mexicans plundering the property of the citizens and sacking the mines, which they generally take care to destroy after getting out all the ore which has been extracted. The Apaches, in revenge for the killing of five or six of their number by a detachment of United States troops from Fort Buchanan, had slain over one hundred Americans between the Rio Grande and Colorado, and the roads throughout the country were dangerous to traverse. Among the victims was Lieut. MOWRY, with whom we held a conversation in our office just prior to his departure for the Territory, little dreaming that the hale, fine-looking, soldier-like officer who then spoke to us with such hope and confidence of the anticipated results of his expedition would so soon be numbered with the dead. We believe Mr. MOWRY had cast his lot with the Secessionists -- more's the pity, for a more competent officer it would have been difficult to find for the arduous duties to which he was assigned. We have as yet heard only the commencement of the troubles in Arizona.

abstract: At a regular semi-monthly meeting of the Commissioners, yesterday, the usual requisitions were passed. From the report of the Warden, it appeared that, during the past two weeks, 696 persons had been transferred from the City Prison to the Workhouse, of whom 481 were females. The Warden also reported that an unusually large number of boys had been sent up within the past month. One, a lad fourteen years of age, had been in prison two weeks, awaiting a charge of burglary, when his case might have been disposed of in a few hours. So with another boy, who had been in prison since Aug. 23, on a charge of grand larceny, and not yet tried.
lead_paragraph: At a regular semi-monthly meeting of the Commissioners, yesterday, the usual requisitions were passed. abstract: The sum of one million three hundred and fifty thousand dollars, from the Treasury of the United States, was received at the Sub-Treasury office in this city yesterday. The greater portion of the amount was in gold. The opportune arrival of this large sum will do much to relieve many of our citizens from the pecuniary difficulties under which they were suffering, by having made large advances to the Government.
lead_paragraph: The sum of one million three hundred and fifty thousand dollars, from the Treasury of the United States, was received at the Sub-Treasury office in this city yesterday. abstract: The intelligence that we receive from NewOrleans and Pensacola affords a new evidence of the truth of the old saying that "there are two sides to every story."
lead_paragraph: The intelligence that we receive from NewOrleans and Pensacola affords a new evidence of the truth of the old saying that "there are two sides to every story." The country has been for some time in possession of the rebel accounts of their defeat of the blockading squadron at the mouth of the Mississippi River, and of their surprise of BILLY WILSON's Zouaves on Santa Rosa Island, the destruction of his camp, and almost capture of Fort Pickens itself. In each story there was much to disturb the complacency of those Unionists who put implicit confidence in the veracity of rebel bulletins -- a class of our population, we are happy to say, that is rapidly diminishing in numbers. The reports brought by the McClellan, a Government steamer, directly from the Gulf, will go far to destroy the credibility of Southern chevaliers when describing their conflicts with the Yankees.
headline: {'main': 'Lies of the Rebel Bulletins.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Lies of the Rebel Bulletins.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

The troops, it is said, retired ...

abstract: The November number of Harper's, in its outer jacket of delicate buff, is before us. With this issue the Twenty-third volume of the Magazine is completed. When we say that it seems customary with the proprietors and editors of magazines to exert themselves for the production of an unusually good number with which to commence and close each volume, we do not at all mean to ...
lead_paragraph: The November number of Harper's, in its outer jacket of delicate buff, is before us. With this issue the Twenty-third volume of the Magazine is completed. When we say that it seems customary with the proprietors and editors of magazines to exert themselves for the production of an unusually good number with which to commence and close each volume, we do not at all mean to insinuate that our friends of Franklin Square fail to preserve an excellent average the year round. They simply base and cap the semi-annual sheaves with their best grain. It is very seldom, indeed, that they present the public with anything that cannot be ground into a good quality of mental flour. But on these regularly recurring occasions they resolve to outdo themselves -- and generally succeed.

abstract: We have had an interview with an intelligent Philadelphian who formerly resided at Portsmouth, Va., and who very recently succeeded in making his way North, after trying to do so for three months. Our informant procured a pass to come North some time since from the rebel Secretary of War, but his case was entirely in the hands of the Vigilance Committees of Norfolk and Portsmouth, and ...
lead_paragraph: We have had an interview with an intelligent Philadelphian who formerly resided at Portsmouth, Va., and who very recently succeeded in making his way North, after trying to do so for three months. Our informant procured a pass to come North some time since from the rebel Secretary of War, but his case was entirely in the hands of the Vigilance Committees of Norfolk and Portsmouth, and they refused to allow his departure until last week. He states that in the town of Portsmouth there are from two thousand to three thousand persons of strong and unwavering Union sentiments. They are extremely anxious to leave the rebel Confederacy, and seek the protection of the old flag, but they are prevented, on one pretext or another, by the Vigilance Committee, which is large and active. As there are between 12,000 and 13,000 people in Portsmouth, this statement goes to show that a very strong minority, even in that hot-bed of secession, still remain true to their country. Union feeling, our informant states, was pretty openly expressed among certain classes in Norfolk and Portsmouth, in spite of the rebel Government and the Vigilance Committees, and the advance of the Federal forces in that direction will be hailed with joy by many true and loyal men.

abstract: We understand that Gov. ANDREW, while in Washington, made some inquiries with regard to sending abroad by the Government, for army cloths. He presented to the Quartermaster-General a statement of the capacity of the New-England mills for the manufacture of these cloths, and the substance of the views of our manufacturers, as he understood them. Gen. MEIGS, who is very frank, mainly and clear in his business methods, listened, attentively ...
lead_paragraph: We understand that Gov. ANDREW, while in Washington, made some inquiries with regard to sending abroad by the Government, for army cloths. He presented to the Quartermaster-General a statement of the capacity of the New-England mills for the manufacture of these cloths, and the substance of the views of our manufacturers, as he understood them. Gen. MEIGS, who is very frank, mainly and clear in his business methods, listened, attentively and explained his views without any reservation. He regretted the necessity which has compelled him, for temporary purposes, to invest some money abroad. He fully acceded to Gov. ANDREW's ideas with regard to employing home industry, but he said that it was necessary to have an immediate stock on hand, and to be kept ahead of the demands made by the troops in his department, and not remain a long way in arrears, as he now is. He will doubtless want all that the New-England mills will make, at fair prices, but will still need all that he is buying abroad, to enable him to keep up a proper stock distributed in the various depots over the country.

abstract: If we may trust the testimony of a Key West letter-writer, the Nashville has really effected her escape. Her arrival at Cardenas, with Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON on board, is reported as vouched for by Consul SAVAGE, ...
lead_paragraph: If we may trust the testimony of a Key West letter-writer, the Nashville has really effected her escape. Her arrival at Cardenas, with Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON on board, is reported as vouched for by Consul SAVAGE, who is said to have sent urgent messages to Key West, in order to stimulate pursuit by some of the National vessels at that place. Along with this cheerful and inspiriting evidence of the vigor of the blockade, we learn that on the 10th inst., a fore-and-aft schooner, the Sallie, issued unmolested from Charleston, and three days after earned the reward of her enterprize by capturing a merchant brig belonging to a firm in New-York, and laden with sugar and molasses.

abstract: The United States steamer Connecticut, Commander WOODHULL, from Bermuda on the 21st inst., having left this port on the 17th inst., for the purpose of intercepting the steamship Nashville, said to have left Charleston for England, with Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON on board, returned to this port yesterday. The Nashville had not been heard of at Bermuda. The Connecticut proceeded to the Navy-yard.

abstract: Col. BUFFORD and Capt. DREWER, of Gen. McCTERNAND'S staff accompanied by several other gentlemen, went to Columbus yesterday on the propeler Sampson for the purpose of exchanging prisoners. The party were cordially received by Gens. POLK and PILLOW, and 16 prisoners were released. The town is well fortified. A battery of eight 24 pounders is placed at the upper end of the town.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO, Thursday, Oct. 24.

abstract: The Boston Post publishes a letter, addressed to a gentleman in Boston, by Hon. HORATIO KING, Ex-Postmaster General. By extracts from speeches of those who are now prominent Secessionists, he exhibits their inconsistency, and then after having demonstrated the fallacy of State Sovereignty, he exposes the barefacedness with which the rebels intrigued at Washington during the last part of Mr. BUCHANAN's term. He declares that the rebellion must be suppressed, and concludes thus:

abstract: Capt. Ronckandorff, U.S.A.; Dr. Howell, U.S.A.; Lieut. Whittemore, U.S.A.; Major Newby, Sixth Regiment New-York Volunteers, from Fort Pickens; Capt. Norman, do.; Lieut. D'Orville, do., Lieut. Kraehl, do.; Stephen Hill, do. From Pensacola -- Capt. Pachard and wife, Mrs. Butler, Mr. Gillet, Mr. Johnson and Frank Smith. From Tortugas -- Dr. Leavitt and wife. From Key West -- Capt. Gillem, Mrs. Gillem, three children and servant, and 14 discharged soldiers and three slaves. She also brings seven refugees from Pensacola, who escaped, who report the rebel forces to be about 8,000 or 10,000 men. The army was poorly clothed, but well armed, and provisions were scarce and very high.

abstract: If our amiable friend of the Herald were a drinking man we should have no doubt that he is afflicted with delirium tremens. His columas give evidence of disease of some kind in the ravings which fill them, day after day, about the TIMES and Tribune.
lead_paragraph: If our amiable friend of the Herald were a drinking man we should have no doubt that he is afflicted with delirium tremens. His columas give evidence of disease of some kind in the ravings which fill them, day after day, about the TIMES and Tribune. There is a little too much method in his balderdash, however, -- too evident a desire to hurt somebody, to make such an explanation plausible. Under all the insane bluster and lying braggadocio with which he amuses and instructs his readers, lurks a venemous spite which betrays the systematic malignity which is among the most amiable and conspicuous characteristics of that modest journalist. The assiduity with which he pries into the private business affairs of his neighbors, -- the charming impartiality with which he lies or tells the truth, as may best serve his turn -- his contemptuous disregard of all the considerations which influence men who have any reputation to lose, or any social position to maintain, give a touch of heroism to what in any less gifted and unscrupulous scamp would be merely repulsive. The old reprobate reminds one of the standard villain of the novelist, -- a bad Jesuit priest though he adds some touches of character which are peculiarly his own. If such a priest were to be kicked out of his parish for immorality, out of his family for cold-blooded brutality, and out of society because he was universally regarded as a slimy and viperous nuisance, he would have just about the education, the propensities and the experience required for the work which the Herald performs. BENNETT will regard it as a compliment when we say that he is quite adequate to the task without any such preliminary training. His natural genius for this kind of work renders all education superfluous.

abstract: Gen. McCLELLAN was yesterday again at his headquarters across the Potomac, and everything along the National lines remained quiet. There has been no renewal of the fighting near Leesburgh, but we hear that the enemy have shown themselves in force above and below, and it has been thought advisable to withdraw our troops for the present, from the Virginia side.
lead_paragraph: Gen. McCLELLAN was yesterday again at his headquarters across the Potomac, and everything along the National lines remained quiet. There has been no renewal of the fighting near Leesburgh, but we hear that the enemy have shown themselves in force above and below, and it has been thought advisable to withdraw our troops for the present, from the Virginia side. From the best data at present attainable, it is probable that the number of our men killed on Monday was 79; wounded, 141; missing, prisoners, and not yet returned to their commands, about 400 -- in all, say 620, which figure will probably be considerably reduced by those returning to camp.

abstract: The Philadelphia Press, of Wednesday, relates these incidents of Col. BAKER'S career:  "Col. BAKER'S last effort on the floor of the Senate merits particular attention. It was in the early part of August last. BRECKINRIDGE was delivering a set ...
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Press, of Wednesday, relates these incidents of Col. BAKER'S career: "Col. BAKER'S last effort on the floor of the Senate merits particular attention. It was in the early part of August last. BRECKINRIDGE was delivering a set disunion harangue, as ingenious and able as any heard on behalf of secession. BAKER, whose camp was a mile or two from the Capitol, entered the Senate Chamber hastily from the duties of a drill, while BRECKINRIDGE was speaking. He was presently called into the lobby by a message from Mr. HOLT, of Kentucky, who begged him to reply to BRECKINRIDGE, as no one else would probably be ready to do so. He did so off-hand, when BRECKINRIDGE sat down, and made one of the most thrilling speeches which had been heard for years in the chamber. It squelched Mr. BRECKINRIDGE. Who would not rather now be BAKER dead than BRECKINRIDGE living.

abstract: Fort Lafayette has received an accession to its population from Franklin County, in the persons of two brothers from the town of Malone. JOS. R. FLANDERS, one of the two, is a lawyer, was a member of the Constitutional Convention of 1846, and of the Legislature in 1847, and has been County Judge in Franklin County. His brother, FRANCIS D. FLANDERS, was the editor of the Franklin County Gazette, in which both these gentlemen were accustomed to express the most thorough sympathy with the Secessionists. Being publicly asked why they did not go South and fight for a cause to which they were so much devoted, they replied that they could do it more service here. They have been very properly arrested in their work of aiding and abetting treason.

abstract: If is not often that we get so complete a statement of the case of an enemy, as that published by us yesterday, copied from the Richmond Whig. "Unless," says that paper, ...
lead_paragraph: If is not often that we get so complete a statement of the case of an enemy, as that published by us yesterday, copied from the Richmond Whig. "Unless," says that paper, "we are prepared to conquer peace upon the enemy's soil, the sooner we propose terms of submission the better. The enemy has command of the sea, and a defensive policy is simply to place ourselves at his mercy." This confession, uttered in the Capital of Rebeldom, and directly under the noses of the despots that rule there, is the most notable thing that has yet come to us from the seceding States. It is evidence that the actual condition of the rebels is rapidly being understood by themselves. They do not act upon the offensive because they cannot. A defensive policy is nothing less than destruction, because it allows the North to take away from the South every attribute of independence, if not the very means of existence. What is the condition of a people who depend, for almost every luxury and necessity, upon other nations, and are completely cut off from intercourse with all others? For one whose productions and social organization are like those of the South, it is subjection in its harshest and most odious form. Suppose the Government should not proceed a step further, except to rigidly enforce the blockade, and protect the loyal States, can the rebels put forth a single claim to have their assumed nationality respected? The final result is no less certain than if we could instantly overwhelm them in the field with a resistless force.

abstract: Brigadier-Gen. THOS. W. SHERMAN, (who must not be confounded with W.T. SHERMAN, of Ohio,) is the commander of the military division of this expedition, and is considered one of the best officers in the...
lead_paragraph: Brigadier-Gen. THOS. W. SHERMAN, (who must not be confounded with W.T. SHERMAN, of Ohio,) is the commander of the military division of this expedition, and is considered one of the best officers in the United States Army. Gen. SHERMAN graduated at West Point, and served with distinction in the Mexican War, under TAYLOR and SCOTT. He was breveted Major for gallant and meritorious conduct at the battle of Buena Vista. In the Mexican War he commanded and gave his name to "Sherman's Battery," which he organized in Mexico. When this secession war broke out Gen. SHERMAN was doing duty on the frontier. Gen. SHERMAN is a native of Rhode Island. It was his namesake, Gen. W.T. SHERMAN, (the successor of Gen. ANDERSON in Kentucky,) who commanded a brigade at the battle of Bull Run. Gen. SHERMAN arrived at Fortress Monroe on Tuesday last, and sailed the following day. His headquarters are on board the Atlantic. Our correspondent states that the land force of the expedition will reach 15,000. This is not the entire force. It is supposed that additional troops will be taken from Fortress Monroe, but we have no means as yet of knowing what these troops are. They will probably include SERRELL's Engineers and the Third New-Hampshire Regiment. Dr. C.H. CRANE, for some time past examining surgeon of recruits at the medical purveying depot in Grand-street, is Medical Director assigned to Gen. SHERMAN's Division. Dr. CRANE entered the service as Assistant, Surgeon, with the rank of First Lieutenant, on the 2d of February, 1848, and was recently appointed full Surgeon, with the rank of Major. He is a native of Rhode Island, but was appointed from Massachusetts, and has seen a good deal of service on the frontiers.

abstract: A private correspondence of the Patric gives some details of the organization of the French naval force to be dispatched to the coast of Mexico. The ships of war ordered for this expedition are the steam-frigates...
lead_paragraph: A private correspondence of the Patric gives some details of the organization of the French naval force to be dispatched to the coast of Mexico. The ships of war ordered for this expedition are the steam-frigates Guerriere, (fitting at Brest,) l'Astree, (from Lorient,) and l'Ardente, (from Brest,) a steam corvette (from Rochefort) and the cutter Morceaux (from Cherbourg.) Admiral JURIEN DE LAGRAVIERE, who will command the squadron, will hoist his flag on board the Guerriere, which is being prepared for sea as quickly as possible.

abstract: The situation in the vicinity of Washington continues much the same as reported yesterday. The most important military movement has been the extension of the picket lines of FRANKLIN'S Division a mile beyond Annandale, on the Little...
lead_paragraph: The situation in the vicinity of Washington continues much the same as reported yesterday. The most important military movement has been the extension of the picket lines of FRANKLIN'S Division a mile beyond Annandale, on the Little River Turnpike, leading direct to Fairfax Court House. The rebel steamer Page was yesterday again cruising on the Lower Potomac, but was closely watched by two or three National gunboats. The rebels threw several shells, one to the Maryland shore, more by way of testing the range of their guns, probably, than with the expectation of doing any damage.

abstract: Wm. Forrest et al., Executors, &c., vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of Oct. 9. The plaintiffs are Executors of Daniel Fanshaw, upon whose estate a large assessment was made in 1857 for constructing a sewer in Third-avenue. Mr. Fanshaw voluntarily paid the assessment, without testing its validity by adjudication. Subsequently, in 1859, the assessments in respect to such sewer were set aside by the Court for fraud and irregularity; and the Executors of the estate now sue to recover back the amount thus paid. The cause now comes up on demurrer to the complaint, and the facts in respect thereof will be found in the following opinion of the Court:

abstract: President Hopkins, of Williams College, who returned from Europe in the Arabia last week, was  warmly welcomed by the students on his arrival at Williamstown, on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: President Hopkins, of Williams College, who returned from Europe in the Arabia last week, was warmly welcomed by the students on his arrival at Williamstown, on Saturday night. The college buildings were all illuminated, and the students in a body called at the President's house, where songs were sung, and an address of welcome was delivered by S.C. Armstrong, of the Senior class, which was responded to very happily by Dr. Hopkins.

abstract: It appears that the arrangement effected on Monday by the Bank of France, has been made with Messrs. ROTHSCHILD and five other Paris banking houses, and it is to the effect that the Bank are to have, through these firms, the power to draw bills upon London to the amount of L2,000,000,of which L1,000,000 will be on Messrs. ROTHSCHILD, and L1,000,000 on Messrs. BARING. The knowledge of this circumstance has produced a slight decline -- about an 1/8 cent. in the rate of exchange, and when the drawing of the bills commences, a further downward movement must be expected, but it is not considered likely that the reaction will be a point that will attract gold from London. The measure will probably not do more than check for the present the drain of specie from Paris to this side. At the maturity of the bills, which will be drawn at three months' date, the amount will have to be repaid unless a renewal be obtained, and the rate of exchange at that period will be proportionality influenced in our favor. On the other hand, the difficulty in France, if affairs should not meanwhile take a better course, will then return, and, perhaps, with increased force from the present postponement. It may be hoped, however, that the results of the excellent vintage and other circumstances will operate to bring about some restoration of trade and confidence.

abstract: We alluded last Monday to the sale of the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad, as to come off yesterday, under amicable arrangements between all the parties in interest. This sale took place at Cleveland, in exact accordance with the programme, and the sale is said to have been immediately confirmed by the court. At any rate, when the sale is so confirmed, and there is not likely to be any delay in the confirmation, the reorganization of this important line of road, extending from Pittsburgh, Penn., 465 miles to Chicago, will at once be carried out, and from the magnitude of the interests involved, deserves the attention of the public. The old Ohio and Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana, and Fort Wayne and Chicago bonds will be merged in mortgage issues of the new corporation, corresponding in priority of liens with the old mortgages.

abstract: The repulse of the National troops that occurred near Leesburgh, on Monday, has been followed by the entire withdrawal of our army from the Virginia side in that vicinity.
lead_paragraph: The repulse of the National troops that occurred near Leesburgh, on Monday, has been followed by the entire withdrawal of our army from the Virginia side in that vicinity. Preparations were made for throwing the entire divisions of Gens. STONE and BANKS across the river, to hold the position from which our troops had been driven; and several thousands had been crossed in pursuance of that plan, when the matter was reconsidered, and every man beyond the river was ordered back. The recrossing was effected in the face of the enemy, without loss.

abstract: A very large class of Southern rebels, whose activity and vehemence in behalf of secession did much to accomplish the success of the cause, are waking up to a most startling and  painful disappointment in the operation of the...
lead_paragraph: A very large class of Southern rebels, whose activity and vehemence in behalf of secession did much to accomplish the success of the cause, are waking up to a most startling and painful disappointment in the operation of the Sequestration act of the Confederate Congress. It is the debtor class we speak of -- those who were owing various amounts of money, large and small, to citizens of the Northern States, which it was inconvenient to pay. War, it was foreseen, would extinguish all business relations between the North and South, and destroy the ability, if it did not forfeit the right, of the Northern creditor to coerce the payment of debts owed by people in the South. The amount of Southern indebtedness to the North is enormous. It has been the chronic relation of the two sections to each other -- that of creditor on the one side, and debtor on the other. The balance has been for many years, and was at the beginning of secession, and is now, hundreds of millions of dollars in favor of the North. Secession was considered a respectable dodge for repudiation. It cloaked, under the garb of "loyalty to the South," the private dishonor of swindling one's creditors. It promised relief from pressing obligations, and a rich reward in the private appropriation of the merchandise of Northern men incautiously credited to Southern dealers.

abstract: The approaching State election excites comparatively little interest. Party feeling seems to be dormant in presence of the overwhelming perils of the country, and the universal desire of men of all parties is to throw the...
lead_paragraph: The approaching State election excites comparatively little interest. Party feeling seems to be dormant in presence of the overwhelming perils of the country, and the universal desire of men of all parties is to throw the whole moral weight of this great State in favor of a vigorous, prompt and energetic prosecution of the war. The People's ticket, nominated at Syracuse, is regarded as the embodiment of this sentiment, and will, therefore, according to present appearances, sweep the State by a very large majority. There is a taint of suspicion, to say the least, upon the Democratic ticket which has been nominated in opposition: -- and tens of thousands of staunch Democrats will refuse to vote it, because they will not run the risk of being misunderstood upon the great question which absorbs all others.

abstract: We publish this morning, from our correspondents, a very full account of the great Naval Expedition, which has at last left Annapolis, and is on its way to some part of the Southern coast.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning, from our correspondents, a very full account of the great Naval Expedition, which has at last left Annapolis, and is on its way to some part of the Southern coast. Its destination remains, as yet, a profound secret, and probably will so remain until it is revealed by the blow which it proposes to strike. There are in the expedition thirty-one large transport vessels, conveying over 12,000 troops, with all their arms, provisions, &c., -- sixteen steam gunboats, with eight or ten other vessels of war, carrying in all about 400 guns. It is in every respect a most powerful and admirably organized expedition, and but for accidents which cannot be foreseen, it will unquestionably render very essential service to the Union cause. It is under the command of able and experienced officers, and the troops embarked are among the best in the volunteer army.

lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Baltimore, which left Liverpool on the 16th and Queenstown on the 17th inst., passed Cape Race last evening on her way to this port. Her advices are four days later than those by the Africa, which has arrived here. The Liverpool Cotton Market is reported to be considerably excited, and sales were heavy, at another advance of 1/8d.@1/4d. The Breadstuffs Market was also excited, and prices were higher, both in Liverpool and London. Provisions continued somewhat dull.

abstract: Commodore H. PAULDING relieved Commodore BREEZE yesterday, as commandant of the Brooklyn Navy-yard. The customary salutes were fired on the occasion, viz.; fifteen guns for Commodore BREEZE, who has been twenty years a Post Captain, and thirteen guns for Commodore PAULDING.
lead_paragraph: Commodore H. PAULDING relieved Commodore BREEZE yesterday, as commandant of the Brooklyn Navy-yard. The customary salutes were fired on the occasion, viz.; fifteen guns for Commodore BREEZE, who has been twenty years a Post Captain, and thirteen guns for Commodore PAULDING. It is not at present known to what duty Commodore BREEZE will be assigned. He has been in command of the Brooklyn Navy-yard upwards of three years, and leaves it with the best wishes and regrets of all with whom he has been connected. Commodore PAULDING has been in the navy upwards of fifty years, having first entered in September, 1811. Twenty-four years of his service were spent at sea, eight years on duty on shore, and the remainder unemployed. He has lately been acting as President of the Navy Retiring Board, convened in this City. Commodore PAULDING is a native and a citizen of New-York.

abstract: We abandon the attempt to ascertain whether Gen. FREMONT has been removed from his command or not. Every day brings from Washington a contradiction of the previous day's report.
lead_paragraph: We abandon the attempt to ascertain whether Gen. FREMONT has been removed from his command or not. Every day brings from Washington a contradiction of the previous day's report. The Government does not seem inclined to favor the public with any authentic information on the subject, -- and we are tired of dealing with reports which mislead the Community, and excite resentments which can not but be highly injurious to the public good Gen. FREMONT is still in command of the Western Department, -- in the field at the head of his troops and in active pursuit of the rebels who, at the last advices, did not seem inclined to be overtaken.

abstract: The work of carrying westward the transcontinental telegraphic line has progressed with so little blazonment, that it is with almost an electric thrill one reads the words of greeting yesterday flashed instantaneously over the wires direct from California.
lead_paragraph: The work of carrying westward the transcontinental telegraphic line has progressed with so little blazonment, that it is with almost an electric thrill one reads the words of greeting yesterday flashed instantaneously over the wires direct from California. The magnificent idea of joining the Atlantic with the Pacific by the magnetic wire is to-day a realized fact. New-York, Queen of the Atlantic, and San Francisco, Queen of the Pacific are now united by this noblest symbol of our modern civilization.

abstract: The following prisoners were on Friday released from Fort Lafayette, on taking the oath of allegiance: ELIAS V. SCHANBEL, a Pennsylvania politician and stump speaker, who was arrested for treasonable language; Capt. CHAS. M. HAGELIN, a Swede, who was arrested for conveying passengers to a Southern port, but whose innocence of any treasonable intent has been thoroughly established; J.J. SHAFER, a Canadian, claiming to be an officer in the British army, refused to take the oath of allegiance, and was therefore allowed to remain in prison. He was arrested for carrying letters to the rebels.

abstract: Mr. EDWARD LABOULAYE, not unknown in America as the author of a remarkable book The Political History of the United States, publishes a long article, of ten columns, in the Journal des Debats, (Oct. 2 and 3,) on the American crisis, characterized by very accurate, just and generous appreciations of our affairs. He speaks as "an old friend of the United States, and a defender of her institutions," and thinks that, "at a time when it is considered in good taste to despise her," he has a right to cast his vote on the great question. There has been nothing published in Europe showing so thorough an intelligence of all the aspects of the question, and the views cannot fail to exercise the most beneficial influence on European opinion. We give below a translation of the more striking passages.
lead_paragraph: Mr. EDWARD LABOULAYE, not unknown in America as the author of a remarkable book The Political History of the United States, publishes a long article, of ten columns, in the Journal des Debats, (Oct. 2 and 3,) on the American crisis, characterized by very accurate, just and generous appreciations of our affairs. We give below a translation of the more striking passages.

abstract: Affairs in the vicinity of Washington continue generally unchanged. Gen. HEINTZELMAN, whose Division constitutes the extreme left, resting on the Potomac, is gradually extending his pickets further towards the rebel positions down the river, while the Excelsior Brigade, on the other side of the river, is making a corresponding movement. The great feature of the day yesterday.
lead_paragraph: Affairs in the vicinity of Washington continue generally unchanged. Gen. HEINTZELMAN, whose Division constitutes the extreme left, resting on the Potomac, is gradually extending his pickets further towards the rebel positions down the river, while the Excelsior Brigade, on the other side of the river, is making a corresponding movement. The great feature of the day yesterday was the review of Gen. FITZ JOHN PORTER's Division, which is represented to have been the finest spectacle of the kind which has yet been presented.

abstract: The attitude which the Emperor of Russia has assumed in relation to the rebellion, and his hearty recognition of the efforts of this Government to suppress it, have not only elicited expressions of good will from Americans, but have been made the occasion of various comments from the British Press.
lead_paragraph: The attitude which the Emperor of Russia has assumed in relation to the rebellion, and his hearty recognition of the efforts of this Government to suppress it, have not only elicited expressions of good will from Americans, but have been made the occasion of various comments from the British Press. The London Morning Herald (Derbyite) has some very sensible remarks upon the incongruity presented by the British Government, as compared with the Russian, at this critical period. It seems passing strange that the Government of Great Britain, which has always made such great professions of being the bulwark of liberty for the oppressed, especially now that it is represented by the Liberal wing, headed by Lord PALMERSTON, should have manifested so openly its wish for the disruption of the Union, and the success of the Confederates. It is the only nation which has openly shown a determination to favor the Southern Confederates, and it has been put to the blush by the frank expressions of the Emperor of Russia in favor of the United States. The policy of Russia has completely nonplussed the English. They had a suspicion that they had terribly blundered when LOUIS NAPOLEON refused to encourage the Southern Confederates. The policy of France occasioned a modification of the tone adopted by the British Cabinet and Press; that of Russia cannot fail to have a decided influence upon England.

abstract: The Naval Expedition about setting sail from Hampton Roads to some point on the Southern coast, will be accompanied by one thousand negroes, able-bodied men, being a...
lead_paragraph: The Naval Expedition about setting sail from Hampton Roads to some point on the Southern coast, will be accompanied by one thousand negroes, able-bodied men, being a part of the number of escaped slaves that have gathered about Fortress Monroe since the commencement of hostilities in Eastern Virginia. These negroes accompany the expedition in the capacity of laborers. When the army has effected its landing on the Southern coast, the first object will be to secure a position, and fortify it beyond the possibility of successful assault. The object is not to burn Savannah, or Charleston, or Mobile, and escape again to sea. The mere destruction of private property involved in such a foray would do nothing to suppress rebellion, nor to produce fair compensation for the enormous cost of the expedition itself. The object is to take possession of rebel soil, to hold it after taken, and to restore the Constitution and laws of the National Government, so that Unionists may be protected in persons and property, if any such are found yet residing in the South; and rebels punished for their treason to the Government.

abstract: Tuesday was the day appointed by the Convention of Western Virginia for taking the vote of the people upon the proposition to erect that portion of Virginia into a new State, to be called Kanawha. We are inclined to think that a very light vote has been cast.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday was the day appointed by the Convention of Western Virginia for taking the vote of the people upon the proposition to erect that portion of Virginia into a new State, to be called Kanawha. We are inclined to think that a very light vote has been cast. A majority of the votes given will, in all probability, be in favor of the new State. But we discover, in the popular manifestations that have attracted our attention, a lack of that confidence, either in the present or future, that would lead a people to any very energetic and definite attempts to adjust their internal government or external relations. This state of uncertainty will lead to the same result that a state of indifference would produce. But the one must not, in justice to the people of Western Virginia, be mistaken for the other.
headline: {'main': 'The New State of Kanawha.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New State of Kanawha.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -Friday evening Mr. JAMES LEONARD successfully accomplished the difficult task of playing eight blindfold games of chess, simultaneously, at the Morphy Rooms, Broadway, in the presence of a numerous and highly respectable assemblage of the votaries of the game, who manifested deep interest in the proceedings. Mr. LEONARD's opponents were Messrs. Chadwick, Marks, Bryant, Apgar, Gilberg, Belcher, Switzen and Seward. The latter was mated on the 20th move, and Mr. BRYANT on the 24th; Mr. MARKS, mated on the 12th move, by an error on Mr. LEONARD's part. Mr. CHADWICK drew the game, and the remainder resigned, save BELCHER, he winning. The games were all more or less characterized by brilliant play on the part of Mr. LEONARD, and but few errors occurred to mar the success of the difficult undertaking.

Mr. CHADWICK drew the game, and the remainder resigned, save BELCHER, he winning. The games were all more or less characterized by brilliant play on the part of Mr. LEONARD, and but few errors occurred to mar the success of the difficult undertaking.
