abstract: The following is an account of the attack on BILLY WILSON'S camp, as given by three contrabands who were sent here in the McClellan, by Col. BROWN, from Fort Pickens. They are PETER DYSON, an intelligent black man, about 35 years of age, who,...
lead_paragraph: The following is an account of the attack on BILLY WILSON'S camp, as given by three contrabands who were sent here in the McClellan, by Col. BROWN, from Fort Pickens. They are PETER DYSON, an intelligent black man, about 35 years of age, who, with his wife, a yellow woman, escaped from a Mrs. HAUSON, a boarding-house keeper in Pensacola; they got to Fort Pickens in a skiff, about two and a half months ago. DYSON is a first-rate mason and bricklayer, and has worked on the Government forts at Pensacola for the last twenty years. The third is a young colored married woman, about 25 years old, who was owned by COLE CROSBY, and hired out to a Mrs. WM. O'BRIEN at Pensacola, and ran away to her owner at Perdita, below Port Pickens, because her mistress wanted her to do the housework, and pay her 75 cents a day besides, which she would have to earn by working out. She left Perdita with two men, in a sloop, and while beating up for Fort Pickens, was fallen in with by the Colorado, and taken on board, and to the fort; her name is OLIVE KELLY, and she has been at the fort about a month. From the three we gleaned the following:

abstract: The week ending with the present issue of the TIMES has done little to enlighten the future probabilities of the war. It has not, however, been without cheering indications of...
lead_paragraph: The week ending with the present issue of the TIMES has done little to enlighten the future probabilities of the war. It has not, however, been without cheering indications of progress. Much of Missouri has been recovered from the enemy. Retreating before the advancing columns of Gen. FREMONT, Gen. PRICE has not been sufficiently expeditious to escape the Union forces in pursuit of him, and, at the latest advices, was in a fair way to be surrounded by the commands of SIEGEL, ASBOTH, LANE, STURGIS, and MONTGOMERY, who were closing about him from all quarters. Should a contest, which seems inevitable, occur, it seems hardly possible that the Missourian can fail to be cut to pieces by his antagonists, whose joint numbers exceed the largest force assigned to him by the most exaggerated rumors. In the eastern part of the State, the rebels, so far from repeating their dastardly attempts upon the railroad bridges, have been beaten by an inferior force of Union men at Fredericktown, and compelled to leave the field. So far, therefore, as relates to the military occupation of Missouri by the rebels, which a fortnight ago threatened to include the entire State, the arms of the Union have been eminently successful. Save in the southernmost tier of counties, the authority of the National Government is in the ascendant. A rebellious and insubordinate spirit unquestionably exists more or less in every county, but without the presence of armed supporters it is kept in awe by the Union population, and is not likely to assume a dangerous attitude or proportions.

abstract: Every steamer from Europe carries over to us some new and startling diagnosis of our national malady, and some new remedy for it, by some one or other of the learned ignoramuses and quacks of England. Statesmen, prelates, priests, Members of Parliament, journalists, literateurs swells and snobs -- each and all, must have their pompous say-so about our ailment; and each of them, with infinite solemnity, presents us with his moonshine nostrum for its cure. His Grace the Archbishop of York has just discovered, after profound study, that the American difficulty springs from the baneful influence of what he calls "secular education;" Rev. GEORGE DAWSON -- who is a Dissenter, and against whom the Archbishop cannot enforce the Conformity law -- thinks that the war arises from "the Continent of America having been prosperous too long;" the Honorable BULWER believes we are too big; the Honorable LINDSAY thinks we are "not sincerely anxious to abolish Slavery;" the Honorable GREGORY takes universal suffrage to be our grand bane; the Honorable RAMSDEN (be who announced in Parliament that our "bubble had burst.") reiterates that no republic can endure simply because it is a republic. A hundred honorables and reverends think the Morrill Tariff, and especially the import duty on Manchester goods, is the source of all our woes. The Honorable NEW DEGATE announced to nine hundred "ladies and gentlemen" at Sparkenhoe that the absence of the "patriarchal principle" in the United States is at the "bottom of the split." The learned A. ALISON (not he of the "History of Europe," but he of the "History of Civilization,") says the unhappy Americans must select a king from some of the reigning families of Europe -- say the Cobourg family, for instance -- and institute a National Church, for which he kindly furnishes thirty-nine new articles; and they will at once get out of the slough in which they are now floundering. These are but specimens of the enlightened opinions prevalent in England among the most learned civil and ecclesiastical doctors, which are sent over hebdomadally for the benefit of poor moribund America. Now, with equal deference to each of them, we would propose to try their respective nostrums all at once. Let us, then, abolish the common school system of secular education in all those Free States; let us split up in to "four or more" (well, say a hundred,) of what [???] calls "separate and sovereign commonwealths;" let us issue a paper edict, (or a score of them,) abolishing Slavery; let us restrict the privilege of suffrage to nabobs; let us adopt the patriarchal principle -- after we discover what it is; let us abolish the Morrill tariff, the Republic, and -- as Mr. ALISON desires -- the belief in original sin and in a plurality of gods; let us curtail the national prosperity which afflicts us, by burning down New-York, burning up our mercantile marine, destroying our manufactures, and investing in the British funds whatever cash we may have left; and let us select a king from some of the scrofulous royal scallawags of Europe. And then, if all these means fail to pacify the fighting democracy, let us invite John Bull to take our case in hand, as he now proposes to take our sister Republic of Mexico, and govern us, as he governs India, by fire and sword.

abstract: If we are to credit a paragraph that is going the rounds, CASSIUS M. CLAY, our Minister to Russia, has intimated that, "in view of the attitude of the rebels, he would prefer to surrender his present position, as Representative to Russia, and enter the army in defence of the Government." We don't see why he should not come home if he wishes to. CASSIUS, true to his name, is more an antique Roman than a red-tape diplomat. His mission, thus far, has produced one injudicious speech, one stupid letter and a religious manifesto addressed to "New Reformation" ALISON, published by that notorious quack in one of his pamphlets. Had there been any regard to the fitness of things, Mr. CLAY's desire, expressed to the Administration early in the month of May, to exchange his twelve thousand dollar mission for a military position, would have met with the consideration it was entitled to. His own State, now in her crisis, requires the assistance of all her loyal sons, and the gallant Kentuckian could undoubtedly render immense service once on the native heath. Why should he not come?

abstract: The Naval Expedition, which has enlisted so much interest, is fairly on its way to its Southern destination. It was detained in Hampton Roads longer than was anticipated.
lead_paragraph: The Naval Expedition, which has enlisted so much interest, is fairly on its way to its Southern destination. It was detained in Hampton Roads longer than was anticipated by some of those accidents which seem to be inseparable from great and complicated enterprises of the kind, and one day was very judiciously devoted by Gen. SHERMAN to exercising the men in the difficult duty of disembarking. But all preparations were at last complete, and the squadron is rapidly nearing the scene of its intended operations.

abstract: The People ex rel. J.A.H. Hasbrouck vs. The Board of Supervisors. This was an application for a mandamus to compel the Board of Supervisors to audit an account against the county, presented by the relator, ...
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. J.A.H. Hasbrouck vs. The Board of Supervisors. This was an application for a mandamus to compel the Board of Supervisors to audit an account against the county, presented by the relator, for about $1,400, the account being for printing the calendars of the Supreme Court, for printing and stationery for the County Clerk, and for printing blank indictments for the District-Attorney. The case was stated in the TIMES of July 4 last. The bills were duly certified by the officers in whose departments the work was done, but the Board, after the delay of a year or two, decided unfavorably to them on the ground that they were not responsible for printing and stationery for the individual uses of the clerks and officers of the county. They also said there was no money with which to pay.

abstract: -- Baltimore is a perfect barometer of the war. If you would see how the National fortunes stand, you have but to note the state of feeling and its manifestations in that divided city. Let our arms meet with a reverse -- up goes the secesh mercury; let the Government show the tusks of power, and down sinks treason to the lower registers, though only to lie perdu till an opportunity comes. A fortnight ago, the Monumental City polled a splendid Union majority. But the disaster at Ball's Bluff has made treason once more rampant, and Baltimore is reported again all feverish and unsettled. Happily, while secession proposes, Fort McHenry disposes; and Gen. DIX is altogether too keen to be dixied.
lead_paragraph: -- Baltimore is a perfect barometer of the war. abstract: Mr. JOHN C. RIVES, of Washington, has authorized Col. TAIT to give a monthly check for ten dollars to the wife of each member of the District of Columbia Volunteers. What a magnificent gift! Mr. RIVERS is a Virginian by birth, a noble representative of the old pure stock. It is but the other day that the rebel Congress confiscated estates in Virginia belonging to two of his sons. He has taken a splendid way to revenge himself.

abstract: The political elements in the City are beginning to crystallize. As the day of election approaches, those of our citizens who are in favor of political reforms, and of sustaining ...
lead_paragraph: The political elements in the City are beginning to crystallize. As the day of election approaches, those of our citizens who are in favor of political reforms, and of sustaining the Administration in a vigorous prosecution of the war, begin to realize the necessity of waiving all merely personal and partisan preferences, and uniting their strength in support of a single ticket.

abstract: Our news from Western Virginia is generally good, but to-day it is better than good it is the best we have received from any quarter for several days.
lead_paragraph: Our news from Western Virginia is generally good, but to-day it is better than good it is the best we have received from any quarter for several days. Gen. KELLY, the hero of Phillippa, having sufficiently recovered from the serious wound received there to resume active operations, has again made his mark against the rebels. He marched from New Creek, in Hampshire County, on Friday night last, and attacked the enemy a Romney on Saturday afternoon, routing them and capturing many prisoners, together with three pieces of cannon and all their wagons and camp equipage. The rebels, in their precipitate retreat, took the road toward Winchester. The National loss was but trifling.

abstract: Mr. B. ULLMAN Will take his last benefit tonight at the Academy of Music. A programme of unusual interest has been provided for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: Mr. B. ULLMAN Will take his last benefit tonight at the Academy of Music. A programme of unusual interest has been provided for the occasion. Two operttas are to be revived, "Betty" and "Les Noces de Jeannette," either of which, it is presumable, would, under ordinary circumstances, attract an overflowing audience. All the artistes are in the casts, and as the performance will terminate the opera season, there cannot, we think, be a doubt about the attendance. There will also be a grand concert. The matinee, on Saturday, was well attended, but the rain-storm interfered very seriously with the possible profits of the occasion. Mr. ULLMAN takes his last Brooklyn benefit to-morrow night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

abstract: A year or two ago, a handsome octoroon girl was settled by her father, a Mississippi planter, at Cleveland with some old colored servants, under the guardianship of the Judge of Probate and Rev. J.C. White. The sum of $30,000 was appropriated to her support, the funds being derived from the rent of some property in Cincinnati amounting to $2,100 per annum. Owing to the depression in business, the present income of the property is only $600. The Cleveland Herald states that in view of this condition of affairs, the establishment has been broken up, the old servants dismissed to shift for themselves, and the girl has been taken into the family of Mr. White, who has removed to Rhode Island. The case is now before the Cuyahoga Probate Court, Mr. White having carried off the girl without previously consulting the co-guardian, Judge Tilden.

abstract: Public mention of a private entertainment is sometimes not improper, and we drop a line here for the eyes of the personal friends of the pioneer of the anti-Slavery cause, just to say that on his recent passage through New-York, he was honored at a friend's...
lead_paragraph: Public mention of a private entertainment is sometimes not improper, and we drop a line here for the eyes of the personal friends of the pioneer of the anti-Slavery cause, just to say that on his recent passage through New-York, he was honored at a friend's house with a social reception of ladies and gentlemen, who constituted, on their coming together, one of the most intellectual and brilliant evening parties held in this City this fall. Among the guests were many persons of both sexes widely known in literature, many distinguished members of the learned professions, and many of the staunch early friends of the cause, who are now in venerable years. Mr. GARRISON appeared in greatly improved health, full of a line animation, exhibiting (as everywhere) his characteristic mirthfulness and seriousness.

abstract: Capt. WILEY, of the brig C.F. O'Brien, which arrived yesterday from Montevideo, reports that on Sept. 20, lat. 20 ,16', lon. 31 , he saw the British brig Spartan, from Rio Janeiro for St. Thomas.
lead_paragraph: Capt. WILEY, of the brig C.F. O'Brien, which arrived yesterday from Montevideo, reports that on Sept. 20, lat. 20 ,16', lon. 31 , he saw the British brig Spartan, from Rio Janeiro for St. Thomas. The Captain of the Spartan reported having, Oct. 5, been chased twelve hours, in lat. 19°, lon. 47°, by a steamer, bark-rigged, round stern, which had no sails higher than topgallant sails. After being overtaken, she was boarded, but being an English vessel was allowed to proceed. The steamer had a large American ensign flying during the whole time; the officers of the steamer would not tell her name or what her business was. The Captain of the brig, on arriving at St. Thomas, was invited on board of one of our men-of-war, and seeing a painting of the privateer Sumter on board, pronounced her to be the same vessel that boarded him. She was very light, and could not have had much coal in.

abstract: The lying bulletin of the gorgeous HOLLINS is at length supplemented by the official report of Capt. POPE, of the steamer Richmond, who gives us his version of the naval affair at the Southwest Pass. It adds several important particulars to the intelligence received the other day by the McClellan.
lead_paragraph: The lying bulletin of the gorgeous HOLLINS is at length supplemented by the official report of Capt. POPE, of the steamer Richmond, who gives us his version of the naval affair at the Southwest Pass. It adds several important particulars to the intelligence received the other day by the McClellan. But while the glories of the Bobadil commander of "the little Confederate mosquito fleet" are considerably scorn of their lustre, the conduct of our own officers seems to have been anything but what we had a right to expect at their hands. The not very clear statement of Capt. POPE bears no other interpretation than that it was owing to the cowardice of the blatherskite HOLLINS that he did not nab our whole squadron; while a very little of the old American pluck on the part of our naval commanders would have secured the capture or destruction of the rebel fleet.

abstract: The appointment of Gen. LEE, of the Confederate army, to supersede Gen. ZOLLICOFFER, who is heading the invasion of Eastern Kentucky, indicates the entire abandonment, for the season, of the rebel campaign in Western Virginia. There was abundant reason for rebel discouragement in this deserted theatre of war.
lead_paragraph: The appointment of Gen. LEE, of the Confederate army, to supersede Gen. ZOLLICOFFER, who is heading the invasion of Eastern Kentucky, indicates the entire abandonment, for the season, of the rebel campaign in Western Virginia. There was abundant reason for rebel discouragement in this deserted theatre of war. Gov. WISE made a complete wreck of his reputation, not only as an upright man, but as an efficient leader, in his brief campaign in the Valley of the Kanawha. He went forth from Richmond on his errand west of the mountains literally as Saul did, "breathing threatening and slaughter" against those he was to oppose. But he found more human nature than heroism among Western Virginians. The Secessionists did not volunteer as he expected -- they did not rush enthusiastically to his standard -- they did not bring their guns and their ammunition, their meal and their flour, their horses and their herds, and offer all to Gov. WISE, a free gift from Virginians on the altar of their seceded State. On the contrary, WISE's recruits were few. They were mostly loafers and vagabonds, "lewd fellows of the baser sort," cowardly and addicted to stealing. The men of property preferred staying at home to campaigning under WISE. And as for their meat and flour, their cattle and provender, they held such articles only for sale at round prices, and did not receive Confederate scrip, even from the late Governor of Virginia' and the laureled conqueror of JOHN BROWN, in payment for their farm produce!

abstract: We have at last quite full accounts of the disaster sustained by our troops a week ago to-day on the Upper Potomac.
lead_paragraph: We have at last quite full accounts of the disaster sustained by our troops a week ago to-day on the Upper Potomac. There was a heavy loss of life on our part, and a lamentable scene of confusion at the river on the retreat, caused by the utterly unaccountable neglect of the officers in command to provide the means of crossing. One scow and two small boats constituted the entire provision for advancing and retreating. It seems impossible to justify such utter neglect of one of the most evident and imperative duties of an army in the field.

abstract: It was pointed out in this journal, at the then of the victory at Hatteras Inlet, that there were three points which it was imperative we should have possession of in order to command Pamlico and Albemarle Sounds and their extensive coasts.
lead_paragraph: It was pointed out in this journal, at the then of the victory at Hatteras Inlet, that there were three points which it was imperative we should have possession of in order to command Pamlico and Albemarle Sounds and their extensive coasts. Among these was Oregon Inlet -- a passage through the sandy bar, of recent formation, not down on any of our maps, but affording from four and a-half to five feet of water. That point was not taken possession of. We have now information from the North Carolina coast that the rebels have done that for us. They have still further buoyed out the passage, which affords them abundant water for their shipping and enables them to "give Hatteras the slip." Furthermore, they are fortifying the banks so as to protect the inlet, using the brick and stone of the lighthouse which they blew up to construct their batteries. Thus while our soldiers are valorously defending themselves against the Confederate mosquitoes at Hatteras, the Carolina skippers have free ingress by private entrance to the Sound, and can laugh at the phlebotomized denizens of the Hatteras forts.

abstract: We think that the President of the United States owes a simple act of justice to Mr. CAMERON, his Secretary of War, which he cannot longer refrain from performing, without sinking the respect that is due to the Government itself, and permitting very serious injury to the public service.
lead_paragraph: We think that the President of the United States owes a simple act of justice to Mr. CAMERON, his Secretary of War, which he cannot longer refrain from performing, without sinking the respect that is due to the Government itself, and permitting very serious injury to the public service. It is the President's duty to vindicate Mr. CAMERON from the incessant attacks made upon him in several of the Western papers while in the discharge of official duties that the President himself has set him to perform. The St. Louis Republican, the St. Louis Democrat, the Cincinnati Commercial, and to some extent, the Cincinnati Gazette, have been prominent in this crusade against Mr. CAMERON; making his visit to the Western Military Department the occasion of their-abuse, and his orders issued in matters affecting the military service in that Department, the subject of their disloyal criticisms.

lead_paragraph: The Enquirer gives a list of the shares of stock in the Richmond and Petersburgh Railroad, sequestered under the confiscation act of Congress. The total number is 747. That paper adds: All of the shareholders enumerated are Philadelphians, with the exception of Mrs. ELLIES, who resides in the interior of Pennsylvania, and Mrs. VAN COURTLANDT, who is a resident of New-York. The entire number of shares constituting the capital stock of the company is 9,866 -- less than one-twentieth of which, it will be seen, was in the hands of foreigners. The market value of the sequestered shares, as determined by the last quotations, would be about $42,579 -- or $57 per share.

abstract: Many of the errors which must necessarily disfigure the progress of the war will arise from an imperfect topographical knowledge of the country over which the fighting is to be done. We have wisely chosen to make the soil of rebellion our battle-ground.
lead_paragraph: Many of the errors which must necessarily disfigure the progress of the war will arise from an imperfect topographical knowledge of the country over which the fighting is to be done. We have wisely chosen to make the soil of rebellion our battle-ground. The National Generals have to lead their men into territories, the minute geography and topography of which can only be known to the inhabitants, whose reports and guidance will never be accepted as the basis of active operations without a certain hesitancy and reserve. The official reports of the affair at Bull Run show that after months of delay and apparently careful reconnoissance over a circuit of thirty miles diameter, adjoining the Capital of the country, our military leaders were at fault, and to some extent owed their reverses to imperfect knowledge of the size and character of the roads, along which upon an inspection of the map they had planned their advance. Two or three similar errors have occurred in Western Virginia. And they must be expected to recur again and again so long as the war advances into the Southern States.
headline: {'main': 'The Want of Military Maps.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Want of Military Maps.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Major ZAGONI, whose brilliant cavalry charge at the head of FREMONT's body guard upon the rebels at Springfield we announced in our yesterday's issue, was formerly an officer under Gen. GARIBALDI. While in his service he was brevetted Captain of artillery by the Piedmontese Government, and decorations, which he habitually wears, testify to the brave deeds which he achieved before coming to this country. In person Major ZAGONI is tall and very fine looking, and his appearance would indicate that he is about thirty-five years of age.

abstract: The New-Orleans Crescent of the 4th gives a full and jubilant account of what it calls "the great naval victory" achieved off Southwest Pass, by HOLLINS. From it we gather that the fleet left New-Orleans on Wednesday, and arrived without accident at the two rebel forts, about twenty miles above our fleet that night, where they lay all Thursday and Friday nights. It seems that it was the intention to have...
lead_paragraph: The New-Orleans Crescent of the 4th gives a full and jubilant account of what it calls "the great naval victory" achieved off Southwest Pass, by HOLLINS. From it we gather that the fleet left New-Orleans on Wednesday, and arrived without accident at the two rebel forts, about twenty miles above our fleet that night, where they lay all Thursday and Friday nights. It seems that it was the intention to have made the attack on Thursday night, but the fog was too thick, and it was deferred. On Friday night, about 12 o'clock, the fleet left the forts in the following order: The Manassas leading the way, with orders to go right in among the fleet, and run the first vessel she could get at, sending up a rocket at the instant she made an attack. Then came the Tuscarora, and the towboat Watson with the five barges in tow; these had orders to set fire to the barges the moment they saw the rocket from the Manassas. After these were the Calhoun, Ivy, McRea and Jackson, and last was the launch, bringing up the rear.

abstract: The extracts we have been able to give from recent Southern papers are very important as indicating the probable tactics of the rebels. We have the statement from Richmond that large shipments of lumber are...
lead_paragraph: The extracts we have been able to give from recent Southern papers are very important as indicating the probable tactics of the rebels. We have the statement from Richmond that large shipments of lumber are making from that city to Manassas, and that bales of blankets are going forward to the same point, "indicating that the army are about going into Winter quarters there." The other statement, also from Richmond, communicated to a Memphis paper, is, that while "feints" may be made in the East, "a powerful [Confederate] army will be thrown into Kentucky. The great struggle will be in that State for the present."

abstract: Capt. R.N. EAGLE, Fifth Cavalry, United States Army, recruiting officer in Hudson-street for the mounted service, will shortly take command of his Company, which has been in active service for some months past, and which, under Lieut. TOMPKINS, made the brilliant charge at Fairfax Court-house. Capt. ...
lead_paragraph: Capt. R.N. EAGLE, Fifth Cavalry, United States Army, recruiting officer in Hudson-street for the mounted service, will shortly take command of his Company, which has been in active service for some months past, and which, under Lieut. TOMPKINS, made the brilliant charge at Fairfax Court-house. Capt. EAGLE has seen a good deal of service. He had a command of a company of Texan Rangers previous to receiving a First Lieutenant's commission in the United States Army, in 1855, and since then has been on duty with his company on the frontiers. He is a native of this City, but was appointed from Texas.

abstract: Mr. ULLMAN was favored by the elements last night. The pluvial gods, who have presided so handsomely at all his previous operatic entertainments, withdrew their attentions on this occasion, and permitted the musically-inclined to gratify their tastes without the incumbrance of an umbrella.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ULLMAN was favored by the elements last night. The pluvial gods, who have presided so handsomely at all his previous operatic entertainments, withdrew their attentions on this occasion, and permitted the musically-inclined to gratify their tastes without the incumbrance of an umbrella. The attendance, in consequence, was all that a sanguine manager could desire. All the best seats in the house were occupied, and even the realms above were fairly tenanted. Such houses from the start would have insured us an early opera season; as it is, they will heal some of the gaping wounds of a stricken management.

abstract: We copy from  yesterday's Tribune a portion of a letter from  Washington, holding out the prospect that our army will go into Winter quarters at Washington, and representing that we may consider ourselves very well off if we can maintain our present position until Spring.
lead_paragraph: We copy from yesterday's Tribune a portion of a letter from Washington, holding out the prospect that our army will go into Winter quarters at Washington, and representing that we may consider ourselves very well off if we can maintain our present position until Spring. The reason given for this very extraordinary belief is, that we have really no army in the field, -- that "there is not one really well disciplined regiment in the country," -- and that "the army of the Potomac is yet much more a mere mob than it is an army of soldiers." There might be something in this, if our troops were to be marched against veterans; but as they have to encounter soldiers no more used to war than they are themselves, the reasons urged for delay deem to us utterly inconclusive.

abstract: The mass meeting held at the Cooper Institute last evening, to ratify the State and County ticket of the People's Union, was, in numbers and enthusiasm, a very successful demonstration. The audience filled every portion of the spacious hall and so great was the throng at the Eighth-street...
lead_paragraph: The mass meeting held at the Cooper Institute last evening, to ratify the State and County ticket of the People's Union, was, in numbers and enthusiasm, a very successful demonstration. The audience filled every portion of the spacious hall and so great was the throng at the Eighth-street front of the edifice, that impromptu meetings were organized outside, and addressed by volunteer orators from among the mass assembled there. Within doors, his Honor, Judge SLOSSON, was called to the Chair, and flanked by an imposing array of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries, selected from among the most respectable members of all parties. Hon. NATHANIEL WOLFE of Kentucky, Hon. L.H. CHANDLER of Virginia, Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND, Hon. HORACE GREELEY, JOSEPH HOXIE, Esq., and others, spoke at length upon the objects and principles of the People's Union Party, and the imperative necessity of sustaining the Government of the United States in its present struggle with rebellion. The audience was attentive and enthusiastic, continually cheering the watch-words of the Union, and even overpowering the music of a fine band, stationed in the hall, with their plaudits. This demonstration augurs well for the success of the Union ticket.

abstract: Our Washington correspondent some days since published a paragraph refreshing severely on the integrity and reputation of Col. CHARLES, THOMAS, Assistant Quartermaster-General of the United States Army. We have been unable to learn that there was any other foundation for this impeachment of the character of Col. THOMAS than the loose, and possibly malicious rumors of political circles. So far as we have any knowledge of this officer, he has always borne the reputation of an upright and an honorable man, -- and we regret that the attack referred to should have found admission to our columns.

abstract: It is reported that Col. WILLIAM GATES, Third Artillery, United States Army, will take command of Forts Hamilton and Lafayette. Col. GATES is one of the oldest officers in the army, having been first commissioned as Second Lieutenant of Artillery on the 6th of March, 1806, after graduating at West Point.
lead_paragraph: It is reported that Col. WILLIAM GATES, Third Artillery, United States Army, will take command of Forts Hamilton and Lafayette. Col. GATES is one of the oldest officers in the army, having been first commissioned as Second Lieutenant of Artillery on the 6th of March, 1806, after graduating at West Point. He was promoted to the Colonelcy of the Third Artillery on the 13th of October, 1845, and is the senior Artillery Colonel in the army. It will be recollected that Col. GATES was summoned before the Army Retiring Board in Washington, and that the effort made to place him on the retired list was unsuccessful. He paid a visit to Fort Hamilton a few days ago, and it was universally remarked that he appeared to be as active and energetic as any man of half his age need be. Col. GATES is a native of Massachusetts, and was appointed from that State.

abstract: NOT VERY "WELL TOLD." -- Our hydrocephalous old neighbor, the Herald, was compelled to issue an extra sheet again yesterday, to work off its accumulation of stale news and of bile against the TIMES. It fills four or five columns with its usual rigmarole of vituperation, -- made up in about equal parts of interested malignity and of those "lies well told," -- which it avows to be the favorite food of its "general public." It falls off a little, however, in the flavor of its falsehoods. The great bulk of them are beginning to be stale and stupid, -- they have been kept too long and have survived their original beauty as well as usefulness. The new ones thrown in, moreover, are decidedly flat; they are lies, it is true, and good so far as that goes, -- but they are not "well told."

abstract: We have news from the Pacific Coast to Sunday, the 27th, by the Pacific telegraph. The intelligence of the death of Col. BAKER caused the deepest grief in California. Speculations were already rife as to his successor, and it was thought (probable that GEORGE STARKE, of Portland, would be the man. Late advices from Oregon speak in the most glowing terms of the gold mine of the Nez Perces region.
lead_paragraph: We have news from the Pacific Coast to Sunday, the 27th, by the Pacific telegraph. The intelligence of the death of Col. BAKER caused the deepest grief in California. abstract: Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine can scarcely be considered as the organ of any political party in England. The principles it advocates were long ago defunct and belong to a past age. It ignores all the great moral revolutions which have occurred in Great
lead_paragraph: Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine can scarcely be considered as the organ of any political party in England. The principles it advocates were long ago defunct and belong to a past age. It ignores all the great moral revolutions which have occurred in Great Britain during the last quarter of a century, and writes as if there had been no great measures of Parliamentary reform, no repeal of the Corn laws, no spread of education, no legal amendments -- all calculated to extend the power of the people and increase the democratic element in the State. In the number of that periodical for the present month appears an article styled; "Democracy Teaching by Example," in which the writer, after imputing to us everything that is corrupt in our Government, proceeds to justify the rebellion of the Southern States under the terms of the Constitution, and in a tone of pity for our unfortunate condition recommends us to retire from a conflict which is "making the Government of the North ridiculous in the eyes of Europe." He exults in the thought that the great experiment of a Republic has signally failed, and kindly suggests to us to yield at once with a good grace -- to allow the South to have their own monarch, and that we also should be permitted to select our own. Unless a king is to spring already armed for us from the brain of Jupiter, he does not inform us where we are to find that expensive luxury; but as he alludes in terms of high praise to the beneficent rule of the Emperor of Austria and the King of Naples, he would probably expect us to send for the last relic of the Bourbon dynasty, and adopt that gentleman, now "out of place," by the soubriquet of "Francis the First" of North America.

abstract: -- A message from Caprera brings GARIBALDI again upon the scene. The rumored coming of the Italian hero to take service in the National army has been enveloped in such an element of humbug, that we have already freely expressed our opinion against the step. Indeed, the wanton construction which was put upon the proposition by the leading English journal made any other course inconsistent with public dignity. The General's letter to our Consut at Antwerp might easily alter our verdict, were it not a deduction from facts which it would be folly to overlook. The soul of the great Italian fairly glows through his short, simple, warm-hearted message:

abstract: The Oswego Times disclaims all thought of arraying the friends of Gen. FREMONT against the Government. It recognizes the necessity of loyal obedience on the part of subordinates, and of standing by the Government on the part of the people. It insists, on the other hand,
lead_paragraph: The Oswego Times disclaims all thought of arraying the friends of Gen. FREMONT against the Government. It recognizes the necessity of loyal obedience on the part of subordinates, and of standing by the Government on the part of the people. It insists, on the other hand, fairly enough, that the Government, having appointed Gen. FREMONT to a very responsible command, should give him a cordial and a generous support, or else remove him. And it thus speaks of the object for which it proposes to hold a State Convention of Gen. FREMONT's friends:

abstract: Men sometimes talk very foolishly and act sensibly after all, especially when necessity is their guide. The grand card of the rebels throughout has been cotton. It was their talisman that was to shield them from all
lead_paragraph: Men sometimes talk very foolishly and act sensibly after all, especially when necessity is their guide. The grand card of the rebels throughout has been cotton. It was their talisman that was to shield them from all harm, and conduct them to all success. The lamp of Aladdin was nothing to it. All they had to do was to hold fast to their cotton bales. The world would be only too happy to come for it, taking it upon any terms.

abstract: The Calcutta, China and West India mails have arrived. Calcutta advices are to Sept. 9. The ravages of cholera were becoming less serious in the Northwest Provinces. In the course of six weeks it had carried off more than five hundred soldiers occupying stations in detachments distinct from one another. The commercial news from Calcutta is more satisfactory than it has been or late. Trade has been stimulated by the prospects of a good harvest.

abstract: The great naval and military expedition, intended for operations on the Southern Coast, has at last left for its destination wherever that may be. The fleet sailed from Hampton Roads on Tuesday morning, in fine style, the weather being all that could be desired.
lead_paragraph: The great naval and military expedition, intended for operations on the Southern Coast, has at last left for its destination wherever that may be. The fleet sailed from Hampton Roads on Tuesday morning, in fine style, the weather being all that could be desired. The U.S. transport Thomas Swann, which arrived at this port yesterday, reports having spoken a portion of the fleet on Tuesday off Cape Henry. As there is now little likelihood that the progress of the vessels will be delayed by bad weather, we may expect soon to hear that some favored spot in JEFF. DAVIS' dominions has been colonized by Northern missionaries.

abstract: The trial of the privateers of the Savannah was nearly brought to a close yesterday, nothing remaining but the verdict of the jury, which, however, it is quite possible may never be given, as the jury were out four hours before the Court adjourned for the night, without agreeing.
lead_paragraph: The trial of the privateers of the Savannah was nearly brought to a close yesterday, nothing remaining but the verdict of the jury, which, however, it is quite possible may never be given, as the jury were out four hours before the Court adjourned for the night, without agreeing. The questions which the jury were to consider were reduced by Judge NELSON, in his charge, to a very narrow compass. He first disposed of the question of the jurisdiction of the Court, holding that the mere taking of the prisoners into Hampton Roads, for the purpose of transferring them from the Minnesota to the Harriet Lane, in pursuance of the order of the Commodore to take the prisoners to New-York for trial, was not such a bringing them into the District of Virginia as would, under the statute, require their trial to be held there, and moreover, that the language of the act of 1825 was to be taken in the alternative, and that the trial could be had either in the District where they were apprehended or into which they were first brought, and that as these prisoners were apprehended by the civil authorities in this District, their trial was rightly had here.

abstract: The progress of pacification in Mexico is not so rapid, as those who anxiously seek some escape from forcible intervention in the affairs of that Republic would gladly have it.
lead_paragraph: The progress of pacification in Mexico is not so rapid, as those who anxiously seek some escape from forcible intervention in the affairs of that Republic would gladly have it. The National Legislature is almost equally divided between supporters of President JUAREZ and those who oppose him; the latter interest, to the number of fifty-one, having recently addressed the President a formal request that he resign; and the former, to the number of fifty-two, having presented a counter memorial imploring him to retain office. It is to the latter request Senor JUAREZ has listened.

FREMONT'S administration, which we publish in the TIMES to-day, is certainly the most remarkable document that has seen the light since the beginning of the present war.
lead_paragraph: The report of Adj.-Gen. THOMAS to the Secretary of War, in regard to the condition of the Western Military Department and the manner of conducting business under MajorGen. FREMONT'S administration, which we publish in the TIMES to-day, is certainly the most remarkable document that has seen the light since the beginning of the present war. We allude not so much to the matter of the report, though that is astounding, perplexing and painful enough; but to the fact that such a document, so singular in its details, so damaging, if true, to the National cause in its revelations of our weakness to the enemy, and so disgraceful to one of the first officers of the country and to his aids and associates, was permitted to be published at all, in the informal and unsustained shape of the diary of a traveling Adjutant.

abstract: A meeting of the electors of the Sixth Senatorial District is to be held to-morrow evening at Irving Hall, to ratify the nomination of WASHINGTON SMITH for the State Senate.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the electors of the Sixth Senatorial District is to be held to-morrow evening at Irving Hall, to ratify the nomination of WASHINGTON SMITH for the State Senate. Mr. SMITH is the nominee of the Republican Party in that District, and is a man of energy, integrity and political efficiency. He has always been a zealous and devoted advocate of Republican principles, and has very strong claims upon the confidence and support of the Republican electors. Several well known and popular speakers are expected to address the meeting. The call, signed by a large number of prominent citizens of the District, will be found in another column.

abstract: A gentleman of much learning and taste, who lived many years in Boston and now resides in Europe, having received photographs from several friends here taken by Mr. J.A. WHIPPLE, No. 96 Washington-street, writes that in all Europe there cannot be found any photographs so excellent as those taken by the above-named artist, and that all the Europeans to whom he had shown these specimens concurred in the same opinion. Mr. WHIPPLE is unsurpassed in his profession, even in this country. -- Boston Journal.
lead_paragraph: A gentleman of much learning and taste, who lived many years in Boston and now resides in Europe, having received photographs from several friends here taken by Mr. J.A. abstract: The Paris correspondent of the London Times writes that the discussions as to the common line of policy to be adopted by France and England on the American question have been again renewed. The subject has been mooted before, but was postponed. Possibly information brought over by Prince NAPOLEON may have contributed to make the Emperor more inclined to listen to proposals which might be made in this respect by England.

abstract: The steamship Europa arrived at Halifax yesterday, with advices from Europe three days later. She left Liverpool on the 19th and Queenstown on thh 20th inst. The Liverpool Cotton market continued agitated, and prices still had an upward tendency.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Europa arrived at Halifax yesterday, with advices from Europe three days later. She left Liverpool on the 19th and Queenstown on thh 20th inst. The Liverpool Cotton market continued agitated, and prices still had an upward tendency. The stock on hand was estimated at 633,000 bales, of which 350,000 were American. The sales of the week had been 116,500 bales, of which 56,000 were taken by speculators. Breadstuffs also still had an advancing tendency, and Provisions were somewhat more active. An increased business is reported in American stocks in the London market.

abstract: The body of an unknown man, some few days ago, was discovered by a citizen of Middletown, N.J., floating in the water. The corpse was well and fashionably dressed, and in one of the pockets was found $110 in gold, beside some loose change. An inquest was held, and so much money being found upon the deceased, it was supposed that the murder could not have possibly been done for gain, and the verdict was that deceased had come to his death by some unknown means. The Coroner, however, advertised the case for further information. It so happened that a gentleman in busines in this City received a letter from the city of Mainz, Grand Duchy of Hesse Darmstadt, Germany, asking for information of a SIGISMUED FELLNER, who had left for America in the steamship Bavaria, having a large amount of valuables in money and jewels.

abstract: It is now a week since the battle took place between the opposing forces which met this side of Leesburgh. During that time many versions of the affair have been given, all more or loss incorrect, and  the country has been balancing between the blame which certain correspendents insist should fall upon Gen. STONE and the unbounded praise which the same parties lavish upon the late Col. BAKER.
lead_paragraph: From Our Special Correspondent.
